Jeremiah 3:12 Jeremiah, shout toward the north: Israel, I am your Lord— come back to me! You were unfaithful and made me furious, but I am merciful, and so I will forgive you.
Jeremiah 3:13 Just admit that you rebelled and worshiped foreign gods under large trees everywhere.
Jeremiah 3:14 You are unfaithful children, but you belong to me. Come home! I'll take one or two of you from each town and clan and bring you to Zion.
Jeremiah 3:15 Then I'll appoint wise rulers who will obey me, and they will care for you like shepherds.
Jeremiah 3:16 You will increase in numbers, and there will be no need to remember the sacred chest or to make a new one.
Jeremiah 3:17 The whole city of Jerusalem will be my throne. All nations will come here to worship me, and they will no longer follow their stubborn, evil hearts.
Jeremiah 3:18 Then, in countries to the north, you people of Judah and Israel will be reunited, and you will return to the land I gave your ancestors.
Jeremiah 3:19 I have always wanted to treat you as my children and give you the best land, the most beautiful on earth. I wanted you to call me “Father” and not turn from me.
Jeremiah 3:20 But instead, you are like a wife who broke her wedding vows. You have been unfaithful to me. I, the Lord, have spoken.
Jeremiah 3:21 Listen to the noise on the hilltops! It's the people of Israel, weeping and begging me to answer their prayers. They forgot about me and chose the wrong path.
Jeremiah 3:22 I will tell them, “Come back, and I will cure you of your unfaithfulness.” They will answer, “We will come back, because you are the Lord our God.
Jeremiah 3:23 On hilltops, we worshiped idols and made loud noises, but it was all for nothing— only you can save us.
Jeremiah 3:24 Since the days of our ancestors when our nation was young, that shameful god Baal has taken our crops and livestock, our sons and daughters.
Jeremiah 3:25 We have rebelled against you just like our ancestors, and we are ashamed of our sins.”
Jeremiah 4:1 The Lord said: Israel, if you really want to come back to me, get rid of those disgusting idols.
Jeremiah 4:2 Make promises only in my name, and do what you promise! Then all nations will praise me, and I will bless them.
Jeremiah 4:3 People of Jerusalem and Judah, don't be so stubborn! Your hearts have become hard, like unplowed ground where thornbushes grow.
Jeremiah 4:4 With all your hearts, keep the agreement I made with you. But if you are stubborn and keep on sinning, my anger will burn like a fire that cannot be put out. *
Jeremiah 4:5 “Sound the trumpets, my people. Warn the people of Judah, ‘Run for your lives!
Jeremiah 4:6 Head for Jerusalem or another walled town!’ “Jeremiah, tell them I'm sending disaster from the north.
Jeremiah 4:7 An army will come out, like a lion from its den. It will destroy nations and leave your towns empty and in ruins.”
Jeremiah 4:8 Then I told the people of Israel, “Put on sackcloth! Mourn and cry out, ‘The Lord is still angry with us.’ ”
Jeremiah 4:9 The Lord said, “When all this happens, the king and his officials, the prophets and the priests will be shocked and terrified.”
Jeremiah 4:10 I said, “You are the Lord God. So why have you fooled everyone, especially the people of Jerusalem? Why did you promise peace, when a knife is at our throats?”
Jeremiah 4:11+JER When disaster comes, the Lord will tell you people of Jerusalem, “I am sending a windstorm from the desert— not a welcome breeze. And it will sweep you away as punishment for your sins.
Jeremiah 4:13 Look! The enemy army swoops down like an eagle; their cavalry and chariots race faster than storm clouds blown by the wind.” Then you will answer, “We are doomed!”
Jeremiah 4:14 But Jerusalem, there is still time for you to be saved. Wash the evil from your hearts and stop making sinful plans,
Jeremiah 4:15 before a message of disaster arrives from the hills of Ephraim and the town of Dan.
Jeremiah 4:16+JER The Lord said, “Tell the nations that my people have rebelled against me. And so an army will come from far away to surround Jerusalem and the towns of Judah. I, the Lord, have spoken.
Jeremiah 4:18 “People of Judah, your hearts will be in pain, but it's your own fault that you will be punished.”
Jeremiah 4:19 I can't stand the pain! My heart pounds, as I twist and turn in agony. I hear the signal trumpet and the battle cry of the enemy, and I cannot be silent.
Jeremiah 4:20 I see the enemy defeating us time after time, leaving everything in ruins. Even my own home is destroyed in a moment.
Jeremiah 4:21 How long will I see enemy flags and hear their trumpets?
Jeremiah 4:22 I heard the Lord say, “My people ignore me. They are foolish children who do not understand that they will be punished. All they know is how to sin.”
Jeremiah 4:23 After this, I looked around. The earth was barren, with no form of life. The sun, moon, and stars had disappeared.
Jeremiah 4:24 The mountains were shaking;
Jeremiah 4:25 no people could be seen, and all the birds had flown away.
Jeremiah 4:26 Farmland had become a desert, and towns were in ruins. The Lord's fierce anger had done all of this.
Jeremiah 4:27+JER The Lord said: I have made my decision, and I won't change my mind. This land will be destroyed, although not completely. The sky will turn dark, and the earth will mourn.
Jeremiah 4:29 Enemy cavalry and archers shout their battle cry. People run for their lives and try to find safety among trees and rocks. Every town is empty.
Jeremiah 4:30 Jerusalem, your land has been wiped out. But you act like a prostitute and try to win back your lovers, who now hate you. You can put on a red dress, gold jewelry, and eye shadow, but it's no use— your lovers are out to kill you!
Jeremiah 4:31 I heard groaning and crying. Was it a woman giving birth to her first child? No, it was Jerusalem, gasping for breath and begging for help. “I'm dying!” she said. “They have murdered me.”
Jeremiah 5:1 “Search Jerusalem for honest people who try to be faithful. If you can find even one, I'll forgive the whole city.
Jeremiah 5:2 Everyone breaks promises made in my name.”
Jeremiah 5:3 I answered, “I know that you look for truth. You punished your people for their lies, but in spite of the pain, they became more stubborn and refused to turn back to you.”
Jeremiah 5:4 Then I thought to myself, “These common people act like fools, and they have never learned what the Lord their God demands of them.
Jeremiah 5:5 So I'll go and talk to the leaders. They know what God demands.” But even they had decided not to obey the Lord.
Jeremiah 5:6 The people have rebelled and rejected the Lord too many times. So enemies will attack like lions from the forest or wolves from the desert. Those enemies will watch the towns of Judah, and like leopards they will tear to pieces whoever goes outside.
Jeremiah 5:7 People of Judah, how can I forgive you? I gave you everything, but you abandoned me and worshiped idols. You men go to prostitutes and are unfaithful to your wives.
Jeremiah 5:8 You are no better than animals, and you always want sex with someone else's wife.
Jeremiah 5:9 Why shouldn't I punish the people of Judah?
Jeremiah 5:10 I will tell their enemies, “Go through my vineyard. Don't destroy the vines, but cut off the branches, because they are the people who don't belong to me.”
Jeremiah 5:11 In every way, Judah and Israel have been unfaithful to me. *
Jeremiah 5:12 Their prophets lie and say, “The Lord won't punish us. We will have peace and plenty of food.”
Jeremiah 5:13 They tell these lies in my name, so now they will be killed in war or starve to death.
Jeremiah 5:14 I am the Lord God All-Powerful. Jeremiah, I will tell you exactly what to say. Your words will be a fire; Israel and Judah will be the fuel.
Jeremiah 5:15 People of Israel, I have made my decision. An army from a distant country will attack you. I've chosen an ancient nation, and you won't understand their language.
Jeremiah 5:16 All of them are warriors, and their arrows bring death.
Jeremiah 5:17 This nation will eat your crops and livestock; they will leave no fruit on your vines or fig trees. And although you feel safe behind thick walls, your towns will be destroyed and your children killed.
Jeremiah 5:18 The Lord said: Jeremiah, the enemy army won't kill everyone in Judah.
Jeremiah 5:19 And the people who survive will ask, “Why did the Lord our God do such terrible things to us?” Then tell them: I am the Lord, but you abandoned me and worshiped other gods in your own land. Now you will be slaves in a foreign country.
Jeremiah 5:20 Tell these things to each other, you people of Judah, you descendants of Jacob.
Jeremiah 5:21 You fools! Why don't you listen when I speak? Why can't you understand
Jeremiah 5:22 that you should worship me with fear and trembling? I'm the one who made the shore to hold back the ocean. Waves may crash on the beach, but they can come no farther.
Jeremiah 5:23 You stubborn people have rebelled and turned your backs on me.
Jeremiah 5:24 You refuse to say, “Let's worship the Lord! He's the one who sends rain in spring and autumn and gives us a good harvest.”
Jeremiah 5:25 That's why I cannot bless you! *
Jeremiah 5:26 A hunter traps birds and puts them in a cage, but some of you trap humans and make them your slaves.
Jeremiah 5:27 You are evil, and you lie and cheat to make yourselves rich. You are powerful
Jeremiah 5:28 and prosperous, but you refuse to help the poor get the justice they deserve.
Jeremiah 5:29 You need to be punished, and so I will take revenge.
Jeremiah 5:30 Look at the terrible things going on in this country. I am shocked!
Jeremiah 5:31 Prophets give their messages in the name of a false god, my priests don't want to serve me, and you—my own people— like it this way! But on the day of disaster, where will you turn for help?
Jeremiah 6:1 Run for your lives, people of Benjamin. Get out of Jerusalem. Sound a trumpet in Tekoa and light a signal fire in Beth-Haccherem. Soon you will be struck by disaster from the north.
Jeremiah 6:2 Jerusalem is a lovely pasture,
Jeremiah 6:3 but shepherds will surround it and divided up, then let their flocks eat all the grass.
Jeremiah 6:4 Kings will tell their troops, “If we reach Jerusalem in the morning, we'll attack at noon. But if we arrive later,
Jeremiah 6:5 we'll attack after dark and destroy its fortresses.”
Jeremiah 6:6 I am the Lord All-Powerful, and I will command these armies to chop down trees and build a ramp up to the walls of Jerusalem. People of Jerusalem, I must punish you for your injustice.
Jeremiah 6:7 Evil pours from your city like water from a spring. Sounds of injustice and violence echo within your walls; victims are everywhere, wounded and dying.
Jeremiah 6:8 Listen to me, you people of Jerusalem and Judah. I will abandon you, and your land will become an empty desert.
Jeremiah 6:9 I will tell your enemies to leave your nation bare like a vine stripped of grapes. I, the Lord All-Powerful, have spoken.
Jeremiah 6:10 I have told the people that you, Lord, will punish them, but they just laugh and refuse to listen.
Jeremiah 6:11 Your anger against Judah flames up inside me, and I can't hold it in much longer. Don't hold back my anger! Let it sweep away everyone— the children at play and all adults, young and old alike.
Jeremiah 6:12 I'll punish the people of Judah and give to others their houses and fields, as well as their wives. I, the Lord, have spoken.
Jeremiah 6:13 Everyone is greedy and dishonest, whether poor or rich. Even the prophets and priests cannot be trusted.
Jeremiah 6:14 All they ever offer to my deeply wounded people are empty hopes for peace.
Jeremiah 6:15 They should be ashamed of their disgusting sins, but they don't even blush. And so, when I punish Judah, they will end up on the ground, dead like everyone else. I, the Lord, have spoken.
Jeremiah 6:16 The Lord said: My people, when you stood at the crossroads, I told you, “Follow the road your ancestors took, and you will find peace.” But you refused.
Jeremiah 6:17 I also sent prophets to warn you of danger, but when they sounded the alarm, you paid no attention.
Jeremiah 6:18 So I tell all nations on earth, “Watch what I will do!
Jeremiah 6:19 My people ignored me and rejected my laws. They planned to do evil, and now the evil they planned will happen to them.”
Jeremiah 6:20 People of Judah, you bring me incense from Sheba and spices from distant lands. You offer sacrifices of all kinds. But why bother? I hate these gifts of yours!
Jeremiah 6:21 So I will put stumbling blocks in your path, and everyone will die, including parents and children, neighbors and friends.
Jeremiah 6:22 The Lord said, “Look toward the north, where a powerful nation has prepared for war.
Jeremiah 6:23 Its well-armed troops are cruel and never show mercy. Their galloping horses sound like ocean waves pounding on the shore. This army will attack you, lovely Jerusalem.”
Jeremiah 6:24 Then the people said, “Just hearing about them makes us tremble with fear, and we twist and turn in pain like a woman giving birth.”
Jeremiah 6:25 The Lord said, “Don't work in your fields or walk along the roads. It's too dangerous. The enemy is well armed
Jeremiah 6:26 and attacks without warning. So mourn, my people, as though your only child had died. Wear clothes made of sackcloth and roll in the ash pile.”
Jeremiah 6:27 Jeremiah, test my people as though they were metal.
Jeremiah 6:28 And you'll find they are hard like bronze and iron. They are stubborn rebels, always spreading lies. *
Jeremiah 6:29+JER Silver can be purified in a fiery furnace, but my people are too wicked to be made pure, and so I have rejected them.
Jeremiah 7:1+JER The Lord told me to stand by the gate of the temple and tell the people who were going in that the Lord All-Powerful, the God of Israel, had said: Pay attention, people of Judah! Change your ways and start living right, then I will let you keep on living in your own country.
Jeremiah 7:4 Don't fool yourselves! My temple is here in Jerusalem, but that doesn't mean I will protect you.
Jeremiah 7:5 I will keep you safe only if you change your ways and are fair and honest with each other.
Jeremiah 7:6 Stop taking advantage of foreigners, orphans, and widows. Don't kill innocent people. And stop worshiping other gods.
Jeremiah 7:7 Then I will let you enjoy a long life in this land I gave your ancestors.
Jeremiah 7:8 But just look at what is happening! You put your trust in worthless lies.
Jeremiah 7:9 You steal and murder; you lie in court and are unfaithful in marriage. You worship idols and offer incense to Baal, when these gods have never done anything for you.
Jeremiah 7:10 And then you come into my temple and worship me! Do you think I will protect you so that you can go on sinning?
Jeremiah 7:11 You are thieves, and you have made my temple your hideout. But I've seen everything you have done.
Jeremiah 7:12 Go to Shiloh, where my sacred tent once stood. Take a look at what I did there. My people Israel sinned, and so I destroyed Shiloh!
Jeremiah 7:13 While you have been sinning, I have been trying to talk to you, but you refuse to listen.
Jeremiah 7:14 Don't think this temple will protect you. Long ago I told your ancestors to build it and worship me here, but now I have decided to tear it down, just as I destroyed Shiloh.
Jeremiah 7:15 And as for you, people of Judah, I'm going to send you away from my land, just as I sent away the people of Ephraim and the other northern tribes.
Jeremiah 7:16 Jeremiah, don't pray for these people! I, the Lord, would refuse to listen.
Jeremiah 7:17 Do you see what the people of Judah are doing in their towns and in the streets of Jerusalem?
Jeremiah 7:18 Children gather firewood, their fathers build fires, and their mothers mix dough to bake bread for the goddess they call the Queen of Heaven. They even offer wine sacrifices to other gods, just to insult me.
Jeremiah 7:19 But they are not only insulting me; they are also harming themselves by doing these shameful things.
Jeremiah 7:20 And now, I, the Lord All-Powerful, will flood Judah with my fiery anger until nothing is left—no people or animals, no trees or crops.
Jeremiah 7:21 The Lord told me to say to the people of Judah: I am the Lord All-Powerful, the God of Israel, but I won't accept sacrifices from you. So don't even bother bringing them to me. You might as well just cook the meat for yourselves.
Jeremiah 7:22 At the time I brought your ancestors out of Egypt, I didn't command them to offer sacrifices to me.
Jeremiah 7:23 Instead, I told them, “If you listen to me and do what I tell you, I will be your God, you will be my people, and all will go well for you.”
Jeremiah 7:24 But your ancestors refused to listen. They were stubborn, and whenever I wanted them to go one way, they always went the other.
Jeremiah 7:25 Ever since your ancestors left Egypt, I have been sending my servants the prophets to speak for me.
Jeremiah 7:26 But you have ignored me and become even more stubborn and sinful than your ancestors ever were!
Jeremiah 7:27 Jeremiah, no matter what you do, the people won't listen.
Jeremiah 7:28 So you must say to them: People of Judah, I am the Lord your God, but you have refused to obey me, and you didn't change when I punished you. And now, you no longer even pretend to be faithful to me.
Jeremiah 7:29 Shave your head bald and throw away the hair. Sing a funeral song on top of a barren hill. You people have made me angry, and I have abandoned you.
Jeremiah 7:30 You have disobeyed me by putting your disgusting idols in my temple, and now the temple itself is disgusting to me.
Jeremiah 7:31 At Topheth in Hinnom Valley you have built altars where you kill your children and burn them as sacrifices to other gods. I would never think of telling you to do this.
Jeremiah 7:32 So watch out! Someday that place will no longer be called Topheth or Hinnom Valley. It will be called Slaughter Valley, because you will bury your dead there until you run out of room,
Jeremiah 7:33 and then bodies will lie scattered on the ground. Birds and wild animals will come and eat, and no one will be around to scare them off.
Jeremiah 7:34 When I am finished with your land, there will be deathly silence in the empty ruins of Jerusalem and the towns of Judah—no happy voices, no sounds of parties or wedding celebrations.
Jeremiah 8:1 Then the bones of the dead kings of Judah and their officials will be dug up, along with the bones of the priests, the prophets, and everyone else in Jerusalem
Jeremiah 8:2 who loved and worshiped the sun, moon, and stars. These bones will be scattered and left lying on the ground like trash, where the sun and moon and stars can shine on them.
Jeremiah 8:3 Some of you people of Judah will be left alive, but I will force you to go to foreign countries, and you will wish you were dead. I, the Lord God All-Powerful, have spoken.
Jeremiah 8:4 The Lord said: People of Jerusalem, when you stumble and fall, you get back up, and if you take a wrong road, you turn around and go back.
Jeremiah 8:5 So why do you refuse to come back to me? Why do you hold so tightly to your false gods?
Jeremiah 8:6 I listen carefully, but none of you admit that you've done wrong. Without a second thought, you run down the wrong road like horses running blindly into battle.
Jeremiah 8:7 Storks, doves, swallows, and thrushes all know when it's time to fly away for the winter and when to come back. But you, my people, don't know what I demand.
Jeremiah 8:8 You say, “We are wise because we have the teachings and laws of the Lord.” But I say that your teachers have turned my words into lies!
Jeremiah 8:9 Your wise men have rejected what I say, and so they have no wisdom. Now they will be trapped and put to shame; they won't know what to do.
Jeremiah 8:10 I'll give their wives and fields to strangers. Everyone is greedy and dishonest, whether poor or rich. Even the prophets and priests cannot be trusted.
Jeremiah 8:11 All they ever offer to my deeply wounded people are empty hopes for peace.
Jeremiah 8:12 They should be ashamed of the way they live, but they don't even blush. And so, when I punish Judah, they will end up on the ground, dead like everyone else.
Jeremiah 8:13 I will wipe them out. They are vines without grapes; fig trees without figs or leaves. They have not done a thing that I told them! I, the Lord, have spoken.
Jeremiah 8:14 The people of Judah say to each other, “What are we waiting for? Let's run to a town with walls and die there. We rebelled against the Lord, and we were sentenced to die by drinking poison.
Jeremiah 8:15 We had hoped for peace and a time of healing, but all we got was terror.
Jeremiah 8:16 Our enemies have reached the town of Dan in the north, and the snorting of their horses makes us tremble with fear. The enemy will destroy Jerusalem and our entire nation. No one will survive.”
Jeremiah 8:17 “Watch out!” the Lord says. “I'm sending poisonous snakes to attack you, and no one can stop them.”
Jeremiah 8:18 I'm burdened with sorrow and feel like giving up.
Jeremiah 8:19 In a foreign land my people are crying. Listen! You'll hear them say, “Has the Lord deserted Zion? Is he no longer its king?” I hear the Lord reply, “Why did you make me angry by worshiping useless idols?”
Jeremiah 8:20 The people complain, “Spring and summer have come and gone, but still the Lord hasn't rescued us.”
Jeremiah 8:21 My people are crushed, and so is my heart. I am horrified and mourn.
Jeremiah 8:22 If medicine and doctors may be found in Gilead, why aren't my people healed?
Jeremiah 9:1 I wish that my eyes were fountains of tears, so I could cry day and night for my people who were killed.
Jeremiah 9:2 I wish I could go into the desert and find a hiding place from all who are treacherous and unfaithful to God.
Jeremiah 9:3 The Lord replied: Lies come from the mouths of my people, like arrows from a bow. With each dishonest deed their power increases, and not one of them will admit that I am God.
Jeremiah 9:4 Jeremiah, all your friends and relatives tell lies about you, so don't trust them.
Jeremiah 9:5 They wear themselves out, always looking for a new way to cheat their friends.
Jeremiah 9:6 Everyone takes advantage of everyone else, and no one will admit that I am God.
Jeremiah 9:7 And so I will purify the hearts of my people just as gold is purified in a furnace. I have no other choice.
Jeremiah 9:8 They say they want peace, but this lie is deadly, like an arrow that strikes when you least expect it.
Jeremiah 9:9 Give me one good reason not to punish them as they deserve. I, the Lord All-Powerful, have spoken.
Jeremiah 9:10 I weep for the pastureland in the hill country. It's so barren and scorched that no one travels there. No cattle can be found there, and birds and wild animals have all disappeared.
Jeremiah 9:11 I heard the Lord reply, “When I am finished, Jerusalem and the towns of Judah will be piles of ruins where only jackals live.”
Jeremiah 9:12 I said to the Lord, “None of us can understand why the land has become like an uncrossable desert. Won't you explain why?”
Jeremiah 9:13 The Lord said: I destroyed the land because the people disobeyed me and rejected my laws and teachings.
Jeremiah 9:14 They were stubborn and worshiped Baal, just as their ancestors did.
Jeremiah 9:15 So I, the Lord All-Powerful, the God of Israel, promise them poison to eat and drink.
Jeremiah 9:16 I'll scatter them in foreign countries that they and their ancestors have never even heard of. Finally, I will send enemy soldiers to kill every last one of them.
Jeremiah 9:17 The Lord All-Powerful said, “Make arrangements now for the women who are paid to weep at funerals, especially the women who can cry the loudest.”
Jeremiah 9:18 The people answered, “Let them come quickly and cry for us, until our own eyes are flooded with tears.
Jeremiah 9:19 Now those of us on Zion cry, ‘We are ruined! We can't stand the shame. Our homes have been destroyed, and we must leave our land.’
Jeremiah 9:20 “We ask you women to pay attention to what the Lord says. We will teach you a funeral song that you can teach your daughters and friends:
Jeremiah 9:21 ‘We were in our fortress, but death sneaked in through our windows. It even struck down children at play and our strongest young men.’
Jeremiah 9:22 “The Lord has told us the ground will be covered with dead bodies, like ungathered stalks of grain or manure in a field.”
Jeremiah 9:23 The Lord says: Don't brag about your wisdom or strength or wealth.
Jeremiah 9:24 If you feel you must brag, then have enough sense to brag about worshiping me, the Lord. What I like best is showing kindness, justice, and mercy to everyone on earth.
Jeremiah 9:25+JER Someday I will punish the nations of Egypt, Edom, Ammon, and Moab, and the tribes of the desert. The men of these nations are circumcised, but they don't worship me. And it's the same with you people of Judah. Your bodies are circumcised, but your hearts are unchanged.
Jeremiah 10:1+JER The Lord said: Listen to me, you people of Israel. Don't follow the customs of those nations who become frightened when they see something strange happen in the sky.
Jeremiah 10:3 Their religion is worthless! They chop down a tree, carve the wood into an idol,
Jeremiah 10:4 cover it with silver and gold, and then nail it down so it won't fall over.
Jeremiah 10:5 An idol is no better than a scarecrow. It can't speak, and it has to be carried, because it can't walk. Why worship an idol that can't help or harm you?
Jeremiah 10:6 Our Lord, great and powerful, you alone are God.
Jeremiah 10:7 You are King of the nations. Everyone should worship you. No human anywhere on earth is wiser than you.
Jeremiah 10:8 Idols are worthless, and anyone who worships them is a fool!
Jeremiah 10:9 Idols are made by humans. A carver shapes the wood. A metalworker hammers out a covering of gold from Uphaz or of silver from Tarshish. Then the idol is dressed in blue and purple clothes.
Jeremiah 10:10 You, Lord, are the only true and living God. You will rule for all time. When you are angry the earth shakes, and nations are destroyed.
Jeremiah 10:11 You told me to say that idols did not create the heavens and the earth, and that you, the Lord, will destroy every idol.
Jeremiah 10:12 With your wisdom and power you created the earth and spread out the heavens.
Jeremiah 10:13 The waters in the heavens roar at your command. You make clouds appear— you send the winds from your storehouse and make lightning flash in the rain.
Jeremiah 10:14 People who make idols are so stupid! They will be disappointed, because their false gods are not alive.
Jeremiah 10:15 Idols are merely a joke, and when the time is right, they will be destroyed.
Jeremiah 10:16 But you, Israel's God, created all things, and you chose Israel to be your very own. Your name is the Lord All-Powerful.
Jeremiah 10:17 I said to the people of Judah, “Gather your things; you are surrounded.
Jeremiah 10:18 The Lord said these troubles will lead to your capture, and he will throw you from this land like a rock from a sling.”
Jeremiah 10:19 The people answered, “We are wounded and doomed to die. Why did we say we could stand the pain?
Jeremiah 10:20 Our homes are destroyed; our children are dead. No one is left to help us find shelter.”
Jeremiah 10:21 But I told them, “Our leaders were stupid failures, because they refused to listen to the Lord. And so we've been scattered like sheep.
Jeremiah 10:22 “Sounds of destruction rumble from the north like distant thunder. Soon our towns will be ruins where only jackals live.”
Jeremiah 10:23 I know, Lord, that we humans are not in control of our own lives.
Jeremiah 10:24 Correct me, as I deserve, but not in your anger, or I will be dead.
Jeremiah 10:25 Our enemies refuse to admit that you are God or to worship you. They have wiped out our people and left our nation lying in ruins. So get angry and sweep them away!
Jeremiah 11:1+JER The Lord God told me to say to the people of Judah and Jerusalem: I, the Lord, am warning you that I will put a curse on anyone who doesn't keep the agreement I made with Israel. So pay attention to what it says.
Jeremiah 11:4 My commands haven't changed since I brought your ancestors out of Egypt, a nation that seemed like a blazing furnace where iron ore is melted. I told your ancestors that if they obeyed my commands, I would be their God, and they would be my people.
Jeremiah 11:5 Then I did what I had promised and gave them this wonderful land, where you now live. “Yes, Lord,” I replied, “that's true.”
Jeremiah 11:6 Then the Lord told me to say to everyone on the streets of Jerusalem and in the towns of Judah: Pay attention to the commands in my agreement with you.
Jeremiah 11:7 Ever since I brought your ancestors out of Egypt, I have been telling your people to obey me. But you and your ancestors
Jeremiah 11:8 have always been stubborn. You have refused to listen, and instead you have done whatever your sinful hearts have desired. You have not kept the agreement we made, so I will make you suffer every curse that goes with it.
Jeremiah 11:9 The Lord said to me: Jeremiah, the people of Judah and Jerusalem are plotting against me.
Jeremiah 11:10 They have sinned in the same way their ancestors did, by turning from me and worshiping other gods. The northern kingdom of Israel broke the agreement I made with your ancestors, and now the southern kingdom of Judah has done the same.
Jeremiah 11:11 Here is what I've decided to do. I will bring suffering on the people of Judah and Jerusalem, and no one will escape. They will beg me to help, but I won't listen to their prayers.
Jeremiah 11:12+JER Then they will offer sacrifices to their other gods and ask them for help. After all, the people of Judah have more gods than towns, and more shameful altars for Baal than there are streets in Jerusalem. But those gods won't be able to rescue the people of Judah from disaster.
Jeremiah 11:14 Jeremiah, don't pray for these people or beg me to rescue them. If you do, I won't listen, and I certainly won't listen if they pray!
Jeremiah 11:15 Then the Lord told me to say to the people of Judah: You are my chosen people, but you have no right to be here in my temple, doing such evil things. The sacrifices you offer me won't protect you from disaster, so stop celebrating.
Jeremiah 11:16 Once you were like an olive tree covered with fruit. But soon I will send a noisy mob to break off your branches and set you on fire.
Jeremiah 11:17 I am the Lord All-Powerful. You people of Judah were like a tree that I had planted, but you have made me angry by offering sacrifices to Baal, just as the northern kingdom did. And now I'm going to pull you up by the roots. *
Jeremiah 11:18 Some people plotted to kill me. And like a lamb being led to the butcher, I knew nothing about their plans.
Jeremiah 11:19 But then the Lord told me that they had planned to chop me down like a tree— fruit and all— so that no one would ever remember me again.
Jeremiah 11:20 I prayed, “Lord All-Powerful, you always do what is right, and you know every thought. So I trust you to help me and to take revenge.”
Jeremiah 11:21 Then the Lord said: Jeremiah, some men from Anathoth say they will kill you, if you keep on speaking for me.
Jeremiah 11:22 But I will punish them. Their young men will die in battle, and their children will starve to death.
Jeremiah 11:23 And when I am finished, no one from their families will be left alive.
Jeremiah 12:1 Whenever I complain to you, Lord, you are always fair. But now I have questions about your justice. Why is life easy for sinners? Why are they successful?
Jeremiah 12:2 You plant them like trees; you let them prosper and produce fruit. Yet even when they praise you, they don't mean it.
Jeremiah 12:3 But you know, Lord, how faithful I've always been, even in my thoughts. So drag my enemies away and butcher them like sheep!
Jeremiah 12:4 How long will the ground be dry and the pasturelands parched? The birds and animals are dead and gone. And all of this happened because the people are so sinful. They even brag, “God can't see the sins we commit.”
Jeremiah 12:5 Jeremiah, if you get tired in a race against people, how can you possibly run against horses? If you fall in open fields, what will happen in the forest along the Jordan River?
Jeremiah 12:6 Even your own family has turned against you. They act friendly, but don't trust them. They're out to get you, and so is everyone else.
Jeremiah 12:7 I loved my people and chose them as my very own. But now I will reject them and hand them over to their enemies.
Jeremiah 12:8 My people have turned against me and roar at me like lions. That's why I hate them.
Jeremiah 12:9 My people are like a hawk surrounded and attacked by other hawks. Tell the wild animals to come and eat their fill.
Jeremiah 12:10 My beautiful land is ruined like a field or a vineyard trampled by shepherds and stripped bare by their flocks.
Jeremiah 12:11 Every field I see lies barren, and no one cares.
Jeremiah 12:12 A destroying army marches along desert roads and attacks everywhere. They are my deadly sword; no one is safe from them.
Jeremiah 12:13 My people, you planted wheat, but because I was furious, I let only weeds grow. You wore yourselves out and gained only shame!
Jeremiah 12:14 The Lord said: I gave this land to my people Israel, but enemies around it have attacked and robbed it. So I will uproot them from their own countries just as I will uproot Judah from its land.
Jeremiah 12:15 But later, I will have pity on these nations and bring them back to their own lands.
Jeremiah 12:16 They once taught my people to worship Baal. But if they admit I am the only true God, and if they let my people teach them how to worship me, these nations will also become my people.
Jeremiah 12:17 However, if they don't listen to me, I will uproot them from their lands and completely destroy them. I, the Lord, have spoken.
Jeremiah 13:1 The Lord told me, “Go and buy a pair of linen shorts. Wear them for a while, but don't wash them.”
Jeremiah 13:2 So I bought a pair of shorts and put them on.
Jeremiah 13:3 Then the Lord said,
Jeremiah 13:4 “Take off the shorts. Go to Parah and hide the shorts in a crack between some large rocks.”
Jeremiah 13:5 And that's what I did.
Jeremiah 13:6 Some time later the Lord said, “Go back and get the shorts.”
Jeremiah 13:7 I went back and dug the shorts out of their hiding place, but the cloth had rotted, and the shorts were ruined.
Jeremiah 13:8 Then the Lord said:
Jeremiah 13:9 Jeremiah, I will use Babylonia to destroy the pride of the people of Judah and Jerusalem.
Jeremiah 13:10 The people of Judah are evil and stubborn. So instead of listening to me, they do whatever they want and even worship other gods. When I am finished with these people, they will be good for nothing, just like this pair of shorts.
Jeremiah 13:11 These shorts were tight around your waist, and that's how tightly I held onto the kingdoms of Israel and Judah. I wanted them to be my people. I wanted to make them famous, so that other nations would praise and honor me, but they refused to obey me.
Jeremiah 13:12 Jeremiah, tell the people of Judah, “The Lord God of Israel orders you to fill your wine jars with wine.” They will answer, “Of course we fill our wine jars with wine! Why are you telling us something we already know?”
Jeremiah 13:13 Then say to them: I am the Lord, and what I'm going to do will make everyone in Judah and Jerusalem appear to be full of wine. And the worst ones will be the kings of David's family and the priests and the prophets.
Jeremiah 13:14 Then I will smash them against each other like jars. I will have no pity on the young or the old, and they will all be destroyed. I, the Lord, have spoken.
Jeremiah 13:15 People of Judah, don't be too proud to listen to what the Lord has said.
Jeremiah 13:16 You hope for light, but God is sending darkness. Evening shadows already deepen in the hills. So return to God and confess your sins to him before you trip and fall.
Jeremiah 13:17 If you are too proud to listen, I will weep alone. Tears will stream from my eyes when the Lord's people are taken away as prisoners.
Jeremiah 13:18 The Lord told me to tell you that your king and his mother must surrender their thrones and remove their crowns.
Jeremiah 13:19 The cities in the Southern Desert are surrounded; no one can get in or out. Everyone in Judah will be taken away.
Jeremiah 13:20 Jerusalem, you were so proud of ruling the people of Judah. But where are they now? Look north, and you will see your enemies approaching.
Jeremiah 13:21 You once trusted them to help, but now I'll let them rule you. What do you say about that? You will be in pain like a woman giving birth.
Jeremiah 13:22 Do you know why your clothes were torn off and you were abused? It was because of your terrible sins.
Jeremiah 13:23 Can you ever change and do what's right? Can people change the color of their skin, or can a leopard remove its spots? If so, then maybe you can change and learn to do right.
Jeremiah 13:24 I will scatter you, just as the desert wind blows husks from grain tossed in the air.
Jeremiah 13:25 I won't change my mind. I, the Lord, have spoken. You rejected me and worshiped false gods. *
Jeremiah 13:26 You were married to me, but you were unfaithful. You even became a prostitute by worshiping disgusting gods on hilltops and in fields.
Jeremiah 13:27 So I'll rip off your clothes and leave you naked and ashamed for everyone to see. You are doomed! Will you ever be worthy to worship me again?
Jeremiah 14:1 When there had been no rain for a long time, the Lord told me to say to the people:
Jeremiah 14:2 Judah and Jerusalem weep as the land dries up.
Jeremiah 14:3 Rulers send their servants to the storage pits for water. But there's none to be found; they return in despair with their jars still empty.
Jeremiah 14:4 There has been no rain, and farmers feel sick as they watch cracks appear in the dry ground.
Jeremiah 14:5 A deer gives birth in a field, then abandons her newborn fawn and leaves in search of grass.
Jeremiah 14:6 Wild donkeys go blind from starvation. So they stand on barren hilltops and sniff the air, hoping to smell green grass.
Jeremiah 14:7 We rejected you and did evil, so we deserve to be punished. But if you rescue us, Lord, everyone will see how great you are.
Jeremiah 14:8 You're our only hope; you alone can save us now. You help us one day, but you're gone the next.
Jeremiah 14:9 Did this disaster take you by surprise? Are you a warrior with your hands tied? You have chosen us, and your temple is here. Don't abandon us!
Jeremiah 14:10 My people, you love to wander away; you don't even try to stay close to me. So now I will reject you and punish you for your sins. I, the Lord, have spoken.
Jeremiah 14:11 The Lord said, “Jeremiah, don't ask me to help these people.
Jeremiah 14:12 They may even go without eating and offer sacrifices to please me and to give thanks. But when they cry out for my help, I won't listen, and I won't accept their sacrifices. Instead, I'll send war, starvation, and disease to wipe them out.”
Jeremiah 14:13 I replied, “The other prophets keep telling everyone that you won't send starvation or war, and that you're going to give us peace.”
Jeremiah 14:14 The Lord answered: They claim to speak for me, but they're lying! I didn't even speak to them, much less choose them to be my prophets. Their messages come from worthless dreams, useless fortunetelling, and their own imaginations.
Jeremiah 14:15 Those lying prophets say there will be peace and plenty of food. But I say that those same prophets will die from war and hunger.
Jeremiah 14:16 And everyone who listens to them will be killed, just as they deserve. Their dead bodies will be thrown out into the streets of Jerusalem, because their families will also be dead, and no one will be left to bury them.
Jeremiah 14:17 Jeremiah, go and tell the people how you feel about all this. So I told them: “Tears will flood my eyes both day and night, because my nation suffers from a deadly wound.
Jeremiah 14:18 In the fields I see the bodies of those killed in battle. And in the towns I see crowds dying of hunger. But the prophets and priests go about their business, without understanding what has happened.”
Jeremiah 14:19 Have you rejected Judah, Lord? Do you hate Jerusalem? Why did you strike down Judah with a fatal wound? We had hoped for peace and a time of healing, but all we got was terror.
Jeremiah 14:20 We and our ancestors are guilty of rebelling against you.
Jeremiah 14:21 If you save us, it will show how great you are. Don't let our enemies disgrace your temple, your beautiful throne. Don't forget that you promised to rescue us.
Jeremiah 14:22 Idols can't send rain, and showers don't fall by themselves. Only you control the rain, so we put our trust in you, the Lord our God.
Jeremiah 15:1 The Lord said to me: Even if Moses and Samuel were here, praying with you, I wouldn't change my mind. So send the people of Judah away.
Jeremiah 15:2 And when they ask where they are going, tell them that I, the Lord, have said: Some of you are going to die of horrible diseases. Others are going to die in war or from starvation. The rest will be led away to a foreign country.
Jeremiah 15:3 I will punish you in four different ways: You will be killed in war and your bodies dragged off by dogs, your flesh will be eaten by birds, and your bones will be chewed on by wild animals.
Jeremiah 15:4 This punishment will happen because of the horrible things your King Manasseh did. And you will be disgusting to all nations on earth.
Jeremiah 15:5 People of Jerusalem, who will feel sorry for you? Will anyone bother to ask if you are well?
Jeremiah 15:6 My people, you abandoned me and walked away. I am tired of showing mercy; that's why I'll destroy you
Jeremiah 15:7 by scattering you like straw blown by the wind. I will punish you with sorrow and death, because you refuse to change your ways.
Jeremiah 15:8 There will be more widows in Judah than grains of sand on a beach. A surprise attack at noon! And the mothers in Jerusalem mourn for their children.
Jeremiah 15:9 A mother is in deep despair and struggles for breath. Her daylight has turned to darkness— she has suffered the loss of her seven sons. I will kill anyone who survives. I, the Lord, have spoken.
Jeremiah 15:10 I wish I had never been born! I'm always in trouble with everyone in Judah. I never lend or borrow money, but everyone curses me just the same.
Jeremiah 15:11 Then the Lord replied, “I promise to protect you, and when disaster comes, even your enemies will beg you for help.”
Jeremiah 15:12 People of Judah, just as you can't break iron mixed with bronze, you can't defeat the enemies that will attack from the north.
Jeremiah 15:13 I will give them everything you own, because you have sinned everywhere in your country.
Jeremiah 15:14 My anger is a fire that cannot be put out, so I will make you slaves of your enemies in a foreign land.
Jeremiah 15:15 You can see how I suffer insult after insult, all because of you, Lord. Don't be so patient with my enemies; take revenge on them before they kill me.
Jeremiah 15:16 When you spoke to me, I was glad to obey, because I belong to you, the Lord All-Powerful.
Jeremiah 15:17 I don't go to parties and have a good time. Instead, I keep to myself, because you have filled me with your anger.
Jeremiah 15:18 I am badly injured and in constant pain. Are you going to disappoint me, like a stream that goes dry in the heat of summer?
Jeremiah 15:19 Then the Lord told me: Stop talking like a fool! If you turn back to me and speak my message, I will let you be my prophet once again. I hope the people of Judah will accept what you say. But you can ignore their threats, *
Jeremiah 15:20 because I am making you strong, like a bronze wall. They are evil and violent, but when they attack,
Jeremiah 15:21 I will be there to rescue you. I, the Lord, have spoken.
Jeremiah 16:1 The Lord said to me:
Jeremiah 16:2 Jeremiah, don't get married and have children—Judah is no place to raise a family.
Jeremiah 16:3 I'll tell you what's going to happen to children and their parents here.
Jeremiah 16:4 They will die of horrible diseases and of war and starvation. No one will give them a funeral or bury them, and their bodies will be food for the birds and wild animals. And what's left will lie on the ground like manure.
Jeremiah 16:5 When someone dies, don't visit the family or show any sorrow. I will no longer love or bless or have any pity on the people of Judah.
Jeremiah 16:6 Rich and poor alike will die and be left unburied. No one will mourn and show their sorrow by cutting themselves or shaving their heads.
Jeremiah 16:7 No one will bring food and wine to help comfort those who are mourning the death of their father or mother.
Jeremiah 16:8 Don't even set foot in a house where there is eating and drinking and celebrating.
Jeremiah 16:9 Warn the people of Judah that I, the Lord All-Powerful, will put an end to all their parties and wedding celebrations.
Jeremiah 16:10 They will ask, “Why has the Lord our God threatened us with so many disasters? Have we done something wrong or sinned against him?”
Jeremiah 16:11 Then tell them I have said: People of Judah, your ancestors turned away from me; they rejected my laws and teachings and started worshiping other gods.
Jeremiah 16:12 And you have done even worse! You are stubborn, and instead of obeying me, you do whatever evil comes to your mind.
Jeremiah 16:13 So I will throw you into a land that you and your ancestors know nothing about, a place where you will have to worship other gods both day and night. And I won't feel the least bit sorry for you.
Jeremiah 16:14 A time will come when you will again worship me. But you will no longer call me the Living Lord who rescued Israel from Egypt.
Jeremiah 16:15 Instead, you will call me the Living Lord who rescued you from that country in the north and from the other countries where I had forced you to go. Someday I will bring you back to this land that I gave your ancestors.
Jeremiah 16:16 But for now, I am sending enemies who will catch you like fish and hunt you down like wild animals in the hills and the caves.
Jeremiah 16:17 I can see everything you are doing, even if you try to hide your sins from me.
Jeremiah 16:18 I will punish you double for your sins, because you have polluted my own land. You have filled it with lifeless idols that remind me of dead bodies.
Jeremiah 16:19 Our Lord, you are the one who gives me strength and protects me like a fortress when I am in trouble. People will come to you from distant nations and say, “Our ancestors worshiped false and useless gods,
Jeremiah 16:20 worthless idols made by human hands.”
Jeremiah 16:21 Then the Lord replied, “That's why I will teach them about my power, and they will know that I truly am the Lord.”
Jeremiah 17:1 People of Judah, your sins cannot be erased. They are written on your hearts like words chiseled in stone or carved on the corners of your altars. *
Jeremiah 17:2 One generation after another has set up pagan altars and worshiped the goddess Asherah everywhere in your country— on hills and mountains, and under large trees.
Jeremiah 17:3 So I'll take everything you own, including your altars, and give it all to your enemies.
Jeremiah 17:4 You will lose the land that I gave you, and I will make you slaves in a foreign country, because you have made my anger blaze up like a fire that won't stop burning.
Jeremiah 17:5 I, the Lord, have put a curse on those who turn from me and trust in human strength.
Jeremiah 17:6 They will dry up like a bush in salty desert soil, where nothing can grow.
Jeremiah 17:7 But I will bless those who trust me, the Lord.
Jeremiah 17:8 They will be like trees growing beside a stream— trees with roots that reach down to the water, and with leaves that are always green. They bear fruit every year and are never worried by a lack of rain.
Jeremiah 17:9 You people of Judah are so deceitful that you even fool yourselves, and you can't change.
Jeremiah 17:10 But I know your deeds and your thoughts, and I will make sure you get what you deserve.
Jeremiah 17:11 You cheated others, but everything you gained will fly away, like birds hatched from stolen eggs. Then you will discover what fools you are.
Jeremiah 17:12 Our Lord, your temple is a glorious throne that has stood on a mountain from the beginning.
Jeremiah 17:13 You are a spring of water giving Israel life and hope. But if the people reject what you have told me, they will be swept away like words written in dust.
Jeremiah 17:14 You, Lord, are the one I praise. So heal me and rescue me! Then I will be completely well and perfectly safe.
Jeremiah 17:15 The people of Judah say to me, “Jeremiah, you claimed to tell us what the Lord has said. So why hasn't it come true?”
Jeremiah 17:16 Our Lord, you chose me to care for your people, and that's what I have done. You know everything I have said, and I have never once asked you to punish them.
Jeremiah 17:17 I trust you for protection in times of trouble, so don't frighten me.
Jeremiah 17:18 Keep me from failure and disgrace, but make my enemies fail and be disgraced. Send destruction to make their worst fears come true.
Jeremiah 17:19+JER The Lord said: Jeremiah, stand at each city gate in Jerusalem, including the one the king uses, and speak to him and everyone else. Tell them I have said: I am the Lord, so pay attention.
Jeremiah 17:21+JER If you value your lives, don't do any work on the Sabbath. Don't carry anything through the city gates or through the door of your house, or anywhere else. Keep the Sabbath day sacred! I gave this command to your ancestors, but they were stubborn and refused to obey or to be corrected. But if you obey,
Jeremiah 17:25 then Judah and Jerusalem will always be ruled by kings from David's family. The king and his officials will ride through these gates on horses or in chariots, and the people of Judah and Jerusalem will be with them. There will always be people living in Jerusalem,
Jeremiah 17:26 and others will come here from the nearby villages, from the towns of Judah and Benjamin, from the hill country and the foothills to the west, and from the Southern Desert. They will bring sacrifices to please me and to give me thanks, as well as offerings of grain and incense.
Jeremiah 17:27 But if you keep on carrying things through the city gates on the Sabbath and keep treating it as any other day, I will set fire to these gates and burn down the whole city, including the fortresses.
Jeremiah 18:1 The Lord told me,
Jeremiah 18:2 “Jeremiah, go to the pottery shop, and when you get there, I will tell you what to say to the people.”
Jeremiah 18:3 I went there and saw the potter making clay pots on his pottery wheel.
Jeremiah 18:4 And whenever the clay would not take the shape he wanted, he would change his mind and form it into some other shape.
Jeremiah 18:5 Then the Lord told me to say:
Jeremiah 18:6 People of Israel, I, the Lord, have power over you, just as a potter has power over clay.
Jeremiah 18:7 If I threaten to uproot and shatter an evil nation,
Jeremiah 18:8 and that nation turns from its evil, I will change my mind.
Jeremiah 18:9 If I promise to make a nation strong,
Jeremiah 18:10 but its people start disobeying me and doing evil, then I will change my mind and not help them at all.
Jeremiah 18:11 So listen to me, people of Judah and Jerusalem! I have decided to strike you with disaster, and I won't change my mind unless you stop sinning and start living right.
Jeremiah 18:12 But I know you won't listen. You might as well answer, “We don't care what you say. We have made plans to sin, and we are going to be stubborn and do as we please!”
Jeremiah 18:13 So I, the Lord, command you to ask the nations, and find out if they have ever heard of such a horrible sin as what you have done.
Jeremiah 18:14 The snow on Lebanon's mountains never melts away, and the streams there never run dry.
Jeremiah 18:15 But you, my people, have turned from me to burn incense to worthless idols. You have left the ancient road to follow an unknown path where you stumble over idols.
Jeremiah 18:16 Your land will be ruined, and every passerby will look at it with horror and make insulting remarks.
Jeremiah 18:17 When your enemies attack, I will scatter you like dust blown by an eastern wind. Then, on that day of disaster, I will turn my back on you.
Jeremiah 18:18 Some of the people said, “Let's get rid of Jeremiah! We will always have priests to teach us God's laws, as well as wise people to give us advice, and prophets to speak the Lord's messages. So, instead of listening to Jeremiah any longer, let's accuse him of a crime.”
Jeremiah 18:19 Please, Lord, answer my prayer. Make my enemies stop accusing me of evil.
Jeremiah 18:20 I tried to help them, but they are paying me back by digging a pit to trap me. I even begged you not to punish them.
Jeremiah 18:21 But now I am asking you to let their children starve or be killed in war. Let women lose their husbands and sons to disease and violence.
Jeremiah 18:22 These people have dug pits and set traps for me, Lord. Make them scream in fear when you send enemy troops to attack their homes.
Jeremiah 18:23 You know they plan to kill me. So get angry and punish them! Don't ever forgive their terrible crimes.
Jeremiah 19:1 The Lord said: Jeremiah, go to the pottery shop and buy a clay jar. Then take along some of the city officials and leading priests
Jeremiah 19:2 and go to Hinnom Valley, just outside Potsherd Gate. Tell the people that I have said:
Jeremiah 19:3 I am the Lord All-Powerful, the God of Israel, and you kings of Judah and you people of Jerusalem had better pay attention. I am going to bring so much trouble on this valley that everyone who hears about it will be shocked.
Jeremiah 19:4+JER The people of Judah stopped worshiping me and made this valley into a place of worship for Baal and other gods that have never helped them or their ancestors or their kings. And they have committed murder here, burning their young, innocent children as sacrifices to Baal. I have never even thought of telling you to do that.
Jeremiah 19:6 So watch out! Someday this place will no longer be called Topheth or Hinnom Valley. It will be called Slaughter Valley!
Jeremiah 19:7 You people of Judah and Jerusalem may have big plans, but here in this valley I'll ruin those plans. I'll let your enemies kill you, and I'll tell the birds and wild animals to eat your dead bodies.
Jeremiah 19:8 I will turn Jerusalem into a pile of rubble, and every passerby will be shocked and horrified and will make insulting remarks.
Jeremiah 19:9 And while your enemies are trying to break through your city walls to kill you, the food supply will run out. You will become so hungry that you will eat the flesh of your friends and even of your own children.
Jeremiah 19:10 Jeremiah, as soon as you have said this, smash the jar while the people are watching.
Jeremiah 19:11 Then tell them that I have also said: I am the Lord All-Powerful, and I warn you that I will shatter Judah and Jerusalem just like this jar that is broken beyond repair. You will bury your dead here in Topheth, but so many of you will die that there won't be enough room.
Jeremiah 19:12+JER I will make Jerusalem as unclean as Topheth, by filling the city with your dead bodies. I will do this because you and your kings have gone up to the roofs of your houses and burned incense to the stars in the sky, as though they were gods. And you have given sacrifices of wine to foreign gods.
Jeremiah 19:14 I went to Topheth, where I told the people what the Lord had said. Then I went to the temple courtyard and shouted to the people,
Jeremiah 19:15 “Listen, everyone! Some time ago, the Lord All-Powerful, the God of Israel, warned you that he would bring disaster on Jerusalem and all nearby villages. But you were stubborn and refused to listen. Now the Lord is going to bring the disaster he promised.”
Jeremiah 20:1 Pashhur son of Immer was a priest and the chief of temple security. He heard what I had said,
Jeremiah 20:2 and so he hit me. Then he had me arrested and put in chains at the Benjamin Gate in the Lord's temple.
Jeremiah 20:3 The next day, when Pashhur let me go free, I told him that the Lord had said: No longer will I call you Pashhur. Instead, I will call you Afraid-of-Everything.
Jeremiah 20:4 You will be afraid, and you will bring fear to your friends as well. You will see enemies kill them in battle. Then I will let the king of Babylonia take everyone in Judah prisoner, killing some and dragging the rest away to Babylonia.
Jeremiah 20:5 He will clean out the royal treasury and take everything else of value from Jerusalem.
Jeremiah 20:6 Pashhur, you are guilty of telling lies and claiming they were messages from me. That's why I will let the Babylonians take you, your family, and your friends as prisoners to Babylonia, where you will all die and be buried.
Jeremiah 20:7 You tricked me, Lord, and I was really fooled. You are stronger than I am, and you have defeated me. People never stop sneering and insulting me.
Jeremiah 20:8 You have let me announce only injustice and death. Your message has brought me nothing but insults and trouble.
Jeremiah 20:9 Sometimes I tell myself not to think about you, Lord, or even mention your name. But your message burns in my heart and bones, and I cannot keep silent.
Jeremiah 20:10 I heard the crowds whisper, “Everyone is afraid. Now's our chance to accuse Jeremiah!” All of my so-called friends are just waiting for me to make a mistake. They say, “Maybe Jeremiah can be tricked. Then we can overpower him and get even at last.”
Jeremiah 20:11 But you, Lord, are a mighty soldier, standing at my side. Those troublemakers will fall down and fail— terribly embarrassed, forever ashamed.
Jeremiah 20:12 Lord All-Powerful, you test those who do right, and you know every heart and mind. I have told you my complaints, so let me watch you take revenge on my enemies.
Jeremiah 20:13 I sing praises to you, Lord. You rescue the oppressed from the wicked.
Jeremiah 20:14 Put a curse on the day I was born! Don't bless that day.
Jeremiah 20:15 Put a curse on the man who told my father, “Good news! You have a son.”
Jeremiah 20:16 May that man be like the towns you destroyed without pity. Let him hear shouts of alarm in the morning and battle cries at noon.
Jeremiah 20:17 He deserves to die for not killing me before I was born. Then my mother's body would have been my grave.
Jeremiah 20:18 Why did I have to be born? Was it just to suffer and die in shame?
Jeremiah 21:1 King Zedekiah of Judah sent for Pashhur son of Malchiah and for a priest named Zephaniah son of Maaseiah. Then he told them, “Talk with Jeremiah for me.” So they came to me and said,
Jeremiah 21:2 “King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia has attacked Judah. Please ask the Lord to work miracles for our people, as he has done in the past, so that Nebuchadnezzar will leave us alone.”
Jeremiah 21:3+JER I told them that the Lord God of Israel had told me to say to King Zedekiah: The Babylonians have surrounded Jerusalem and want to kill you and your people. You are asking me to save you, but you have made me furious. So I will stretch out my mighty arm and fight against you myself. Your army is using spears and swords to fight the Babylonians, but I will make your own weapons turn and attack you. I will send a horrible disease to kill many of the people and animals in Jerusalem, and there will be nothing left to eat. Finally, I will let King Nebuchadnezzar and his army fight their way to the center of Jerusalem and capture everyone who is left alive, including you and your officials. But Nebuchadnezzar won't be kind or show any mercy—he will have you killed! I, the Lord, have spoken.
Jeremiah 21:8 Then I told them that the Lord had said: People of Jerusalem, I, the Lord, give you the choice of life or death.
Jeremiah 21:9 The Babylonian army has surrounded Jerusalem, so if you want to live, you must go out and surrender to them. But if you want to die because of hunger, disease, or war, then stay here in the city.
Jeremiah 21:10 I have decided not to rescue Jerusalem. Instead, I am going to let the king of Babylonia burn it to the ground. I, the Lord, have spoken. *
Jeremiah 21:11 Pay attention, you that belong to the royal family.
Jeremiah 21:12 Each new day, make sure that justice is done, and rescue those who are being robbed. Or else my anger will flame up like a fire that never goes out.
Jeremiah 21:13 Jerusalem, from your mountaintop you look out over the valleys and think you are safe. But I, the Lord, am angry,
Jeremiah 21:14 and I will punish you as you deserve. I'll set your palace on fire, and everything around you will go up in smoke.
Jeremiah 22:1+JER The Lord sent me to the palace of the king of Judah to speak to the king, his officials, and everyone else who was there. The Lord told me to say: I am the Lord, so pay attention! You have been allowing people to cheat, rob, and take advantage of widows, orphans, and foreigners who live here. Innocent people have become victims of injustice, and some of them have even been killed. But now I command you to do what is right and see that justice is done. Rescue everyone who has suffered from injustice.
Jeremiah 22:4 If you obey me, the kings from David's family will continue to rule Judah from this palace. They and their officials will ride in and out on their horses or in their chariots.
Jeremiah 22:5 But if you ignore me, I promise in my own name that this palace will lie in ruins.
Jeremiah 22:6 Listen to what I think about it: The palace of Judah's king is as glorious as Gilead or Lebanon's highest peaks. But it will be as empty as a ghost-town when I'm through with it.
Jeremiah 22:7 I'll send troops to tear it apart, and its beautiful cedar beams will be used for firewood.
Jeremiah 22:8 People from different nations will pass by and ask, “Why did the Lord do this to such a great city as Jerusalem?”
Jeremiah 22:9 Others will answer, “It's because the people worshiped foreign gods and broke the agreement that the Lord their God had made with them.”
Jeremiah 22:10 King Josiah is dead, so don't mourn for him. Instead, mourn for his son King Jehoahaz, dragged off to another country, never to return.
Jeremiah 22:11+JER Jehoahaz became king of Judah after his father King Josiah died. But Jehoahaz was taken as a prisoner to a foreign country. Now I, the Lord, promise that he will die there without ever seeing his own land again. *
Jeremiah 22:13 King Jehoiakim, you are doomed! You built a palace with large rooms upstairs.
Jeremiah 22:14 You put in big windows and used cedar paneling and red paint. But you were unfair and forced the builders to work without pay. *
Jeremiah 22:15 More cedar in your palace doesn't make you a better king than your father Josiah. He always did right— he gave justice to the poor and was honest.
Jeremiah 22:16 That's what it means to truly know me. So he lived a comfortable life and always had enough to eat and drink.
Jeremiah 22:17 But all you think about is how to cheat or abuse or murder some innocent victim.
Jeremiah 22:18 Jehoiakim, no one will mourn at your funeral. They won't turn to each other and ask, “Why did our great king have to die?”
Jeremiah 22:19 You will be given a burial fit for a donkey; your body will be dragged outside the city gates and tossed in the dirt. I, the Lord, have spoken.
Jeremiah 22:20 People of Jerusalem, the nations you trusted have been crushed. Go to Lebanon and weep; cry in the land of Bashan and in Moab.
Jeremiah 22:21 When times were good, I warned you. But you ignored me, just as you have done since Israel was young.
Jeremiah 22:22 Now you will be disgraced because of your sins. Your leaders will be swept away by the wind, and the nations you trusted will be captured and dragged to a foreign country.
Jeremiah 22:23 Those who live in the palace paneled with cedar will groan with pain like women giving birth.
Jeremiah 22:24 King Jehoiachin, son of Jehoiakim, even if you were the ring I wear as the sign of my royal power, I would still pull you from my finger.
Jeremiah 22:25 I would hand you over to the enemy you fear, to King Nebuchadnezzar and his army, who want to kill you.
Jeremiah 22:26 You and your mother were born in Judah, but I will throw both of you into a foreign country, where you will die,
Jeremiah 22:27 longing to return home.
Jeremiah 22:28 Jehoiachin, you are unwanted like a broken clay pot. So you and your children will be thrown into a country you know nothing about.
Jeremiah 22:29 Land of Judah, I am the Lord. Now listen to what I say!
Jeremiah 22:30 Erase the names of Jehoiachin's children from the royal records. He is a complete failure, and so none of them will ever be king. I, the Lord, have spoken.
Jeremiah 23:1 You leaders of my people are like shepherds that kill and scatter the sheep.
Jeremiah 23:2 You were supposed to take care of my people, but instead you chased them away. So now I'll punish you severely and make you pay for your crimes!
Jeremiah 23:3 I will bring the rest of my people home from the lands where I have scattered them, and they will grow into a mighty nation.
Jeremiah 23:4 I promise to choose leaders who will care for them like real shepherds. All of my people will be there, and they will never again be frightened.
Jeremiah 23:5 Someday I will appoint an honest king from the family of David, a king who will be wise and rule with justice.
Jeremiah 23:6 As long as he is king, Israel will have peace, and Judah will be safe. The name of this king will be “The Lord Gives Justice.”
Jeremiah 23:7 A time will come when you will again worship me. But you will no longer call me the Living God who rescued Israel from Egypt.
Jeremiah 23:8 Instead, you will call me the Living God who rescued you from the land in the north and from all the other countries where I had forced you to go. And you will once again live in your own land.
Jeremiah 23:9 When I think of the prophets, I am shocked, and I tremble like someone drunk, because of the Lord and his sacred words.
Jeremiah 23:10 Those unfaithful prophets misuse their power all over the country. So God turned the pasturelands into scorching deserts.
Jeremiah 23:11 The Lord told me to say: You prophets and priests think so little of me, the Lord, that you even sin in my own temple!
Jeremiah 23:12 Now I will punish you with disaster, and you will slip and fall in the darkness. I, the Lord, have spoken.
Jeremiah 23:13 The prophets in Samaria were repulsive to me, because they preached in the name of Baal and led my people astray.
Jeremiah 23:14 And you prophets in Jerusalem are even worse. You're unfaithful in marriage and never tell the truth. You even lead others to sin instead of helping them turn back to me. You and the people of Jerusalem are evil like Sodom and Gomorrah.
Jeremiah 23:15 You prophets in Jerusalem have spread evil everywhere. That's why I, the Lord, promise to give you bitter poison to eat and drink.
Jeremiah 23:16 Don't listen to the lies of these false prophets, you people of Judah! The message they preach is something they imagined; it did not come from me, the Lord All-Powerful.
Jeremiah 23:17 These prophets go to people who refuse to respect me and who are stubborn and do whatever they please. The prophets tell them, “The Lord has promised everything will be fine.”
Jeremiah 23:18 But I, the Lord, tell you that these prophets have never attended a meeting of my council in heaven or heard me speak.
Jeremiah 23:19 They are evil! So in my anger I will strike them like a violent storm.
Jeremiah 23:20 I won't calm down, until I have finished what I have decided to do. Someday you will understand exactly what I mean.
Jeremiah 23:21 I did not send these prophets or speak to them, but they ran to find you and to preach their message.
Jeremiah 23:22 If they had been in a meeting of my council in heaven, they would have told you people of Judah to give up your sins and come back to me.
Jeremiah 23:23 I am everywhere— both near and far,
Jeremiah 23:24 in heaven and on earth. There are no secret places where you can hide from me.
Jeremiah 23:25 These unfaithful prophets claim that I have given them a dream or a vision, and then they tell lies in my name.
Jeremiah 23:26 But everything they say comes from their own twisted minds. How long can this go on?
Jeremiah 23:27 They tell each other their dreams and try to get my people to reject me, just as their ancestors left me and worshiped Baal.
Jeremiah 23:28 Their dreams and my truth are as different as straw and wheat. But when prophets speak for me, they must say only what I have told them.
Jeremiah 23:29 My words are a powerful fire; they are a hammer that shatters rocks.
Jeremiah 23:30+JER These unfaithful prophets claim I give them their dreams, but it isn't true. I didn't choose them to be my prophets, and yet they babble on and on, speaking in my name, while stealing words from each other. And when my people hear these liars, they are led astray instead of being helped. So I warn you that I am now the enemy of these prophets. I, the Lord, have spoken.
Jeremiah 23:33 Jeremiah, when a prophet or a priest or anyone else comes to you and asks, “Does the Lord have news for us?” tell them, “You people are a nuisance to the Lord, and he will get rid of you.”
Jeremiah 23:34 If any of you say, “Here is news from the Lord,” I will punish you and your families, even if you are a prophet or a priest.
Jeremiah 23:35 Instead, you must ask your friends and relatives, “What answer did the Lord give?” or “What has the Lord said?”
Jeremiah 23:36 It seems that you each have your own news! So if you say, “Here is news from the Lord,” you are twisting my words into a lie. Remember that I am your God, the Lord All-Powerful.
Jeremiah 23:37 If you go to a prophet, it's all right to ask, “What answer did the Lord give to my question?” or “What has the Lord said?”
Jeremiah 23:38 But if you disobey me and say, “Here is news from the Lord,”
Jeremiah 23:39 I will pick you up and throw you far away. And I will abandon this city of Jerusalem that I gave to your ancestors.
Jeremiah 23:40 You will never be free from your shame and disgrace.
Jeremiah 24:1 The Lord spoke to me in a vision after King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia had come to Judah and taken King Jehoiachin, his officials, and all the skilled workers back to Babylonia. In this vision I saw two baskets of figs in front of the Lord's temple.
Jeremiah 24:2 One basket was full of very good figs that ripened early, and the other was full of rotten figs that were not fit to eat.
Jeremiah 24:3 “Jeremiah,” the Lord asked, “what do you see?” “Figs,” I said. “Some are very good, but the others are too rotten to eat.”
Jeremiah 24:4 Then the Lord told me to say:
Jeremiah 24:5 People of Judah, the good figs stand for those of you I sent away as exiles to Babylonia,
Jeremiah 24:6 where I am watching over them. Then someday I will bring them back to this land. I will plant them, instead of uprooting them, and I will build them up, rather than tearing them down.
Jeremiah 24:7 I will give them a desire to know me and to be my people. They will want me to be their God, and they will turn back to me with all their heart.
Jeremiah 24:8 The rotten figs stand for King Zedekiah of Judah, his officials, and all the others who were not taken away to Babylonia, whether they stayed here in Judah or went to live in Egypt.
Jeremiah 24:9 I will punish them with a terrible disaster, and everyone on earth will tremble when they hear about it. I will force the people of Judah to go to foreign countries, where they will be cursed and insulted.
Jeremiah 24:10 War and hunger and disease will strike them, until they finally disappear from the land that I gave them and their ancestors.
Jeremiah 25:1+JER In the fourth year that Jehoiakim was king of Judah, which was the first year that Nebuchadnezzar was king of Babylonia, the Lord told me to speak to the people of Judah and Jerusalem. So I told them:
Jeremiah 25:3 For 23 years now, ever since the thirteenth year that Josiah was king, I have been telling you what the Lord has told me. But you have not listened.
Jeremiah 25:4 The Lord has sent prophets to you time after time, but you refused to listen.
Jeremiah 25:5 They told you that the Lord had said: Change your ways! If you stop doing evil, I will let you stay forever in this land that I gave your ancestors.
Jeremiah 25:6 I don't want to harm you. So don't make me angry by worshiping idols and other gods.
Jeremiah 25:7 But you refused to listen to my prophets. So I, the Lord, say that you have made me angry by worshiping idols, and you are the ones who were hurt by what you did.
Jeremiah 25:8 You refused to listen to me,
Jeremiah 25:9 and now I will let you be attacked by nations from the north, and especially by my servant, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia. You and other nearby nations will be destroyed and left in ruins forever. Everyone who sees what has happened will be shocked, but they will still make fun of you.
Jeremiah 25:10 I will put an end to your parties and wedding celebrations; no one will grind grain or be here to light the lamps at night.
Jeremiah 25:11 This country will be as empty as a desert, because I will make all of you the slaves of the king of Babylonia for 70 years.
Jeremiah 25:12 When that time is up, I will punish the king of Babylonia and his people for everything they have done wrong, and I will turn that country into a wasteland forever.
Jeremiah 25:13 My servant Jeremiah has told you what I said I will do to Babylonia and to the other nations, and he wrote it all down in this book. I will do everything I threatened.
Jeremiah 25:14 I will pay back the Babylonians for every wrong they have done. Great kings from many other nations will conquer the Babylonians and force them to be slaves.
Jeremiah 25:15 The Lord God of Israel showed me a vision in which he said, “Jeremiah, here is a cup filled with the wine of my anger. Take it and make every nation drink some.
Jeremiah 25:16 They will vomit and act crazy, because of the war this cup of anger will bring to them.”
Jeremiah 25:17 I took the cup from the Lord's hand, and I went to the kings of the nations and made each of them drink some.
Jeremiah 25:18 I started with Jerusalem and the towns of Judah, and the king and his officials were removed from power in disgrace. Everyone still makes insulting jokes about them and uses their names as curse words.
Jeremiah 25:19 The second place I went was Egypt, where everyone had to drink from the cup, including the king and his officials, the other government workers, the rest of the Egyptians,
Jeremiah 25:20 and all the foreigners who lived in the country. Next I went to the king of Uz, and then to the four kings of Philistia, who ruled from Ashkelon, Gaza, Ekron, and what was left of Ashdod.
Jeremiah 25:21 Then I went to the kings of Edom, Moab, Ammon,
Jeremiah 25:22 and to the kings of Tyre, Sidon, and their colonies across the sea.
Jeremiah 25:23+JER After this, I went to the kings of Dedan, Tema, Buz, the tribes of the Arabian Desert,
Jeremiah 25:25 Zimri, Elam, Media,
Jeremiah 25:26 and the countries in the north, both near and far. I went to all the countries on earth, one after another, and finally to Babylonia.
Jeremiah 25:27 The Lord had said to tell each king, “The Lord All-Powerful, the God of Israel, commands you to drink from this cup that is full of the wine of his anger. It will make you so drunk that you will vomit. And when the Lord sends war against the nations, you will be completely defeated.”
Jeremiah 25:28 The Lord told me that if any of them refused to drink from the cup, I must tell them that he had said, “I, the Lord All-Powerful, command you to drink.
Jeremiah 25:29 Starting with my own city of Jerusalem, everyone on earth will suffer from war. So there is no way I will let you escape unharmed.”
Jeremiah 25:30 The Lord told me to say: From my sacred temple I will roar like thunder, while I trample my people and everyone else as though they were grapes.
Jeremiah 25:31 My voice will be heard everywhere on earth, accusing nations of their crimes and sentencing the guilty to death.
Jeremiah 25:32 The Lord All-Powerful says: You can see disaster spreading from far across the earth, from nation to nation like a horrible storm.
Jeremiah 25:33 When it strikes, I will kill so many people that their bodies will cover the ground like manure. No one will be left to bury them or to mourn.
Jeremiah 25:34 The Lord's people are his flock, and you leaders were the shepherds. But now it's your turn to be butchered like sheep. You'll shatter like fine pottery dropped on the floor. So roll on the ground, crying and mourning.
Jeremiah 25:35 You have nowhere to run, nowhere to hide. *
Jeremiah 25:36+JER Listen to the cries of the shepherds, as the Lord's burning anger turns peaceful meadows into barren deserts.
Jeremiah 25:38 Like a lion leaving its den, the Lord has abandoned his people to the destruction of war.
Jeremiah 26:1 Soon after Jehoiakim became king of Judah, the Lord said:
Jeremiah 26:2 Jeremiah, I have a message for everyone who comes from the towns of Judah to worship in my temple. Go to the temple courtyard and speak every word that I tell you.
Jeremiah 26:3 Maybe the people will listen this time. And if they stop doing wrong, I will change my mind and not punish them for their sins.
Jeremiah 26:4 Tell them that I have said: You have refused to listen to me and to obey my laws and teachings.
Jeremiah 26:5 Again and again I have sent my servants the prophets to preach to you, but you ignored them as well. Now I am warning you that if you don't start obeying me at once,
Jeremiah 26:6 I will destroy this temple, just as I destroyed the town of Shiloh. Then everyone on earth will use the name “Jerusalem” as a curse word.
Jeremiah 26:7 The priests, the prophets, and everyone else in the temple heard what I said,
Jeremiah 26:8+JER and as soon as I finished, they all crowded around me and started shouting, “Why did you preach that the Lord will destroy this temple, just as he destroyed Shiloh? Why did you say that Jerusalem will be empty and lie in ruins? You ought to be put to death for saying such things in the Lord's name!” Then they had me arrested.
Jeremiah 26:10 The royal officers heard what had happened, and they came from the palace to the new gate of the temple to be the judges at my trial.
Jeremiah 26:11 While they listened, the priests and the prophets said to the crowd, “All of you have heard Jeremiah prophesy that Jerusalem will be destroyed. He deserves the death penalty.”
Jeremiah 26:12+JER Then I told the judges and everyone else: The Lord himself sent me to tell you about the terrible things he will do to you, to Jerusalem, and to the temple. But if you change your ways and start obeying the Lord, he will change his mind.
Jeremiah 26:14 You must decide what to do with me. Just do whatever you think is right.
Jeremiah 26:15 But if you put me to death, you and everyone else in Jerusalem will be guilty of murdering an innocent man, because everything I preached came from the Lord.
Jeremiah 26:16 The judges and the other people told the priests and prophets, “Since Jeremiah only told us what the Lord our God had said, we don't think he deserves to die.”
Jeremiah 26:17 Then some of the leaders from other towns stepped forward. They told the crowd that
