Jeremiah 49:10 But I will take everything that belongs to you, people of Edom, and I will uncover every place where you try to hide. Then you will die, and so will your children, relatives, and neighbors.
Jeremiah 49:11 But I can be trusted to care for your orphans and widows.
Jeremiah 49:12 Even those nations that don't deserve to be punished will have to drink from the cup of my anger. So how can you possibly hope to escape?
Jeremiah 49:13 I, the Lord, swear in my own name that your city of Bozrah and all your towns will suffer a horrible fate. They will lie in ruins forever, and people will use the name “Bozrah” as a curse word.
Jeremiah 49:14 I have sent a messenger to command the nations to prepare for war against you people of Edom.
Jeremiah 49:15 Your nation will be small, yet hated by other nations.
Jeremiah 49:16 Pride tricks you into thinking that other nations look at you with fear. You live along the cliffs and high in the mountains like the eagles, but I am the Lord, and I will bring you down.
Jeremiah 49:17 People passing by your country will be shocked and horrified to see a disaster
Jeremiah 49:18 as bad as the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah and towns nearby. The towns of Edom will be empty.
Jeremiah 49:19 I, the Lord, will attack you like a lion from the forest, attacking sheep in a meadow along the Jordan. In a moment the flock runs, and the land is empty. Who will I choose to attack you? I will do it myself! No one can force me to fight or chase me away.
Jeremiah 49:20 Listen to my plans for you, people of Edom. Your children will be dragged off and your country destroyed.
Jeremiah 49:21 The sounds of your destruction will reach the Red Sea and cause the earth to shake.
Jeremiah 49:22 An enemy will swoop down to attack you, like an eagle spreading its wings and circling over Bozrah. Your warriors will be as fearful as women giving birth.
Jeremiah 49:23 The Lord says about Damascus: The towns of Hamath and Arpad have heard your bad news. They have lost hope, and worries roll over them like ocean waves.
Jeremiah 49:24 You people of Damascus have lost your courage, and in panic you turn to run, gripped by fear and pain.
Jeremiah 49:25 Once I was pleased with your famous city. But now I warn you, “Escape while you still can!”
Jeremiah 49:26 Soon, even your best soldiers will lie dead in your streets. I, the Lord All-Powerful, have spoken.
Jeremiah 49:27 I will set fire to your city walls and burn down the fortresses King Benhadad built.
Jeremiah 49:28 Here is what the Lord says about the Kedar tribe and the desert villages that were conquered by King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia: Listen, you people of Kedar and the other tribes of the eastern desert. I have told Nebuchadnezzar to attack and destroy you.
Jeremiah 49:29 His fearsome army will surround you, taking your tents and possessions, your sheep and camels.
Jeremiah 49:30 Run and hide, you people of the desert who live in villages! Nebuchadnezzar has big plans for you.
Jeremiah 49:31 You have no city walls and no neighbors to help, yet you think you're safe— so I told him to attack.
Jeremiah 49:32 Then your camels and large herds will be yours no longer. People of the Arabian Desert, disaster will strike you from every side, and you will be scattered everywhere on earth.
Jeremiah 49:33 Only jackals will live where your villages once stood. I, the Lord, have spoken.
Jeremiah 49:34+JER Not long after Zedekiah became king of Judah, the Lord told me to say: People of Elam, I, the Lord All-Powerful, will kill the archers who make your army strong.
Jeremiah 49:36 Enemies will attack from all directions, and you will be led captive to every nation on earth.
Jeremiah 49:37 Their armies will crush and kill you, and you will face the disaster that my anger brings.
Jeremiah 49:38 Your king and his officials will die, and I will rule in their place. I, the Lord, have spoken.
Jeremiah 49:39 But I promise that someday I will bring your people back to their land.
Jeremiah 50:1 The Lord told me to say: Announce what will happen and don't leave anything out.
Jeremiah 50:2 Raise the signal flags; shout so all nations can hear— Babylon will be captured! Marduk, Babylon's god, will be ashamed and terrified, and his idols broken.
Jeremiah 50:3 The attack on the Babylonians will come from the north; they and their animals will run, leaving the land empty.
Jeremiah 50:4 The Lord said: People of Israel and Judah, when these things happen you will weep, and together you will return to your land and worship me, the Lord your God.
Jeremiah 50:5 You will ask the way to Zion and then come and join with me in making an agreement you won't break or forget.
Jeremiah 50:6 My people, you are lost sheep abandoned in the mountains by their shepherds. You don't even remember your resting place.
Jeremiah 50:7 I am your true pastureland, the one who gave hope to your ancestors. But you abandoned me, so when your enemies found you, they felt no guilt as they gobbled you up.
Jeremiah 50:8 Escape from Babylonia, my people. Get out of that country! Don't wait for anyone else.
Jeremiah 50:9 In the north I am bringing great nations together. They will attack Babylon and capture it. The arrows they shoot are like the best soldiers, always finding their target.
Jeremiah 50:10 Babylonia will be conquered, and its enemies will carry off everything they want.
Jeremiah 50:11 People of Babylonia, you were glad to rob my people. You had a good time, making more noise than horses and jumping around like calves threshing grain.
Jeremiah 50:12 The city of Babylon was like a mother to you. But it will be disgraced and become nothing but a barren desert.
Jeremiah 50:13 My anger will destroy Babylon, and no one will live there. Everyone who passes by will be shocked to see what has happened.
Jeremiah 50:14 Babylon has rebelled against me. Archers, take your places. Shoot all your arrows at Babylon.
Jeremiah 50:15 Attack from every side! Babylon surrenders! The enemy tears down its walls and towers. I am taking my revenge by doing to Babylon what it did to other cities.
Jeremiah 50:16 There is no one in Babylonia to plant or harvest crops. Even foreigners who lived there have left for their homelands, afraid of the enemy armies.
Jeremiah 50:17 Israel is a flock of sheep scattered by hungry lions. The king of Assyria first gobbled Israel up. Then Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylonia, crunched on Israel's bones.
Jeremiah 50:18 I, the Lord All-Powerful, the God of Israel, punished the king of Assyria, and I will also punish the king of Babylonia.
Jeremiah 50:19 But I will bring Israel back to its own land. The people will be like sheep eating their fill on Mount Carmel and in Bashan, in the hill country of Ephraim and in Gilead.
Jeremiah 50:20 I will rescue a few people from Israel and Judah. I will forgive them so completely that their sin and guilt will disappear, never to be found.
Jeremiah 50:21 The Lord said: I have told the enemies of Babylonia, “Attack the people of Merathaim and Pekod. Kill them all! Destroy their possessions!”
Jeremiah 50:22 Sounds of war and the noise of destruction can be heard.
Jeremiah 50:23 Babylonia was a hammer pounding every country, but now it lies broken. What a shock to the nations of the world!
Jeremiah 50:24 Babylonia challenged me, the Lord God All-Powerful, but that nation doesn't know it is caught in a trap that I set.
Jeremiah 50:25 I've brought out my weapons, and with them I will put a curse on Babylonia.
Jeremiah 50:26 Come from far away, you enemies of Babylon! Pile up the grain from its storehouses, and destroy it completely, along with everything else.
Jeremiah 50:27 Kill the soldiers of Babylonia, because the time has come for them to be punished.
Jeremiah 50:28 The Babylonian army destroyed my temple, but soon I will take revenge. Then refugees from Babylon will tell about it in Zion.
Jeremiah 50:29 Attack Babylon, enemy archers; set up camp around the city, and don't let anyone escape. It challenged me, the holy God, so do to it what it did to other cities.
Jeremiah 50:30 People of Babylon, I, the Lord, promise that even your best soldiers will lie dead in the streets.
Jeremiah 50:31 Babylon, you should be named, “The Proud One.” But the time has come when I, the Lord All-Powerful, will punish you.
Jeremiah 50:32 You are proud, but you will stumble and fall, and no one will help you up. I will set your villages on fire, and everything around you will go up in flames.
Jeremiah 50:33 You Babylonians were cruel to Israel and Judah. You took them captive, and now you refuse to let them go.
Jeremiah 50:34 But I, the Lord All-Powerful, will rescue and protect them. I will bring peace to their land and trouble to yours.
Jeremiah 50:35 I have declared war on you, your officials, and advisors.
Jeremiah 50:36 This war will prove that your prophets are liars and fools. And it will frighten your warriors.
Jeremiah 50:37 Then your chariot horses and the foreigners in your army will refuse to go into battle, and the enemy will carry away everything you treasure.
Jeremiah 50:38 Your rivers and canals will dry up. All of this will happen, because your land is full of idols, and they have made fools of you.
Jeremiah 50:39 Never again will people live in your land— only desert animals, jackals, and unclean birds.
Jeremiah 50:40 I destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah and the nearby towns, and I will destroy Babylon just as completely. No one will live there again.
Jeremiah 50:41 Far to the north, a nation and its allies have been awakened. They are powerful and ready for war.
Jeremiah 50:42 Bows and arrows and swords are in their hands. The soldiers are cruel and show no pity. The hoofbeats of their horses echo like ocean waves crashing against the shore. The army has lined up for battle and is coming to attack you, people of Babylonia!
Jeremiah 50:43 Ever since your king heard about this army, he has been weak with fear; he twists and turns in pain like a woman giving birth.
Jeremiah 50:44 Babylonia, I will attack you like a lion from the forest, attacking sheep in a meadow along the Jordan. In a moment the flock runs, and the land is empty. Who will I choose to attack you? I will do it myself! No one can force me to fight or chase me away.
Jeremiah 50:45 Listen to my plans for you, people of Babylonia. Your children will be dragged off, and your country destroyed.
Jeremiah 50:46 The sounds of your destruction will be heard among the nations, and the earth will shake.
Jeremiah 51:1 I, the Lord, am sending a wind to destroy the people of Babylonia and Babylon, its capital.
Jeremiah 51:2 Foreign soldiers will come from every direction, and when the disaster is over, Babylonia will be empty and worthless.
Jeremiah 51:3 I will tell these soldiers, “Attack quickly, before the Babylonians can string their bows or put on their armor. Kill their best soldiers and destroy their army!”
Jeremiah 51:4 Their troops will fall wounded in the streets of Babylon.
Jeremiah 51:5 Everyone in Israel and Judah is guilty. But I, the Lord All-Powerful, their holy God, have not abandoned them.
Jeremiah 51:6 Get out of Babylon! Run for your lives! If you stay, you will be killed when I take revenge on the city and punish it for its sins.
Jeremiah 51:7 Babylon was my golden cup, filled with the wine of my anger. The nations of the world got drunk on this wine and went insane.
Jeremiah 51:8 But suddenly, Babylon will fall and be destroyed. I, the Lord, told the foreigners who lived there, “Weep for the city! Get medicine for its wounds; maybe they will heal.”
Jeremiah 51:9 The foreigners answered, “We have already tried to treat Babylon's wounds, but they would not heal. Come on, let's all go home to our own countries. Nothing is left in Babylonia; everything is destroyed.”
Jeremiah 51:10 The people of Israel said, “Tell everyone in Zion! The Lord has taken revenge for what Babylon did to us.”
Jeremiah 51:11 I, the Lord, want Babylon destroyed, because its army destroyed my temple. So, you kings of Media, sharpen your arrows and pick up your shields.
Jeremiah 51:12 Raise the signal flag and attack the city walls. Post more guards. Have soldiers watch the city and set up ambushes. I have made plans to destroy Babylon, and nothing will stop me.
Jeremiah 51:13 People of Babylon, you live along the Euphrates River and are surrounded by canals. You are rich, but now the time has come for you to die.
Jeremiah 51:14 I, the Lord All-Powerful, swear by my own life that enemy soldiers will fill your streets like a swarm of locusts. They will shout and celebrate their victory.
Jeremiah 51:15 God used his wisdom and power to create the earth and spread out the heavens.
Jeremiah 51:16 The waters in the heavens roar at his command. He makes clouds appear; he sends the wind from his storehouse and makes lightning flash in the rain.
Jeremiah 51:17 People who make idols are stupid! They will be disappointed, because their false gods cannot breathe.
Jeremiah 51:18 Idols are merely a joke, and when the time is right, they will be destroyed.
Jeremiah 51:19 But the Lord, Israel's God, is all-powerful. He created everything, and he chose Israel to be his very own.
Jeremiah 51:20 Babylonia, you were my hammer; I used you to pound nations and break kingdoms,
Jeremiah 51:21 to shatter cavalry and chariots,
Jeremiah 51:22 as well as men and women, young and old,
Jeremiah 51:23 shepherds and their flocks, farmers and their oxen, and governors and leaders.
Jeremiah 51:24 But now, my people will watch, while I repay you for what you did to Zion.
Jeremiah 51:25 You destroyed the nations and seem strong as a mountain, but I am your enemy. I might even grab you and roll you off a cliff. When I am finished, you'll only be a pile of scorched bricks.
Jeremiah 51:26 Your stone blocks won't be reused for cornerstones or foundations, and I promise that forever you will be a desert. I, the Lord, have spoken.
Jeremiah 51:27 Signal the nations to get ready to attack. Raise a flag and blow a trumpet. Send for the armies of Ararat, Minni, and Ashkenaz. Choose a commander; let the cavalry attack like a swarm of locusts.
Jeremiah 51:28 Tell the kings and governors, the leaders and the people of the kingdoms of the Medes to prepare for war!
Jeremiah 51:29 The earth twists and turns in torment, because I have decided to make Babylonia a desert where no one can live, and I won't change my mind.
Jeremiah 51:30 The Babylonian soldiers have lost their strength and courage. They stay in their fortresses, unable to fight, while the enemy breaks through the city gates, then sets their homes on fire.
Jeremiah 51:31 One messenger after another announces to the king, “Babylon has been captured!
Jeremiah 51:32 The enemy now controls the river crossings! The marshes are on fire! Your army has panicked!”
Jeremiah 51:33 I am the Lord All-Powerful, the God of Israel, and I make this promise— “Soon Babylon will be leveled and packed down like a threshing place at harvest time.”
Jeremiah 51:34 The people of Jerusalem say, “King Nebuchadnezzar made us panic. That monster stuffed himself with us and our treasures, leaving us empty— he gobbled up what he wanted and spit out the rest.
Jeremiah 51:35 The people of Babylonia harmed some of us and killed others. Now, Lord, make them pay!”
Jeremiah 51:36 My people, I am on your side, and I will take revenge on Babylon. I will cut off its water supply, and its stream will dry up.
Jeremiah 51:37 Babylon will be a pile of rubble where only jackals live, and everyone will be afraid to walk among the ruins.
Jeremiah 51:38 The Babylonians roar and growl like young lions.
Jeremiah 51:39 And since they are hungry, I will give them a banquet. They will celebrate, get drunk, then fall asleep, never to wake up!
Jeremiah 51:40 I will lead them away to die, like sheep, lambs, and goats being led to the butcher.
Jeremiah 51:41 All nations now praise Babylon, but when it is captured, those same nations will be horrified.
Jeremiah 51:42 Babylon's enemies will rise like ocean waves and flood the city.
Jeremiah 51:43 Horrible destruction will strike the nearby towns. The land will become a barren desert, where no one can live or even travel.
Jeremiah 51:44 I will punish Marduk, the god of Babylon, and make him vomit out everything he gobbled up. Then nations will no longer bring him gifts, and Babylon's walls will crumble.
Jeremiah 51:45 Get out of Babylon, my people, and run for your lives, before I strike the city in my anger!
Jeremiah 51:46 Don't be afraid or lose hope, though year after year there are rumors of leaders fighting for control in the city of Babylon.
Jeremiah 51:47 The time will come when I will punish Babylon's false gods. Everyone there will die, and the whole nation will be disgraced,
Jeremiah 51:48 when an army attacks from the north and brings destruction. Then the earth and the heavens and everything in them will celebrate.
Jeremiah 51:49 Babylon must be overthrown, because it slaughtered the people of Israel and of many other nations.
Jeremiah 51:50 My people, you escaped death when Jerusalem fell. Now you live far from home, but you should trust me and think about Jerusalem. Leave Babylon! Don't stay!
Jeremiah 51:51 You feel ashamed and disgraced, because foreigners have entered my sacred temple.
Jeremiah 51:52 Soon I will send a war to punish Babylon's idols and leave its wounded people moaning everywhere.
Jeremiah 51:53 Although Babylon's walls reach to the sky, the army I send will destroy that city. I, the Lord, have spoken.
Jeremiah 51:54 Listen to the cries for help coming from Babylon. Everywhere in the country the sounds of destruction can be heard.
Jeremiah 51:55 The shouts of the enemy, like crashing ocean waves, will drown out Babylon's cries as I level the city.
Jeremiah 51:56 An enemy will attack and destroy Babylon. Its soldiers will be captured and their weapons broken, because I am a God who takes revenge against nations for what they do.
Jeremiah 51:57 I, the Lord All-Powerful, the true King, promise that the officials and advisors, the governors and leaders, and the soldiers of Babylon will get drunk, fall asleep, and never wake up.
Jeremiah 51:58 The thick walls of that city will be torn down, and its huge gates burned. Everything that nation worked so hard to gain will go up in smoke.
Jeremiah 51:59 During Zedekiah's fourth year as king of Judah, he went to Babylon. And Baruch's brother Seraiah went along as the officer in charge of arranging for places to stay overnight.
Jeremiah 51:60 Before they left, I wrote on a scroll all the terrible things that would happen to Babylon.
Jeremiah 51:61 I gave the scroll to Seraiah and said: When you get to Babylon, read this scroll aloud,
Jeremiah 51:62 then pray, “Our Lord, you promised to destroy this place and make it into a desert where no people or animals will ever live.”
Jeremiah 51:63 When you finish praying, tie the scroll to a rock and throw it in the Euphrates River. Then say,
Jeremiah 51:64 “This is how Babylon will sink when the Lord destroys it. Everyone in the city will die, and it won't have the strength to rise again.” Jeremiah's writing ends here.
Jeremiah 52:1 Zedekiah was 21 years old when he was appointed king of Judah, and he ruled from Jerusalem for eleven years. His mother Hamutal was the daughter of Jeremiah from the town of Libnah.
Jeremiah 52:2 Zedekiah disobeyed the Lord, just as Jehoiakim had done,
Jeremiah 52:3 and it was Zedekiah who finally rebelled against Nebuchadnezzar. The people of Judah and Jerusalem had made the Lord so angry that he finally turned his back on them. That's why horrible things were happening there.
Jeremiah 52:4 In Zedekiah's ninth year as king, on the tenth day of the tenth month, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia led his entire army to attack Jerusalem. The troops set up camp outside the city and built ramps up to the city walls.
Jeremiah 52:5+JER After a year and a half, all the food in Jerusalem was gone. Then on the ninth day of the fourth month,
Jeremiah 52:7 the Babylonian troops broke through the city wall. That same night, Zedekiah and his soldiers tried to escape through the gate near the royal garden, even though they knew the enemy had the city surrounded. They headed toward the Jordan River valley,
Jeremiah 52:8 but the Babylonian troops caught up with them near Jericho. The Babylonians arrested Zedekiah, but his soldiers scattered in every direction.
Jeremiah 52:9 Zedekiah was taken to Riblah in the land of Hamath, where Nebuchadnezzar put him on trial and found him guilty.
Jeremiah 52:10 Zedekiah's sons and the officials of Judah were killed while he watched,
Jeremiah 52:11 then his eyes were poked out. He was put in chains, then dragged off to Babylon and kept in prison until he died.
Jeremiah 52:12 Jerusalem was captured during Nebuchadnezzar's nineteenth year as king of Babylonia. About a month later, Nebuchadnezzar's officer in charge of the guards arrived in Jerusalem. His name was Nebuzaradan,
Jeremiah 52:13 and he burned down the Lord's temple, the king's palace, and every important building in the city, as well as all the houses.
Jeremiah 52:14 Then he ordered the Babylonian soldiers to break down the walls around Jerusalem.
Jeremiah 52:15 He led away the people left in the city, including everyone who had become loyal to Nebuchadnezzar, the rest of the skilled workers, and even some of the poor people of Judah.
Jeremiah 52:16 Only the very poorest were left behind to work the vineyards and the fields.
Jeremiah 52:17+JER Nebuzaradan ordered his soldiers to go to the temple and take everything made of gold or silver, including bowls, fire pans, sprinkling bowls, pans, lampstands, dishes for incense, and the cups for wine offerings. The Babylonian soldiers took all the bronze things used for worship at the temple, including the pans for hot ashes, and the shovels, lamp snuffers, sprinkling bowls, and dishes for incense. The soldiers also took everything else made of bronze, including the two columns that stood in front of the temple, the large bowl called the Sea, the twelve bulls that held it up, and the movable stands. The soldiers broke these things into pieces so they could take them to Babylonia. There was so much bronze that it could not be weighed.
Jeremiah 52:21 For example, the columns were about 8 meters high and 5.5 meters around. They were hollow, but the bronze was about 75 millimeters thick.
Jeremiah 52:22 Each column had a bronze cap over 2 meters high that was decorated with bronze designs. Some of these designs were like chains and others were like pomegranates.
Jeremiah 52:23 There were 96 pomegranates evenly spaced around each column, and a total of 100 pomegranates were located above the chains.
Jeremiah 52:24 Next, Nebuzaradan arrested Seraiah the chief priest, Zephaniah his assistant, and three temple officials.
Jeremiah 52:25 Then he arrested one of the army commanders, seven of King Zedekiah's personal advisors, and the officer in charge of gathering the troops for battle. He also found 60 more soldiers who were still in Jerusalem.
Jeremiah 52:26+JER Nebuzaradan led them to Riblah in the land of Hamath, where Nebuchadnezzar had them killed. The people of Judah no longer lived in their own country.
Jeremiah 52:28+JER Here is a list of the number of the people of Judah that Nebuchadnezzar took to Babylonia as prisoners: In his seventh year as king, he took 3,023 people. In his eighteenth year as king, he took 832 from Jerusalem. In his twenty-third year as king, his officer Nebuzaradan took 745 people. So, Nebuchadnezzar took a total of 4,600 people from Judah to Babylonia.
Jeremiah 52:31 Jehoiachin was a prisoner in Babylon for 37 years. Then Evil Merodach became king of Babylonia, and in the first year of his rule, on the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month, he let Jehoiachin out of prison.
Jeremiah 52:32 Evil Merodach was kind to Jehoiachin and honored him more than any of the other kings held prisoner there.
Jeremiah 52:33 Jehoiachin was allowed to wear regular clothes instead of a prison uniform, and he even ate at the king's table every day.
Jeremiah 52:34 As long as Jehoiachin lived, he was paid a daily allowance to buy whatever he needed.
Lamentations 1:1 Jerusalem, once so crowded, lies deserted and lonely. This city that was known all over the world is now like a widow. This queen of the nations has been made a slave.
Lamentations 1:2 Each night, bitter tears flood her cheeks. None of her former lovers are there to offer comfort; her friends have betrayed her and are now her enemies.
Lamentations 1:3 The people of Judah are slaves, suffering in a foreign land, with no rest from sorrow. Their enemies captured them and were terribly cruel.
Lamentations 1:4 The roads to Zion mourn because no one travels there to celebrate the festivals. The city gates are deserted; priests are weeping. Young women are raped; Zion is in sorrow!
Lamentations 1:5 Enemies now rule the city and live as they please. The Lord has punished Jerusalem because of her awful sins; he has let her people be dragged away.
Lamentations 1:6 Zion's glory has disappeared. Her leaders are like deer that cannot find pasture; they are hunted down till their strength is gone.
Lamentations 1:7 Her people recall the good life that once was theirs; now they suffer and are scattered. No one was there to protect them from their enemies who sneered when their city was taken.
Lamentations 1:8 Jerusalem's horrible sins have made the city a joke. Those who once admired her now hate her instead— she has been disgraced; she groans and turns away.
Lamentations 1:9 Her sins had made her filthy, but she wasn't worried about what could happen. And when Jerusalem fell, it was so tragic. No one gave her comfort when she cried out, “Help! I'm in trouble, Lord! The enemy has won.”
Lamentations 1:10 Zion's treasures were stolen. Jerusalem saw foreigners enter her place of worship, though the Lord had forbidden them to belong to his people.
Lamentations 1:11 Everyone in the city groans while searching for food; they trade their valuables for barely enough scraps to stay alive. Jerusalem shouts to the Lord, “Please look and see how miserable I am!”
Lamentations 1:12 No passerby even cares. Why doesn't someone notice my terrible sufferings? You were fiercely angry, Lord, and you punished me worst of all.
Lamentations 1:13 From heaven you sent a fire that burned in my bones; you set a trap for my feet and made me turn back. All day long you leave me in shock from constant pain.
Lamentations 1:14 You have tied my sins around my neck, and they weigh so heavily that my strength is gone. You have put me in the power of enemies too strong for me.
Lamentations 1:15 You, Lord, have turned back my warriors and crushed my young heroes. Judah was a woman untouched, but you let her be trampled like grapes in a wine pit.
Lamentations 1:16 Because of this, I mourn, and tears flood my eyes. No one is here to comfort or to encourage me; we have lost the war— my people are suffering.
Lamentations 1:17 Zion reaches out her hands, but no one offers comfort. The Lord has turned the neighboring nations against Jacob's descendants. Jerusalem is merely a filthy rag to her neighbors.
Lamentations 1:18 The Lord was right, but I refused to obey him. Now I ask all of you to look at my sufferings— even my young people have been dragged away.
Lamentations 1:19 I called out to my lovers, but they betrayed me. My priests and my leaders died while searching the city for scraps of food.
Lamentations 1:20 Won't you look and see how upset I am, our Lord? My stomach is in knots, and my heart is broken because I betrayed you. In the streets and at home, my people are slaughtered.
Lamentations 1:21 Everyone heard my groaning, but no one offered comfort. My enemies know of the trouble that you have brought on me, and it makes them glad. Hurry and punish them, as you have promised.
Lamentations 1:22 Don't let their evil deeds escape your sight. Punish them as much as you have punished me because of my sins. I never stop groaning— I've lost all hope!
Lamentations 2:1 The Lord was angry! So he disgraced Zion though it was Israel's pride and his own place of rest. In his anger he threw Zion down from heaven to earth.
Lamentations 2:2 The Lord had no mercy! He destroyed the homes of Jacob's descendants. In his anger he tore down every walled city in Judah; he toppled the nation together with its leaders, leaving them in shame.
Lamentations 2:3 The Lord was so furiously angry that he wiped out the whole army of Israel by not supporting them when the enemy attacked. He was like a raging fire that swallowed up the descendants of Jacob.
Lamentations 2:4 He attacked like an enemy with a bow and arrows, killing our loved ones. He has burned to the ground the homes on Mount Zion.
Lamentations 2:5 The Lord was like an enemy! He left Israel in ruins with its palaces and fortresses destroyed, and with everyone in Judah moaning and weeping.
Lamentations 2:6 He shattered his temple like a hut in a garden; he completely wiped out his meeting place, and did away with festivals and Sabbaths in the city of Zion. In his fierce anger he rejected our king and priests.
Lamentations 2:7 The Lord abandoned his altar and his temple; he let Zion's enemies capture her fortresses. Noisy shouts were heard from the temple, as if it were a time of celebration.
Lamentations 2:8 The Lord had decided to tear down the walls of Zion stone by stone. So he started destroying and did not stop until walls and fortresses mourned and trembled.
Lamentations 2:9 Zion's gates have fallen facedown on the ground; the bars that locked the gates are smashed to pieces. Her king and royal family are prisoners in foreign lands. Her priests don't teach, and her prophets don't have a message from the Lord.
Lamentations 2:10 Zion's leaders are silent. They just sit on the ground, tossing dirt on their heads and wearing sackcloth. Her young women can do nothing but stare at the ground.
Lamentations 2:11 My eyes are red from crying, my stomach is in knots, and I feel sick all over. My people are being wiped out, and children lie helpless in the streets of the city.
Lamentations 2:12 A child begs its mother for food and drink, then blacks out like a wounded soldier lying in the street. The child slowly dies in its mother's arms.
Lamentations 2:13 Zion, how can I comfort you? How great is your pain? Lovely city of Jerusalem, how can I heal your wounds, gaping as wide as the sea?
Lamentations 2:14 Your prophets deceived you with false visions and lying messages— they should have warned you to leave your sins and be saved from disaster.
Lamentations 2:15 Those who pass by shake their heads and sneer as they make fun and shout, “What a lovely city you were, the happiest on earth, but look at you now!”
Lamentations 2:16 Zion, your enemies curse you and snarl like wild animals, while shouting, “This is the day we've waited for! At last, we've got you!”
Lamentations 2:17 The Lord has done everything that he had planned and threatened long ago. He destroyed you without mercy and let your enemies boast about their powerful forces.
Lamentations 2:18 Zion, deep in your heart you cried out to the Lord. Now let your tears overflow your walls day and night. Don't ever lose hope or let your tears stop.
Lamentations 2:19 Get up and pray for help all through the night. Pour out your feelings to the Lord, as you would pour water out of a jug. Beg him to save your people, who are starving to death at every street crossing.
Lamentations 2:20 Think about it, Lord! Have you ever been this cruel to anyone before? Is it right for mothers to eat their children, or for priests and prophets to be killed in your temple?
Lamentations 2:21 My people, both young and old, lie dead in the streets. Because you were angry, my young men and women were brutally slaughtered.
Lamentations 2:22 When you were angry, Lord, you invited my enemies like guests for a party. No one survived that day; enemies killed my children, my own little ones.
Lamentations 3:1 I have suffered much because God was angry.
Lamentations 3:2 He chased me into a dark place, where no light could enter.
Lamentations 3:3 I am the only one he punishes over and over again, without ever stopping.
Lamentations 3:4 God caused my skin and flesh to waste away, and he crushed my bones.
Lamentations 3:5 He attacked and surrounded me with hardships and trouble;
Lamentations 3:6 he forced me to sit in the dark like someone long dead.
Lamentations 3:7 God built a fence around me that I cannot climb over, and he chained me down.
Lamentations 3:8 Even when I shouted and prayed for help, he refused to listen.
Lamentations 3:9 God put big rocks in my way and made me follow a crooked path.
Lamentations 3:10 God was like a bear or a lion waiting in ambush for me;
Lamentations 3:11 he dragged me from the road, then tore me to shreds.
Lamentations 3:12 God took careful aim and shot his arrows
Lamentations 3:13 straight through my heart.
Lamentations 3:14 I am a joke to everyone— no one ever stops making fun of me.
Lamentations 3:15 God has turned my life sour.
Lamentations 3:16 He made me eat gravel and rubbed me in the dirt.
Lamentations 3:17 I cannot find peace or remember happiness.
Lamentations 3:18 I tell myself, “I am finished! I can't count on the Lord to do anything for me.”
Lamentations 3:19 Just thinking of my troubles and my lonely wandering makes me miserable.
Lamentations 3:20 That's all I ever think about, and I am depressed.
Lamentations 3:21 Then I remember something that fills me with hope.
Lamentations 3:22 The Lord's kindness never fails! If he had not been merciful, we would have been destroyed.
Lamentations 3:23 The Lord can always be trusted to show mercy each morning.
Lamentations 3:24 Deep in my heart I say, “The Lord is all I need; I can depend on him!”
Lamentations 3:25 The Lord is kind to everyone who trusts and obeys him.
Lamentations 3:26 It is good to wait patiently for the Lord to save us.
Lamentations 3:27 When we are young, it is good to struggle hard
Lamentations 3:28 and to sit silently alone, if this is what the Lord intends.
Lamentations 3:29 Being rubbed in the dirt can teach us a lesson;
Lamentations 3:30 we can also learn from insults and hard knocks.
Lamentations 3:31 The Lord won't always reject us!
Lamentations 3:32 He causes a lot of suffering, but he also has pity because of his great love.
Lamentations 3:33 The Lord doesn't enjoy sending grief or pain.
Lamentations 3:34 Don't trample prisoners under your feet
Lamentations 3:35 or cheat anyone out of what is rightfully theirs. God Most High sees everything,
Lamentations 3:36 and he knows when you refuse to give someone a fair trial.
Lamentations 3:37 No one can do anything without the Lord's approval.
Lamentations 3:38 Good and bad each happen at the command of God Most High.
Lamentations 3:39 We're still alive! We shouldn't complain when we are being punished for our sins.
Lamentations 3:40 Instead, we should think about the way we are living, and turn back to the Lord.
Lamentations 3:41 When we lift our hands in prayer to God in heaven, we should offer him our hearts and say,
Lamentations 3:42 “We've sinned! We've rebelled against you, and you haven't forgiven us!
Lamentations 3:43 Anger is written all over you, as you pursue and slaughter us without showing pity.
Lamentations 3:44 You are behind a wall of clouds that blocks out our prayers.
Lamentations 3:45 You allowed nations to treat us like garbage;
Lamentations 3:46 our enemies curse us.
Lamentations 3:47 We are terrified and trapped, caught and crushed.”
Lamentations 3:48 My people are destroyed! Tears flood my eyes,
Lamentations 3:49 and they won't stop
Lamentations 3:50 until the Lord looks down from heaven and helps.
Lamentations 3:51 I am horrified when I see what enemies have done to the young women of our city.
Lamentations 3:52 No one had reason to hate me, but I was hunted down like a bird.
Lamentations 3:53 Then they tried to kill me by tossing me into a pit and throwing stones at me.
Lamentations 3:54 Water covered my head— I thought I was gone.
Lamentations 3:55 From the bottom of the pit, I prayed to you, Lord.
Lamentations 3:56 I begged you to listen. “Help!” I shouted. “Save me!” You answered my prayer
Lamentations 3:57 and came when I was in need. You told me, “Don't worry!”
Lamentations 3:58 You rescued me and saved my life.
Lamentations 3:59 You saw them abuse me, Lord, so make things right.
Lamentations 3:60 You know every plot they have made against me.
Lamentations 3:61 Yes, you know their insults and their evil plans.
Lamentations 3:62 All day long they attack with words and whispers.
Lamentations 3:63 No matter what they are doing, they keep on mocking me.
Lamentations 3:64 Pay them back for everything they have done, Lord!
Lamentations 3:65 Put your curse on them and make them suffer.
Lamentations 3:66 Get angry and go after them until not a trace is left under the heavens.
Lamentations 4:1 The purest gold is ruined and has lost its shine; jewels from the temple lie scattered in the streets.
Lamentations 4:2 These are Zion's people, worth more than purest gold; yet they are counted worthless like dishes of clay.
Lamentations 4:3 Even jackals nurse their young, but my people are like ostriches that abandon their own.
Lamentations 4:4 Babies are so thirsty that their tongues are stuck to the roof of the mouth. Children go begging for food, but no one gives them any.
Lamentations 4:5 All who ate expensive foods lie starving in the streets; those who grew up in luxury now sit on trash heaps.
Lamentations 4:6 My nation was punished worse than the people of Sodom, whose city was destroyed in a flash without the help of human hands.
Lamentations 4:7 The leaders of Jerusalem were purer than snow and whiter than milk; their bodies were healthy and glowed like jewels.
Lamentations 4:8 Now they are blacker than tar, and no one recognizes them; their skin clings to their bones and is drier than firewood.
Lamentations 4:9 Being killed with a sword is better than slowly starving to death.
Lamentations 4:10 Life in the city is so bad that loving mothers have boiled and eaten their own children.
Lamentations 4:11 The Lord was so fiercely angry that he burned the city of Zion to the ground.
Lamentations 4:12 Not a king on this earth or the people of any nation believed enemies could break through her gates.
Lamentations 4:13 Jerusalem was punished because her prophets and her priests had sinned and caused the death of innocent victims.
Lamentations 4:14 Yes, her prophets and priests were covered with blood; no one would come near them, as they wandered from street to street.
Lamentations 4:15 Instead, everyone shouted, “Go away! Don't touch us! You're filthy and unfit to belong to God's people!” So they had to leave and become refugees. But foreign nations told them, “You can't stay here!”
Lamentations 4:16 The Lord is the one who sent them scattering, and he has forgotten them. No respect or kindness will be shown to the priests or leaders.
Lamentations 4:17 Our eyes became weary, hopelessly looking for help from a nation that could not save us.
Lamentations 4:18 Enemies hunted us down on every public street. Our time was up; our doom was near.
Lamentations 4:19 They swooped down faster than eagles from the sky. They hunted for us in the hills and set traps to catch us out in the desert.
Lamentations 4:20 The Lord's chosen leader was our hope for survival! We thought he would keep us safe somewhere among the nations, but even he was caught in one of their traps.
Lamentations 4:21 You people of Edom can celebrate now! But your time will come to suffer and stagger around naked.
Lamentations 4:22 The people of Zion have paid for their sins, and the Lord will soon let them return home. But, people of Edom, you will be punished, and your sins exposed.
Lamentations 5:1 Our Lord, don't forget how we have suffered and been disgraced.
Lamentations 5:2 Foreigners and strangers have taken our land and our homes.
Lamentations 5:3 We are like children whose mothers are widows.
Lamentations 5:4 The water we drink and the wood we burn cost far too much.
Lamentations 5:5 We are terribly mistreated; we are worn out and can find no rest.
Lamentations 5:6 We had to surrender to Egypt and Assyria because we were hungry.
Lamentations 5:7 Our ancestors sinned, but they are dead, and we are left to pay for their sins.
Lamentations 5:8 Slaves are now our rulers, and there is no one to set us free.
Lamentations 5:9 We are in danger from brutal desert tribes; we must risk our lives just to bring in our crops.
Lamentations 5:10 Our skin is scorched from fever and hunger.
Lamentations 5:11 On Zion and everywhere in Judah our wives and daughters are being raped.
Lamentations 5:12 Our rulers are strung up by their arms, and our nation's advisors are treated shamefully.
Lamentations 5:13 Young men are forced to do the work of slaves; boys must carry heavy loads of wood.
Lamentations 5:14 Our leaders are not allowed to decide cases in court, and young people no longer play music.
Lamentations 5:15 Our hearts are sad; instead of dancing, we mourn.
Lamentations 5:16 Zion's glory has disappeared! And we are doomed because of our sins.
Lamentations 5:17 We feel sick all over and can't even see straight;
Lamentations 5:18 our city is in ruins, overrun by wild dogs.
Lamentations 5:19 You will rule forever, Lord! You are King for all time.
Lamentations 5:20 Why have you forgotten us for so long?
Lamentations 5:21 Bring us back to you! Give us a fresh start.
Lamentations 5:22 Or do you despise us so much that you don't want us?
Ezekiel 1:1+EZK I am Ezekiel—a priest and the son of Buzi. Five years after King Jehoiachin of Judah had been led away as a prisoner to Babylonia, I was living near the Chebar River among those who had been taken there with him. Then on the fifth day of the fourth month of the thirtieth year, the heavens suddenly opened. The Lord placed his hand upon me and showed me some visions.
Ezekiel 1:4 I saw a windstorm blowing in from the north. Lightning flashed from a huge cloud and lit up the whole sky with a dazzling brightness. The fiery center of the cloud was as shiny as polished metal,
Ezekiel 1:5 and in that center I saw what looked like four living creatures. They were somewhat like humans,
Ezekiel 1:6 except that each one had four faces and four wings.
Ezekiel 1:7 Their legs were straight, but their feet looked like the hoofs of calves and sparkled like bronze.
Ezekiel 1:8 Under each of their wings, these creatures had a human hand.
Ezekiel 1:9 The four creatures were standing back to back with the tips of their wings touching. They moved together in every direction, without turning their bodies.
Ezekiel 1:10 Each creature had the face of a human in front, the face of a lion on the right side, the face of a bull on the left, and the face of an eagle in back.
Ezekiel 1:11 Two wings of each creature were spread out and touched the wings of the creatures on either side. The other two wings of each creature were folded against its body.
Ezekiel 1:12 The four living creatures went wherever the Spirit led them, and they moved together without turning their bodies, because each creature faced straight ahead.
Ezekiel 1:13 The creatures were glowing like hot coals, and I saw something like a flaming torch moving back and forth among them. Lightning flashed from the torch every time its flame blazed up.
Ezekiel 1:14 The creatures themselves moved as quickly as sparks jumping from a fire.
Ezekiel 1:15 I then noticed that on the ground beside each of the four living creatures was a wheel,
Ezekiel 1:16 shining like chrysolite. Each wheel was exactly the same and had a second wheel that cut through the middle of it,
Ezekiel 1:17 so that they could move in any direction without turning.
Ezekiel 1:18 The rims of the wheels were large and frightening, and they had eyes all the way around them.
Ezekiel 1:19+EZK The creatures controlled when and where the wheels moved—the wheels went wherever the four creatures went and stopped whenever they stopped. Even when the creatures flew in the air, the wheels were beside them.
Ezekiel 1:22+EZK Above the living creatures, I saw something that was sparkling like ice, and it reminded me of a dome. Each creature had two of its wings stretched out toward the creatures on either side, with the other two wings folded against its body.
Ezekiel 1:24 Whenever the creatures flew, their wings roared like an ocean or a large army or even the voice of God All-Powerful. And whenever the creatures stopped, they folded their wings against their bodies.
Ezekiel 1:25 When the creatures stopped flapping their wings, I heard a sound coming from above the dome.
Ezekiel 1:26 I then saw what looked like a throne made of sapphire, and sitting on the throne was a figure in the shape of a human.
Ezekiel 1:27 From the waist up, it was glowing like metal in a hot furnace, and from the waist down it looked like the flames of a fire. The figure was surrounded by a bright light,
Ezekiel 1:28 as colorful as a rainbow that appears after a storm. I realized I was seeing the brightness of the Lord's glory! So I bowed with my face to the ground, and just then I heard a voice speaking to me.
Ezekiel 2:1 The Lord said, “Ezekiel, son of man, I want you to stand up and listen.”
Ezekiel 2:2 After he said this, his Spirit took control of me and lifted me to my feet. Then the Lord said:
Ezekiel 2:3 Ezekiel, I am sending you to the people of Israel. They are just like their ancestors who rebelled against me and refused to stop.
Ezekiel 2:4 They are stubborn and hardheaded. But I, the Lord God, have chosen you to tell them what I say.
Ezekiel 2:5 Those rebels may not even listen, but at least they will know that a prophet has come to them.
Ezekiel 2:6 Don't be afraid of them or of anything they say. You may think you're in the middle of a thorn patch or a bunch of scorpions. But be brave
Ezekiel 2:7 and preach my message to them, whether they choose to listen or not.
Ezekiel 2:8 Ezekiel, don't rebel against me, as they have done. Instead, listen to everything I tell you. And now, Ezekiel, open your mouth and eat what I am going to give you.
Ezekiel 2:9 Just then, I saw a hand stretched out toward me. And in it was a scroll.
Ezekiel 2:10 The hand opened the scroll, and both sides of it were filled with words of sadness, mourning, and grief.
Ezekiel 3:1 The Lord said, “Ezekiel, son of man, after you eat this scroll, go speak to the people of Israel.”
Ezekiel 3:2+EZK He handed me the scroll and said, “Eat this and fill up on it.” So I ate the scroll, and it tasted sweet as honey.
Ezekiel 3:4 The Lord said: Ezekiel, I am sending you to your own people.
Ezekiel 3:5+EZK They are Israelites, not some strangers who speak a foreign language you can't understand. If I were to send you to foreign nations, they would listen to you.
Ezekiel 3:7 But the people of Israel will refuse to listen, because they have refused to listen to me. All of them are stubborn and hardheaded,
Ezekiel 3:8 so I will make you as stubborn as they are.
Ezekiel 3:9 You will be so determined to speak my message that nothing will stop you. I will make you hard like a diamond, and you'll have no reason to be afraid of those arrogant rebels.
Ezekiel 3:10 Listen carefully to everything I say and then think about it.
Ezekiel 3:11 Then go to the people who were brought here to Babylonia with you and tell them you have a message from me, the Lord God. Do this, whether they listen to you or not.
Ezekiel 3:12 The Spirit lifted me up, and as the glory of the Lord started to leave, I heard a loud, thundering noise behind me.
Ezekiel 3:13 It was the sound made by the creatures' wings as they brushed against each other, and by the rumble of the wheels beside them.
Ezekiel 3:14 Then the Spirit carried me away. The Lord's power had taken complete control of me, and I was both annoyed and angry.
Ezekiel 3:15 When I was back with the others living at Abib Hill near the Chebar River, I sat among them for seven days, shocked at what had happened to me.
Ezekiel 3:16 Seven days after I had seen the brightness of the Lord's glory, the Lord said:
Ezekiel 3:17 Ezekiel, son of man, I have appointed you to stand watch for the people of Israel. So listen to what I say, then warn them for me.
Ezekiel 3:18 When I tell wicked people they will die because of their sins, you must warn them to turn from their sinful ways so they won't be punished. If you refuse, you are responsible for their death.
Ezekiel 3:19 However, if you do warn them, and they keep on sinning, they will die because of their sins, and you will be innocent.
Ezekiel 3:20 Now suppose faithful people start sinning, and I decide to put stumbling blocks in their paths to make them fall. They deserve to die because of their sins. So if you refuse to warn them, I will forget about the times they were faithful, and I will hold you responsible for their death.
Ezekiel 3:21 But if you do warn them, and they listen to you and stop sinning, I will let them live. And you will be innocent.
Ezekiel 3:22 The Lord took control of me and said, “Stand up! Go into the valley, and I will talk with you there.”
Ezekiel 3:23 I immediately went to the valley, where I saw the brightness of the Lord's glory, just as I had seen it near the Chebar River, and I bowed with my face to the ground.
Ezekiel 3:24 His Spirit took control of me and lifted me to my feet. Then the Lord said: Go back and lock yourself in your house!
Ezekiel 3:25 You will be tied up to keep you inside,
Ezekiel 3:26 and I will make you unable to talk or to warn those who have rebelled against me.
Ezekiel 3:27 But the time will come, when I will tell you what to say, and you will again be able to speak my message. Some of them will listen; others will be stubborn and refuse to listen.
Ezekiel 4:1 Ezekiel, son of man, find a brick and sketch a picture of Jerusalem on it.
Ezekiel 4:2 Then prepare to attack the brick as if it were a real city. Build a dirt mound and a ramp up to the top and surround the brick with enemy camps. On every side put large wooden poles as though you were going to break down the gate to the city.
Ezekiel 4:3 Set up an iron pan like a wall between you and the brick. All this will be a warning for the people of Israel.
Ezekiel 4:4+EZK After that, lie down on your left side and stay there for 390 days as a sign of Israel's punishment—one day for each year of its suffering.
Ezekiel 4:6 Then turn over and lie on your right side 40 more days. That will be a sign of Judah's punishment—one day for each year of its suffering.
Ezekiel 4:7 The brick stands for Jerusalem, so attack it! Stare at it and shout angry warnings.
Ezekiel 4:8 I will tie you up, so you can't leave until your attack has ended.
Ezekiel 4:9 Get a large bowl. Then mix together wheat, barley, beans, lentils, and millet, and make some bread. This is what you will eat for the 390 days you are lying down.
Ezekiel 4:10 Eat only a small loaf of bread each day
Ezekiel 4:11 and drink only two large cups of water.
Ezekiel 4:12 Use dried human waste to start a fire, then bake the bread on the coals where everyone can watch you.
Ezekiel 4:13 When I scatter the people of Israel among the nations, they will also have to eat food that is unclean, just as you must do.
Ezekiel 4:14 I said, “Lord God, please don't make me do that! Never in my life have I eaten food that would make me unacceptable to you. I've never eaten anything that died a natural death or was killed by a wild animal or that you said was unclean.”
Ezekiel 4:15 The Lord replied, “Instead of human waste, I will let you bake your bread on a fire made from cow manure.
Ezekiel 4:16 Ezekiel, the people of Jerusalem will starve. They will have so little food and water that they will be afraid and hopeless.
Ezekiel 4:17 Everyone will be shocked at what is happening, and, because of their sins, they will die a slow death.”
Ezekiel 5:1 Ezekiel, son of man, get a sharp sword and use it to cut off your hair and beard. Weigh the hair and divide it into three equal piles.
Ezekiel 5:2 After you attack the brick that stands for Jerusalem, burn one pile of your hair on the brick. Chop up the second pile and let the small pieces of hair fall around the brick. Throw the third pile into the wind, and I will strike it with my own sword.
Ezekiel 5:3 Keep a few of the hairs and wrap them in the hem of your clothes.
Ezekiel 5:4 Then pull out a few of those hairs and throw them in the fire, so they will also burn. This fire will spread, destroying everyone in Israel.
Ezekiel 5:5 I am the Lord God, and I have made Jerusalem the most important place in the world, and all other nations admire it.
Ezekiel 5:6 But the people of Jerusalem rebelled and refuse to obey me. They ignored my laws and have become even more sinful than the nations around them.
Ezekiel 5:7 So tell the people of Jerusalem: I am the Lord God! You have refused to obey my laws and teachings, and instead you have obeyed the laws of the surrounding nations. You have become more rebellious than any of them!
Ezekiel 5:8 Now all those nations will watch as I turn against you and punish you
Ezekiel 5:9 for your sins. Your punishment will be more horrible than anything I've ever done or will ever do again.
Ezekiel 5:10 Parents will be so desperate for food that they will eat their own children, and children will eat their parents. Those who survive this horror will be scattered in every direction.
Ezekiel 5:11 Your sins have disgusted me and made my temple unfit as a place to worship me. So I swear by my own life that I will cut you down and show you no pity.
Ezekiel 5:12 A third of you will die here in Jerusalem from disease or starvation. Another third will be killed in war. And I will scatter the last third of you in every direction, then track you down and kill you.
Ezekiel 5:13 You will feel my fierce anger until I have finished taking revenge. Then you will know that I, the Lord, was furious because of your disobedience.
Ezekiel 5:14 Every passerby will laugh at your destruction. Foreign nations
Ezekiel 5:15 will insult you and make fun of you, but they will also be shocked and terrified at what I did in my anger.
Ezekiel 5:16 I will destroy your crops until you starve to death, and disasters will strike you like arrows.
Ezekiel 5:17 Starvation and wild animals will kill your children. I'll punish you with horrible diseases, and your enemies will strike you down with their swords. I, the Lord, have spoken.
Ezekiel 6:1 The Lord God said:
Ezekiel 6:2 Ezekiel, son of man, face the hills of Israel and tell them:
Ezekiel 6:3 Listen, you mountains and hills, and every valley and gorge! I, the Lord, am about to turn against you and crush all the places where foreign gods are worshiped.
Ezekiel 6:4 Every altar will be smashed, and in front of the idols I will put to death the people who worship them.
Ezekiel 6:5 Dead bodies and bones will be lying around the idols and the altars.
Ezekiel 6:6 Every town in Israel will be destroyed to make sure that each shrine, idol, and altar is smashed—everything the Israelites made will be a pile of ruins.
Ezekiel 6:7 All over the country, your people will die. And those who survive will know that I, the Lord, did these things.
Ezekiel 6:8 I will let some of the people live through this punishment, but I will scatter them among the nations,
Ezekiel 6:9 where they will be prisoners. And when they think of me, they will realize that they disgraced me by rebelling and by worshiping idols. They will hate themselves for the evil things they did,
Ezekiel 6:10 and they will know that I am the Lord and that my warnings must be taken seriously.
Ezekiel 6:11 The Lord God then said: Ezekiel, beat your fists together and stomp your feet in despair! Moan in sorrow, because the people of Israel have done disgusting things and now will be killed by enemy troops, or they will die from starvation and disease.
Ezekiel 6:12 Those who live far away will be struck with deadly diseases. Those who live nearby will be killed in war. And the ones who are left will starve to death. I will let loose my anger on them!
Ezekiel 6:13 These people used to offer incense to idols at altars built on hills and mountaintops and in the shade of large oak trees. But when they see dead bodies lying around those altars, they will know that I am the Lord.
Ezekiel 6:14 I will make their country a barren wasteland, from the Southern Desert to the town of Diblah in the north. Then they will know that I, the Lord, have done these things.
Ezekiel 7:1 The Lord God said:
Ezekiel 7:2 Ezekiel, son of man, tell the people of Israel that I am saying: Israel will soon come to an end! Your whole country is about to be destroyed
Ezekiel 7:3 as punishment for your disgusting sins. I, the Lord, am so angry
Ezekiel 7:4 that I will show no pity. I will punish you for the evil you've done, and you will know that I am the Lord.
Ezekiel 7:5 There's never been anything like the coming disaster.
Ezekiel 7:6 And when it comes, your life will be over.
Ezekiel 7:7 You people of Israel are doomed! Soon there will be panic on the mountaintops instead of celebration.
Ezekiel 7:8 I will let loose my anger and punish you for the evil things you've done. You'll get what you deserve.
Ezekiel 7:9 Your sins are so terrible, that you'll get no mercy from me. Then you will know that I, the Lord, have punished you.
Ezekiel 7:10 Disaster is near! Injustice and arrogance are everywhere,
Ezekiel 7:11 and violent criminals run free. None of you will survive the disaster, and everything you own and value will be shattered.
Ezekiel 7:12 The time is coming when everyone will be ruined. Buying and selling will stop,
Ezekiel 7:13 and people who sell property will never get it back, because all of you must be punished for your sins. And I won't change my mind!
Ezekiel 7:14 A signal has been blown on the trumpet, and weapons are prepared for battle. But no one goes to war, because in my anger I will strike down everyone in Israel.
Ezekiel 7:15 War, disease, and starvation are everywhere! People who live in the countryside will be killed in battle, and those who live in towns will die from starvation or deadly diseases.
Ezekiel 7:16 Anyone who survives will escape into the hills, like doves who leave the valleys to find safety. All of you will moan because of your sins.
Ezekiel 7:17 Your hands will tremble, and your knees go limp.
Ezekiel 7:18 You will put on sackcloth to show your sorrow, but terror will overpower you. Shame will be written all over your faces, and you will shave your heads in despair.
Ezekiel 7:19 Your silver and gold will be thrown into the streets like garbage, because those are the two things that led you into sin, and now they cannot save you from my anger. They are not even worth enough to buy food.
Ezekiel 7:20 You took great pride in using your beautiful jewelry to make disgusting idols of foreign gods. So I will make your jewelry worthless.
Ezekiel 7:21 Wicked foreigners will rob and disgrace you.
Ezekiel 7:22 They will break into my temple and leave it unfit as a place to worship me, but I will look away and let it happen.
Ezekiel 7:23 Your whole country is in confusion! Murder and violence are everywhere in Israel,
Ezekiel 7:24 so I will tell the most wicked nations to come and take over your homes. They will put an end to the pride you have in your strong army, and they will make your places of worship unfit to use.
Ezekiel 7:25 You will be terrified and will desperately look for peace—but there will be no peace.
Ezekiel 7:26 One tragedy will follow another, and you'll hear only bad news. People will beg prophets to give them a message from me. Priests will stop teaching my Law, and wise leaders won't be able to give advice.
Ezekiel 7:27 Even your king and his officials will lose hope and cry in despair. Your hands will tremble with fear. I will punish you for your sins and treat you the same way you have treated others. Then you will know that I am the Lord.
Ezekiel 8:1 Six years after King Jehoiachin and the rest of us had been led away as prisoners to Babylonia, the leaders of Judah were meeting with me in my house. On the fifth day of the sixth month, the Lord God suddenly took control of me,
Ezekiel 8:2 and I saw something in the shape of a human. This figure was like fire from the waist down, and it was bright as polished metal from the waist up.
Ezekiel 8:3 It reached out what seemed to be a hand and grabbed my hair. Then in my vision the Lord's Spirit lifted me into the sky and carried me to Jerusalem. The Spirit took me to the north gate of the temple's inner courtyard, where there was an idol that disgusted the Lord and made him furious.
Ezekiel 8:4 Then I saw the brightness of the glory of the God of Israel, just as I had seen it near the Chebar River.
Ezekiel 8:5 God said to me, “Ezekiel, son of man, look north.” And when I did, I saw that repulsive idol by the altar near the gate.
Ezekiel 8:6 God then said, “Do you see the terrible sins of the people of Israel? Their sins are making my holy temple unfit as a place to worship me. Yet you will see even worse things than this.”
Ezekiel 8:7 Next, I was taken to the entrance of the courtyard, where I saw a hole in the wall.
Ezekiel 8:8 God said, “Make this hole bigger.” And when I did, I realized it was a doorway.
Ezekiel 8:9 “Go in,” God said, “and see what horrible and evil things the people are doing.”
Ezekiel 8:10 Inside, I saw that the walls were covered with pictures of reptiles and disgusting, unclean animals, as well as with idols that the Israelites were worshiping.
Ezekiel 8:11 Seventy Israelite leaders were standing there, including Jaazaniah son of Shaphan. Each of these leaders was holding an incense burner, and the smell of incense filled the room.
Ezekiel 8:12 God said, “Ezekiel, do you see what horrible things Israel's leaders are doing in secret? They have filled their rooms with idols. And they say I can't see them, because they think I have already deserted Israel.
Ezekiel 8:13 But I will show you something even worse than this.”
Ezekiel 8:14 He took me to the north gate of the temple, where I saw women mourning for the god Tammuz.
Ezekiel 8:15 God asked me, “Can you believe what these women are doing? But now I want to show you something even worse.”
Ezekiel 8:16 I was then led into the temple's inner courtyard, where I saw about 25 men standing near the entrance, between the porch and the altar. Their backs were to the Lord's temple, and they were bowing down to the rising sun.
Ezekiel 8:17 God said, “Ezekiel, it's bad enough that the people of Judah are doing these disgusting things. But they have also spread violence and injustice everywhere in Israel and have made me very angry. They have disgraced and insulted me in the worst possible way.
Ezekiel 8:18 So in my fierce anger, I will punish them without mercy and refuse to help them when they cry out to me.”
Ezekiel 9:1 After that, I heard the Lord shout, “Come to Jerusalem, you men chosen to destroy the city. And bring your weapons!”
Ezekiel 9:2 I saw six men come through the north gate of the temple, each one holding a deadly weapon. A seventh man dressed in a linen robe was with them, and he was carrying things to write with. The men went into the temple and stood by the bronze altar.
Ezekiel 9:3 The brightness of God's glory then left its place above the statues of the winged creatures inside the temple and moved to the entrance. The Lord said to the man in the linen robe,
Ezekiel 9:4 “Walk through the city of Jerusalem and mark the forehead of anyone who is truly upset and sad about the terrible things that are being done here.”
Ezekiel 9:5+EZK He turned to the other six men and said, “Follow him and put to death everyone who doesn't have a mark on their forehead. Show no mercy or pity! Kill men and women, parents and children. Begin here at my temple, but be sure not to harm those who are marked.” The men immediately killed the leaders who were standing there.
Ezekiel 9:7 Then the Lord said, “Pollute the temple by piling the dead bodies in the courtyards. Now get busy!” They left and started killing the people of Jerusalem.
Ezekiel 9:8 I was then alone, so I bowed down and cried out to the Lord, “Why are you doing this? Are you so angry with the people of Jerusalem that everyone must die?”
Ezekiel 9:9 The Lord answered, “The people of Israel and Judah have done horrible things. Their country is filled with murderers, and Jerusalem itself is filled with violence. They think that I have deserted them, and that I can't see what they are doing.
Ezekiel 9:10 And so I will not have pity on them or forgive them. They will be punished for what they have done.”
Ezekiel 9:11 Just then, the man in the linen robe returned and said, “I have done what you commanded.”
Ezekiel 10:1 I saw the dome that was above the four winged creatures, and on it was the sapphire throne.
Ezekiel 10:2 The Lord said to the man in the linen robe, “Walk among the four wheels beside the creatures and pick up as many hot coals as you can carry. Then scatter them over the city of Jerusalem.” I watched him as he followed the Lord's instructions.
Ezekiel 10:3 The winged creatures were standing south of the temple when the man walked among them. A cloud filled the inner courtyard,
Ezekiel 10:4 and the brightness of the Lord's glory moved from above the creatures and stopped at the entrance of the temple. The entire temple was filled with his glory, and the courtyard was dazzling bright.
Ezekiel 10:5 The sound of the creatures' wings was as loud as the voice of God All-Powerful and could even be heard in the outer courtyard.
Ezekiel 10:6 The man in the robe was now standing beside a wheel.
Ezekiel 10:7 One of the four creatures reached its hand into the fire among them and gave him some of the hot coals. The man took the coals and left.
Ezekiel 10:8 I noticed again that each of the four winged creatures had what looked like human hands under their wings,
Ezekiel 10:9 and I saw the four wheels near the creatures. These wheels were shining like chrysolite.
Ezekiel 10:10 Each wheel was exactly the same and had a second wheel that cut through the middle of it,
Ezekiel 10:11 so that they could move in any direction without turning. The wheels moved together whenever the creatures moved.
Ezekiel 10:12 I also noticed that the wheels and the creatures' bodies, including their backs, their hands, and their wings, were covered with eyes.
Ezekiel 10:13 And I heard a voice calling these “the wheels that spin.”
Ezekiel 10:14 Each of the winged creatures had four faces: the face of a bull, the face of a human, the face of a lion, and the face of an eagle.
Ezekiel 10:15+EZK These were the same creatures I had seen near the Chebar River. They controlled when and where the wheels moved—the wheels went wherever the creatures went and stopped whenever they stopped. Even when the creatures flew in the air, the wheels stayed beside them.
Ezekiel 10:18 Then I watched the brightness of the Lord's glory move from the entrance of the temple and stop above the winged creatures.
Ezekiel 10:19 They spread their wings and flew into the air with the wheels at their side. They stopped at the east gate of the temple, and the Lord's glory was above them.
Ezekiel 10:20 I knew for sure that these were the same creatures I had seen beneath the Lord's glory near the Chebar River.
Ezekiel 10:21+EZK They had four wings with hands beneath them, and they had the same four faces as those near the River. Each creature moved straight ahead without turning.
Ezekiel 11:1 The Lord's Spirit lifted me up and took me to the east gate of the temple, where I saw 25 men, including the two leaders, Jaazaniah son of Azzur and Pelatiah son of Benaiah.
Ezekiel 11:2 The Lord said, “Ezekiel, son of man, these men are making evil plans and giving dangerous advice to the people of Jerusalem.
Ezekiel 11:3 They say things like, ‘Let's build more houses. This city is like a cooking pot over a fire, and we are the meat, but at least the pot keeps us from being burned in the fire.’
Ezekiel 11:4 So, Ezekiel, condemn them!”
Ezekiel 11:5 The Lord's Spirit took control of me and told me to tell these leaders: I, the Lord God, know what you leaders are saying.
Ezekiel 11:6 You have murdered so many people that the city is filled with dead bodies!
Ezekiel 11:7 This city is indeed a cooking pot, but the bodies of those you killed are the meat. And so I will force you to leave Jerusalem,
Ezekiel 11:8 and I'll send armies to attack you, just as you fear.
Ezekiel 11:9 Then you will be captured and punished by foreign enemies.
Ezekiel 11:10 You will be killed in your own country, but not before you realize that I, the Lord, have done these things.
Ezekiel 11:11 You leaders claim to be meat in a cooking pot, but you won't be protected by this city. No, you will die at the border of Israel.
Ezekiel 11:12 You will realize that while you were following the laws of nearby nations, you were disobeying my laws and teachings. And I am the Lord!
Ezekiel 11:13 Before I finished speaking, Pelatiah dropped dead. I bowed down and cried out, “Please, Lord God, don't kill everyone left in Israel.”
Ezekiel 11:14 The Lord replied:
Ezekiel 11:15 Ezekiel, son of man, the people living in Jerusalem claim that you and the other Israelites who were taken to Babylonia are too far away to worship me. They also claim that the land of Israel now belongs only to them.
Ezekiel 11:16 But here is what I want you to tell the Israelites in Babylonia: It's true that I, the Lord God, have forced you out of your own country and made you live among foreign nations. But for now, I will be with you wherever you are, so that you can worship me.
Ezekiel 11:17 And someday, I will gather you from the nations where you are scattered and let you live in Israel again.
Ezekiel 11:18 When that happens, I want you to clear the land of all those idols I hate so much.
Ezekiel 11:19 Then I will take away your stubbornness and make you eager to be completely faithful to me. You will want to obey me
Ezekiel 11:20 and all my laws and teachings. You will be my people, and I will be your God.
Ezekiel 11:21 But those who worship idols will be punished and get what they deserve. I, the Lord God, have spoken.
Ezekiel 11:22 After the Lord had finished speaking, the winged creatures spread their wings and flew into the air, and the wheels were beside them. The brightness of the Lord's glory above them
Ezekiel 11:23 left Jerusalem and stopped at a hill east of the city.
Ezekiel 11:24 Then in my vision, the Lord's Spirit lifted me up and carried me back to the other exiles in Babylonia. The vision faded away,
Ezekiel 11:25 and I told them everything the Lord had shown me.
Ezekiel 12:1 The Lord said:
Ezekiel 12:2 Ezekiel, son of man, you are living among rebellious people. They have eyes, but refuse to see; they have ears, but refuse to listen.
Ezekiel 12:3 So before it gets dark, here is what I want you to do. Pack a few things as though you were going to be taken away as a prisoner. Then go outside where everyone can see you and walk around from place to place. Maybe as they watch, they will realize what rebels they are.
Ezekiel 12:4 After you have done this, return to your house. Later that evening leave your house as if you were going into exile.
Ezekiel 12:5 Dig through the wall of your house and crawl out, carrying the bag with you. Make sure everyone is watching.
Ezekiel 12:6 Lift the bag to your shoulders, and with your face covered, take it into the darkness, so that you cannot see the land you are leaving. All this will be a warning for the people of Israel.
Ezekiel 12:7 I did everything the Lord had said. I packed a few things. Then as the sun was going down, and while everyone was watching, I dug a hole through one of the walls of my house. I pulled out my bag, then lifted it to my shoulders and left in the darkness.
Ezekiel 12:8 The next morning, the Lord
Ezekiel 12:9 reminded me that those rebellious people didn't even ask what I was doing.
Ezekiel 12:10 So he sent me back to tell them: The Lord God has a message for the leader of Jerusalem and everyone living there!
Ezekiel 12:11 I have done these things to show them what will happen when they are taken away as prisoners.
Ezekiel 12:12 The leader of Jerusalem will lift his own bag to his shoulders at sunset and leave through a hole that the others have dug in the wall of his house. He will cover his face, so he can't see the land he is leaving.
Ezekiel 12:13 The Lord will spread out a net and trap him as he leaves Jerusalem. He will then be led away to the city of Babylon, but will never see that place, even though he will die there.
Ezekiel 12:14 His own officials and troops will scatter in every direction, and the Lord will track them down and put them to death.
Ezekiel 12:15 The Lord will force the rest of the people in Jerusalem to live in foreign nations, where they will realize that he has done all these things.
Ezekiel 12:16 Some of them will survive the war, the starvation, and the deadly diseases. That way, they will be able to tell foreigners how disgusting their sins were, and that it was the Lord who punished them in this way.
Ezekiel 12:17 The Lord said:
Ezekiel 12:18 Ezekiel, son of man, shake with fear when you eat, and tremble when you drink.
Ezekiel 12:19 Tell the people of Israel that I, the Lord, say that someday everyone in Jerusalem will shake when they eat and tremble when they drink. Their country will be destroyed and left empty, because they have been cruel and violent.
Ezekiel 12:20 Every town will lie in ruins, and the land will be a barren desert. Then they will know that I am the Lord.
Ezekiel 12:21 The Lord said:
Ezekiel 12:22 Ezekiel, son of man, you've heard people in Israel use the saying, “Time passes, and prophets are proved wrong.”
Ezekiel 12:23 Now tell the people that I, the Lord, am going to prove that saying wrong. No one will ever be able to use it again in Israel, because very soon everything I have said will come true!
Ezekiel 12:24 The people will hear no more useless warnings and false messages.
Ezekiel 12:25 I will give them my message, and what I say will certainly happen. Warn those rebels that the time has come for them to be punished. I, the Lord, make this promise.
Ezekiel 12:26+EZK Ezekiel, the people of Israel are also saying that your visions and messages are only about things in the future.
Ezekiel 12:28 So tell them that my words will soon come true, just as I have warned. I, the Lord, have spoken.
Ezekiel 13:1 The Lord said:
Ezekiel 13:2 Ezekiel, son of man, condemn the prophets of Israel who say they speak in my name, but who preach messages that come from their own imagination. Tell them it's time to hear my message.
Ezekiel 13:3 I, the Lord God, say those lying prophets are doomed! They don't see visions—they make up their own messages!
Ezekiel 13:4 Israel's prophets are no better than jackals that hunt for food among the ruins of a city.
Ezekiel 13:5 They don't warn the people about coming trouble or tell them how dangerous it is to sin against me.
Ezekiel 13:6 Those prophets lie by claiming they speak for me, but I have not even chosen them to be my prophets. And they still think their words will come true.
Ezekiel 13:7 They say they're preaching my messages, but they are full of lies—I did not speak to them!
Ezekiel 13:8 So I am going to punish those lying prophets for deceiving the people of Israel with false messages.
Ezekiel 13:9 I will turn against them and no longer let them belong to my people. They will not be allowed to call themselves Israelites or even to set foot in Israel. Then they will realize that I am the Lord God.
Ezekiel 13:10 Those prophets refuse to be honest. They tell my people there will be peace, even though there's no peace to be found. They are like workers who think they can fix a shaky wall by covering it with paint.
Ezekiel 13:11 But when I send rainstorms, hailstones, and strong winds, the wall will surely collapse.
Ezekiel 13:12 People will then ask the workers why the paint didn't hold it up.
Ezekiel 13:13 That wall is the city of Jerusalem. And I, the Lord God, am so angry that I will send strong winds, rainstorms, and hailstones to destroy it.
Ezekiel 13:14 The lying prophets have tried to cover up the evil in Jerusalem, but I will tear down the city, all the way to its foundations. And when it collapses, those prophets will be killed, and everyone will know that I have done these things.
Ezekiel 13:15 The city of Jerusalem and its lying prophets will feel my fierce anger. Then I will announce that the city has fallen and that the lying prophets are dead,
Ezekiel 13:16 because they promised my people peace, when there was no peace. I, the Lord God, have spoken.
Ezekiel 13:17 Ezekiel, son of man, now condemn the women of Israel who preach messages that come from their own imagination.
Ezekiel 13:18 Tell them they're doomed! They wear magic charms on their wrists and scarves on their heads, then trick others into believing they can predict the future. They won't get away with telling those lies.
Ezekiel 13:19 They charge my people a few handfuls of barley and a couple pieces of bread, and then give messages that are insulting to me. They use lies to sentence the innocent to death and to help the guilty go free. And my people believe them!
Ezekiel 13:20 I hate the magic charms they use to trick people into believing their lies. I will rip those charms from their wrists and set free the people they have trapped like birds.
Ezekiel 13:21 I will tear the scarves from their heads and rescue my people from their power once and for all. Then they will know that I am the Lord God.
Ezekiel 13:22 They do things I would never do. They lie to good people and encourage them to do wrong, and they convince the wicked to ruin their own lives by not turning from sin.
Ezekiel 13:23 I will no longer let these women give false messages and use magic, and I will free my people from their control. Then they will know that I, the Lord, have done these things.
Ezekiel 14:1 One day, some of Israel's leaders came to me and asked for a message from the Lord.
Ezekiel 14:2 While they were there, the Lord said:
Ezekiel 14:3 Ezekiel, son of man, these men have started worshiping idols, though they know it will cause them to sin even more. So I refuse to give them a message!
Ezekiel 14:4 Tell the people of Israel that if they sin by worshiping idols and then go to a prophet to find out what I say, I will give them the answer their sins deserve.
Ezekiel 14:5 When they hear my message, maybe they will see that they need to turn back to me and stop worshiping those idols.
Ezekiel 14:6 Now, Ezekiel, tell everyone in Israel: I am the Lord God. Stop worshiping those idols I hate so much and come back to me.
Ezekiel 14:7 Suppose one of you Israelites or a foreigner living in Israel rejects me and starts worshiping idols. If you then go to a prophet to find out what I say, I will answer
Ezekiel 14:8 by turning against you. I will make you a warning to anyone who might think of doing the same thing, and you will no longer belong to my people. Then you will know that I am the Lord and that you have sinned against me.
Ezekiel 14:9 If a prophet gives a false message, I am the one who caused that prophet to lie. But I will still reject him and cut him off from my people,
Ezekiel 14:10 and anyone who goes to that prophet for a message will be punished in the same way.
