Amos 5:23 No more of your noisy songs! I won't listen when you play your harps.
Amos 5:24 But let justice and fairness flow like a river that never runs dry.
Amos 5:25 Israel, for forty years you wandered in the desert, without bringing offerings or sacrifices to me.
Amos 5:26 Now you will have to carry the two idols you made— Sakkuth, the one you call king, and Kaiwan, the one you built in the shape of a star.
Amos 5:27 I will force you to march as captives beyond Damascus. I, the Lord God All-Powerful, have spoken!
Amos 6:1 Do you rulers in Jerusalem and in the city of Samaria feel safe and at ease? Everyone bows down to you, and you think you are better than any other nation. But you are in for trouble!
Amos 6:2 Look what happened to the cities of Calneh, powerful Hamath, and Gath in Philistia. Are you greater than any of those kingdoms?
Amos 6:3 You are cruel, and you forget the coming day of judgment.
Amos 6:4 You rich people lounge around on beds with ivory posts, while dining on the meat of your lambs and calves.
Amos 6:5 You sing foolish songs to the music of harps, and you make up new tunes, just as David used to do.
Amos 6:6 You drink all the wine you want and wear expensive perfume, but you don't care about the ruin of your nation.
Amos 6:7 So you will be the first to be dragged off as captives; your good times will end.
Amos 6:8 The Lord God All-Powerful has sworn by his own name: “You descendants of Jacob make me angry by your pride, and I hate your fortresses. And so I will surrender your city and possessions to your enemies.”
Amos 6:9 If only ten of you survive by hiding in a house you will still die.
Amos 6:10 As you carry out a corpse to prepare it for burial, your relative in the house will ask, “Are there others?” You will answer, “No!” Then your relative will reply, “Be quiet! Don't dare mention the name of the Lord.”
Amos 6:11 At the Lord's command, houses great and small will be smashed to pieces.
Amos 6:12 Horses can't gallop on rocks; oceans can't be plowed. But you have turned justice and fairness into bitter poison.
Amos 6:13 You celebrate the defeat of Lo-Debar and Karnaim, and you boast by saying, “We did it on our own.”
Amos 6:14 But the Lord God All-Powerful will send a nation to attack you people of Israel. They will capture Lebo-Hamath in the north, Arabah Creek in the south, and everything in between.
Amos 7:1 The Lord God showed me that he is going to send locusts to attack your crops. It will happen after the king has already been given his share of the grain and before the rest of the grain has been harvested.
Amos 7:2 In my vision the locusts ate every crop in the land, and I said to the Lord, “Please forgive your nation. It's so weak. How can it survive?”
Amos 7:3 Then the Lord felt sorry and answered, “I won't let it be destroyed.”
Amos 7:4 The Lord showed me that he is going to send a ball of fire to burn up everything on earth, including the ocean.
Amos 7:5 Then I said, “Won't you please stop? How can our weak nation survive?”
Amos 7:6 Again the Lord felt sorry and answered, “I won't let it be destroyed.”
Amos 7:7 The Lord showed me a vision of himself standing beside a wall and holding a string with a weight tied to the end of it. The string and weight had been used to measure the straightness of the wall.
Amos 7:8 Then he asked, “Amos, what do you see?” “A measuring line,” I answered. The Lord said, “I'm using this measuring line to show that my people Israel don't measure up, and I won't forgive them any more.
Amos 7:9 Their sacred places will be destroyed, and I will send war against the nation of King Jeroboam.”
Amos 7:10 Amaziah the priest at Bethel sent this message to King Jeroboam of Israel, “Amos is plotting against you in the very heart of Israel. Our nation cannot put up with his message for very long.
Amos 7:11 Here is what he is saying: ‘Jeroboam will be put to death, and the people will be taken to a foreign country.’ ”
Amos 7:12 Then Amaziah told me, “Amos, take your visions and get out! Go back to Judah and earn your living there as a prophet.
Amos 7:13 Don't do any more preaching at Bethel. The king worships here at our national temple.”
Amos 7:14 I answered: I'm not a prophet! And I wasn't trained to be a prophet. I am a shepherd, and I take care of fig trees.
Amos 7:15 But the Lord told me to leave my herds and preach to the people of Israel.
Amos 7:16 And here you are, telling me not to preach!
Amos 7:17 Now, listen to what the Lord says about you: Your wife will become a prostitute in the city, your sons and daughters will be killed in war, and your land will be divided among others. You will die in a country of foreigners, and the people of Israel will be dragged from their homeland.
Amos 8:1 The Lord God showed me a basket of ripe fruit
Amos 8:2 and asked, “Amos, what do you see?” “A basket of ripe fruit,” I replied. Then he said, “This is the end for my people Israel. I won't forgive them again.
Amos 8:3 Instead of singing in the temple, they will cry and weep. Dead bodies will be everywhere. So keep silent! I, the Lord, have spoken!”
Amos 8:4 You people crush those in need and wipe out the poor.
Amos 8:5 You say to yourselves, “How much longer before the end of the New Moon Festival? When will the Sabbath be over? Our wheat is ready, and we want to sell it now. We can't wait to cheat and charge high prices for the grain we sell. We will use dishonest scales
Amos 8:6 and mix dust in the grain. Those who are needy and poor don't have any money. We will make them our slaves for the price of a pair of sandals.”
Amos 8:7 I, the Lord, won't forget any of this, though you take great pride in your ancestor Jacob.
Amos 8:8 Your country will tremble, and you will mourn. It will be like the Nile River that rises and overflows, then sinks back down.
Amos 8:9 On that day, I, the Lord God, will make the sun go down at noon, and I will turn daylight into darkness.
Amos 8:10 Your festivals and joyful singing will turn into sorrow. You will wear sackcloth and shave your heads, as you would at the death of your only son. It will be a horrible day.
Amos 8:11 I, the Lord, also promise you a terrible shortage, but not of food and water. You will hunger and thirst to hear my message.
Amos 8:12 You will search everywhere— from north to south, from east to west. You will go all over the earth, seeking a message from me, the Lord. But you won't find one.
Amos 8:13 Your beautiful young women and your young men will faint from thirst.
Amos 8:14 You made promises to the goddess Ashimah at Samaria; you made vows to other gods at the shrines of Dan and Beersheba. So now you will fall and never get up.
Amos 9:1 I saw a vision of the Lord standing by the temple altar, and he said, “Shake the columns until the tops fall loose, and the doorposts crumble. Then make the pieces fall on the people below. I will take a sword and kill anyone who escapes.
Amos 9:2 “If they dig deep into the earth or climb to the sky, I'll reach out and get them.
Amos 9:3 If they escape to the peaks of Mount Carmel, I'll search and find them. And if they hide from me at the bottom of the ocean, I'll command a sea monster to bite them.
Amos 9:4 I'll send a sword to kill them, wherever their enemies drag them off as captives. I'm determined to hurt them, not to help them.”
Amos 9:5 When the Lord God All-Powerful touches the earth, it melts, and its people mourn. God makes the earth rise and then fall, just like the Nile River.
Amos 9:6 He built his palace in the heavens and let its foundations rest on the earth. He scoops up the ocean and empties it on the earth. His name is the Lord.
Amos 9:7 Israel, I am the Lord God, and the Ethiopians are no less important to me than you are. I brought you out of Egypt, but I also brought the Philistines from Crete and the Arameans from Kir.
Amos 9:8 My eyes have seen what a sinful nation you are, and I'll wipe you out. But I will leave a few of Jacob's descendants. I, the Lord, have spoken!
Amos 9:9 At my command, all of you will be sifted like grain. Israelites who remain faithful will be scattered among the nations. And the others will be trapped like trash in a sifter.
Amos 9:10 Some of you are evil, and you deny that you will ever get caught. But you will be killed.
Amos 9:11 In the future, I will rebuild David's fallen kingdom. I will build it from its ruins and set it up again, just as it used to be.
Amos 9:12 Then you will capture Edom and the other nations that are mine. I, the Lord, have spoken, and my words will come true.
Amos 9:13 You will have such a harvest that you won't be able to bring in all of your wheat before plowing time. You will have grapes left over from season to season; your fruitful vineyards will cover the mountains.
Amos 9:14 I'll make Israel prosper again. You will rebuild your towns and live in them. You will drink wine from your own vineyards and eat the fruit you grow.
Amos 9:15 I'll plant your roots deep in the land I have given you, and you won't ever be uprooted again. I, the Lord God, have spoken!
Obadiah 1:1 The Lord God gave Obadiah a message about Edom, and this is what we heard: “I, the Lord, have sent a messenger with orders for the nations to attack Edom.”
Obadiah 1:2 The Lord said to Edom: I will make you the weakest and most despised nation.
Obadiah 1:3 You live in a mountain fortress, because your pride makes you feel safe from attack, but you are mistaken.
Obadiah 1:4 I will still bring you down, even if you fly higher than an eagle or nest among the stars. I, the Lord, have spoken!
Obadiah 1:5 If thieves break in at night, they steal only what they want. And people who harvest grapes always leave some unpicked. But, Edom, you are doomed!
Obadiah 1:6 Everything you treasure most will be taken from you.
Obadiah 1:7 Your allies can't be trusted. They will force you out of your own country. And your best friends will trick and trap you, even before you know it.
Obadiah 1:8 Edom, when this happens, I, the Lord, will destroy all your marvelous wisdom.
Obadiah 1:9 Warriors from the city of Teman will be terrified, and you descendants of Esau will be wiped out.
Obadiah 1:10 You were cruel to your relatives, the descendants of Jacob. Now you will be destroyed, disgraced forever.
Obadiah 1:11 You stood there and watched as foreigners entered Jerusalem and took what they wanted. In fact, you were no better than those foreigners.
Obadiah 1:12 Why did you celebrate when such a dreadful disaster struck your relatives? Why were you so pleased when everyone in Judah was suffering?
Obadiah 1:13 They are my people, and you were cruel to them. You went through their towns, sneering and stealing whatever was left.
Obadiah 1:14 In their time of torment, you ambushed refugees and handed them over to their attackers.
Obadiah 1:15 The day is coming when I, the Lord, will judge the nations. And, Edom, you will pay in full for what you have done.
Obadiah 1:16 I forced the people of Judah to drink the wine of my anger on my sacred mountain. Soon the neighboring nations must drink their fill— then vanish without a trace.
Obadiah 1:17 The Lord's people who escape will go to Mount Zion, and it will be holy. Then Jacob's descendants will capture the land of those who took their land.
Obadiah 1:18 Israel will be a fire, and Edom will be straw going up in flames. The Lord has spoken!
Obadiah 1:19 The people of Israel who live in the Southern Desert will take the land of Edom. Those who live in the hills will capture Philistia, Ephraim, and Samaria. And the tribe of Benjamin will conquer Gilead.
Obadiah 1:20 Those who return from captivity will control Phoenicia as far as Zarephath. Captives from Jerusalem who were taken to Sepharad will capture the towns of the Southern Desert.
Obadiah 1:21 Those the Lord has saved will live on Mount Zion and rule over Edom. Then the kingdom will belong to the Lord.
Jonah 1:1 One day the Lord told Jonah, the son of Amittai,
Jonah 1:2 to go to the great city of Nineveh and say to the people, “The Lord has seen your terrible sins. You are doomed!”
Jonah 1:3 Instead, Jonah ran from the Lord. He went to the seaport of Joppa and found a ship that was going to Spain. So he paid his fare, then got on the ship and sailed away to escape.
Jonah 1:4 But the Lord made a strong wind blow, and such a bad storm came up that the ship was about to be broken to pieces.
Jonah 1:5 The sailors were frightened, and they all started praying to their gods. They even threw the ship's cargo overboard to make the ship lighter. All this time, Jonah was down below deck, sound asleep.
Jonah 1:6 The ship's captain went to him and said, “How can you sleep at a time like this? Get up and pray to your God! Maybe he will have pity on us and keep us from drowning.”
Jonah 1:7 Finally, the sailors got together and said, “Let's ask our gods to show us who caused all this trouble.” It turned out to be Jonah.
Jonah 1:8 They started asking him, “Are you the one who brought all this trouble on us? What business are you in? Where do you come from? What is your country? Who are your people?”
Jonah 1:9 Jonah answered, “I'm a Hebrew, and I worship the Lord God of heaven, who made the sea and the dry land.”
Jonah 1:10 When the sailors heard this, they were frightened, because Jonah had already told them he was running from the Lord. Then they said, “Do you know what you have done?”
Jonah 1:11 The storm kept getting worse, until finally the sailors asked him, “What should we do with you to make the sea calm down?”
Jonah 1:12 Jonah told them, “Throw me into the sea, and it will calm down. I'm the cause of this terrible storm.”
Jonah 1:13 The sailors tried their best to row to the shore. But they could not do it, and the storm kept getting worse every minute.
Jonah 1:14 So they prayed to the Lord, “Please don't let us drown for taking this man's life. Don't hold us guilty for killing an innocent man. All of this happened because you wanted it to.”
Jonah 1:15 Then they threw Jonah overboard, and the sea calmed down.
Jonah 1:16 The sailors were so terrified that they offered a sacrifice to the Lord and made all kinds of promises.
Jonah 1:17 The Lord sent a big fish to swallow Jonah, and Jonah was inside the fish for three days and three nights.
Jonah 2:1 From inside the fish, Jonah prayed to the Lord his God:
Jonah 2:2 When I was in trouble, Lord, I prayed to you, and you listened to me. From deep in the world of the dead, I begged for your help, and you answered my prayer.
Jonah 2:3 You threw me down to the bottom of the sea. The water was churning all around; I was completely covered by your mighty waves.
Jonah 2:4 I thought I was swept away from your sight, never again to see your holy temple.
Jonah 2:5 I was almost drowned by the swirling waters that surrounded me. Seaweed had wrapped around my head.
Jonah 2:6 I had sunk down deep below the mountains beneath the sea. I knew that forever, I would be a prisoner there. But, you, Lord God, rescued me from that pit.
Jonah 2:7 When my life was slipping away, I remembered you— and in your holy temple you heard my prayer.
Jonah 2:8 All who worship worthless idols turn from the God who offers them mercy.
Jonah 2:9 But with shouts of praise, I will offer a sacrifice to you, my Lord. I will keep my promise, because you are the one with power to save.
Jonah 2:10 The Lord commanded the fish to vomit up Jonah on the shore. And it did.
Jonah 3:1 Once again the Lord told Jonah
Jonah 3:2 to go to that great city of Nineveh and preach his message of doom.
Jonah 3:3 Jonah obeyed the Lord and went to Nineveh. The city was so big that it took three days just to walk through it.
Jonah 3:4 After walking for a day, Jonah warned the people, “Forty days from now, Nineveh will be destroyed!”
Jonah 3:5 They believed God's message and set a time when they would go without eating to show their sorrow. Then everyone in the city, no matter who they were, dressed in sackcloth.
Jonah 3:6 When the king of Nineveh heard what was happening, he also dressed in sackcloth; he left the royal palace and sat in dust.
Jonah 3:7+JON Then he and his officials sent out an order for everyone in the city to obey. It said: None of you or your animals may eat or drink a thing. Each of you must wear sackcloth, and you must even put sackcloth on your animals. You must also pray to the Lord God with all your heart and stop being sinful and cruel. Maybe God will change his mind and have mercy on us, so we won't be destroyed.
Jonah 3:10 When God saw that the people had stopped doing evil things, he had pity and did not destroy them as he had planned.
Jonah 4:1 Jonah was really upset and angry.
Jonah 4:2 So he prayed: Our Lord, I knew from the very beginning that you wouldn't destroy Nineveh. That's why I left my own country and headed for Spain. You are a kind and merciful God, and you are very patient. You always show love, and you don't like to punish anyone.
Jonah 4:3 Now let me die! I'd be better off dead.
Jonah 4:4 The Lord replied, “What right do you have to be angry?”
Jonah 4:5 Jonah then left through the east gate of the city and made a shelter to protect himself from the sun. He sat under the shelter, waiting to see what would happen to Nineveh.
Jonah 4:6 The Lord made a vine grow up to shade Jonah's head and protect him from the sun. Jonah was very happy to have the vine,
Jonah 4:7 but early the next morning the Lord sent a worm to chew on the vine, and the vine dried up.
Jonah 4:8 During the day the Lord sent a scorching wind, and the sun beat down on Jonah's head, making him feel faint. Jonah was ready to die, and he shouted, “I wish I were dead!”
Jonah 4:9 But the Lord asked, “Jonah, do you have the right to be angry about the vine?” “Yes, I do,” he answered, “and I'm angry enough to die.”
Jonah 4:10 But the Lord said: You are concerned about a vine that you did not plant or take care of, a vine that grew up in one night and died the next.
Jonah 4:11 In that city of Nineveh there are more than 120,000 people who cannot tell right from wrong, and many cattle are also there. Don't you think I should be concerned about that big city?
Micah 1:1 I am Micah from Moresheth. And this is the message about Samaria and Jerusalem that the Lord gave to me when Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah were the kings of Judah.
Micah 1:2 Listen, all of you! Earth and everything on it, pay close attention. The Lord God accuses you from his holy temple.
Micah 1:3 And he will come down to crush underfoot every pagan altar.
Micah 1:4 Mountains will melt beneath his feet like wax beside a fire. Valleys will vanish like water rushing down a ravine.
Micah 1:5 This will happen because of the terrible sins of Israel, the descendants of Jacob. Samaria has led Israel to sin, and pagan altars at Jerusalem have made Judah sin.
Micah 1:6 So the Lord will leave Samaria in ruins— merely an empty field where vineyards are planted. He will scatter its stones and destroy its foundations.
Micah 1:7 Samaria's idols will be smashed, and the wages of temple prostitutes will be destroyed by fire. Silver and gold from those idols will then be used by foreigners as payment for prostitutes.
Micah 1:8 Because of this tragedy, I go barefoot and naked. My crying and weeping sound like howling wolves or ostriches.
Micah 1:9 The nation is fatally wounded. Judah is doomed. Jerusalem will fall.
Micah 1:10 Don't tell it in Gath! Don't even cry. Instead, roll in the dust at Beth-Leaphrah.
Micah 1:11 Depart naked and ashamed, you people of Shaphir. The town of Bethezel mourns because no one from Zaanan went out to help.
Micah 1:12 Everyone in Maroth hoped for the best, but the Lord sent disaster down on Jerusalem.
Micah 1:13 Get the war chariots ready, you people of Lachish. You led Jerusalem into sin, just as Israel did.
Micah 1:14 Now you will have to give a going-away gift to Moresheth. Israel's kings will discover that they cannot trust the town of Achzib.
Micah 1:15 People of Mareshah, the Lord will send someone to capture your town. Then Israel's glorious king will be forced to hide in Adullam Cave.
Micah 1:16 Judah, shave your head as bald as a vulture and start mourning. Your precious children will be dragged off to a foreign country.
Micah 2:1 Doomed! You're doomed! At night you lie in bed, making evil plans. And when morning comes, you do what you've planned because you have the power.
Micah 2:2 You grab any field or house that you want; you cheat families out of homes and land.
Micah 2:3 But here is what the Lord says: “I am planning trouble for you. Your necks will be caught in a noose, and you will be disgraced in this time of disaster.”
Micah 2:4 When that happens, this sorrowful song will be sung about you: “Ruined! Completely ruined! The Lord has taken our land and given it to traitors.”
Micah 2:5 And so you will never again own property among the Lord's people.
Micah 2:6 “Enough of your preaching!” That's what you tell me. “We won't be disgraced, so stop preaching!”
Micah 2:7 Descendants of Jacob, is it right for you to claim that the Lord did what he did because he was angry? Doesn't he always bless those who do right?
Micah 2:8 My people, you have turned against one another! You have even stolen clothes right off the backs of innocent neighbors who pass by in peace.
Micah 2:9 You take over lovely homes that belong to the women of my nation. Then you cheat their children out of the inheritance that comes from the Lord.
Micah 2:10 Get out of here, you crooks! You'll find no rest here. You're not fit to belong to the Lord's people, and you will be destroyed.
Micah 2:11 The only prophet you want is a liar who will say, “Drink and get drunk!”
Micah 2:12 I, the Lord, promise to bring together the people of Israel who have survived. I will gather them, just as a shepherd brings sheep together, and there will be many.
Micah 2:13 I will break down the gate and lead them out— then I will be their king.
Micah 3:1 Listen to me, you rulers of Israel! You know right from wrong,
Micah 3:2 but you prefer to do evil instead of what is right. You skin my people alive. You strip off their flesh,
Micah 3:3 break their bones, cook it all in a pot, and gulp it down.
Micah 3:4 Someday you will beg the Lord to help you, but he will turn away because of your sins.
Micah 3:5 You lying prophets promise security for anyone who gives you food, but disaster for anyone who refuses to feed you. Here is what the Lord says to you prophets:
Micah 3:6 “You will live in the dark, far from the sight of the sun, with no message from me.
Micah 3:7 You prophets and fortunetellers will all be disgraced, with no message from me.”
Micah 3:8 But the Lord has filled me with power and his Spirit. I have been given the courage to speak about justice and to tell you people of Israel that you have sinned.
Micah 3:9 So listen to my message, you rulers of Israel! You hate justice and twist the truth.
Micah 3:10 You make cruelty and murder a way of life in Jerusalem.
Micah 3:11 You leaders accept bribes for dishonest decisions. You priests and prophets teach and preach, but only for money. Then you say, “The Lord is on our side. No harm will come to us.”
Micah 3:12 And so, because of you, Jerusalem will be plowed under and left in ruins. Thorns will cover the mountain where the temple now stands.
Micah 4:1 In the future, the mountain with the Lord's temple will be the highest of all. It will reach above the hills, and every nation will rush to it.
Micah 4:2 People of many nations will come and say, “Let's go up to the mountain of the Lord God of Jacob and worship in his temple.” The Lord will teach us his Law from Jerusalem, and we will obey him.
Micah 4:3 He will settle arguments between distant and powerful nations. They will pound their swords and their spears into rakes and shovels; they will never again make war or attack one another.
Micah 4:4 Everyone will find rest beneath their own fig trees or grape vines, and they will live in peace. This is a solemn promise of the Lord All-Powerful.
Micah 4:5 Others may follow their gods, but we will always follow the Lord our God.
Micah 4:6 The Lord said: At that time I will gather my people— the lame and the outcasts, and all others into whose lives I have brought sorrow.
Micah 4:7 Then the lame and the outcasts will belong to my people and become a strong nation. I, the Lord, will rule them from Mount Zion forever.
Micah 4:8 Mount Zion in Jerusalem, guardian of my people, you will rule again.
Micah 4:9 Jerusalem, why are you crying? Don't you have a king? Have your advisors gone? Are you suffering like a woman in childbirth?
Micah 4:10 Keep on groaning with pain, you people of Jerusalem! If you escape from your city to the countryside, you will still be taken as prisoners to Babylonia. But later I will rescue you from your enemies.
Micah 4:11 Zion, because of your sins you are surrounded by many nations who say, “We can hardly wait to see you disgraced.”
Micah 4:12 But they don't know that I, the Lord, have gathered them here to grind them like grain.
Micah 4:13 Smash them to pieces, Zion! I'll let you be like a bull with iron horns and bronze hoofs. Crush those nations and bring their wealth to me, the Lord of the earth.
Micah 5:1 Jerusalem, enemy troops have surrounded you; they have struck Israel's ruler in the face with a stick.
Micah 5:2 Bethlehem Ephrath, you are one of the smallest towns in the nation of Judah. But the Lord will choose one of your people to rule the nation— someone whose family goes back to ancient times.
Micah 5:3 The Lord will abandon Israel only until this ruler is born, and the rest of his family returns to Israel.
Micah 5:4 Like a shepherd taking care of his sheep, this ruler will lead and care for his people by the power and glorious name of the Lord his God. His people will live securely, and the whole earth will know his true greatness,
Micah 5:5 because he will bring peace. Let Assyria attack our country and our palaces. We will counterattack, led by a number of rulers
Micah 5:6 whose strong army will defeat the nation of Assyria. Yes, our leaders will rescue us, if those Assyrians dare to invade our land.
Micah 5:7 A few of Jacob's descendants survived and are scattered among the nations. But the Lord will let them cover the earth like dew and rain that refreshes the soil.
Micah 5:8 At present they are scattered, but later they will attack, as though they were fierce lions pouncing on sheep. Their enemies will be torn to shreds, with no one to save them;
Micah 5:9 they will be helpless, completely destroyed.
Micah 5:10 The Lord said: At that time I will wipe out your cavalry and chariots,
Micah 5:11 as well as your cities and your fortresses.
Micah 5:12 I will stop you from telling fortunes and practicing witchcraft.
Micah 5:13 You will no longer worship the idols or stone images you have made— I will destroy them,
Micah 5:14 together with the sacred poles and even your towns.
Micah 5:15 I will become furious and take revenge on the nations that refuse to obey me.
Micah 6:1 The Lord said to his people: Come and present your case to the hills and mountains.
Micah 6:2 Israel, I am bringing charges against you— I call upon the mountains and the earth's firm foundation to be my witnesses.
Micah 6:3 My people, have I wronged you in any way at all? Please tell me.
Micah 6:4 I rescued you from Egypt, where you were slaves. I sent Moses, Aaron, and Miriam to be your leaders.
Micah 6:5 Don't forget the evil plans of King Balak of Moab or what Balaam son of Beor said to him. Remember how I, the Lord, saved you many times on your way from Acacia to Gilgal.
Micah 6:6 What offering should I bring when I bow down to worship the Lord God Most High? Should I try to please him by sacrificing calves a year old?
Micah 6:7 Will thousands of sheep or rivers of olive oil make God satisfied with me? Should I sacrifice to the Lord my first-born child as payment for my terrible sins?
Micah 6:8 The Lord God has told us what is right and what he demands: “See that justice is done, let mercy be your first concern, and humbly obey your God.”
Micah 6:9 I am the Lord, and you are wise to respect my power to punish. So listen to my message for the city of Jerusalem:
Micah 6:10 You store up stolen treasures and use dishonest scales.
Micah 6:11 But I, the Lord, will punish you for cheating with weights and with measures.
Micah 6:12 You rich people are violent, and everyone tells lies.
Micah 6:13 Because of your sins, I will wound you and leave you ruined and defenseless.
Micah 6:14 You will eat, but still be hungry; you will store up goods, but lose everything— I, the Lord, will let it all be captured in war.
Micah 6:15 You won't harvest what you plant or use the oil from your olive trees or drink the wine from grapes you grow.
Micah 6:16 Jerusalem, this will happen because you followed the sinful example of kings Omri and Ahab. Now I will destroy you and your property. Then the people of every nation will make fun and insult you.
Micah 7:1 I feel so empty inside— like someone starving for grapes or figs, after the vines and trees have all been picked clean.
Micah 7:2 No one is loyal to God; no one does right. Everyone is brutal and eager to deceive everyone else.
Micah 7:3 People cooperate to commit crime. Judges and leaders demand bribes, and rulers cheat in court.
Micah 7:4 The most honest of them is worse than a thorn patch. Your doom has come! Lookouts sound the warning, and everyone panics.
Micah 7:5 Don't trust anyone, not even your best friend, and be careful what you say to the one you love.
Micah 7:6 Sons refuse to respect their own fathers, daughters rebel against their own mothers, and daughters-in-law despise their mothers-in-law. Your family is now your enemy.
Micah 7:7 But I trust the Lord God to save me, and I will wait for him to answer my prayer.
Micah 7:8 My enemies, don't be glad because of my troubles! I may have fallen, but I will get up; I may be sitting in the dark, but the Lord is my light.
Micah 7:9 I have sinned against the Lord. And so I must endure his anger, until he comes to my defense. But I know that I will see him making things right for me and leading me to the light.
Micah 7:10 You, my enemies, said, “The Lord God is helpless.” Now each of you will be disgraced and put to shame. I will see you trampled like mud in the street.
Micah 7:11 Towns of Judah, the day is coming when your walls will be rebuilt, and your boundaries enlarged.
Micah 7:12 People will flock to you from Assyria and Egypt, from Babylonia and everywhere else.
Micah 7:13 Those nations will suffer disaster because of what they did.
Micah 7:14 Lead your people, Lord! Come and be our shepherd. Grasslands surround us, but we live in a forest. So lead us to Bashan and Gilead, and let us find pasture as we did long ago.
Micah 7:15 I, the Lord, will work miracles just as I did when I led you out of Egypt.
Micah 7:16 Nations will see this and be ashamed because of their helpless armies. They will be in shock, unable to speak or hear,
Micah 7:17 because of their fear of me, your Lord and God. Then they will come trembling, crawling out of their fortresses like insects or snakes, lapping up the dust.
Micah 7:18 Our God, no one is like you. We are all that is left of your chosen people, and you freely forgive our sin and guilt. You don't stay angry forever; you're glad to have pity
Micah 7:19 and pleased to be merciful. You will trample on our sins and throw them in the sea.
Micah 7:20 You will keep your word and be faithful to Jacob and to Abraham, as you promised our ancestors many years ago.
Nahum 1:1 I am Nahum from Elkosh. And this is the message that I wrote down about Nineveh.
Nahum 1:2 The Lord God demands loyalty. In his anger, he takes revenge on his enemies.
Nahum 1:3 The Lord is powerful, yet patient; he makes sure that the guilty are always punished. He can be seen in storms and in whirlwinds; clouds are the dust from his feet.
Nahum 1:4 At the Lord's command, oceans and rivers dry up. Bashan, Mount Carmel, and Lebanon wither, and their flowers fade.
Nahum 1:5 At the sight of the Lord, mountains and hills tremble and melt; the earth and its people shudder and shake.
Nahum 1:6 Who can stand the heat of his furious anger? It flashes out like fire and shatters stones.
Nahum 1:7 The Lord is good. He protects those who trust him in times of trouble.
Nahum 1:8 But like a roaring flood, the Lord chases his enemies into dark places and destroys them.
Nahum 1:9 So don't plot against the Lord! He wipes out his enemies, and they never revive.
Nahum 1:10 They are like drunkards overcome by wine, or like twisted thornbushes burning in a fire.
Nahum 1:11 Assyria, one of your rulers has made evil plans against the Lord.
Nahum 1:12 But the Lord says, “Assyria, no matter how strong you are, you will be cut down! My people Judah, I have troubled you before, but I won't do it again.
Nahum 1:13 I'll snap your chains and set you free from the Assyrians.”
Nahum 1:14 Assyria, this is what else the Lord says to you: “Your name will be forgotten. I will destroy every idol in your temple, and I will send you to the grave, because you are worthless.”
Nahum 1:15 Look toward the mountains, people of Judah! Here comes a messenger with good news of peace. Celebrate your festivals. Keep your promises to God. Your evil enemies are destroyed and will never again invade your country.
Nahum 2:1 Nineveh, someone is coming to attack and scatter you. Guard your fortresses! Watch the road! Be brave! Prepare for battle!
Nahum 2:2 Judah and Israel are like trees with branches broken by their enemies. But the Lord is going to restore their power and glory. *
Nahum 2:3 Nineveh, on this day of attack, your enemies' shields are red; their uniforms are crimson.
Nahum 2:4 Their horses prance, and their armored chariots dart around like lightning or flaming torches.
Nahum 2:5 An officer gives a command. But his soldiers stumble, as they hasten to build a shelter to protect themselves against rocks thrown down from the city wall.
Nahum 2:6 The river gates fly open, and panic floods the palace.
Nahum 2:7 Nineveh is disgraced. The queen is dragged off. Her servant women mourn; they moan like doves, and they beat their breasts in sorrow.
Nahum 2:8 Nineveh is like a pond with leaking water. Shouts of “Stop! Don't go!” can be heard everywhere. But everyone is leaving.
Nahum 2:9 Enemy soldiers shout, “The city is full of treasure and all kinds of wealth. Steal her silver! Grab her gold!”
Nahum 2:10 Nineveh is doomed! Destroyed! Her people tremble with fear; their faces turn pale.
Nahum 2:11 What happened to this city? They were safer there than powerful lions in a den, with no one to disturb them.
Nahum 2:12 These are the same lions that ferociously attacked their victims, then dragged away the flesh to feed their young.
Nahum 2:13 The Lord All-Powerful is against you, Nineveh. God will burn your chariots and send an army to kill those young lions of yours. You will never again make victims of others or send messengers to threaten everyone on this earth.
Nahum 3:1 Doom to the crime capital! Nineveh, city of murder and treachery,
Nahum 3:2 here is your fate— cracking whips, churning wheels; galloping horses, roaring chariots;
Nahum 3:3 cavalry attacking, swords and spears flashing; soldiers stumbling over piles of dead bodies.
Nahum 3:4 You were nothing more than a prostitute using your magical charms and witchcraft to attract and trap nations.
Nahum 3:5 But I, the Lord All-Powerful, am now your enemy. I will pull up your skirt and let nations and kingdoms stare at your nakedness.
Nahum 3:6 I will cover you with garbage, treat you like trash, and rub you in the dirt.
Nahum 3:7 Everyone who sees you will turn away and shout, “Nineveh is done for! Is anyone willing to mourn or to give her comfort?”
Nahum 3:8 Nineveh, do you feel safer than the city of Thebes? The Nile River was its wall of defense.
Nahum 3:9 Thebes trusted the mighty power of Ethiopia and Egypt; the nations of Put and Libya were her allies.
Nahum 3:10 But she was captured and taken to a foreign country. Her children were murdered at every street corner. The members of her royal family were auctioned off, and her high officials were bound in chains.
Nahum 3:11 Nineveh, now it's your turn! You will get drunk and try to hide from your enemy.
Nahum 3:12 Your fortresses are fig trees with ripe figs. Merely shake the trees, and fruit will fall into every open mouth.
Nahum 3:13 Your army is weak. Fire has destroyed the crossbars on your city gates; now they stand wide open to your enemy.
Nahum 3:14 Your city is under attack. Haul in extra water! Strengthen your defenses! Start making bricks! Stir the mortar!
Nahum 3:15 You will still go up in flames and be cut down by swords that will wipe you out like a field attacked by grasshoppers. So, go ahead and increase like a swarm of locusts!
Nahum 3:16 More merchants are in your city than there are stars in the sky— but they are like locusts that eat everything, then fly away.
Nahum 3:17 Your guards and your officials are swarms of locusts. On a chilly day they settle on a fence, but when the sun comes out, they take off to who-knows-where.
Nahum 3:18 King of Assyria, your officials and leaders are sound asleep, while your people are scattered in the mountains. Yes, your people are sheep without a shepherd.
Nahum 3:19 You're fatally wounded. There's no hope for you. But everyone claps when they hear this news, because your constant cruelty has caused them pain.
Habakkuk 1:1 I am Habakkuk the prophet. And this is the message that the Lord gave me.
Habakkuk 1:2 Our Lord, how long must I beg for your help before you listen? How long before you save us from all this violence?
Habakkuk 1:3 Why do you make me watch such terrible injustice? Why do you allow violence, lawlessness, crime, and cruelty to spread everywhere?
Habakkuk 1:4 Laws cannot be enforced; justice is always the loser; criminals crowd out honest people and twist the laws around.
Habakkuk 1:5 Look and be amazed at what's happening among the nations! Even if you were told, you would never believe what's taking place now.
Habakkuk 1:6 I am sending the Babylonians. They are fierce and cruel— marching across the land, conquering cities and towns.
Habakkuk 1:7 How fearsome and frightening. Their only laws and rules are the ones they make up.
Habakkuk 1:8 Their cavalry troops are faster than leopards, more ferocious than wolves hunting at sunset, and swifter than hungry eagles suddenly swooping down.
Habakkuk 1:9 They are eager to destroy, and they gather captives like handfuls of sand.
Habakkuk 1:10 They make fun of rulers and laugh at fortresses, while building dirt mounds so they can capture cities.
Habakkuk 1:11 Then suddenly they disappear like a gust of wind— those sinful people who worship their own strength.
Habakkuk 1:12 Holy Lord God, mighty rock, you are eternal, and we are safe from death. You are using those Babylonians to judge and punish others.
Habakkuk 1:13 But you can't stand sin or wrong. So don't sit by in silence while they gobble up people who are better than they are.
Habakkuk 1:14 The people you put on this earth are like fish or reptiles without a leader.
Habakkuk 1:15 Then an enemy comes along and takes them captive with hooks and nets. It makes him so happy
Habakkuk 1:16 that he offers sacrifices to his fishing nets, because they make him rich and provide choice foods.
Habakkuk 1:17 Will he keep hauling in his nets and destroying nations without showing mercy?
Habakkuk 2:1 While standing guard on the watchtower, I waited for the Lord's answer, before explaining the reason for my complaint.
Habakkuk 2:2 Then the Lord told me: “I will give you my message in the form of a vision. Write it clearly enough to be read at a glance.
Habakkuk 2:3 At the time I have decided, my words will come true. You can trust what I say about the future. It may take a long time, but keep on waiting— it will happen!
Habakkuk 2:4 “I, the Lord, refuse to accept anyone who is proud. Only those who live by faith are acceptable to me.”
Habakkuk 2:5 Wine is treacherous, and arrogant people are never satisfied. They are no less greedy than death itself— they open their mouths as wide as the world of the dead and swallow everyone.
Habakkuk 2:6 But they will be mocked with these words: You're doomed! You stored up stolen goods and cheated others of what belonged to them.
Habakkuk 2:7 But without warning, those you owe will demand payment. Then you will become a frightened victim.
Habakkuk 2:8 You robbed cities and nations everywhere on earth and murdered their people. Now those who survived will be as cruel to you.
Habakkuk 2:9 You're doomed! You made your family rich at the expense of others. You even said to yourself, “I'm above the law.”
Habakkuk 2:10 But you will bring shame on your family and ruin to yourself for what you did to others.
Habakkuk 2:11 The very stones and wood in your home will testify against you.
Habakkuk 2:12 You're doomed! You built a city on crime and violence.
Habakkuk 2:13 But the Lord All-Powerful sends up in flames what nations and people work so hard to gain.
Habakkuk 2:14 Just as water fills the sea, the land will be filled with people who know and honor the Lord.
Habakkuk 2:15 You're doomed! You get your friends drunk, just to see them naked.
Habakkuk 2:16 Now you will be disgraced instead of praised. The Lord will make you drunk, and when others see you naked, you will lose their respect.
Habakkuk 2:17 You destroyed trees and animals on Mount Lebanon; you were ruthless to towns and people everywhere. Now you will be terrorized.
Habakkuk 2:18 What is an idol worth? It's merely a false god. Why trust a speechless image made from wood or metal by human hands?
Habakkuk 2:19 What can you learn from idols covered with silver or gold? They can't even breathe. Pity anyone who says to an idol of wood or stone, “Get up and do something!”
Habakkuk 2:20 Let all the world be silent— the Lord is present in his holy temple.
Habakkuk 3:1 This is my prayer:
Habakkuk 3:2 I know your reputation, Lord, and I am amazed at what you have done. Please turn from your anger and be merciful; do for us what you did for our ancestors.
Habakkuk 3:3 You are the same Holy God who came from Teman and Paran to help us. The brightness of your glory covered the heavens, and your praises were heard everywhere on earth.
Habakkuk 3:4 Your glory shone like the sun, and light flashed from your hands, hiding your mighty power.
Habakkuk 3:5 Dreadful diseases and plagues marched in front and followed behind.
Habakkuk 3:6 When you stopped, the earth shook; when you stared, nations trembled; when you walked along your ancient paths, eternal mountains and hills crumbled and collapsed.
Habakkuk 3:7 The tents of desert tribes in Cushan and Midian were ripped apart.
Habakkuk 3:8 Our Lord, were you angry with the monsters of the deep? You attacked in your chariot and wiped them out.
Habakkuk 3:9 Your arrows were ready and obeyed your commands. You split the earth apart with rivers and streams;
Habakkuk 3:10 mountains trembled at the sight of you; rain poured from the clouds; ocean waves roared and rose.
Habakkuk 3:11 The sun and moon stood still, while your arrows and spears flashed like lightning.
Habakkuk 3:12 In your furious anger, you trampled on nations
Habakkuk 3:13 to rescue your people and save your chosen one. You crushed a nation's ruler and stripped his evil kingdom of its power.
Habakkuk 3:14 His troops had come like a storm, hoping to scatter us and glad to gobble us up. To them we were refugees in hiding— but you smashed their heads with their own weapons.
Habakkuk 3:15 Then your chariots churned the waters of the sea.
Habakkuk 3:16 When I heard this message, I felt weak from fear, and my lips quivered. My bones seemed to melt, and I stumbled around. But I will patiently wait. Someday those vicious enemies will be struck by disaster.
Habakkuk 3:17 Fig trees may no longer bloom, or vineyards produce grapes; olive trees may be fruitless, and harvest time a failure; sheep pens may be empty, and cattle stalls vacant—
Habakkuk 3:18 but I will still celebrate because the Lord God is my Savior.
Habakkuk 3:19 The Lord gives me strength. He makes my feet as sure as those of a deer, and he helps me stand on the mountains. To the music director: Use stringed instruments.
Zephaniah 1:1 I am Zephaniah, the son of Cushi, the grandson of Gedaliah, the great-grandson of Amariah, and the great-great-grandson of Hezekiah. When Josiah son of Amon was king of Judah, the Lord gave me this message.
Zephaniah 1:2 I, the Lord, now promise to destroy everything on this earth—
Zephaniah 1:3 people and animals, birds and fish. Everyone who is evil will crash to the ground, and I will wipe out the entire human race.
Zephaniah 1:4 I will reach out to punish Judah and Jerusalem— nothing will remain of the god Baal; nothing will be remembered of his pagan priests.
Zephaniah 1:5 Not a trace will be found of those who worship stars from their rooftops, or bow down to the god Milcom, while claiming loyalty to me, the Lord.
Zephaniah 1:6 Nothing will remain of anyone who has turned away and rejected me.
Zephaniah 1:7 Be silent! I am the Lord God, and the time is near. I am preparing to sacrifice my people and to invite my guests.
Zephaniah 1:8 On that day I will punish national leaders and sons of the king, along with all who follow foreign customs.
Zephaniah 1:9 I will punish worshipers of pagan gods and cruel palace officials who abuse their power.
Zephaniah 1:10 I, the Lord, promise that on that day noisy crying will be heard from Fish Gate, New Town, and Upper Hills.
Zephaniah 1:11 Everyone in Lower Hollow will mourn loudly, because merchants and money changers will be wiped out.
Zephaniah 1:12 I'll search Jerusalem with lamps and punish those people who sit there unworried while thinking, “The Lord won't do anything, good or bad.”
Zephaniah 1:13 Their possessions will be taken, their homes left in ruins. They won't get to live in the houses they build, or drink wine from the grapes in their own vineyards.
Zephaniah 1:14 The great day of the Lord is coming soon, very soon. On that terrible day, fearsome shouts of warriors will be heard everywhere.
Zephaniah 1:15 It will be a time of anger— of trouble and torment, of disaster and destruction, of darkness and despair, of storm clouds and shadows,
Zephaniah 1:16 of trumpet calls and battle cries against fortified cities and mighty fortresses.
Zephaniah 1:17 The Lord warns everyone who has sinned against him, “I'll strike you blind! Then your blood and your insides will gush out like vomit.
Zephaniah 1:18 Not even your silver or gold can save you on that day when I, the Lord, am angry. My anger will flare up like a furious fire scorching the earth and everyone on it.”
Zephaniah 2:1 You disgraceful nation, gather around,
Zephaniah 2:2 before it's too late. The Lord has set a time when his fierce anger will strike like a storm and sweep you away.
Zephaniah 2:3 If you humbly obey the Lord, then come and worship him. If you do right and are humble, perhaps you will be safe on that day when the Lord turns loose his anger.
Zephaniah 2:4 Gaza and Ashkelon will be deserted and left in ruins. Ashdod will be emptied in broad daylight, and Ekron uprooted.
Zephaniah 2:5 To you people of Philistia who live along the coast, the Lord has this to say: “I am now your enemy, and I'll wipe you out!”
Zephaniah 2:6 Your seacoast will be changed into pastureland and sheep pens.
Zephaniah 2:7 The Lord God hasn't forgotten those survivors in Judah, and he will help them— his people will take your land to use for pasture. And when evening comes, they will rest in houses at Ashkelon. *
Zephaniah 2:8 The Lord All-Powerful, the God of Israel, said: I've heard Moab and Ammon insult my people and threaten their nation.
Zephaniah 2:9 And so, I swear by my very life that Moab and Ammon will end up like Sodom and Gomorrah— covered with thornbushes and salt pits forever. Then my people who survive will take their land.
Zephaniah 2:10 This is how Moab and Ammon will at last be repaid for their pride— and for sneering at the nation that belongs to me, the Lord All-Powerful.
Zephaniah 2:11 I will fiercely attack. Then every god on this earth will shrink to nothing, and everyone of every nation will bow down to me, right where they are.
Zephaniah 2:12 People of Ethiopia, the sword of the Lord will slaughter you!
Zephaniah 2:13 The Lord will reach to the north to crush Assyria and overthrow Nineveh.
Zephaniah 2:14 Herds of wild animals will live in its rubble; all kinds of desert owls will perch on its stones and hoot in the windows. Noisy ravens will be heard inside its buildings, stripped bare of cedar.
Zephaniah 2:15 This is the glorious city that felt secure and said, “I am the only one!” Now it's merely ruins, a home for wild animals. Every passerby simply sneers and makes vulgar signs.
Zephaniah 3:1 Too bad for that disgusting, corrupt, and lawless city!
Zephaniah 3:2 Forever rebellious and rejecting correction, Jerusalem refuses to trust or obey the Lord God.
Zephaniah 3:3 Its officials are roaring lions, its judges are wolves; in the evening they attack, by morning nothing is left.
Zephaniah 3:4 Jerusalem's prophets are proud and not to be trusted. The priests have disgraced the place of worship and abused God's Law.
Zephaniah 3:5 All who do evil are shameless, but the Lord does right and is always fair. With the dawn of each day, God brings about justice.
Zephaniah 3:6 The Lord wiped out nations and left fortresses crumbling in the dirt. Their streets and towns were reduced to ruins and emptied of people.
Zephaniah 3:7 God felt certain that Jerusalem would learn to respect and obey him. Then he would hold back from punishing the city and not wipe it out. But everyone there was eager to start sinning again.
Zephaniah 3:8 The Lord said: Just wait for the day when I accuse you nations. I have decided on a day, when I will bring together every nation and kingdom and punish them all in my fiery anger. I will become furious and destroy the earth.
Zephaniah 3:9 I will purify each language and make those languages acceptable for praising me. Then, with hearts united, everyone will serve only me, the Lord.
Zephaniah 3:10 From across the rivers of Ethiopia, my scattered people, my true worshipers, will bring offerings to me.
Zephaniah 3:11 When that time comes, you won't rebel against me and be put to shame. I'll do away with those who are proud and arrogant. Never will any of them strut around on my holy mountain.
Zephaniah 3:12 But I, the Lord, won't destroy any of your people who are truly humble and turn to me for safety.
Zephaniah 3:13 The people of Israel who survive will live right and refuse to tell lies. They will eat and rest with nothing to fear.
Zephaniah 3:14 Everyone in Jerusalem and Judah, celebrate and shout with all your heart!
Zephaniah 3:15 Zion, your punishment is over. The Lord has forced your enemies to turn and retreat. Your Lord is King of Israel and stands at your side; you don't have to worry about any more troubles.
Zephaniah 3:16 Jerusalem, the time is coming, when it will be said to you: “Don't be discouraged or grow weak from fear!
Zephaniah 3:17 The Lord your God wins victory after victory and is always with you. He celebrates and sings because of you, and he will refresh your life with his love.”
Zephaniah 3:18 The Lord has promised: Your sorrow has ended, and you can celebrate.
Zephaniah 3:19 I will punish those who mistreat you. I will bring together the lame and the outcasts, then they will be praised, instead of despised, in every country on earth.
Zephaniah 3:20 I will lead you home, and with your own eyes you will see me bless you with all you once owned. Then you will be famous everywhere on this earth. I, the Lord, have spoken!
Haggai 1:1 On the first day of the sixth month of the second year that Darius was king of Persia, the Lord told Haggai the prophet to speak his message to the governor of Judah and to the high priest. So Haggai told Governor Zerubbabel and High Priest Joshua
Haggai 1:2+HAG that the Lord All-Powerful had said to them and to the people: You say this isn't the right time to build a temple for me. But is it right for you to live in expensive houses, while my temple is a pile of ruins? Just look at what's happening.
Haggai 1:6 You harvest less than you plant, you never have enough to eat or drink, your clothes don't keep you warm, and your wages are stored in bags full of holes.
Haggai 1:7 Think about what I have said!
Haggai 1:8 But first, go to the hills and get wood for my temple, so I can take pride in it and be worshiped there.
Haggai 1:9 You expected much, but received only a little. And when you brought it home, I made that little disappear. Why have I done this? It's because you hurry off to build your own houses, while my temple is still in ruins.
Haggai 1:10 That's also why the dew doesn't fall and your harvest fails.
Haggai 1:11 And so, at my command everything will become barren—your farmland and pastures, your vineyards and olive trees, your animals and you yourselves. All your hard work will be for nothing.
Haggai 1:12 Zerubbabel and Joshua, together with the others who had returned from exile in Babylonia, obeyed the Lord's message spoken by his prophet Haggai, and they started showing proper respect for the Lord.
Haggai 1:13 Haggai then told them that the Lord had promised to be with them.
Haggai 1:14 So the Lord God All-Powerful made everyone eager to work on his temple, especially Zerubbabel and Joshua.
Haggai 1:15 And the work began on the twenty-fourth day of that same month.
Haggai 2:1+HAG On the twenty-first day of the next month, the Lord told Haggai the prophet to speak this message to Governor Zerubbabel, High Priest Joshua, and everyone else:
Haggai 2:3 Does anyone remember how glorious this temple used to be? Now it looks like nothing.
Haggai 2:4 But cheer up! Because I, the Lord All-Powerful, will be here to help you with the work,
Haggai 2:5 just as I promised your ancestors when I brought them out of Egypt. Don't worry. My Spirit is right here with you.
Haggai 2:6 Soon I will again shake the heavens and the earth, the sea and the dry land.
Haggai 2:7 I will shake the nations, and their treasures will be brought here. Then the brightness of my glory will fill this temple.
Haggai 2:8 All silver and gold belong to me,
Haggai 2:9 and I promise that this new temple will be more glorious than the first one. I will also bless this city with peace.
Haggai 2:10 On the twenty-fourth day of the ninth month, the Lord God All-Powerful told the prophet Haggai
Haggai 2:11 to ask the priests for their opinion on the following matters:
Haggai 2:12 Suppose meat ready to be sacrificed to God is being carried in the folds of someone's clothing, and the clothing rubs against some bread or stew or wine or olive oil or any other food. Would those foods that were touched then become acceptable for sacrifice? “Of course not,” the priests answered.
Haggai 2:13 Then Haggai said, “Suppose someone has touched a dead body and is considered unacceptable to worship God. If that person touches these foods, would they become unclean?” “Of course they would,” the priests answered.
Haggai 2:14 So the Lord told Haggai to say: That's how it is with this entire nation. Everything you do and every sacrifice you offer is unacceptable to me.
Haggai 2:15 But from now on, things will get better. Before you started laying the foundation for the temple,
Haggai 2:16 you recalled what life was like in the past. When you wanted 200 kilograms of wheat, there were only 10, and when you wanted 50 jars of wine, there were only 20.
Haggai 2:17 I made all of your hard work useless by sending mildew, mold, and hail—but you still did not return to me, your Lord.
Haggai 2:18 Today you have completed the foundation for my temple, so listen to what your future will be like.
Haggai 2:19 Although you have not yet harvested any grain, grapes, figs, pomegranates, or olives, I will richly bless you in the days ahead.
Haggai 2:20 That same day the Lord spoke to Haggai again and said:
Haggai 2:21 Tell Governor Zerubbabel of Judah that I am going to shake the heavens and the earth
Haggai 2:22 and wipe out kings and their kingdoms. I will overturn war chariots, and then cavalry troops will start slaughtering each other.
Haggai 2:23 But tell my servant Zerubbabel that I, the Lord All-Powerful, have chosen him, and he will rule in my name.
Zechariah 1:1 I am the prophet Zechariah, the son of Berechiah and the grandson of Iddo. In the eighth month of the second year that Darius was king of Persia, the Lord told me to say:
Zechariah 1:2+ZEC Israel, I, the Lord All-Powerful, was very angry with your ancestors. But if you people will return to me, I will turn and help you.
Zechariah 1:4 Don't be stubborn like your ancestors. They were warned by the earlier prophets to give up their evil and turn back to me, but they paid no attention.
Zechariah 1:5 Where are your ancestors now? Not even prophets live forever.
Zechariah 1:6 But my warnings and my words spoken by the prophets caught up with your ancestors. So they turned back to me and said, “Lord All-Powerful, you have punished us for our sins, just as you had planned.”
Zechariah 1:7+ZEC On the twenty-fourth day of Shebat, which was the eleventh month of that same year, the Lord spoke to me in a vision during the night: In a valley among myrtle trees, I saw someone on a red horse, with riders on red, brown, and white horses behind him.
Zechariah 1:9 An angel was there to explain things to me, and I asked, “Sir, who are these riders?” “I'll tell you,” the angel answered.
Zechariah 1:10 At once, the man standing among the myrtle trees said, “These are the ones the Lord has sent to find out what's happening on earth.”
Zechariah 1:11 Then the riders spoke to the Lord's angel, who was standing among the myrtle trees, and they said, “We have gone everywhere and have discovered that the whole world is at peace.”
Zechariah 1:12 At this, the angel said, “Lord All-Powerful, for 70 years you have been angry with Jerusalem and the towns of Judah. When are you ever going to have mercy on them?”
Zechariah 1:13 The Lord's answer was kind and comforting.
Zechariah 1:14 So the angel told me to announce: I, the Lord All-Powerful, am very protective of Jerusalem.
Zechariah 1:15 For a while I was angry at the nations, but now I am furious, because they have made things worse for Jerusalem and are not the least bit concerned.
Zechariah 1:16 And so, I will have pity on Jerusalem. The city will be completely rebuilt, and my temple will stand again.
Zechariah 1:17 I also promise that my towns will prosper—Jerusalem will once again be my chosen city, and I will comfort the people of Zion.
Zechariah 1:18 Next, I saw four animal horns.
Zechariah 1:19+ZEC The angel who was sent to explain was there, and so I asked, “What do these mean?” His answer was, “These horns are the nations that scattered the people of Judah, Israel, and Jerusalem, and took away their freedom.” Then the Lord showed me four blacksmiths, and I asked, “What are they going to do?” He replied, “They are going to terrify and crush those horns.”
Zechariah 2:1 This time I saw someone holding a measuring line,
Zechariah 2:2 and I asked, “Where are you going?” “To measure Jerusalem,” was the answer. “To find out how wide and long it is.”
Zechariah 2:3 The angel who had spoken to me came toward me, when another angel came up to him
Zechariah 2:4 and said, “Hurry! Tell that man with the measuring line that Jerusalem won't have any boundaries. It will be too full of people and animals even to have a wall.
Zechariah 2:5 The Lord himself has promised to be a protective wall of fire surrounding Jerusalem, and he will be its shining glory in the heart of the city.”
Zechariah 2:6 The Lord says to his people, “Run! Escape from the land in the north, where I scattered you to the four winds.
Zechariah 2:7 Leave Babylonia and hurry back to Zion.”
Zechariah 2:8 Then the glorious Lord All-Powerful ordered me to say to the nations that had raided and robbed Zion: Zion is as precious to the Lord as are his eyes. Whatever you do to Zion, you do to him.
Zechariah 2:9 And so, he will put you in the power of your slaves, and they will raid and rob you. Then you will know that I am a prophet of the Lord All-Powerful.
Zechariah 2:10 City of Zion, sing and celebrate! The Lord has promised to come and live with you.
Zechariah 2:11 When he does, many nations will turn to him and become his people. At that time you will know that I am a prophet of the Lord All-Powerful.
Zechariah 2:12 Then Judah will be his part of the holy land, and Jerusalem will again be his chosen city.
Zechariah 2:13 Everyone, be silent! The Lord is present and moving about in his holy place.
Zechariah 3:1 I was given another vision. This time Joshua the high priest was standing in front of the Lord's angel. And there was Satan, standing at Joshua's right side, ready to accuse him.
Zechariah 3:2 But the Lord said, “Satan, you are wrong. Jerusalem is my chosen city, and this man was rescued like a stick from a flaming fire.”
Zechariah 3:3 Joshua's clothes were filthy.
Zechariah 3:4 So the angel told some of the people to remove Joshua's filthy clothes. Then he said to Joshua, “This means you are forgiven. Now I will dress you in priestly clothes.”
Zechariah 3:5 I spoke up and said, “Also put a clean priestly turban on his head.” Then they dressed him in priestly clothes and put the turban on him, while the Lord's angel stood there watching.
Zechariah 3:6 After this, the angel encouraged Joshua by telling him that the Lord All-Powerful had promised:
Zechariah 3:7 If you truly obey me, I will put you in charge of my temple, including the courtyard around it, and you will be allowed to speak at any time with the angels standing beside me.
Zechariah 3:8 Listen carefully, High Priest Joshua and all of you other priests. You are a sign of things to come, because I am going to bring my servant, the Chosen King.
Zechariah 3:9 Joshua, I have placed in front of you a stone with seven sides. I will engrave something on that stone, and in a single day I will forgive this guilty country.
Zechariah 3:10 Then each of you will live at peace and entertain your friends in your own vineyard and under your own fig trees.
Zechariah 4:1 The angel who explained the visions woke me from what seemed like sleep.
Zechariah 4:2 Then he asked, “What do you see?” “A solid gold lampstand with an oil container above it,” I answered. “On the stand are seven lamps, each with seven flames.
Zechariah 4:3 One olive tree is on the right side and another on the left of the oil container.
Zechariah 4:4 But, sir, what do these mean?”
Zechariah 4:5 Then he asked, “Don't you know?” “No sir,” I replied.
Zechariah 4:6 So the angel explained that it was the following message of the Lord to Zerubbabel: I am the Lord All-Powerful. So don't depend on your own power or strength, but on my Spirit.
Zechariah 4:7 Zerubbabel, that mountain in front of you will be leveled to the ground. Then you will bring out the temple's most important stone and shout, “God has been very kind.”
Zechariah 4:8 The Lord spoke to me again and said:
Zechariah 4:9 Zerubbabel laid the foundation for the temple, and he will complete it. Then everyone will know that you were sent by me, the Lord All-Powerful.
Zechariah 4:10 Those who have made fun of this day of small beginnings will celebrate when they see Zerubbabel holding this important stone. Those seven lamps represent my eyes—the eyes of the Lord—and they see everything on this earth.
Zechariah 4:11 Then I asked the angel, “What about the olive trees on each side of the lampstand? What do they represent?
Zechariah 4:12 And what is the meaning of the two branches from which golden olive oil flows through the two gold pipes?”
Zechariah 4:13 “Don't you know?” he asked. “No sir, I don't,” was my answer.
Zechariah 4:14 Then he told me, “These branches are the two chosen leaders who stand beside the Lord of all the earth.”
Zechariah 5:1 When I looked the next time, I saw a flying scroll,
Zechariah 5:2 and the angel asked, “What do you see?” “A flying scroll,” I answered. “About nine meters long and four and a half meters wide.”
Zechariah 5:3 Then he told me: This scroll puts a curse on everyone in the land who steals or tells lies. The writing on one side tells about the destruction of those who steal, while the writing on the other side tells about the destruction of those who lie.
Zechariah 5:4 The Lord All-Powerful has said, “I am sending this scroll into the house of everyone who is a robber or tells lies in my name, and it will remain there until every piece of wood and stone in that house crumbles.”
Zechariah 5:5 Now the angel who was there to explain the visions came over and said, “Look up and tell me what you see coming.”
Zechariah 5:6 “I don't know what it is,” was my reply. “It's a big basket,” he said. “And it shows what everyone in the land has in mind.”
Zechariah 5:7 The lead cover of the basket was opened, and in the basket was a woman.
Zechariah 5:8 “This woman represents evil,” the angel explained. Then he threw her back into the basket and slammed the heavy cover down tight.
Zechariah 5:9 Right after this I saw two women coming through the sky with wings outstretched like a stork in the wind. Suddenly they lifted the basket into the air,
Zechariah 5:10 and I asked the angel, “Where are they taking the basket?”
Zechariah 5:11 “To Babylonia,” he answered, “where they will build a house for the basket and set it down inside.”
Zechariah 6:1 Finally, I looked up and saw four chariots coming from between two bronze mountains.
Zechariah 6:2 The first chariot was pulled by red horses, and the second by black horses;
Zechariah 6:3 the third chariot was pulled by white horses, and the fourth by spotted gray horses.
Zechariah 6:4 “Sir,” I asked the angel. “What do these stand for?”
Zechariah 6:5 Then he explained, “These are the four winds of heaven, and now they are going out, after presenting themselves to the Lord of all the earth.
Zechariah 6:6 The chariot with black horses goes toward the north, the chariot with white horses goes toward the west, and the one with spotted horses goes toward the south.”
Zechariah 6:7 The horses came out eager to patrol the earth, and the angel told them, “Start patrolling the earth.” When they had gone on their way,
Zechariah 6:8 he shouted to me, “Those that have gone to the country in the north will do what the Lord's Spirit wants them to do there.”
Zechariah 6:9 The Lord said to me:
Zechariah 6:10+ZEC Heldai, Tobijah, and Jedaiah have returned from Babylonia. Collect enough silver and gold from them to make a crown. Then go with them to the house of Josiah son of Zephaniah and put the crown on the head of the high priest Joshua son of Jehozadak.
Zechariah 6:12+ZEC Tell him that I, the Lord All-Powerful, say, “Someone will reach out from here like a branch and build a temple for me. I will name him ‘Branch,’ and he will rule with royal honors. A priest will stand beside his throne, and the two of them will be good friends.
Zechariah 6:14 This crown will be kept in my temple as a reminder and will be taken care of by Heldai, Tobijah, Jedaiah, and Josiah.”
Zechariah 6:15 When people from distant lands come and help build the temple of the Lord All-Powerful, you will know that the Lord is the one who sent me. And this will happen, if you truly obey the Lord your God.
Zechariah 7:1 On the fourth day of Chislev, the ninth month of the fourth year that Darius was king of Persia, the Lord again spoke to me.
Zechariah 7:2+ZEC It happened after the people of Bethel had sent Sharezer with Regem-Melech and his men to ask the priests in the Lord's temple and the prophets to pray for them. So they prayed, “Should we mourn and go without eating during the fifth month, as we have done for many years?”
Zechariah 7:4+ZEC It was then that the Lord All-Powerful told me to say to everyone in the country, including the priests: For 70 years you have gone without eating during the fifth and seventh months of the year. But did you really do it for me?
Zechariah 7:6 And when you eat and drink, isn't it for your own enjoyment?
Zechariah 7:7 My message today is the same one I commanded the earlier prophets to speak to Jerusalem and its villages when they were prosperous, and when all of Judah, including the Southern Desert and the hill country, was filled with people.
Zechariah 7:8+ZEC So once again, I, the Lord All-Powerful, tell you, “See that justice is done and be kind and merciful to one another!
Zechariah 7:10 Don't mistreat widows or orphans or foreigners or anyone who is poor, and stop making plans to hurt each other.”
Zechariah 7:11+ZEC But everyone who heard those prophets, stubbornly refused to obey. Instead, they turned their backs on everything my Spirit had commanded the earlier prophets to preach. So I, the Lord, became angry
Zechariah 7:13 and said, “You people paid no attention when I called out to you, and now I'll pay no attention when you call out to me.”
Zechariah 7:14 That's why I came with a whirlwind and scattered them among foreign nations, leaving their lovely country empty of people and in ruins.
Zechariah 8:1 The Lord All-Powerful said to me:
Zechariah 8:2 I love Zion so much that her enemies make me angry.
Zechariah 8:3 I will return to Jerusalem and live there on Mount Zion. Then Jerusalem will be known as my faithful city, and Zion will be known as my holy mountain.
Zechariah 8:4 Very old people with walking sticks will once again sit around in Jerusalem,
Zechariah 8:5 while boys and girls play in the streets.
Zechariah 8:6 This may seem impossible for my people who are left, but it isn't impossible for me, the Lord All-Powerful.
Zechariah 8:7 I will save those who were taken to lands in the east and the west,
Zechariah 8:8 and I will bring them to live in Jerusalem. They will be my people, and I will be their God, faithful to bring about justice.
Zechariah 8:9 I am the Lord All-Powerful! So don't give up. Think about the message my prophets spoke when the foundation of my temple was laid.
Zechariah 8:10 Before that time, neither people nor animals were rewarded for their work, and no one was safe anywhere, because I had turned them against each other.
Zechariah 8:11 My people, only a few of you are left, and I promise not to punish you as I did before.
Zechariah 8:12 Instead, I will make sure that your crops are planted in peace and your vineyards are fruitful, that your fields are fertile, and the dew falls from the sky.
Zechariah 8:13 People of Judah and Israel, you have been a curse to the nations, but I will save you and make you a blessing to them. So don't be afraid or lose courage.
Zechariah 8:14 When your ancestors made me angry, I decided to punish you with disasters, and I didn't hold back.
Zechariah 8:15 Now you no longer need to be afraid. I have decided to treat Jerusalem and Judah with kindness.
Zechariah 8:16 But you must be truthful with each other, and in court you must give fair decisions that lead to peace.
Zechariah 8:17 Don't ever plan evil things against others or tell lies under oath. I, the Lord, hate such things.
Zechariah 8:18 The Lord All-Powerful told me to say:
Zechariah 8:19 People of Judah, I, the Lord, demand that whenever you go without food as a way of worshiping me, it should become a time of celebration. No matter if it's the fourth month, the fifth month, the seventh month, or the tenth month, you should have a joyful festival. So love truth and live at peace.
Zechariah 8:20 I tell you that people will come here from cities everywhere.
Zechariah 8:21 Those of one town will go to another and say, “We're going to ask the Lord All-Powerful to treat us with kindness. Come and join us.”
Zechariah 8:22 Many people from strong nations will come to Jerusalem to worship me and to ask me to treat them with kindness.
Zechariah 8:23 When this happens, ten people from nations with different languages will grab a Jew by his clothes and say, “Let us go with you. We've heard that God is on your side.” I, the Lord All-Powerful, have spoken!
Zechariah 9:1 This is a message from the Lord: His eyes are on everyone, especially the tribes of Israel. So he pronounces judgment against the cities of Hadrach and Damascus.
Zechariah 9:2 Judgment will also fall on the nearby city of Hamath, as well as on Tyre and Sidon, whose people are clever.
Zechariah 9:3 Tyre has built a fortress and piled up silver and gold, as though they were dust or mud from the streets.
Zechariah 9:4 Now the Lord will punish Tyre with poverty; he will sink its ships and send it up in flames.
Zechariah 9:5 Both Ashkelon and Gaza will tremble with fear; Ekron will lose all hope. Gaza's king will be killed, and Ashkelon emptied of its people.
Zechariah 9:6 A mob of half-breeds will settle in Ashdod, and the Lord himself will rob Philistia of pride.
Zechariah 9:7 No longer will the Philistines eat meat with blood in it or any unclean food. They will become part of the people of our God from the tribe of Judah. And God will accept the people of Ekron, as he did the Jebusites.
Zechariah 9:8 God says, “I will stand guard to protect my temple from those who come to attack. I know what's happening, and no one will mistreat my people ever again.”
Zechariah 9:9 Everyone in Jerusalem, celebrate and shout! Your king has won a victory, and he is coming to you. He is humble and rides on a donkey; he comes on the colt of a donkey.
Zechariah 9:10 I, the Lord, will take away war chariots and horses from Israel and Jerusalem. Bows that were made for battle will be broken. I will bring peace to nations, and your king will rule from sea to sea. His kingdom will reach from the Euphrates River across the earth.
Zechariah 9:11 When I made a sacred agreement with you, my people, we sealed it with blood. Now some of you are captives in waterless pits, but I will come to your rescue
Zechariah 9:12 and offer you hope. Return to your fortress, because today I will reward you with twice what you had.
Zechariah 9:13 I will use Judah as my bow and Israel as my arrow. I will take the people of Zion as my sword and attack the Greeks.
Zechariah 9:14 Like a cloud, the Lord God will appear over his people, and his arrows will flash like lightning. God will sound his trumpet and attack in a whirlwind from the south.
Zechariah 9:15 The Lord All-Powerful will protect his people, and they will trample down the sharpshooters and their slingshots. They will drink and get rowdy; they will be as full as a bowl at the time of sacrifice.
Zechariah 9:16 The Lord God will save them on that day, because they are his people, and they will shine on his land like jewels in a crown.
Zechariah 9:17 How lovely they will be. Young people will grow there like grain in a field or grapes in a vineyard.
Zechariah 10:1 I, the Lord, am the one who sends storm clouds and showers of rain to make fields produce. So when the crops need rain, you should pray to me.
Zechariah 10:2 You can't believe idols and fortunetellers, or depend on the hope you receive from witchcraft and interpreters of dreams. But you have tried all of these, and now you are like sheep without a shepherd.
Zechariah 10:3 I, the Lord All-Powerful, am fiercely angry with you leaders, and I will punish you. I care for my people, the nation of Judah, and I will change this flock of sheep into charging war horses.
Zechariah 10:4 From this flock will come leaders who will be strong like cornerstones and tent pegs and weapons of war.
Zechariah 10:5 They will join in the fighting, and together they will trample their enemies like mud. They will fight, because I, the Lord, will be on their side. And they will crush the enemy cavalry.
Zechariah 10:6 I will strengthen the kingdoms of Judah and Israel. And I will show mercy because I am the Lord, their God. I will answer their prayers and bring them home. Then it will seem as though I had never rejected them.
Zechariah 10:7 Israel will be like a tribe of warriors celebrating with wine. When their children see this, they will also be happy because of me, the Lord.
Zechariah 10:8 I will give a signal for them to come together because I have rescued them. And there will be as many as ever before.
Zechariah 10:9 Although I scattered my people in distant countries, they won't forget me. Once their children are raised, they will return—
Zechariah 10:10 I will bring them home from Egypt and Assyria, then let them settle as far as Gilead and Lebanon, until the land overflows with them.
Zechariah 10:11 My people will go through an ocean of troubles, but I will overcome the waves and dry up the deepest part of the Nile. Assyria's great pride will be put down, and the power of Egypt will disappear.
Zechariah 10:12 I'll strengthen my people because of who I am, and they will follow me. I, the Lord, have spoken!
Zechariah 11:1 Lebanon, open your gates! Let the fire come in to destroy your cedar trees.
Zechariah 11:2 Cry, you cypress trees! The glorious cedars have fallen and are rotting. Cry, you oak trees of Bashan! The dense forest has been chopped down.
Zechariah 11:3 Listen! Shepherds are crying. Their glorious pastures have been ruined. Listen! Lions are roaring. The forests of the Jordan Valley are no more to be found.
Zechariah 11:4 The Lord my God said to me: Tend those sheep doomed for slaughter!
Zechariah 11:5 The people who buy and butcher them go unpunished, while everyone who sells them says, “Praise the Lord! I'm rich.” Not even their shepherds have pity on them.
Zechariah 11:6 Tend those sheep because I, the Lord, will no longer have pity on the people of this earth. I'll turn neighbor against neighbor and make them slaves of a king. They will bring disaster on the earth, and I'll do nothing to rescue any of them.
Zechariah 11:7 So I became a shepherd of those sheep doomed to be slaughtered by the sheep dealers. And I gave names to the two sticks I used for tending the sheep: One of them was named “Mercy” and the other “Unity.”
Zechariah 11:8 In less than a month, I became impatient with three shepherds who didn't like me, and I got rid of them.
Zechariah 11:9 Then I said, “I refuse to be your shepherd. Let the sheep that are going to die, go on and die, and those that are going to be destroyed, go on and be destroyed. Then let the others eat one another alive.”
Zechariah 11:10 On that same day, I broke the stick named “Mercy” to show that the Lord had canceled his agreement with all people.
Zechariah 11:11 The sheep dealers who saw me knew at once that this was a message from the Lord.
Zechariah 11:12+ZEC I told them, “Pay me my wages, if you think you should; otherwise, forget it.” So they handed me my wages, a measly 30 pieces of silver. Then the Lord said, “Throw the money into the treasury.” So I threw the money into the treasury at the Lord's temple.
Zechariah 11:14 Then I broke the stick named “Unity” and canceled the ties between Judah and Israel.
Zechariah 11:15 Next, the Lord said to me, “Act like a shepherd again—this time a worthless shepherd.
Zechariah 11:16 Once more I am going to let a worthless nobody rule the land—one who won't care for the strays or search for the young or heal the sick or feed the healthy. He will just dine on the fattest sheep, leaving nothing but a few bones.”
Zechariah 11:17 You worthless shepherd, deserting the sheep! I hope a sword will cripple your arm and blind your right eye.
Zechariah 12:1 This is a message from the Lord about Israel: I am the Lord! I stretched out the heavens; I put the earth on its foundations and gave breath to humans.
