Zechariah 12:2 I have decided that Jerusalem will become a bowl of wine that makes the neighboring nations drunk. And when Jerusalem is attacked, Judah will also be attacked.
Zechariah 12:3 But I will turn Jerusalem into a heavy stone that crushes anyone who tries to lift it. When all nations on earth surround Jerusalem,
Zechariah 12:4 I will blind every horse and make them panic, and every rider will be confused. But at the same time, I will watch over Judah.
Zechariah 12:5 Then every clan in Judah will realize that I, the Lord All-Powerful, am their God, and that I am the source of their strength.
Zechariah 12:6 At that time I will let the clans of Judah be like a ball of fire in a wood pile or a fiery torch in a hay stack. Then Judah will send the surrounding nations up in smoke. And once again the city of Jerusalem will be filled with people.
Zechariah 12:7 But I will first give victory to Judah, so the kingdom of David and the city of Jerusalem in all of their glory won't be thought of more highly than Judah itself.
Zechariah 12:8 I, the Lord God, will protect Jerusalem. Even the weakest person there will be as strong as David, and David's kingdom will rule as though my very own angel were its leader.
Zechariah 12:9 I am determined to wipe out every nation that attacks Jerusalem.
Zechariah 12:10 I, the Lord, will make the descendants of David and the people of Jerusalem feel deep sorrow and pray when they see the one they pierced with a spear. They will mourn and weep for him, as parents weep over the death of their only child or their first-born.
Zechariah 12:11 On that day the people of Jerusalem will mourn as much as everyone did for Hadad Rimmon on the flatlands near Megiddo.
Zechariah 12:12 Everyone of each family in the land will mourn, and the men will mourn separately from the women. This includes those from the family of David, and the families of Nathan,
Zechariah 12:13 Levi, Shimei,
Zechariah 12:14 and all other families as well.
Zechariah 13:1 In the future there will be a fountain, where David's descendants and the people of Jerusalem can wash away their sin and guilt.
Zechariah 13:2 The Lord All-Powerful says: When that time comes, I will get rid of every idol in the country, and they will be forgotten forever. I will also do away with their prophets and those evil spirits that control them.
Zechariah 13:3 If any such prophets ever appear again, their own parents must warn them that they will die for telling lies in my name—the name of the Lord. If those prophets don't stop speaking, their parents must then kill them with a sword.
Zechariah 13:4 Those prophets will be ashamed of their so-called visions, and they won't deceive anyone by dressing like a true prophet.
Zechariah 13:5 Instead, they will say, “I'm no prophet. I've been a farmer all my life.”
Zechariah 13:6 And if any of them are asked why they are wounded, they will answer, “It happened at the house of some friends.”
Zechariah 13:7 The Lord All-Powerful said: My sword, wake up! Attack my shepherd and friend. Strike down the shepherd! Scatter the little sheep, and I will destroy them.
Zechariah 13:8 Nowhere in the land will more than a third of them be left alive.
Zechariah 13:9 Then I will purify them and put them to the test, just as gold and silver are purified and tested. They will pray in my name, and I will answer them. I will say, “You are my people,” and they will reply, “You, Lord, are our God!”
Zechariah 14:1 The Lord will have his day. And when it comes, everything that was ever taken from Jerusalem will be returned and divided among its people.
Zechariah 14:2 But first, he will bring many nations to attack Jerusalem—homes will be robbed, women raped, and half of the population dragged off, though the others will be allowed to remain.
Zechariah 14:3 The Lord will attack those nations like a warrior fighting in battle.
Zechariah 14:4 He will take his stand on the Mount of Olives east of Jerusalem, and the mountain will split in half, forming a wide valley that runs from east to west.
Zechariah 14:5 Then you people will escape from the Lord's mountain, through this valley, which reaches to Azal. You will run in all directions, just as everyone did when the earthquake struck in the time of King Uzziah of Judah. Afterwards, the Lord my God will appear with his holy angels.
Zechariah 14:6 It will be a bright day that won't turn cloudy or cold.
Zechariah 14:7 And the Lord has decided when it will happen—this time of unending day.
Zechariah 14:8 In both summer and winter, life-giving streams will flow from Jerusalem, half of them to the Dead Sea in the east and half to the Mediterranean Sea in the west.
Zechariah 14:9 Then there will be only one Lord who rules as King and whose name is worshiped everywhere on earth.
Zechariah 14:10+ZEC From Geba down to Rimmon south of Jerusalem, the entire country will be turned into flatlands, with Jerusalem still towering above. Then the city will be full of people, from Benjamin Gate, Old Gate Place, and Hananel Tower in the northeast part of the city over to Corner Gate in the northwest and down to King's Wine Press in the south. Jerusalem will always be secure and will never again be destroyed.
Zechariah 14:12 Here is what the Lord will do to those who attack Jerusalem: While they are standing there, he will make their flesh rot and their eyes fall from their sockets and their tongues drop out.
Zechariah 14:13 The Lord will make them go into a frenzy and start attacking each other,
Zechariah 14:14+ZEC until even the people of Judah turn against those in Jerusalem. This same terrible disaster will also strike every animal nearby, including horses, mules, camels, and donkeys. Finally, everything of value in the surrounding nations will be collected and brought to Jerusalem—gold, silver, and piles of clothing.
Zechariah 14:16 Afterwards, the survivors from those nations that attacked Jerusalem will go there each year to worship the King, the Lord All-Powerful, and to celebrate the Festival of Shelters.
Zechariah 14:17 No rain will fall on the land of anyone in any country who refuses to go to Jerusalem to worship the King, the Lord All-Powerful.
Zechariah 14:18+ZEC This horrible disaster will strike the Egyptians and everyone else who refuses to go there for the celebration.
Zechariah 14:20+ZEC At that time the words “Dedicated to the Lord” will be engraved on the bells worn by horses. In fact, every ordinary cooking pot in Jerusalem will be just as sacred to the Lord All-Powerful as the bowls used at the altar. Any one of them will be acceptable for boiling the meat of sacrificed animals, and there will no longer be a need to sell special pots and bowls.
Malachi 1:1 I am Malachi. And this is the message that the Lord gave me for Israel.
Malachi 1:2 Israel, I, the Lord, have loved you. And yet you ask in what way have I loved you. Don't forget that Esau was the brother of your ancestor Jacob, but I chose Jacob
Malachi 1:3 instead of Esau. And I turned Esau's hill country into a barren desert where jackals roam.
Malachi 1:4 Esau's descendants may say, “Although our nation Edom is in ruins, we will rebuild it.” But I, the Lord All-Powerful, promise to tear down whatever they build. Then everyone will know that I will never stop being angry with them as long as they are so sinful.
Malachi 1:5 Israel, when you see this, you will shout, “The Lord's great reputation reaches beyond our borders.”
Malachi 1:6 I, the Lord All-Powerful, have something to say to you priests. Children respect their fathers, and servants respect their masters. I am your father and your master, so why don't you respect me? You priests have insulted me, and now you ask, “How did we insult you?”
Malachi 1:7 You embarrass me by offering worthless food on my altar. Then you ask, “How have we embarrassed you?” You have done it by saying, “What's so great about the Lord's altar?”
Malachi 1:8 But isn't it wrong to offer animals that are blind, lame, or sick? Just try giving those animals to your governor. That certainly wouldn't please him or make him want to help you.
Malachi 1:9 I am the Lord God All-Powerful, and you had better try to please me. You have sinned. Now see if I will have mercy on any of you.
Malachi 1:10 I wish someone would lock the doors of my temple, so you would stop wasting time building fires on my altar. I am not pleased with you priests, and I refuse to accept any more of your offerings.
Malachi 1:11 From dawn until dusk my name is praised by every nation on this earth, as they burn incense and offer the proper sacrifices to me.
Malachi 1:12 But even you priests insult me by saying, “There's nothing special about the Lord's altar, and these sacrifices are worthless.”
Malachi 1:13 You get so disgusted that you even make vulgar signs at me. And for an offering, you bring stolen animals or those that are lame or sick. Should I accept these?
Malachi 1:14 Instead of offering the acceptable animals you have promised, you bring me those that are unhealthy. I will punish you for this, because I am the great King, the Lord All-Powerful, and I am worshiped by nations everywhere.
Malachi 2:1 I, the Lord All-Powerful, have something else to say to you priests.
Malachi 2:2 You had better take seriously the need to honor my name. Otherwise, when you give a blessing, I will turn it into a curse. In fact, I have already done this, because you haven't taken to heart your duties as priests.
Malachi 2:3 I will punish your descendants and rub your faces in the manure from your animal sacrifices, and then be done with you.
Malachi 2:4 I am telling you this, so I can continue to keep my agreement with your ancestor Levi.
Malachi 2:5 I blessed him with a full life, as I had promised, and he kept his part of the agreement by honoring me and respecting my name.
Malachi 2:6 He taught the truth and never told lies, and he led a lot of people to turn from sin, because he obeyed me and lived right.
Malachi 2:7 You priests should be eager to spread knowledge, and everyone should come to you for instruction, because you speak for me, the Lord All-Powerful.
Malachi 2:8 But you have turned your backs on me. Your teachings have led others to do sinful things, and you have broken the agreement I made with your ancestor Levi.
Malachi 2:9 So I caused everyone to hate and despise you, because you disobeyed me and failed to treat all people alike.
Malachi 2:10 Don't you know that we all have God as our Father? Didn't the one God create each of us? Then why do you cheat each other by breaking the agreement God made with your ancestors?
Malachi 2:11 You people in Judah and Jerusalem have been unfaithful to the Lord. You have disgraced the temple that he loves, and you have committed the disgusting sin of marrying the worshipers of other gods.
Malachi 2:12 I pray that the Lord will no longer let those who are guilty belong to his people, even if they eagerly decide to offer the Lord a gift.
Malachi 2:13 And what else are you doing? You cry noisily and flood the Lord's altar with your tears, because he isn't pleased with your offerings and refuses to accept them.
Malachi 2:14 And why isn't God pleased? It's because he knows that each of you men has been unfaithful to the wife you married when you were young. You promised that she would be your partner, but now you have broken that promise.
Malachi 2:15 Didn't God create you and your wife to become like one person? And why did he do this? It was so you would have children, and then lead them to become God's people. Don't ever be unfaithful to your wife.
Malachi 2:16 The Lord God All-Powerful of Israel hates anyone who is cruel enough to divorce his wife. So take care never to be unfaithful!
Malachi 2:17 You have worn out the Lord with your words. And yet, you ask, “How did we do that?” You did it by saying, “The Lord is pleased with evil and doesn't care about justice.”
Malachi 3:1 I, the Lord All-Powerful, will send my messenger to prepare the way for me. Then suddenly the Lord you are looking for will appear in his temple. The messenger you desire is coming with my promise, and he is on his way.
Malachi 3:2 On the day the Lord comes, he will be like a furnace that purifies silver or like strong soap in a washbasin. No one will be able to stand up to him.
Malachi 3:3 The Lord will purify the descendants of Levi, as though they were gold or silver. Then they will bring the proper offerings to the Lord,
Malachi 3:4 and the offerings of the people of Judah and Jerusalem will please him, just as they did in the past.
Malachi 3:5 The Lord All-Powerful said: I'm now on my way to judge you. And I will quickly condemn all who practice witchcraft or cheat in marriage or tell lies in court or rob workers of their pay or mistreat widows and orphans or steal the property of foreigners or refuse to respect me.
Malachi 3:6 Descendants of Jacob, I am the Lord All-Powerful, and I never change. That's why you haven't been wiped out,
Malachi 3:7 even though you have ignored and disobeyed my laws ever since the time of your ancestors. But if you return to me, I will return to you. And yet you ask, “How can we return?”
Malachi 3:8 You people are robbing me, your God. And, here you are, asking, “How are we robbing you?” You are robbing me of the offerings and of the ten percent that belongs to me.
Malachi 3:9 That's why your whole nation is under a curse.
Malachi 3:10 I am the Lord All-Powerful, and I challenge you to put me to the test. Bring the entire ten percent into the storehouse, so there will be food in my house. Then I will open the windows of heaven and flood you with blessing after blessing.
Malachi 3:11 I will also stop locusts from destroying your crops and keeping your vineyards from producing.
Malachi 3:12 Everyone of every nation will talk about how I have blessed you and about your wonderful land. I, the Lord All-Powerful, have spoken!
Malachi 3:13 You have said horrible things about me, and yet you ask, “What have we said?”
Malachi 3:14 Here is what you have said: “It's foolish to serve the Lord God All-Powerful. What do we get for obeying God and from going around looking sad?
Malachi 3:15 See how happy those arrogant people are. Everyone who does wrong is successful, and when they put God to the test, they always get away with it.”
Malachi 3:16 All those who truly respected the Lord and honored his name started discussing these things, and when God saw what was happening, he had their names written as a reminder in his book.
Malachi 3:17 Then the Lord All-Powerful said: You people are precious to me, and when I come to bring justice, I will protect you, just as parents protect an obedient child.
Malachi 3:18 Then everyone will once again see the difference between those who obey me by doing right and those who reject me by doing wrong.
Malachi 4:1 The day of judgment is certain to come. And it will be like a red-hot furnace with flames that burn up proud and sinful people, as though they were straw. Not a branch or a root will be left. I, the Lord All-Powerful, have spoken!
Malachi 4:2 But for you that honor my name, victory will shine like the sun with healing in its rays, and you will jump around like calves at play.
Malachi 4:3 When I come to bring justice, you will trample those who are evil, as though they were ashes under your feet. I, the Lord All-Powerful, have spoken!
Malachi 4:4 Don't ever forget the laws and teachings I gave my servant Moses on Mount Sinai.
Malachi 4:5 I, the Lord, promise to send the prophet Elijah before that great and terrible day comes.
Malachi 4:6 He will lead children and parents to love each other more, so that when I come, I won't bring destruction to the land.
Matthew 1:1 Jesus Christ came from the family of King David and also from the family of Abraham. And this is a list of his ancestors.
Matthew 1:2+MAT From Abraham to King David, his ancestors were: Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Judah and his brothers (Judah's sons were Perez and Zerah, and their mother was Tamar), Hezron; Ram, Amminadab, Nahshon, Salmon, Boaz (his mother was Rahab), Obed (his mother was Ruth), Jesse, and King David.
Matthew 1:6+MAT From David to the time of the exile in Babylonia, the ancestors of Jesus were: David, Solomon (his mother had been Uriah's wife), Rehoboam, Abijah, Asa, Jehoshaphat, Jehoram; Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, Hezekiah, Manasseh, Amon, Josiah, and Jehoiachin and his brothers.
Matthew 1:12+MAT From the exile to the birth of Jesus, his ancestors were: Jehoiachin, Shealtiel, Zerubbabel, Abiud, Eliakim, Azor, Zadok, Achim; Eliud, Eleazar, Matthan, Jacob, and Joseph, the husband of Mary, the mother of Jesus, who is called the Messiah.
Matthew 1:17 There were 14 generations from Abraham to David. There were also 14 from David to the exile in Babylonia and 14 more to the birth of the Messiah.
Matthew 1:18 This is how Jesus Christ was born. A young woman named Mary was engaged to Joseph from King David's family. But before they were married, she learned that she was going to have a baby by God's Holy Spirit.
Matthew 1:19 Joseph was a good man and did not want to embarrass Mary in front of everyone. So he decided to quietly call off the wedding.
Matthew 1:20 While Joseph was thinking about this, an angel from the Lord appeared to him in a dream. The angel said, “Joseph, the baby that Mary will have is from the Holy Spirit. Go ahead and marry her.
Matthew 1:21 Then after her baby is born, name him Jesus, because he will save his people from their sins.”
Matthew 1:22 So the Lord's promise came true, just as the prophet had said,
Matthew 1:23 “A virgin will have a baby boy, and he will be called Immanuel,” which means “God is with us.”
Matthew 1:24 After Joseph woke up, he and Mary were soon married, just as the Lord's angel had told him to do.
Matthew 1:25 But they did not sleep together before her baby was born. Then Joseph named him Jesus.
Matthew 2:1 When Jesus was born in the village of Bethlehem in Judea, Herod was king. During this time some wise men from the east came to Jerusalem
Matthew 2:2 and said, “Where is the child born to be king of the Jews? We saw his star in the east and have come to worship him.”
Matthew 2:3 When King Herod heard about this, he was worried, and so was everyone else in Jerusalem.
Matthew 2:4 Herod brought together the chief priests and the teachers of the Law of Moses and asked them, “Where will the Messiah be born?”
Matthew 2:5 They told him, “He will be born in Bethlehem, just as the prophet wrote,
Matthew 2:6 ‘Bethlehem in the land of Judea, you are very important among the towns of Judea. From your town will come a leader, who will be like a shepherd for my people Israel.’ ”
Matthew 2:7 Herod secretly called in the wise men and asked them when they had first seen the star.
Matthew 2:8 He told them, “Go to Bethlehem and search carefully for the child. As soon as you find him, let me know. I also want to go and worship him.”
Matthew 2:9 The wise men listened to what the king said and then left. And the star they had seen in the east went on ahead of them until it stopped over the place where the child was.
Matthew 2:10 They were thrilled and excited to see the star.
Matthew 2:11 When the men went into the house and saw the child with Mary, his mother, they knelt down and worshiped him. They took out their gifts of gold, frankincense, and myrrh and gave them to him.
Matthew 2:12 Later they were warned in a dream not to return to Herod, and they went back home by another road.
Matthew 2:13 After the wise men had gone, an angel from the Lord appeared to Joseph in a dream and said, “Get up! Hurry and take the child and his mother to Egypt! Stay there until I tell you to return, because Herod is looking for the child and wants to kill him.”
Matthew 2:14 That night, Joseph got up and took his wife and the child to Egypt,
Matthew 2:15 where they stayed until Herod died. So the Lord's promise came true, just as the prophet had said, “I called my son out of Egypt.”
Matthew 2:16 When Herod found out that the wise men from the east had tricked him, he was very angry. He gave orders for his men to kill all the boys who lived in or near Bethlehem and were two years old and younger. This was based on what he had learned from the wise men.
Matthew 2:17 So the Lord's promise came true, just as the prophet Jeremiah had said,
Matthew 2:18 “In Ramah a voice was heard crying and weeping loudly. Rachel was mourning for her children, and she refused to be comforted, because they were dead.”
Matthew 2:19 After King Herod died, an angel from the Lord appeared in a dream to Joseph while he was still in Egypt.
Matthew 2:20 The angel said, “Get up and take the child and his mother back to Israel. The people who wanted to kill him are now dead.”
Matthew 2:21 Joseph got up and left with them for Israel.
Matthew 2:22 But when he heard that Herod's son Archelaus was now ruler of Judea, he was afraid to go there. Then in a dream he was told to go to Galilee,
Matthew 2:23 and they went to live there in the town of Nazareth. So the Lord's promise came true, just as the prophet had said, “He will be called a Nazarene.”
Matthew 3:1 Years later, John the Baptist started preaching in the desert of Judea.
Matthew 3:2 He said, “Turn back to God! The kingdom of heaven will soon be here.”
Matthew 3:3 John was the one the prophet Isaiah was talking about, when he said, “In the desert someone is shouting, ‘Get the road ready for the Lord! Make a straight path for him.’ ”
Matthew 3:4 John wore clothes made of camel's hair. He had a leather strap around his waist and ate grasshoppers and wild honey.
Matthew 3:5 From Jerusalem and all Judea and from the Jordan River Valley crowds of people went to John.
Matthew 3:6 They told how sorry they were for their sins, and he baptized them in the river.
Matthew 3:7 Many Pharisees and Sadducees also came to be baptized. But John said to them: You bunch of snakes! Who warned you to run from the coming judgment?
Matthew 3:8 Do something to show you have really given up your sins.
Matthew 3:9 And don't start telling yourselves that you belong to Abraham's family. I tell you that God can turn these stones into children for Abraham.
Matthew 3:10 An ax is ready to cut the trees down at their roots. Any tree that doesn't produce good fruit will be chopped down and thrown into a fire.
Matthew 3:11 I baptize you with water so you will give up your sins. But someone more powerful is going to come, and I am not good enough even to carry his sandals. He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and with fire.
Matthew 3:12 His threshing fork is in his hand, and he is ready to separate the wheat from the husks. He will store the wheat in a barn and burn the husks in a fire that never goes out.
Matthew 3:13 Jesus left Galilee and went to the Jordan River to be baptized by John.
Matthew 3:14 But John kept objecting and said, “I ought to be baptized by you. Why have you come to me?”
Matthew 3:15 Jesus answered, “For now this is how it should be, because we must do all God wants us to do.” Then John agreed.
Matthew 3:16 So Jesus was baptized. And as soon as he came out of the water, the sky opened, and he saw the Spirit of God coming down on him like a dove.
Matthew 3:17 Then a voice from heaven said, “This is my own dear Son, and I am pleased with him.”
Matthew 4:1 The Holy Spirit led Jesus into the desert, so that the devil could test him.
Matthew 4:2 After Jesus had gone without eating for 40 days and nights, he was very hungry.
Matthew 4:3 Then the devil came to him and said, “If you are God's Son, tell these stones to turn into bread.”
Matthew 4:4 Jesus answered, “The Scriptures say: ‘No one can live only on food. People need every word that God has spoken.’ ”
Matthew 4:5 Next, the devil took Jesus into the holy city to the highest part of the temple.
Matthew 4:6 The devil said, “If you are God's Son, jump off. The Scriptures say: ‘God will give his angels orders about you. They will catch you in their arms, and you won't hurt your feet on the stones.’ ”
Matthew 4:7 Jesus answered, “The Scriptures also say, ‘Don't try to test the Lord your God!’ ”
Matthew 4:8 Finally, the devil took Jesus up on a very high mountain and showed him all the kingdoms on earth and their power.
Matthew 4:9 The devil said to him, “I will give all this to you, if you will bow down and worship me.”
Matthew 4:10 Jesus answered, “Go away Satan! The Scriptures say: ‘Worship the Lord your God and serve only him.’ ”
Matthew 4:11 Then the devil left Jesus, and angels came to help him.
Matthew 4:12 When Jesus heard that John had been put in prison, he went to Galilee.
Matthew 4:13 But instead of staying in Nazareth, Jesus moved to Capernaum. This town was beside Lake Galilee in the territory of Zebulun and Naphtali.
Matthew 4:14 So God's promise came true, just as the prophet Isaiah had said,
Matthew 4:15 “Listen, lands of Zebulun and Naphtali, lands along the road to the sea and across the Jordan. Listen Galilee, land of the Gentiles!
Matthew 4:16 Although your people live in darkness, they will see a bright light. Although they live in the shadow of death, a light will shine on them.”
Matthew 4:17 Then Jesus started preaching, “Turn back to God! The kingdom of heaven will soon be here.”
Matthew 4:18 While Jesus was walking along the shore of Lake Galilee, he saw two brothers. One was Simon, also known as Peter, and the other was Andrew. They were fishermen, and they were casting their net into the lake.
Matthew 4:19 Jesus said to them, “Follow me! I will teach you how to bring in people instead of fish.”
Matthew 4:20 Right then the two brothers dropped their nets and went with him.
Matthew 4:21 Jesus walked on until he saw James and John, the sons of Zebedee. They were in a boat with their father, mending their nets. Jesus asked them to come with him.
Matthew 4:22 At once they left the boat and their father and went with Jesus.
Matthew 4:23 Jesus went all over Galilee, teaching in their synagogues and preaching the good news about God's kingdom. He also healed every kind of disease and sickness.
Matthew 4:24 News about him spread all over Syria, and people with every kind of sickness or disease were brought to him. Some of them had a lot of demons in them, others were thought to be crazy, and still others could not walk. But Jesus healed them all.
Matthew 4:25 Large crowds followed Jesus from Galilee and the region around the ten cities known as Decapolis. They also came from Jerusalem, Judea, and from across the Jordan River.
Matthew 5:1 When Jesus saw the crowds, he went up on the side of a mountain and sat down. Jesus' disciples gathered around him,
Matthew 5:2 and he taught them:
Matthew 5:3 God blesses those people who depend only on him. They belong to the kingdom of heaven!
Matthew 5:4 God blesses those people who grieve. They will find comfort!
Matthew 5:5 God blesses those people who are humble. The earth will belong to them!
Matthew 5:6 God blesses those people who want to obey him more than to eat or drink. They will be given what they want!
Matthew 5:7 God blesses those people who are merciful. They will be treated with mercy!
Matthew 5:8 God blesses those people whose hearts are pure. They will see him!
Matthew 5:9 God blesses those people who make peace. They will be called his children!
Matthew 5:10 God blesses those people who are treated badly for doing right. They belong to the kingdom of heaven.
Matthew 5:11 God will bless you when people insult you, mistreat you, and tell all kinds of evil lies about you because of me.
Matthew 5:12 Be happy and excited! You will have a great reward in heaven. People did these same things to the prophets who lived long ago.
Matthew 5:13 You are the salt for everyone on earth. But if salt no longer tastes like salt, how can it make food salty? All it is good for is to be thrown out and walked on.
Matthew 5:14 You are the light for the whole world. A city built on top of a hill cannot be hidden,
Matthew 5:15 and no one lights a lamp and puts it under a clay pot. Instead, it is placed on a lampstand, where it can give light to everyone in the house.
Matthew 5:16 Make your light shine, so others will see the good you do and will praise your Father in heaven.
Matthew 5:17 Don't suppose I came to do away with the Law and the Prophets. I did not come to do away with them, but to give them their full meaning.
Matthew 5:18 Heaven and earth may disappear. But I promise you not even a period or comma will ever disappear from the Law. Everything written in it must happen.
Matthew 5:19 If you reject even the least important command in the Law and teach others to do the same, you will be the least important person in the kingdom of heaven. But if you obey and teach others its commands, you will have an important place in the kingdom.
Matthew 5:20 You must obey God's commands better than the Pharisees and the teachers of the Law obey them. If you don't, I promise you will never get into the kingdom of heaven.
Matthew 5:21 You know our ancestors were told, “Do not murder” and “A murderer must be brought to trial.”
Matthew 5:22 But I promise you if you are angry with someone, you will have to stand trial. If you call someone a fool, you will be taken to court. And if you say that someone is worthless, you will be in danger of the fires of hell.
Matthew 5:23 So if you are about to place your gift on the altar and remember that someone is angry with you,
Matthew 5:24 leave your gift there in front of the altar. Make peace with that person, then come back and offer your gift to God.
Matthew 5:25 Before you are dragged into court, make friends with the person who has accused you of doing wrong. If you don't, you will be handed over to the judge and then to the officer who will put you in jail.
Matthew 5:26 I promise you will not get out until you have paid the last cent you owe.
Matthew 5:27 You know the commandment which says, “Be faithful in marriage.”
Matthew 5:28 But I tell you if you look at another woman and want her, you are already unfaithful in your thoughts.
Matthew 5:29 If your right eye causes you to sin, poke it out and throw it away. It is better to lose one part of your body, than for your whole body to end up in hell.
Matthew 5:30 If your right hand causes you to sin, chop it off and throw it away! It is better to lose one part of your body, than for your whole body to be thrown into hell.
Matthew 5:31 You have been taught that a man who divorces his wife must write out divorce papers for her.
Matthew 5:32 But I tell you not to divorce your wife unless she has committed some terrible sexual sin. If you divorce her, you will cause her to be unfaithful, just as any man who marries her is guilty of taking another man's wife.
Matthew 5:33 You know our ancestors were told, “Don't use the Lord's name to make a promise unless you are going to keep it.”
Matthew 5:34 But I tell you not to swear by anything when you make a promise! Heaven is God's throne, so don't swear by heaven.
Matthew 5:35 The earth is God's footstool, so don't swear by the earth. Jerusalem is the city of the great king, so don't swear by it.
Matthew 5:36 Don't swear by your own head. You cannot make one hair white or black.
Matthew 5:37 When you make a promise, say only “Yes” or “No.” Anything else comes from the devil.
Matthew 5:38 You know you have been taught, “An eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth.”
Matthew 5:39 But I tell you not to try to get even with a person who has done something to you. When someone slaps your right cheek, turn and let that person slap your other cheek.
Matthew 5:40 If someone sues you for your shirt, give up your coat as well.
Matthew 5:41 If a soldier forces you to carry his pack one kilometer, carry it two kilometers.
Matthew 5:42 When people ask you for something, give it to them. When they want to borrow money, lend it to them.
Matthew 5:43 You have heard people say, “Love your neighbors and hate your enemies.”
Matthew 5:44 But I tell you to love your enemies and pray for anyone who mistreats you.
Matthew 5:45 Then you will be acting like your Father in heaven. He makes the sun rise on both good and bad people. And he sends rain for the ones who do right and for the ones who do wrong.
Matthew 5:46 If you love only those people who love you, will God reward you for this? Even tax collectors love their friends.
Matthew 5:47 If you greet only your friends, what's so great about this? Don't even unbelievers do that?
Matthew 5:48 But you must always act like your Father in heaven.
Matthew 6:1 When you do good deeds, don't try to show off. If you do, you won't get a reward from your Father in heaven.
Matthew 6:2 When you give to the poor, don't blow a loud horn. That's what show-offs do in the synagogues and on the street corners, because they are always looking for praise. I can assure you that they already have their reward.
Matthew 6:3 When you give to the poor, don't let anyone know about it.
Matthew 6:4 Then your gift will be given in secret. Your Father knows what is done in secret and will reward you.
Matthew 6:5 When you pray, don't be like those show-offs who love to stand up and pray in the synagogues and on the street corners. They do this just to look good. I can assure you that they already have their reward.
Matthew 6:6 When you pray, go into a room alone and close the door. Pray to your Father in private. He knows what is done in private and will reward you.
Matthew 6:7 When you pray, don't talk on and on as people do who don't know God. They think God likes to hear long prayers.
Matthew 6:8 Don't be like them. Your Father knows what you need even before you ask.
Matthew 6:9 You should pray like this: Our Father in heaven, help us to honor your name.
Matthew 6:10 Come and set up your kingdom, so that everyone on earth will obey you, as you are obeyed in heaven.
Matthew 6:11 Give us our food for today.
Matthew 6:12 Forgive us for doing wrong, as we forgive others.
Matthew 6:13 Keep us from being tempted and protect us from evil.
Matthew 6:14 If you forgive others for the wrongs they do to you, your Father in heaven will forgive you.
Matthew 6:15 But if you don't forgive others, your Father will not forgive your sins.
Matthew 6:16 When you go without eating, don't try to look gloomy as those show-offs do when they go without eating. I can assure you that they already have their reward.
Matthew 6:17 Instead, comb your hair and wash your face.
Matthew 6:18 Then others won't know you are going without eating. But your Father sees what is done in private, and he will reward you.
Matthew 6:19 Don't store up treasures on earth! Moths and rust can destroy them, and thieves can break in and steal them.
Matthew 6:20 Instead, store up your treasures in heaven, where moths and rust cannot destroy them, and thieves cannot break in and steal them.
Matthew 6:21 Your heart will always be where your treasure is.
Matthew 6:22 Your eyes are a window for your body. When they are good, you have all the light you need.
Matthew 6:23 But when your eyes are bad, everything is dark. If the light inside you is dark, you surely are in the dark.
Matthew 6:24 You cannot be the slave of two masters! You will like one more than the other or be more loyal to one than the other. You cannot serve both God and money.
Matthew 6:25 I tell you not to worry about your life. Don't worry about having something to eat, drink, or wear. Isn't life more than food or clothing?
Matthew 6:26 Look at the birds in the sky! They don't plant or harvest. They don't even store grain in barns. Yet your Father in heaven takes care of them. Aren't you worth much more than birds?
Matthew 6:27 Can worry make you live longer?
Matthew 6:28 Why worry about clothes? Look how the wild flowers grow. They don't work hard to make their clothes.
Matthew 6:29 But I tell you that Solomon with all his wealth wasn't as well clothed as one of them.
Matthew 6:30 God gives such beauty to everything that grows in the fields, even though it is here today and thrown into a fire tomorrow. God will surely do even more for you! Why do you have such little faith?
Matthew 6:31 Don't worry and ask yourselves, “Will we have anything to eat? Will we have anything to drink? Will we have any clothes to wear?”
Matthew 6:32 Only people who don't know God are always worrying about such things. Your Father in heaven knows you need all of these.
Matthew 6:33 But more than anything else, put God's work first and do what he wants. Then the other things will be yours as well.
Matthew 6:34 Don't worry about tomorrow. It will take care of itself. You have enough to worry about today.
Matthew 7:1 Don't condemn others, and God won't condemn you.
Matthew 7:2 God will be as hard on you as you are on others! He will treat you exactly as you treat them.
Matthew 7:3 You can see the speck in your friend's eye, but you don't notice the log in your own eye.
Matthew 7:4 How can you say, “My friend, let me take the speck out of your eye,” when you don't see the log in your own eye?
Matthew 7:5 You're nothing but show-offs! First, take the log out of your own eye; then you can see how to take the speck out of your friend's eye.
Matthew 7:6 Don't give to dogs what belongs to God. They will only turn and attack you. Don't throw pearls down in front of pigs. They will trample all over them.
Matthew 7:7 Ask, and you will receive. Search, and you will find. Knock, and the door will be opened for you.
Matthew 7:8 Everyone who asks will receive. Everyone who searches will find. And the door will be opened for everyone who knocks.
Matthew 7:9 Would any of you give your hungry child a stone, if the child asked for some bread?
Matthew 7:10 Would you give your child a snake if the child asked for a fish?
Matthew 7:11 As bad as you are, you still know how to give good gifts to your children. But your heavenly Father is even more ready to give good things to people who ask.
Matthew 7:12 Treat others as you want them to treat you. This is what the Law and the Prophets are all about.
Matthew 7:13 Go in through the narrow gate. The gate to destruction is wide, and the road that leads there is easy to follow. A lot of people go through that gate.
Matthew 7:14 But the gate to life is very narrow. The road that leads there is so hard to follow that only a few people find it.
Matthew 7:15 Watch out for false prophets! They dress up like sheep, but inside they are wolves who have come to attack you.
Matthew 7:16 You can tell what they are by what they do. No one picks grapes or figs from thornbushes.
Matthew 7:17 A good tree produces good fruit, and a bad tree produces bad fruit.
Matthew 7:18 A good tree cannot produce bad fruit, and a bad tree cannot produce good fruit.
Matthew 7:19 Every tree producing bad fruit will be chopped down and burned.
Matthew 7:20 You can tell who the false prophets are by their deeds.
Matthew 7:21 Not everyone who calls me their Lord will get into the kingdom of heaven. Only the ones who obey my Father in heaven will get in.
Matthew 7:22 On the day of judgment many will call me their Lord. They will say, “We preached in your name, and in your name we forced out demons and worked many miracles.”
Matthew 7:23 But I will tell them, “I will have nothing to do with you! Get out of my sight, you evil people!”
Matthew 7:24 Anyone who hears and obeys these teachings of mine is like a wise person who built a house on solid rock.
Matthew 7:25 Rain poured down, rivers flooded, and winds beat against that house. But it was built on solid rock, and so it did not fall.
Matthew 7:26 Anyone who hears my teachings and doesn't obey them is like a foolish person who built a house on sand.
Matthew 7:27 Rain poured down, rivers flooded, and the winds blew and beat against that house. Finally, it fell with a crash.
Matthew 7:28 When Jesus finished speaking, the crowds were surprised at his teaching.
Matthew 7:29 He taught them like someone with authority, and not like their teachers of the Law of Moses.
Matthew 8:1 As Jesus came down the mountain, he was followed by large crowds.
Matthew 8:2 Suddenly a man with leprosy came and knelt in front of Jesus. He said, “Lord, you have the power to make me well, if only you wanted to.”
Matthew 8:3 Jesus put his hand on the man and said, “I want to! Now you are well.” At once the man's leprosy disappeared.
Matthew 8:4 Jesus told him, “Don't tell anyone about this, but go and show the priest that you are well. Then take a gift to the temple just as Moses commanded, and everyone will know that you have been healed.”
Matthew 8:5 When Jesus was going into the town of Capernaum, an army officer came up to him and said,
Matthew 8:6 “Lord, my servant is at home in such terrible pain that he can't even move.”
Matthew 8:7 “I will go and heal him,” Jesus replied.
Matthew 8:8 But the officer said, “Lord, I'm not good enough for you to come into my house. Just give the order, and my servant will get well.
Matthew 8:9 I have officers who give orders to me, and I have soldiers who take orders from me. I can say to one of them, ‘Go!’ and he goes. I can say to another, ‘Come!’ and he comes. I can say to my servant, ‘Do this!’ and he will do it.”
Matthew 8:10 When Jesus heard this, he was so surprised that he turned and said to the crowd following him, “I tell you in all of Israel I've never found anyone with this much faith!
Matthew 8:11 Many people will come from everywhere to enjoy the feast in the kingdom of heaven with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
Matthew 8:12 But the ones who should have been in the kingdom will be thrown out into the dark. They will cry and grit their teeth in pain.”
Matthew 8:13 Then Jesus said to the officer, “You may go home now. Your faith has made it happen.” Right then his servant was healed.
Matthew 8:14 Jesus went to the home of Peter, where he found that Peter's mother-in-law was sick in bed with fever.
Matthew 8:15 He took her by the hand, and the fever left her. Then she got up and served Jesus a meal.
Matthew 8:16 That evening many people with demons in them were brought to Jesus. And with only a word he forced out the evil spirits and healed everyone who was sick.
Matthew 8:17 So God's promise came true, just as the prophet Isaiah had said, “He healed our diseases and made us well.”
Matthew 8:18 When Jesus saw the crowd, he went across Lake Galilee.
Matthew 8:19 A teacher of the Law of Moses came up to him and said, “Teacher, I'll go anywhere with you!”
Matthew 8:20 Jesus replied, “Foxes have dens, and birds have nests. But the Son of Man doesn't have a place to call his own.”
Matthew 8:21 Another disciple said to Jesus, “Lord, let me wait till I bury my father.”
Matthew 8:22 Jesus answered, “Follow me, and let the dead bury their dead.”
Matthew 8:23 After Jesus left in a boat with his disciples,
Matthew 8:24 a terrible storm suddenly struck the lake, and waves started splashing into their boat. Jesus was sound asleep,
Matthew 8:25 so the disciples went over to him and woke him up. They said, “Lord, wake up! Save us before we drown!”
Matthew 8:26 But Jesus replied, “Why are you so afraid? You surely don't have much faith.” Then he got up and ordered the wind and the waves to calm down. And everything was calm.
Matthew 8:27 The men in the boat were amazed and said, “Who is this? Even the wind and the waves obey him.”
Matthew 8:28 After Jesus had crossed the lake, he came to shore near the town of Gadara and started down the road. Two men with demons in them came to him from the tombs. They were so fierce that no one could travel that way.
Matthew 8:29 Suddenly they shouted, “Jesus, Son of God, what do you want with us? Have you come to punish us before our time?”
Matthew 8:30 Not far from there a large herd of pigs was feeding.
Matthew 8:31 So the demons begged Jesus, “If you force us out, please send us into those pigs!”
Matthew 8:32 Jesus told them to go, and they went out of the men and into the pigs. All at once the pigs rushed down the steep bank into the lake and drowned.
Matthew 8:33 The people taking care of the pigs ran to the town and told everything, especially what had happened to the two men.
Matthew 8:34 Everyone in town came out to meet Jesus. When they saw him, they begged him to leave their part of the country.
Matthew 9:1 Jesus got into a boat and crossed back over to the town where he lived.
Matthew 9:2 Some people soon brought to him a man lying on a mat because he could not walk. When Jesus saw how much faith they had, he said to the man, “My friend, don't worry! Your sins are forgiven.”
Matthew 9:3 Some teachers of the Law of Moses said to themselves, “Jesus must think he is God!”
Matthew 9:4 But Jesus knew what was in their minds, and he said, “Why are you thinking such evil things?
Matthew 9:5 Is it easier for me to tell this man his sins are forgiven or to tell him to get up and walk?
Matthew 9:6 But I will show you that the Son of Man has the right to forgive sins here on earth.” So Jesus said to the man, “Get up! Pick up your mat and go on home.”
Matthew 9:7 The man got up and went home.
Matthew 9:8 When the crowds saw this, they were afraid and praised God for giving such authority to people.
Matthew 9:9 As Jesus was leaving, he saw a tax collector named Matthew sitting at the place for paying taxes. Jesus said to him, “Follow me.” Matthew got up and went with him.
Matthew 9:10 Later, Jesus and his disciples were having dinner at Matthew's house. Many tax collectors and other sinners were also there.
Matthew 9:11 Some Pharisees asked Jesus' disciples, “Why does your teacher eat with tax collectors and other sinners?”
Matthew 9:12 Jesus heard them and answered, “Healthy people don't need a doctor, but sick people do.
Matthew 9:13 Go and learn what the Scriptures mean when they say, ‘Instead of offering sacrifices to me, I want you to be merciful to others.’ I didn't come to invite good people to be my followers. I came to invite sinners.”
Matthew 9:14 Some followers of John the Baptist came and asked Jesus, “Why do we and the Pharisees often go without eating, while your disciples never do?”
Matthew 9:15 Jesus answered: The friends of a bridegroom aren't sad while he is still with them. But the time will come when he will be taken from them. Then they will go without eating.
Matthew 9:16 No one uses a new piece of cloth to patch old clothes. The patch would shrink and tear a bigger hole.
Matthew 9:17 No one pours new wine into old wineskins. The wine would swell and burst the old skins. Then the wine would be lost, and the skins would be ruined. New wine must be put into new wineskins. Both the skins and the wine will then be safe.
Matthew 9:18 While Jesus was still speaking, an official came and knelt in front of him. The man said, “My daughter has just now died! Please come and place your hand on her. Then she will live again.”
Matthew 9:19 Jesus and his disciples got up and went with the man.
Matthew 9:20 A woman who had been bleeding for twelve years came up behind Jesus and barely touched his clothes.
Matthew 9:21 She had said to herself, “If I can just touch his clothes, I will be healed.”
Matthew 9:22 Jesus turned. He saw the woman and said, “Don't worry! You are now healed because of your faith.” At that moment she was healed.
Matthew 9:23 When Jesus went into the home of the official and saw the musicians and the crowd of mourners,
Matthew 9:24 he said, “Get out of here! The little girl isn't dead. She is just asleep.” Everyone started laughing at Jesus.
Matthew 9:25 But after the crowd had been sent out of the house, Jesus went to the girl's bedside. He took her by the hand and helped her up.
Matthew 9:26 News about this spread all over that part of the country.
Matthew 9:27 As Jesus was leaving that place, two blind men began following him and shouting, “Son of David, have pity on us!”
Matthew 9:28 After Jesus had gone indoors, the two blind men came up to him. He asked them, “Do you believe I can make you well?” “Yes, Lord,” they answered.
Matthew 9:29 Jesus touched their eyes and said, “Because of your faith, you will be healed.”
Matthew 9:30 They were able to see, and Jesus strictly warned them not to tell anyone about him.
Matthew 9:31 But they left and talked about him to everyone in that part of the country.
Matthew 9:32 As Jesus and his disciples were on their way, some people brought to him a man who could not talk because a demon was in him.
Matthew 9:33 After Jesus had forced the demon out, the man started talking. The crowds were so amazed they began saying, “Nothing like this has ever happened in Israel!”
Matthew 9:34 But the Pharisees said, “The leader of the demons gives him the power to force out demons.”
Matthew 9:35 Jesus went to every town and village. He taught in their synagogues and preached the good news about God's kingdom. Jesus also healed every kind of disease and sickness.
Matthew 9:36 When he saw the crowds, he felt sorry for them. They were confused and helpless, like sheep without a shepherd.
Matthew 9:37 He said to his disciples, “A large crop is in the fields, but there are only a few workers.
Matthew 9:38 Ask the Lord in charge of the harvest to send out workers to bring it in.”
Matthew 10:1 Jesus called together his twelve disciples. He gave them the power to force out evil spirits and to heal every kind of disease and sickness.
Matthew 10:2 The first of the twelve apostles was Simon, better known as Peter. His brother Andrew was an apostle, and so were James and John, the two sons of Zebedee.
Matthew 10:3 Philip, Bartholomew, Thomas, Matthew the tax collector, James the son of Alphaeus, and Thaddaeus were also apostles.
Matthew 10:4 The others were Simon, known as the Eager One, and Judas Iscariot, who later betrayed Jesus.
Matthew 10:5 Jesus sent out the twelve apostles with these instructions: Stay away from the Gentiles and don't go to any Samaritan town.
Matthew 10:6 Go only to the people of Israel, because they are like a flock of lost sheep.
Matthew 10:7 As you go, announce that the kingdom of heaven will soon be here.
Matthew 10:8 Heal the sick, raise the dead to life, heal people who have leprosy, and force out demons. You received without paying, now give without being paid.
Matthew 10:9 Don't take along any gold, silver, or copper coins.
Matthew 10:10 And don't carry a traveling bag or an extra shirt or sandals or a walking stick. Workers deserve their food.
Matthew 10:11 So when you go to a town or a village, find someone able and willing to have you as their guest and stay with them until you leave.
Matthew 10:12 When you go to a home, give it your blessing of peace.
Matthew 10:13 If the home is deserving, let your blessing remain with them. But if the home doesn't accept you, take back your blessing of peace.
Matthew 10:14 If someone won't welcome you or listen to your message, leave their home or town. And shake the dust from your feet at them.
Matthew 10:15 I promise you the day of judgment will be easier for the towns of Sodom and Gomorrah than for that town.
Matthew 10:16 I am sending you like lambs into a pack of wolves. So be as wise as snakes and as innocent as doves.
Matthew 10:17 Watch out for people who will take you to court and have you beaten in their synagogues.
Matthew 10:18 Because of me, you will be dragged before rulers and kings to tell them and the Gentiles about your faith.
Matthew 10:19 But when someone arrests you, don't worry about what you will say or how you will say it. At that time you will be given the words to say.
Matthew 10:20 But you will not really be the one speaking. The Spirit from your Father will tell you what to say.
Matthew 10:21 Brothers and sisters will betray one another and have each other put to death. Parents will betray their own children, and children will turn against their parents and have them killed.
Matthew 10:22 Everyone will hate you because of me. But if you remain faithful until the end, you will be saved.
Matthew 10:23 When people mistreat you in one town, hurry to another one. I promise you before you have gone to all the towns of Israel, the Son of Man will come.
Matthew 10:24 Students are not better than their teacher, and slaves are not better than their master.
Matthew 10:25 It is enough for students to be like their teacher and for slaves to be like their master. If people call the head of the family Satan, what will they say about the rest of the family?
Matthew 10:26 Don't be afraid of anyone! Everything that is hidden will be found out, and every secret will be known.
Matthew 10:27 Whatever I say to you in the dark, you must tell in the light. And you must announce from the housetops whatever I have whispered to you.
Matthew 10:28 Don't be afraid of people. They can kill you, but they cannot harm your soul. Instead, you should fear God who can destroy both your body and your soul in hell.
Matthew 10:29 Aren't two sparrows sold for only a penny? But your Father knows when any one of them falls to the ground.
Matthew 10:30 Even the hairs on your head are counted.
Matthew 10:31 So don't be afraid! You are worth much more than many sparrows.
Matthew 10:32 If you tell others you belong to me, I will tell my Father in heaven you are my followers.
Matthew 10:33 But if you reject me, I will tell my Father in heaven you don't belong to me.
Matthew 10:34 Don't think I came to bring peace to the earth! I came to bring trouble, not peace.
Matthew 10:35 I came to turn sons against their fathers, daughters against their mothers, and daughters-in-law against their mothers-in-law.
Matthew 10:36 Your worst enemies will be in your own family.
Matthew 10:37 If you love your father or mother or even your sons and daughters more than me, you are not fit to be my disciples.
Matthew 10:38 And unless you are willing to take up your cross and follow me, you are not fit to be my disciples.
Matthew 10:39 If you try to save your life, you will lose it. But if you give it up for me, you will surely find it.
Matthew 10:40 Anyone who welcomes you welcomes me. And anyone who welcomes me also welcomes the one who sent me.
Matthew 10:41 Anyone who welcomes a prophet, just because that person is a prophet, will be given the same reward as a prophet. Anyone who welcomes a good person, just because that person is good, will be given the same reward as a good person.
Matthew 10:42 And anyone who gives one of my most humble followers a cup of cool water, just because that person is my follower, will be rewarded.
Matthew 11:1 After Jesus had finished instructing his twelve disciples, he left and began teaching and preaching in the towns.
Matthew 11:2 John was in prison when he heard what Christ was doing. So John sent some of his followers
Matthew 11:3 to ask Jesus, “Are you the one we should be looking for? Or must we wait for someone else?”
Matthew 11:4 Jesus answered, “Go and tell John what you have heard and seen.
Matthew 11:5 The blind are now able to see, and the lame can walk. People with leprosy are being healed, and the deaf can hear. The dead are raised to life, and the poor are hearing the good news.
Matthew 11:6 God will bless everyone who doesn't reject me because of what I do.”
Matthew 11:7 As John's followers were going away, Jesus spoke to the crowds about John: What sort of person did you go out into the desert to see? Was he like tall grass blown about by the wind?
Matthew 11:8 What kind of man did you go out to see? Was he someone dressed in fine clothes? People who dress like that live in the king's palace.
Matthew 11:9 What did you really go out to see? Was he a prophet? He certainly was. I tell you that he was more than a prophet.
Matthew 11:10 In the Scriptures God says about him, “I am sending my messenger ahead to get things ready for you.”
Matthew 11:11 I tell you no one ever born on this earth is greater than John the Baptist. But whoever is least in the kingdom of heaven is greater than John.
Matthew 11:12 From the time of John the Baptist until now, violent people have been trying to take over the kingdom of heaven by force.
Matthew 11:13 All the Books of the Prophets and the Law of Moses told what was going to happen up to the time of John.
Matthew 11:14 And if you believe them, John is Elijah, the prophet you are waiting for.
Matthew 11:15 If you have ears, pay attention!
Matthew 11:16 You people are like children sitting in the market and shouting to each other,
Matthew 11:17 “We played the flute, but you would not dance! We sang a funeral song, but you would not mourn!”
Matthew 11:18 John the Baptist did not go around eating and drinking, and you said, “That man has a demon in him!”
Matthew 11:19 But the Son of Man goes around eating and drinking, and you say, “That man eats and drinks too much! He is even a friend of tax collectors and sinners.” Yet Wisdom is shown to be right by what it does.
Matthew 11:20 In the towns where Jesus had worked most of his miracles, the people refused to turn to God. So Jesus was upset with them and said:
Matthew 11:21 You people of Chorazin are in for trouble! You people of Bethsaida are in for trouble too! If the miracles that took place here had happened in Tyre and Sidon, the people there would have turned to God long ago. They would have dressed in sackcloth and put ashes on their heads.
Matthew 11:22 I tell you on the day of judgment the people of Tyre and Sidon will get off easier than you will.
Matthew 11:23 People of Capernaum, do you think you will be honored in heaven? You will go down to hell! If the miracles that took place in your town had happened in Sodom, it would still be standing.
Matthew 11:24 So I tell you on the day of judgment the people of Sodom will get off easier than you.
Matthew 11:25 At that moment Jesus said: My Father, Lord of heaven and earth, I am grateful that you hid all this from wise and educated people and showed it to ordinary people.
Matthew 11:26 Yes, Father, this is what pleased you.
Matthew 11:27 My Father has given me everything, and he is the only one who knows the Son. The only one who truly knows the Father is the Son. But the Son wants to tell others about the Father, so they can know him too.
Matthew 11:28 If you are tired from carrying heavy burdens, come to me and I will give you rest.
Matthew 11:29 Take the yoke I give you. Put it on your shoulders and learn from me. I am gentle and humble, and you will find rest.
Matthew 11:30 This yoke is easy to bear, and this burden is light.
Matthew 12:1 One Sabbath, Jesus and his disciples were walking through some wheat fields. His disciples were hungry and began picking and eating grains of wheat.
Matthew 12:2 Some Pharisees noticed this and said to Jesus, “Why are your disciples picking grain on the Sabbath? They are not supposed to do this!”
Matthew 12:3 Jesus answered: You surely must have read what David did when he and his followers were hungry.
Matthew 12:4 He went into the house of God, and then they ate the sacred loaves of bread that only priests are supposed to eat.
Matthew 12:5 Haven't you read in the Law of Moses that the priests are allowed to work in the temple on the Sabbath? But no one says they are guilty of breaking the law of the Sabbath.
Matthew 12:6 I tell you there is something here greater than the temple.
Matthew 12:7 Don't you know what the Scriptures mean when they say, “Instead of offering sacrifices to me, I want you to be merciful to others?” If you knew what this means, you would not condemn these innocent disciples of mine.
Matthew 12:8 So the Son of Man is Lord over the Sabbath.
Matthew 12:9 Jesus left and went into one of their synagogues,
Matthew 12:10 where there was a man whose hand was paralyzed. Some Pharisees wanted to accuse Jesus of doing something wrong, so they asked him, “Is it right to heal someone on the Sabbath?”
Matthew 12:11 Jesus answered, “If one of your sheep fell into a ditch on the Sabbath, wouldn't you lift it out?
Matthew 12:12 People are worth much more than sheep, and so it is right to do good on the Sabbath.”
Matthew 12:13 Then Jesus told the man, “Hold out your hand.” The man did, and it became as healthy as the other one.
Matthew 12:14 The Pharisees left and started making plans to kill Jesus.
Matthew 12:15 When Jesus found out what was happening, he left there and large crowds followed him. He healed all of their sick,
Matthew 12:16 but warned them not to tell anyone about him.
Matthew 12:17 So God's promise came true, just as Isaiah the prophet had said,
Matthew 12:18 “Here is my chosen servant! I love him, and he pleases me. I will give him my Spirit, and he will bring justice to the nations.
Matthew 12:19 He won't shout or yell or call out in the streets.
Matthew 12:20 He won't break off a bent reed or put out a dying flame, but he will make sure that justice is done.
Matthew 12:21 All nations will place their hope in him.”
Matthew 12:22 Some people brought to Jesus a man who was blind and could not talk because he had a demon in him. Jesus healed the man, and then he was able to talk and see.
Matthew 12:23 The crowds were so amazed they asked, “Could Jesus be the Son of David?”
Matthew 12:24 When the Pharisees heard this, they said, “He forces out demons by the power of Beelzebul, the ruler of the demons!”
Matthew 12:25 Jesus knew what they were thinking, so he said to them: Any kingdom where people fight each other will end up ruined. And a town or family that fights will soon destroy itself.
Matthew 12:26 So if Satan fights against himself, how can his kingdom last?
Matthew 12:27 If I use the power of Beelzebul to force out demons, whose power do your own followers use to force them out? Your followers are the ones who will judge you.
Matthew 12:28 But when I force out demons by the power of God's Spirit, it proves that God's kingdom has already come to you.
Matthew 12:29 How can anyone break into a strong man's house and steal his things, unless he first ties up the strong man? Then he can take everything.
Matthew 12:30 If you are not on my side, you are against me. If you don't gather in the harvest with me, you scatter it.
Matthew 12:31+MAT I tell you any sinful thing you do or say can be forgiven. Even if you speak against the Son of Man, you can be forgiven. But if you speak against the Holy Spirit, you can never be forgiven, either in this life or in the life to come.
Matthew 12:33 A good tree produces good fruit, and a bad tree produces bad fruit. You can tell what a tree is like by the fruit it produces.
Matthew 12:34 You are a bunch of evil snakes, so how can you say anything good? Your words show what is in your hearts.
Matthew 12:35 Good people bring good things out of their hearts, but evil people bring evil things out of their hearts.
Matthew 12:36 I promise you on the day of judgment, everyone will have to account for every careless word they have spoken.
Matthew 12:37 On that day they will be told they are either innocent or guilty because of the things they have said.
Matthew 12:38 Some Pharisees and teachers of the Law of Moses said, “Teacher, we want you to show us a sign from heaven.”
Matthew 12:39 But Jesus replied: You want a sign because you are evil and won't believe! But the only sign you will get is the sign of the prophet Jonah.
Matthew 12:40 He was in the stomach of a big fish for three days and nights, just as the Son of Man will be deep in the earth for three days and nights.
Matthew 12:41 On the day of judgment the people of Nineveh will stand there with you and condemn you. They turned to God when Jonah preached, and yet here is something far greater than Jonah.
Matthew 12:42 The Queen of the South will also stand there with you and condemn you. She traveled a long way to hear Solomon's wisdom, and yet here is something much greater than Solomon.
Matthew 12:43 When an evil spirit leaves a person, it travels through the desert, looking for a place to rest. But when the demon doesn't find a place,
Matthew 12:44 it says, “I will go back to the home I left.” When it gets there and finds the place empty, clean, and neat,
Matthew 12:45 it goes off and finds seven other evil spirits even worse than itself. They all come and make their home there, and the person ends up in worse shape than before. That's how it will be with you evil people of today.
Matthew 12:46 While Jesus was still speaking to the crowds, his mother and brothers came and stood outside because they wanted to talk with him.
Matthew 12:47 Someone told Jesus, “Your mother and brothers are standing outside and want to talk with you.”
Matthew 12:48 Jesus answered, “Who is my mother and who are my brothers?”
Matthew 12:49 Then he pointed to his disciples and said, “These are my mother and my brothers!
Matthew 12:50 Anyone who obeys my Father in heaven is my brother or sister or mother.”
Matthew 13:1 That same day Jesus left the house and went out beside Lake Galilee, where he sat down to teach.
Matthew 13:2 Such large crowds gathered around him that he had to sit in a boat, while the people stood on the shore.
Matthew 13:3 Then he taught them many things by using stories. He said: A farmer went out to scatter seed in a field.
Matthew 13:4 While the farmer was scattering the seed, some of it fell along the road and was eaten by birds.
Matthew 13:5 Other seeds fell on thin, rocky ground and quickly started growing because the soil wasn't very deep.
Matthew 13:6 But when the sun came up, the plants were scorched and dried up, because they did not have deep roots.
Matthew 13:7 Some other seeds fell where thornbushes grew up and choked the plants.
Matthew 13:8 But a few seeds did fall on good ground where the plants produced 100 or 60 or 30 times as much as was scattered.
Matthew 13:9 If you have ears, pay attention!
Matthew 13:10 Jesus' disciples came to him and asked, “Why do you use stories to speak to the people?”
Matthew 13:11 Jesus answered: I have explained the secrets about the kingdom of heaven to you, but not to others.
Matthew 13:12 Everyone who has something will be given more. But people who don't have anything will lose even what little they have.
Matthew 13:13 I use stories when I speak to them because when they look, they cannot see, and when they listen, they cannot hear or understand.
Matthew 13:14 So God's promise came true, just as the prophet Isaiah had said, “These people will listen and listen, but never understand. They will look and look, but never see.
Matthew 13:15 All of them have stubborn minds! They refuse to listen; they cover their eyes. They cannot see or hear or understand. If they could, they would turn to me, and I would heal them.”
Matthew 13:16 But God has blessed you, because your eyes can see and your ears can hear!
Matthew 13:17 Many prophets and good people were eager to see what you see and to hear what you hear. But I tell you they did not see or hear.
Matthew 13:18 Now listen to the meaning of the story about the farmer:
Matthew 13:19 The seeds that fell along the road are the people who hear the message about the kingdom, but don't understand it. Then the evil one comes and snatches the message from their hearts.
Matthew 13:20 The seeds that fell on rocky ground are the people who gladly hear the message and accept it at once.
Matthew 13:21 But they don't have deep roots, and they don't last very long. As soon as life gets hard or the message gets them in trouble, they give up.
Matthew 13:22 The seeds that fell among the thornbushes are also people who hear the message. But they start worrying about the needs of this life and are fooled by the desire to get rich. So the message gets choked out, and they never produce anything.
Matthew 13:23 The seeds that fell on good ground are the people who hear and understand the message. They produce as much as 100 or 60 or 30 times what was planted.
Matthew 13:24 Jesus then told them this story: The kingdom of heaven is like what happened when a farmer scattered good seed in a field.
Matthew 13:25 But while everyone was sleeping, an enemy came and scattered weed seeds in the field and then left.
Matthew 13:26 When the plants came up and began to mature, the farmer's servants could see the weeds.
Matthew 13:27 The servants came and asked, “Sir, didn't you scatter good seed in your field? Where did these weeds come from?”
Matthew 13:28 “An enemy did this,” he replied. His servants then asked, “Do you want us to go out and pull up the weeds?”
Matthew 13:29 “No!” he answered. “You might also pull up the wheat.
Matthew 13:30 Leave the weeds alone until harvest time. Then I'll tell my workers to gather the weeds and tie them up and burn them. But I'll order them to store the wheat in my barn.”
Matthew 13:31 Jesus told them another story: The kingdom of heaven is like what happens when a farmer plants a mustard seed in a field.
Matthew 13:32 Although it is the smallest of all seeds, it grows larger than any garden plant and becomes a tree. Birds even come and nest on its branches.
Matthew 13:33 Jesus also said: The kingdom of heaven is like what happens when a woman mixes a little yeast into three big batches of flour. Finally, all the dough rises.
Matthew 13:34 Jesus used stories when he spoke to the people. In fact, he did not tell them anything without using stories.
Matthew 13:35 So God's promise came true, just as the prophet had said, “I will use stories to speak my message and to explain things hidden since the creation of the world.”
Matthew 13:36 After Jesus left the crowd and went inside, his disciples came to him and said, “Explain to us the story about the weeds in the wheat field.”
Matthew 13:37 Jesus answered: The one who scattered the good seed is the Son of Man.
Matthew 13:38 The field is the world, and the good seeds are the people who belong to the kingdom. The weeds are those who belong to the evil one,
Matthew 13:39 and the one who scattered them is the devil. The harvest is the end of time, and angels are the ones who bring in the harvest.
Matthew 13:40 Weeds are gathered and burned. That's how it will be at the end of time.
Matthew 13:41 The Son of Man will send out his angels, and they will gather from his kingdom everyone who does wrong or causes others to sin.
Matthew 13:42 Then he will throw them into a flaming furnace, where people will cry and grit their teeth in pain.
Matthew 13:43 But everyone who has done right will shine like the sun in their Father's kingdom. If you have ears, pay attention!
Matthew 13:44 The kingdom of heaven is like what happens when someone finds a treasure hidden in a field and buries it again. Such a person is happy and goes and sells everything in order to buy that field.
Matthew 13:45 The kingdom of heaven is like what happens when a shop owner is looking for fine pearls.
Matthew 13:46 After finding a very valuable one, the owner goes and sells everything in order to buy that pearl.
Matthew 13:47 The kingdom of heaven is like what happens when a net is thrown into a lake and catches all kinds of fish.
Matthew 13:48 When the net is full, it is dragged to the shore, and the fishermen sit down to separate the fish. They keep the good ones, but throw the bad ones away.
Matthew 13:49 That's how it will be at the end of time. Angels will come and separate the evil people from the ones who have done right.
Matthew 13:50 Then those evil people will be thrown into a flaming furnace, where they will cry and grit their teeth in pain.
Matthew 13:51 Jesus asked his disciples if they understood all these things. They said, “Yes, we do.”
Matthew 13:52 So he told them, “Every student of the Scriptures who becomes a disciple in the kingdom of heaven is like someone who brings out new and old treasures from the storeroom.”
Matthew 13:53 When Jesus had finished telling these stories, he left
Matthew 13:54 and went to his hometown. He taught in their synagogue, and the people were so amazed that they asked, “Where does he get all this wisdom and the power to work these miracles?
Matthew 13:55 Isn't he the son of the carpenter? Isn't Mary his mother, and aren't James, Joseph, Simon, and Judas his brothers?
Matthew 13:56 Don't his sisters still live here in our town? How can he do all this?”
Matthew 13:57 So the people were upset because of what he was doing. But Jesus said, “Prophets are honored by everyone, except the people of their hometown and their own family.”
Matthew 13:58 And because the people did not have any faith, Jesus did not work many miracles there.
Matthew 14:1 About this time Herod the ruler heard the news about Jesus
Matthew 14:2 and told his officials, “This is John the Baptist! He has come back from death, and that's why he has the power to work these miracles.”
Matthew 14:3+MAT Herod had earlier arrested John and had him chained and put in prison. He did this because John had told him, “It isn't right for you to take Herodias, the wife of your brother Philip.”
Matthew 14:5 Herod wanted to kill John. But the people thought John was a prophet, and Herod was afraid of what they might do.
Matthew 14:6 When Herod's birthday came, the daughter of Herodias danced for the guests. She pleased Herod
Matthew 14:7 so much he swore to give her whatever she wanted.
Matthew 14:8 But the girl's mother told her to say, “Here on a serving plate I want the head of John the Baptist!”
Matthew 14:9 Herod was sorry for what he had said. But he did not want to break the promise he had made in front of his guests. So he ordered a guard
Matthew 14:10 to go to the prison and cut off John's head.
Matthew 14:11 It was taken on a serving plate to the girl, and she gave it to her mother.
Matthew 14:12 John's followers took his body and buried it. Then they told Jesus what had happened.
Matthew 14:13 After Jesus heard about John, he crossed Lake Galilee to go to some place where he could be alone. But the crowds found out and followed him on foot from the towns.
Matthew 14:14 When Jesus got out of the boat, he saw the large crowd. He felt sorry for them and healed everyone who was sick.
Matthew 14:15 That evening the disciples came to Jesus and said, “This place is like a desert, and it's already late. Let the crowds leave, so they can go to the villages and buy some food.”
Matthew 14:16 Jesus replied, “They don't have to leave. Why don't you give them something to eat?”
Matthew 14:17 But they said, “We have only five small loaves of bread and two fish.”
Matthew 14:18 Jesus asked his disciples to bring the food to him,
Matthew 14:19 and he told the crowd to sit down on the grass. Jesus took the five loaves and the two fish. He looked up toward heaven and blessed the food. Then he broke the bread and handed it to his disciples, and they gave it to the people.
Matthew 14:20 After everyone had eaten all they wanted, Jesus' disciples picked up twelve large baskets of leftovers.
Matthew 14:21 There were about 5,000 men who ate, not counting the women and children.
Matthew 14:22 At once, Jesus made his disciples get into a boat and start back across the lake. But he stayed until he had sent the crowds away.
Matthew 14:23 Then he went up on a mountain where he could be alone and pray. Later in the evening, he was still there.
Matthew 14:24 By this time the boat was a long way from the shore. It was going against the wind and was being tossed around by the waves.
Matthew 14:25 A little while before morning, Jesus came walking on the water toward his disciples.
Matthew 14:26 When they saw him, they thought he was a ghost. They were terrified and started screaming.
Matthew 14:27 At once, Jesus said to them, “Don't worry! I am Jesus. Don't be afraid.”
Matthew 14:28 Peter replied, “Lord, if it really is you, tell me to come to you on the water.”
Matthew 14:29 “Come on!” Jesus said. Peter then got out of the boat and started walking on the water toward him.
Matthew 14:30 But when Peter saw how strong the wind was, he was afraid and started sinking. “Save me, Lord!” he shouted.
Matthew 14:31 At once, Jesus reached out his hand. He helped Peter up and said, “You surely don't have much faith. Why do you doubt?”
Matthew 14:32 When Jesus and Peter got into the boat, the wind died down.
Matthew 14:33 The men in the boat worshiped Jesus and said, “You really are the Son of God!”
Matthew 14:34 Jesus and his disciples crossed the lake and came to shore near the town of Gennesaret.
Matthew 14:35 The people found out he was there, and they sent word to everyone who lived in this part of the country. So they brought all the sick people to Jesus.
Matthew 14:36 They begged him just to let them touch his clothes, and everyone who did was healed.
Matthew 15:1 About this time some Pharisees and teachers of the Law of Moses came from Jerusalem. They asked Jesus,
Matthew 15:2 “Why don't your disciples obey what our ancestors taught us to do? They don't even wash their hands before they eat.”
Matthew 15:3 Jesus answered: Why do you disobey God and follow your own teaching?
Matthew 15:4 Didn't God command you to respect your father and mother? Didn't he tell you to put to death all who curse their parents?
Matthew 15:5 But you let people get by without helping their parents when they should. You let them say that what they have has been offered to God.
Matthew 15:6 Is this any way to show respect to your parents? You ignore God's commands in order to follow your own teaching.
Matthew 15:7 And you are nothing but show-offs! Isaiah the prophet was right when he wrote that God had said,
Matthew 15:8 “All of you praise me with your words, but you never really think about me.
Matthew 15:9 It is useless for you to worship me, when you teach rules made up by humans.”
Matthew 15:10 Jesus called the crowd together and said, “Pay attention and try to understand what I mean.
Matthew 15:11 The food you put into your mouth doesn't make you unclean and unfit to worship God. The bad words that come out of your mouth are what make you unclean.”
Matthew 15:12 Then his disciples came over to him and asked, “Do you know you insulted the Pharisees by what you said?”
Matthew 15:13 Jesus answered, “Every plant that my Father in heaven did not plant will be pulled up by the roots.
Matthew 15:14 Stay away from those Pharisees! They are like blind people leading other blind people, and all of them will fall into a ditch.”
Matthew 15:15 Peter replied, “What did you mean when you talked about the things that make people unclean?”
Matthew 15:16 Jesus then said: Don't any of you know by now what I am talking about?
Matthew 15:17 Don't you know that the food you put into your mouth goes into your stomach and then out of your body?
Matthew 15:18 But the words that come out of your mouth come from your heart. And they are what make you unfit to worship God.
Matthew 15:19 Out of your heart come evil thoughts, murder, unfaithfulness in marriage, vulgar deeds, stealing, telling lies, and insulting others.
Matthew 15:20 These are what make you unclean. Eating without washing your hands will not make you unfit to worship God.
Matthew 15:21 Jesus left and went to the territory near the towns of Tyre and Sidon.
Matthew 15:22 Suddenly a Canaanite woman from there came out shouting, “Lord and Son of David, have pity on me! My daughter is full of demons.”
Matthew 15:23 Jesus did not say a word. But the woman kept following along and shouting, so his disciples came up and asked him to send her away.
Matthew 15:24 Jesus said, “I was sent only to the people of Israel! They are like a flock of lost sheep.”
Matthew 15:25 The woman came closer. Then she knelt down and begged, “Please help me, Lord!”
Matthew 15:26 Jesus replied, “It isn't right to take food away from children and feed it to dogs.”
Matthew 15:27 “Lord, this is true,” the woman said, “but even puppies get the crumbs that fall from their owner's table.”
Matthew 15:28 Jesus answered, “Dear woman, you really do have a lot of faith, and you will be given what you want.” At that moment her daughter was healed.
Matthew 15:29 From there, Jesus went along Lake Galilee. Then he climbed a hill and sat down.
