Matthew 15:30 Large crowds came and brought many people who were paralyzed or blind or lame or unable to talk. They placed them, and many others, in front of Jesus, and he healed them all.
Matthew 15:31 Everyone was amazed at what they saw and heard. People who had never spoken could now speak. The lame were healed, the paralyzed could walk, and the blind were able to see. Everyone was praising the God of Israel.
Matthew 15:32 Jesus called his disciples together and told them, “I feel sorry for these people. They have been with me for three days, and they don't have anything to eat. I don't want to send them away hungry. They might faint on their way home.”
Matthew 15:33 His disciples said, “This place is like a desert. Where can we find enough food to feed such a crowd?”
Matthew 15:34 Jesus asked them how much food they had. They replied, “Seven small loaves of bread and a few little fish.”
Matthew 15:35 After Jesus had told the people to sit down,
Matthew 15:36 he took the seven loaves of bread and the fish and gave thanks. He then broke them and handed them to his disciples, who passed them around to the crowds.
Matthew 15:37 Everyone ate all they wanted, and the leftovers filled seven large baskets.
Matthew 15:38 There were 4,000 men who ate, not counting the women and children.
Matthew 15:39 After Jesus had sent the crowds away, he got into a boat and sailed across the lake. He came to shore near the town of Magadan.
Matthew 16:1 The Pharisees and Sadducees came to Jesus and tried to test him by asking for a sign from heaven.
Matthew 16:2 He told them: If the sky is red in the evening, you say the weather will be good.
Matthew 16:3 But if the sky is red and gloomy in the morning, you say it is going to rain. You can tell what the weather will be like by looking at the sky. But you don't understand what is happening now.
Matthew 16:4 You want a sign because you are evil and won't believe! But the only sign you will be given is what happened to Jonah. Then Jesus left.
Matthew 16:5 The disciples had forgotten to bring any bread when they crossed the lake.
Matthew 16:6 Jesus then warned them, “Watch out! Guard against the yeast of the Pharisees and Sadducees.”
Matthew 16:7 The disciples talked this over and said to each other, “He must be saying this because we didn't bring along any bread.”
Matthew 16:8 Jesus knew what they were thinking and said: You surely don't have much faith! Why are you talking about not having any bread?
Matthew 16:9 Don't you understand? Have you forgotten about the 5,000 people and all those baskets of leftovers from just five loaves of bread?
Matthew 16:10 And what about the 4,000 people and all those baskets of leftovers from only seven loaves of bread?
Matthew 16:11 Don't you know by now that I am not talking to you about bread? Watch out for the yeast of the Pharisees and Sadducees!
Matthew 16:12 Finally, the disciples understood that Jesus wasn't talking about the yeast used to make bread, but about the teaching of the Pharisees and Sadducees.
Matthew 16:13 When Jesus and his disciples were near the town of Caesarea Philippi, he asked them, “What do people say about the Son of Man?”
Matthew 16:14 The disciples answered, “Some people say you are John the Baptist or maybe Elijah or Jeremiah or some other prophet.”
Matthew 16:15 Then Jesus asked, “But who do you say I am?”
Matthew 16:16 Simon Peter spoke up, “You are the Messiah, the Son of the living God.”
Matthew 16:17 Jesus told him: Simon, son of Jonah, you are blessed! You didn't discover this on your own. It was shown to you by my Father in heaven.
Matthew 16:18 So I will call you Peter, which means “a rock.” On this rock I will build my church, and death itself will not have any power over it.
Matthew 16:19 I will give you the keys to the kingdom of heaven, and God in heaven will allow whatever you allow on earth. But he will not allow anything you don't allow.
Matthew 16:20 Jesus told his disciples not to tell anyone he was the Messiah.
Matthew 16:21 From then on, Jesus began telling his disciples what would happen to him. He said, “I must go to Jerusalem. There the nation's leaders, the chief priests, and the teachers of the Law of Moses will make me suffer terribly. I will be killed, but three days later I will rise to life.”
Matthew 16:22 Peter took Jesus aside and told him to stop talking like that. He said, “God would never let this happen to you, Lord!”
Matthew 16:23 Jesus turned to Peter and said, “Satan, get away from me! You're in my way because you think like everyone else and not like God.”
Matthew 16:24 Then Jesus said to his disciples: If any of you want to be my followers, you must forget about yourself. You must take up your cross and follow me.
Matthew 16:25 If you want to save your life, you will destroy it. But if you give up your life for me, you will find it.
Matthew 16:26 What will you gain, if you own the whole world but destroy yourself? What would you give to get back your soul?
Matthew 16:27 The Son of Man will soon come in the glory of his Father and with his angels to reward all people for what they have done.
Matthew 16:28 I promise you some of those standing here will not die before they see the Son of Man coming with his kingdom.
Matthew 17:1 Six days later Jesus took Peter and the brothers James and John with him. They went up on a very high mountain where they could be alone.
Matthew 17:2 There in front of the disciples, Jesus was completely changed. His face was shining like the sun, and his clothes became white as light.
Matthew 17:3 All at once Moses and Elijah were there talking with Jesus.
Matthew 17:4 So Peter said to him, “Lord, it is good for us to be here! Let us make three shelters, one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah.”
Matthew 17:5 While Peter was still speaking, the shadow of a bright cloud passed over them. From the cloud a voice said, “This is my own dear Son, and I am pleased with him. Listen to what he says!”
Matthew 17:6 When the disciples heard the voice, they were so afraid they fell flat on the ground.
Matthew 17:7 But Jesus came over and touched them. He said, “Get up and don't be afraid!”
Matthew 17:8 When they opened their eyes, they saw only Jesus.
Matthew 17:9 On their way down from the mountain, Jesus warned his disciples not to tell anyone what they had seen until after the Son of Man had been raised from death.
Matthew 17:10 The disciples asked Jesus, “Don't the teachers of the Law of Moses say Elijah must come before the Messiah does?”
Matthew 17:11 Jesus told them, “Elijah certainly will come and get everything ready.
Matthew 17:12 In fact, he has already come. But the people did not recognize him and treated him just as they wanted to. They will soon make the Son of Man suffer in the same way.”
Matthew 17:13 Then the disciples understood Jesus was talking to them about John the Baptist.
Matthew 17:14 Jesus and his disciples returned to the crowd. A man knelt in front of him
Matthew 17:15 and said, “Lord, have pity on my son! He has a bad case of epilepsy and often falls into a fire or into water.
Matthew 17:16 I brought him to your disciples, but none of them could heal him.”
Matthew 17:17 Jesus said, “You people are too stubborn to have any faith! How much longer must I be with you? Why do I have to put up with you? Bring the boy here.”
Matthew 17:18 Then Jesus spoke sternly to the demon. It went out of the boy, and right then he was healed.
Matthew 17:19 Later the disciples went to Jesus in private and asked him, “Why couldn't we force out the demon?”
Matthew 17:20+MAT Jesus replied: It is because you don't have enough faith! But I can promise you this. If you had faith no larger than a mustard seed, you could tell this mountain to move from here to there. And it would. Everything would be possible for you.
Matthew 17:22 While Jesus and his disciples were going from place to place in Galilee, he told them, “The Son of Man will be handed over to people
Matthew 17:23 who will kill him. But three days later he will rise to life.” All of this made the disciples very sad.
Matthew 17:24 When Jesus and the others arrived in Capernaum, the collectors for the temple tax came to Peter and asked, “Does your teacher pay the temple tax?”
Matthew 17:25 “Yes, he does,” Peter answered. After they had returned home, Jesus went up to Peter and asked him, “Simon, what do you think? Do the kings of this earth collect taxes and fees from their own people or from foreigners?”
Matthew 17:26 Peter answered, “From foreigners.” Jesus replied, “Then their own people don't have to pay.
Matthew 17:27 But we don't want to cause trouble. So go cast a line into the lake and pull out the first fish you hook. Open its mouth, and you will find a coin. Use it to pay your taxes and mine.”
Matthew 18:1 About this time the disciples came to Jesus and asked him who would be the greatest in the kingdom of heaven.
Matthew 18:2 Jesus called for a child to come over and stand near him.
Matthew 18:3 Then he said: I promise you this. If you don't change and become like a child, you will never get into the kingdom of heaven.
Matthew 18:4 But if you are as humble as this child, you are the greatest in the kingdom of heaven.
Matthew 18:5 And when you welcome one of these children because of me, you welcome me.
Matthew 18:6 It will be terrible for people who cause even one of my little followers to sin. Those people would be better off thrown into the deepest part of the ocean with a heavy stone tied around their necks!
Matthew 18:7 The world is in for trouble because of the way it causes people to sin. There will always be something to cause people to sin, but anyone who does this will be in for trouble.
Matthew 18:8 If your hand or foot causes you to sin, chop it off and throw it away! You would be better off to go into life paralyzed or lame than to have two hands or two feet and be thrown into the fire that never goes out.
Matthew 18:9 If your eye causes you to sin, poke it out and get rid of it. You would be better off to go into life with only one eye than to have two eyes and be thrown into the fires of hell.
Matthew 18:10+MAT Don't be cruel to any of these little ones! I promise you their angels are always with my Father in heaven.
Matthew 18:12 Let me ask you this. What would you do if you had 100 sheep and one of them wandered off? Wouldn't you leave the 99 on the hillside and go look for the one that had wandered away?
Matthew 18:13 I am sure that finding it would make you happier than having the 99 that never wandered off.
Matthew 18:14 That's how it is with your Father in heaven. He doesn't want any of these little ones to be lost.
Matthew 18:15 If one of my followers sins against you, go and point out what was wrong. But do it in private, just between the two of you. If that person listens, you have won back a follower.
Matthew 18:16 But if that one refuses to listen, take along one or two others. The Scriptures teach that every complaint must be proven true by two or more witnesses.
Matthew 18:17 If the follower refuses to listen to them, report the matter to the church. Anyone who refuses to listen to the church must be treated like an unbeliever or a tax collector.
Matthew 18:18 I promise you God in heaven will allow whatever you allow on earth, but God will not allow anything you don't allow.
Matthew 18:19 I promise that when any two of you on earth agree about something you are praying for, my Father in heaven will do it for you.
Matthew 18:20 Whenever two or three of you come together in my name, I am there with you.
Matthew 18:21 Peter came up to the Lord and asked, “How many times should I forgive someone who does something wrong to me? Is seven times enough?”
Matthew 18:22 Jesus answered: Not just 7 times, but 77 times!
Matthew 18:23 This story will show you what the kingdom of heaven is like: One day a king decided to call in his officials and ask them to give an account of what they owed him.
Matthew 18:24 As he was doing this, one official was brought in who owed him 50,000,000 silver coins.
Matthew 18:25 But he didn't have any money to pay what he owed. The king ordered him to be sold, along with his wife and children and all he owned, in order to pay the debt.
Matthew 18:26 The official got down on his knees and began begging, “Have pity on me, and I will pay you every cent I owe!”
Matthew 18:27 The king felt sorry for him and let him go free. He even told the official that he did not have to pay back the money.
Matthew 18:28 But as this official was leaving, he happened to meet another official, who owed him 100 silver coins. So he grabbed the man by the throat. He started choking him and said, “Pay me what you owe!”
Matthew 18:29 The man got down on his knees and began begging, “Have pity on me, and I will pay you back.”
Matthew 18:30 But the first official refused to have pity. Instead, he went and had the other official put in jail until he could pay what he owed.
Matthew 18:31 When some other officials found out what had happened, they felt sorry for the man who had been put in jail. Then they told the king what had happened.
Matthew 18:32 The king called the first official back in and said, “You're an evil man! When you begged for mercy, I said you did not have to pay back a cent.
Matthew 18:33 Don't you think you should show pity to someone else, as I did to you?”
Matthew 18:34 The king was so angry that he ordered the official to be tortured until he could pay back everything he owed.
Matthew 18:35 That is how my Father in heaven will treat you, if you don't forgive each of my followers with all your heart.
Matthew 19:1 When Jesus finished teaching, he left Galilee and went to the part of Judea east of the Jordan River.
Matthew 19:2 Large crowds followed him, and he healed their sick.
Matthew 19:3 Some Pharisees wanted to test Jesus. They came up to him and asked, “Is it right for a man to divorce his wife for just any reason?”
Matthew 19:4 Jesus answered, “Don't you know in the beginning the Creator made a man and a woman?
Matthew 19:5 That's why a man leaves his father and mother and gets married. He becomes like one person with his wife.
Matthew 19:6 Then they are no longer two people, but one. And no one should separate a couple God has joined together.”
Matthew 19:7 The Pharisees asked Jesus, “Why did Moses say a man could write out divorce papers and send his wife away?”
Matthew 19:8 Jesus replied, “You are so heartless! That's why Moses allowed you to divorce your wife. But from the beginning God did not intend it to be that way.
Matthew 19:9 I say if your wife has not committed some terrible sexual sin, you must not divorce her to marry someone else. If you do, you are unfaithful.”
Matthew 19:10 The disciples said, “If that's how it is between a man and a woman, it's better not to get married.”
Matthew 19:11 Jesus told them, “Only those people who have been given the gift of staying single can accept this teaching.
Matthew 19:12 Some people are unable to marry because of birth defects or because of what someone has done to their bodies. Others stay single in order to serve God better. Anyone who can accept this teaching should do so.”
Matthew 19:13 Some people brought their children to Jesus, so he could place his hands on them and pray for them. His disciples told the people to stop bothering him.
Matthew 19:14 But Jesus said, “Let the children come to me, and don't try to stop them! People who are like these children belong to God's kingdom.”
Matthew 19:15 After Jesus had placed his hands on the children, he left.
Matthew 19:16 A man came to Jesus and asked, “Teacher, what good thing must I do to have eternal life?”
Matthew 19:17 Jesus said to him, “Why do you ask me about what is good? Only God is good. If you want to have eternal life, you must obey his commandments.”
Matthew 19:18 “Which ones?” the man asked. Jesus answered, “Do not murder. Be faithful in marriage. Do not steal. Do not tell lies about others.
Matthew 19:19 Respect your father and mother. And love others as much as you love yourself.”
Matthew 19:20 The young man said, “I have obeyed all of these. What else must I do?”
Matthew 19:21 Jesus replied, “If you want to be perfect, go sell everything you own! Give the money to the poor, and you will have riches in heaven. Then come and be my follower.”
Matthew 19:22 When the young man heard this, he went away sad, because he was very rich.
Matthew 19:23 Jesus said to his disciples, “I tell you, it's terribly hard for rich people to get into the kingdom of heaven!
Matthew 19:24 In fact, it's easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich person to get into God's kingdom.”
Matthew 19:25 When the disciples heard this, they were greatly surprised and asked, “How can anyone ever be saved?”
Matthew 19:26 Jesus looked straight at them and said, “There are some things people cannot do, but God can do anything.”
Matthew 19:27 Peter replied, “Remember, we have left everything to be your followers! What will we get?”
Matthew 19:28 Jesus answered: Yes, all of you have become my followers. And so in the future world, when the Son of Man sits on his glorious throne, I promise you will sit on twelve thrones to judge the twelve tribes of Israel.
Matthew 19:29 All who have given up home or brothers and sisters or father and mother or children or land for me will be given 100 times as much. They will also have eternal life.
Matthew 19:30 But many who are now first will be last, and many who are last will be first.
Matthew 20:1 As Jesus was telling what the kingdom of heaven would be like, he said: Early one morning a man went out to hire some workers for his vineyard.
Matthew 20:2 After he had agreed to pay them the usual amount for a day's work, he sent them off to his vineyard.
Matthew 20:3 About nine that morning, the man saw some other people standing in the market with nothing to do.
Matthew 20:4 He promised to pay them what was fair, if they would work in his vineyard.
Matthew 20:5 So they went. At noon and again about three in the afternoon he returned to the market. And each time he made the same agreement with others who were loafing around with nothing to do.
Matthew 20:6 Finally, about five in the afternoon the man went back and found some others standing there. He asked them, “Why have you been standing here all day long doing nothing?”
Matthew 20:7 “Because no one has hired us,” they answered. Then he told them to go work in his vineyard.
Matthew 20:8 That evening the owner of the vineyard told the man in charge of the workers to call them in and give them their money. He also told the man to begin with the ones who were hired last.
Matthew 20:9 When the workers arrived, the ones who had been hired at five in the afternoon were given a full day's pay.
Matthew 20:10 The workers who had been hired first thought they would be given more than the others. But when they were given the same,
Matthew 20:11 they began complaining to the owner of the vineyard.
Matthew 20:12 They said, “The ones who were hired last worked for only one hour. But you paid them the same that you did us. And we worked in the hot sun all day long!”
Matthew 20:13 The owner answered one of them, “Friend, I didn't cheat you. I paid you exactly what we agreed on.
Matthew 20:14 Take your money now and go! What business is it of yours if I want to pay them the same that I paid you?
Matthew 20:15 Don't I have the right to do what I want with my own money? Why should you be jealous, if I want to be generous?”
Matthew 20:16 Jesus then said, “So it is. Everyone who is now last will be first, and everyone who is first will be last.”
Matthew 20:17 As Jesus was on his way to Jerusalem, he took his twelve disciples aside and told them in private:
Matthew 20:18 We are now on our way to Jerusalem, where the Son of Man will be handed over to the chief priests and the teachers of the Law of Moses. They will sentence him to death,
Matthew 20:19 and then they will hand him over to foreigners who will make fun of him. They will beat him and nail him to a cross. But on the third day he will rise from death.
Matthew 20:20 The mother of James and John came to Jesus with her two sons. She knelt down and started begging him to do something for her.
Matthew 20:21 Jesus asked her what she wanted, and she said, “When you come into your kingdom, please let one of my sons sit at your right side and the other at your left.”
Matthew 20:22 Jesus answered, “Not one of you knows what you are asking. Are you able to drink from the cup that I must soon drink from?” James and John said, “Yes, we are!”
Matthew 20:23 Jesus replied, “You certainly will drink from my cup! But it isn't for me to say who will sit at my right side and at my left. This is for my Father to say.”
Matthew 20:24 When the ten other disciples heard this, they were angry with the two brothers.
Matthew 20:25 But Jesus called the disciples together and said: You know foreign rulers like to order their people around. And their great leaders have full power over everyone they rule.
Matthew 20:26 But don't act like them. If you want to be great, you must be the servant of all the others.
Matthew 20:27 And if you want to be first, you must be the slave of the rest.
Matthew 20:28 The Son of Man did not come to be a slave master, but a slave who will give his life to rescue many people.
Matthew 20:29 Jesus was followed by a large crowd as he and his disciples were leaving Jericho.
Matthew 20:30 Two blind men were sitting beside the road. And when they heard that Jesus was coming their way, they shouted, “Lord and Son of David, have pity on us!”
Matthew 20:31 The crowd told them to be quiet, but they shouted even louder, “Lord and Son of David, have pity on us!”
Matthew 20:32 When Jesus heard them, he stopped and asked, “What do you want me to do for you?”
Matthew 20:33 They answered, “Lord, we want to see!”
Matthew 20:34 Jesus felt sorry for them and touched their eyes. At once they could see, and they became his followers.
Matthew 21:1 When Jesus and his disciples came near Jerusalem, he went to Bethphage on the Mount of Olives and sent two of them on ahead.
Matthew 21:2 He told them, “Go into the next village, where you will at once find a donkey and her colt. Untie the two donkeys and bring them to me.
Matthew 21:3 If anyone asks why you are doing this, just say, ‘The Lord needs them.’ He will at once let you have the donkeys.”
Matthew 21:4 So God's promise came true, just as the prophet had said,
Matthew 21:5 “Announce to the people of Jerusalem: ‘Your king is coming to you! He is humble and rides on a donkey. He comes on the colt of a donkey.’ ”
Matthew 21:6 The disciples left and did what Jesus had told them to do.
Matthew 21:7 They brought the donkey and its colt and laid some clothes on their backs. Then Jesus got on.
Matthew 21:8 Many people spread clothes in the road, while others put down branches which they had cut from trees.
Matthew 21:9 Some people walked ahead of Jesus and others followed behind. They were all shouting, “Hooray for the Son of David! God bless the one who comes in the name of the Lord. Hooray for God in heaven above!”
Matthew 21:10 When Jesus came to Jerusalem, everyone in the city was excited and asked, “Who can this be?”
Matthew 21:11 The crowds answered, “This is Jesus, the prophet from Nazareth in Galilee.”
Matthew 21:12 Jesus went into the temple and chased out everyone who was selling or buying. He turned over the tables of the moneychangers and the benches of the ones who were selling doves.
Matthew 21:13 He told them, “The Scriptures say, ‘My house should be called a place of worship.’ But you have turned it into a place where robbers hide.”
Matthew 21:14 Blind and lame people came to Jesus in the temple, and he healed them.
Matthew 21:15 But the chief priests and the teachers of the Law of Moses were angry when they saw his miracles and heard the children shouting praises to the Son of David.
Matthew 21:16 The men said to Jesus, “Don't you hear what those children are saying?” “Yes, I do!” Jesus answered. “Don't you know that the Scriptures say, ‘Children and infants will sing praises’?”
Matthew 21:17 Then Jesus left the city and went out to the village of Bethany, where he spent the night.
Matthew 21:18 When Jesus got up the next morning, he was hungry. He started out for the city,
Matthew 21:19 and along the way he saw a fig tree. But when he came to it, he found only leaves and no figs. So he told the tree, “You will never again grow any fruit!” Right then the fig tree dried up.
Matthew 21:20 The disciples were shocked when they saw how quickly the tree had dried up.
Matthew 21:21 But Jesus said to them, “If you have faith and don't doubt, I promise you can do what I did to this tree. And you will be able to do even more. You can tell this mountain to get up and jump into the sea, and it will.
Matthew 21:22 If you have faith when you pray, you will be given whatever you ask for.”
Matthew 21:23 Jesus had gone into the temple and was teaching when the chief priests and the leaders of the people came up to him. They asked, “What right do you have to do these things? Who gave you this authority?”
Matthew 21:24 Jesus answered, “I have just one question to ask you. If you answer it, I will tell you where I got the right to do these things.
Matthew 21:25 Who gave John the right to baptize? Was it God in heaven or merely some human being?” They thought it over and said to each other, “We can't say God gave John this right. Jesus will ask us why we didn't believe John.
Matthew 21:26 On the other hand, these people think John was a prophet, and we are afraid of what they might do to us. That's why we can't say it was merely some human who gave John the right to baptize.”
Matthew 21:27 So they told Jesus, “We don't know.” Jesus said, “Then I won't tell you who gave me the right to do what I do.”
Matthew 21:28 Jesus said: I will tell you a story about a man who had two sons. Then you can tell me what you think. The father went to the older son and said, “Go work in the vineyard today!”
Matthew 21:29 His son told him he would not do it, but later he changed his mind and went.
Matthew 21:30 The man then told his younger son to go work in the vineyard. The boy said he would, but he didn't go.
Matthew 21:31 Which one of the sons obeyed his father? “The older one,” the chief priests and leaders answered. Then Jesus told them: You can be sure tax collectors and prostitutes will get into the kingdom of God before you ever will!
Matthew 21:32 When John the Baptist showed you how to do right, you would not believe him. But these evil people did believe. And even when you saw what they did, you still would not change your minds and believe.
Matthew 21:33 Jesus told the chief priests and leaders to listen to this story: A land owner once planted a vineyard. He built a wall around it and dug a pit to crush the grapes in. He also built a lookout tower. Then he rented out his vineyard and left the country.
Matthew 21:34 When it was harvest time, the owner sent some servants to get his share of the grapes.
Matthew 21:35 But the renters grabbed those servants. They beat up one, killed one, and stoned one of them to death.
Matthew 21:36 He then sent more servants than he did the first time. But the renters treated them in the same way.
Matthew 21:37 Finally, the owner sent his own son to the renters, because he thought they would respect him.
Matthew 21:38 But when they saw the man's son, they said, “Someday he will own the vineyard. Let's kill him! Then we can have it all for ourselves.”
Matthew 21:39 So they grabbed him, threw him out of the vineyard, and killed him.
Matthew 21:40 Jesus asked, “When the owner of that vineyard comes, what do you suppose he will do to those renters?”
Matthew 21:41 The chief priests and leaders answered, “He will kill them in some horrible way. Then he will rent out his vineyard to people who will give him his share of grapes at harvest time.”
Matthew 21:42 Jesus replied, “You surely know that the Scriptures say, ‘The stone the builders tossed aside is now the most important stone of all. This is something the Lord has done, and it is amazing to us.’
Matthew 21:43 I tell you God's kingdom will be taken from you and given to people who will do what he demands.
Matthew 21:44 Anyone who stumbles over this stone will be crushed, and anyone it falls on will be smashed to pieces.”
Matthew 21:45 When the chief priests and the Pharisees heard these stories, they knew Jesus was talking about them.
Matthew 21:46 So they looked for a way to arrest Jesus. But they were afraid to, because the people thought he was a prophet.
Matthew 22:1 Once again Jesus used stories to teach the people:
Matthew 22:2 The kingdom of heaven is like what happened when a king gave a wedding banquet for his son.
Matthew 22:3 The king sent some servants to tell the invited guests to come to the banquet, but the guests refused.
Matthew 22:4 He sent other servants to say to the guests, “The banquet is ready! My cattle and prize calves have all been prepared. Everything is ready. Come to the banquet!”
Matthew 22:5 But the guests did not pay any attention. Some of them left for their farms, and some went to their places of business.
Matthew 22:6 Others grabbed the servants, then beat them up and killed them.
Matthew 22:7 This made the king so furious that he sent an army to kill those murderers and burn down their city.
Matthew 22:8 Then he said to the servants, “It is time for the wedding banquet, and the invited guests don't deserve to come.
Matthew 22:9 Go out to the street corners and tell everyone you meet to come to the banquet.”
Matthew 22:10 They went out on the streets and brought in everyone they could find, good and bad alike. And the banquet room was filled with guests.
Matthew 22:11 When the king went in to meet the guests, he found that one of them wasn't wearing the right kind of clothes for the wedding.
Matthew 22:12 The king asked, “Friend, why didn't you wear proper clothes for the wedding?” But the guest had no excuse.
Matthew 22:13 So the king gave orders for this person to be tied hand and foot and to be thrown outside into the dark. That's where people will cry and grit their teeth in pain.
Matthew 22:14 Many are invited, but only a few are chosen.
Matthew 22:15 The Pharisees got together and planned how they could trick Jesus into saying something wrong.
Matthew 22:16 They sent some of their followers and some of Herod's followers to say to him, “Teacher, we know that you are honest. You teach the truth about what God wants people to do. And you treat everyone with the same respect, no matter who they are.
Matthew 22:17 Tell us what you think! Should we pay taxes to the Emperor or not?”
Matthew 22:18 Jesus knew their evil thoughts and said, “Why are you trying to test me? You show-offs!
Matthew 22:19 Let me see one of the coins used for paying taxes.” They brought him a silver coin,
Matthew 22:20 and he asked, “Whose picture and name are on it?”
Matthew 22:21 “The Emperor's,” they answered. Then Jesus told them, “Give the Emperor what belongs to him and give God what belongs to God.”
Matthew 22:22 His answer surprised them so much that they walked away.
Matthew 22:23 The Sadducees did not believe people would rise to life after death. So that same day some of the Sadducees came to Jesus and said:
Matthew 22:24 Teacher, Moses wrote that if a married man dies and has no children, his brother should marry the widow. Their first son would then be thought of as the son of the dead brother.
Matthew 22:25 Once there were seven brothers who lived here. The first one married, but died without having any children. So his wife was left to his brother.
Matthew 22:26 The same thing happened to the second and third brothers and finally to all seven of them.
Matthew 22:27 At last the woman died.
Matthew 22:28 When God raises people from death, whose wife will this woman be? She had been married to all seven brothers.
Matthew 22:29 Jesus answered: You are completely wrong! You don't know what the Scriptures teach. And you don't know anything about the power of God.
Matthew 22:30 When God raises people to life, they won't marry. They will be like the angels in heaven.
Matthew 22:31 And as for people being raised to life, God was speaking to you when he said,
Matthew 22:32 “I am the God worshiped by Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.” He isn't the God of the dead, but of the living.
Matthew 22:33 The crowds were surprised to hear what Jesus was teaching.
Matthew 22:34 After Jesus had made the Sadducees look foolish, the Pharisees heard about it and got together.
Matthew 22:35 One of them was an expert in the Jewish Law. So he tried to test Jesus by asking,
Matthew 22:36 “Teacher, what is the most important commandment in the Law?”
Matthew 22:37 Jesus answered: Love the Lord your God with all your heart, soul, and mind.
Matthew 22:38 This is the first and most important commandment.
Matthew 22:39 The second most important commandment is like this one. And it is, “Love others as much as you love yourself.”
Matthew 22:40 All the Law of Moses and the Books of the Prophets are based on these two commandments.
Matthew 22:41 While the Pharisees were still there, Jesus asked them,
Matthew 22:42 “What do you think about the Messiah? Whose family will he come from?” They answered, “He will be a son of King David.”
Matthew 22:43 Jesus replied, “How then could the Spirit lead David to call the Messiah his Lord? David said,
Matthew 22:44 ‘The Lord said to my Lord: Sit at my right side until I make your enemies into a footstool for you.’
Matthew 22:45 If David called the Messiah his Lord, how can the Messiah be a son of King David?”
Matthew 22:46 No one was able to give Jesus an answer, and from that day on, no one dared ask him any more questions.
Matthew 23:1 Jesus said to the crowds and to his disciples:
Matthew 23:2 The Pharisees and the teachers of the Law are experts in the Law of Moses.
Matthew 23:3 So obey everything they teach you, but don't do as they do. After all, they say one thing and do something else.
Matthew 23:4 They pile heavy burdens on people's shoulders and won't lift a finger to help.
Matthew 23:5 Everything they do is just to show off in front of others. They even make a big show of wearing Scripture verses on their foreheads and arms, and they wear big tassels for everyone to see.
Matthew 23:6 They love the best seats at banquets and the front seats in the synagogues.
Matthew 23:7 And when they are in the market, they like to have people greet them as their teachers.
Matthew 23:8 But none of you should be called a teacher. You have only one teacher, and all of you are like brothers and sisters.
Matthew 23:9 Don't call anyone on earth your father. All of you have the same Father in heaven.
Matthew 23:10 None of you should be called the leader. The Messiah is your only leader.
Matthew 23:11 Whoever is the greatest should be the servant of the others.
Matthew 23:12 If you put yourself above others, you will be put down. But if you humble yourself, you will be honored.
Matthew 23:13+MAT You Pharisees and teachers of the Law of Moses are in for trouble! You're nothing but show-offs. You lock people out of the kingdom of heaven. You won't go in yourselves, and you keep others from going in.
Matthew 23:15 You Pharisees and teachers of the Law of Moses are in for trouble! You're nothing but show-offs. You travel over land and sea to win one follower. And when you have done so, you make that person twice as fit for hell as you are.
Matthew 23:16 You are in for trouble! You are supposed to lead others, but you are blind. You teach that it doesn't matter if a person swears by the temple. But you say it does matter if someone swears by the gold in the temple.
Matthew 23:17 You blind fools! Which is greater, the gold or the temple that makes the gold sacred?
Matthew 23:18 You also teach that it doesn't matter if a person swears by the altar. But you say it does matter if someone swears by the gift on the altar.
Matthew 23:19 Are you blind? Which is more important, the gift or the altar that makes the gift sacred?
Matthew 23:20 Anyone who swears by the altar also swears by everything on it.
Matthew 23:21 And anyone who swears by the temple also swears by God, who lives there.
Matthew 23:22 To swear by heaven is the same as swearing by God's throne and by the one who sits on that throne.
Matthew 23:23 You Pharisees and teachers are show-offs, and you're in for trouble! You give God a tenth of the spices from your garden, such as mint, dill, and cumin. Yet you neglect the more important matters of the Law, such as justice, mercy, and faithfulness. These are the important things you should have done, though you should not have left the others undone either.
Matthew 23:24 You blind leaders! You strain out a small fly but swallow a camel.
Matthew 23:25 You Pharisees and teachers are show-offs, and you're in for trouble! You wash the outside of your cups and dishes, while inside there is nothing but greed and selfishness.
Matthew 23:26 You blind Pharisee! First clean the inside of a cup, and then the outside will also be clean.
Matthew 23:27 You Pharisees and teachers are in for trouble! You're nothing but show-offs. You're like tombs that have been whitewashed. On the outside they are beautiful, but inside they are full of bones and filth.
Matthew 23:28 That's what you are like. Outside you look good, but inside you are evil and only pretend to be good.
Matthew 23:29 You Pharisees and teachers are nothing but show-offs, and you're in for trouble! You build monuments for the prophets and decorate the tombs of good people.
Matthew 23:30 And you claim you would not have taken part with your ancestors in killing the prophets.
Matthew 23:31 But you prove you really are the relatives of the ones who killed the prophets.
Matthew 23:32 So keep on doing everything they did.
Matthew 23:33 You are nothing but snakes and the children of snakes! How can you escape going to hell?
Matthew 23:34 I will send to you prophets and wise people and experts in the Law of Moses. You will kill them or nail them to a cross or beat them in your synagogues or chase them from town to town.
Matthew 23:35 That's why you will be held guilty for the murder of every good person, beginning with the good man Abel. This also includes Barachiah's son Zechariah, the man you murdered between the temple and the altar.
Matthew 23:36 I can promise that you people living today will be punished for all these things!
Matthew 23:37 Jerusalem, Jerusalem! Your people have killed the prophets and have stoned the messengers who were sent to you. I have often wanted to gather your people, as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings. But you wouldn't let me.
Matthew 23:38 And now your temple will be deserted.
Matthew 23:39 You won't see me again until you say, “Blessed is the one who comes in the name of the Lord.”
Matthew 24:1 After Jesus left the temple, his disciples came over and said, “Look at all these buildings!”
Matthew 24:2 Jesus replied, “Do you see these buildings? They will certainly be torn down! Not one stone will be left in place.”
Matthew 24:3 Later, as Jesus was sitting on the Mount of Olives, his disciples came to him in private and asked, “When will this happen? What will be the sign of your coming and of the end of the world?”
Matthew 24:4 Jesus answered: Don't let anyone fool you.
Matthew 24:5 Many will come and claim to be me. They will say they are the Messiah, and they will fool many people.
Matthew 24:6 You will soon hear about wars and threats of wars, but don't be afraid. These things will have to happen first, but that isn't the end.
Matthew 24:7 Nations and kingdoms will go to war against each other. People will starve to death, and in some places there will be earthquakes.
Matthew 24:8 But this is just the beginning of troubles.
Matthew 24:9 You will be arrested, punished, and even killed. Because of me, you will be hated by people of all nations.
Matthew 24:10 Many will give up and will betray and hate each other.
Matthew 24:11 Many false prophets will come and fool a lot of people.
Matthew 24:12 Evil will spread and cause many people to stop loving others.
Matthew 24:13 But if you keep on being faithful right to the end, you will be saved.
Matthew 24:14 When the good news about the kingdom has been preached all over the world and told to all nations, the end will come.
Matthew 24:15 Someday you will see that “Horrible Thing” in the holy place, just as the prophet Daniel said. Everyone who reads this must try to understand!
Matthew 24:16 If you are living in Judea at that time, run to the mountains.
Matthew 24:17 If you are on the roof of your house, don't go inside to get anything.
Matthew 24:18 If you are out in the field, don't go back for your coat.
Matthew 24:19 It will be a terrible time for women who are expecting babies or nursing young children.
Matthew 24:20 And pray that you won't have to escape in winter or on a Sabbath.
Matthew 24:21 This will be the worst time of suffering since the beginning of the world, and nothing this terrible will ever happen again.
Matthew 24:22 If God doesn't make the time shorter, no one will be left alive. But because of God's chosen ones, he will make the time shorter.
Matthew 24:23 Someone may say, “Here is the Messiah!” or “There he is!” But don't believe it.
Matthew 24:24 False messiahs and false prophets will come and work great miracles and signs. They will even try to fool God's chosen ones.
Matthew 24:25 But I have warned you ahead of time.
Matthew 24:26 If you are told the Messiah is out in the desert, don't go there! And if you are told he is in some secret place, don't believe it!
Matthew 24:27 The coming of the Son of Man will be like lightning that can be seen from east to west.
Matthew 24:28 Where there is a corpse, there will always be vultures.
Matthew 24:29 Right after those days of suffering, “The sun will become dark, and the moon will no longer shine. The stars will fall, and the powers in the sky will be shaken.”
Matthew 24:30 Then a sign will appear in the sky. And there will be the Son of Man. All nations on earth will weep when they see the Son of Man coming on the clouds of heaven with power and great glory.
Matthew 24:31 At the sound of a loud trumpet, he will send his angels to bring his chosen ones together from all over the earth.
Matthew 24:32 Learn a lesson from a fig tree. When its branches sprout and start putting out leaves, you know summer is near.
Matthew 24:33 So when you see all these things happening, you will know the time has almost come.
Matthew 24:34 I can promise you that some of the people of this generation will still be alive when all this happens.
Matthew 24:35 The sky and the earth won't last forever, but my words will.
Matthew 24:36 No one knows the day or hour. The angels in heaven don't know, and the Son himself doesn't know. Only the Father knows.
Matthew 24:37 When the Son of Man appears, things will be just as they were when Noah lived.
Matthew 24:38 People were eating, drinking, and getting married right up to the day the flood came and Noah went into the big boat.
Matthew 24:39 They didn't know anything was happening until the flood came and swept them all away. This is how it will be when the Son of Man appears.
Matthew 24:40 Two men will be in the same field, but only one will be taken. The other will be left.
Matthew 24:41 Two women will be together grinding grain, but only one will be taken. The other will be left.
Matthew 24:42 So be on your guard! You don't know when your Lord will come.
Matthew 24:43 Homeowners never know when a thief is coming, and they are always on guard to keep one from breaking in.
Matthew 24:44 Always be ready! You don't know when the Son of Man will come.
Matthew 24:45 Who are faithful and wise servants? Who are the ones the master will put in charge of giving the other servants their food supplies at the proper time?
Matthew 24:46 Servants are fortunate if their master comes and finds them doing their job.
Matthew 24:47 You may be sure a servant who is always faithful will be put in charge of everything the master owns.
Matthew 24:48 But suppose one of the servants thinks the master won't return until late.
Matthew 24:49 Suppose this evil servant starts beating the other servants and eats and drinks with people who are drunk.
Matthew 24:50 If that happens, the master will surely come on a day and at a time when the servant least expects him.
Matthew 24:51 This servant will then be punished and thrown out with the ones who only pretended to serve their master. There they will cry and grit their teeth in pain.
Matthew 25:1 The kingdom of heaven is like what happened one night when ten young women took their oil lamps and went to a wedding to meet the groom.
Matthew 25:2 Five of them were foolish and five were wise.
Matthew 25:3 The foolish ones took their lamps, but no extra oil.
Matthew 25:4 The ones who were wise took along extra oil for their lamps.
Matthew 25:5 The groom was late arriving, and the young women became drowsy and fell asleep.
Matthew 25:6 Then in the middle of the night someone shouted, “Here's the groom! Come to meet him!”
Matthew 25:7 When the women got up and started getting their lamps ready,
Matthew 25:8 the foolish ones said to the others, “Let us have some of your oil! Our lamps are going out.”
Matthew 25:9 Those who were wise answered, “There's not enough oil for all of us! Go and buy some for yourselves.”
Matthew 25:10 While the foolish ones were on their way to get some oil, the groom arrived. The five who were ready went into the wedding, and the doors were closed.
Matthew 25:11 Later the others returned and shouted, “Sir, sir! Open the door for us!”
Matthew 25:12 But the groom replied, “I don't even know you!”
Matthew 25:13 So, my disciples, always be ready! You don't know the day or the time when all this will happen.
Matthew 25:14 The kingdom is also like what happened when a man went away and put his three servants in charge of all he owned.
Matthew 25:15 The man knew what each servant could do. So he handed 5,000 coins to the first servant, 2,000 to the second, and 1,000 to the third. Then he left the country.
Matthew 25:16 As soon as the man had gone, the servant with the 5,000 coins used them to earn 5,000 more.
Matthew 25:17 The servant who had 2,000 coins did the same with his money and earned 2,000 more.
Matthew 25:18 But the servant with 1,000 coins dug a hole and hid his master's money in the ground.
Matthew 25:19 Some time later the master of those servants returned. He called them in and asked what they had done with his money.
Matthew 25:20 The servant who had been given 5,000 coins brought them in with the 5,000 that he had earned. He said, “Sir, you gave me 5,000 coins, and I have earned 5,000 more.”
Matthew 25:21 “Wonderful!” his master replied. “You are a good and faithful servant. I left you in charge of only a little, but now I will put you in charge of much more. Come and share in my happiness!”
Matthew 25:22 Next, the servant who had been given 2,000 coins came in and said, “Sir, you gave me 2,000 coins, and I have earned 2,000 more.”
Matthew 25:23 “Wonderful!” his master replied. “You are a good and faithful servant. I left you in charge of only a little, but now I will put you in charge of much more. Come and share in my happiness!”
Matthew 25:24 The servant who had been given 1,000 coins then came in and said, “Sir, I know that you are hard to work for. You harvest what you don't plant and gather crops where you haven't scattered seed.
Matthew 25:25 I was frightened and went out and hid your money in the ground. Here is every single coin!”
Matthew 25:26 The master of the servant told him, “You are lazy and good-for-nothing! You know I harvest what I don't plant and gather crops where I haven't scattered seed.
Matthew 25:27 You could have at least put my money in the bank, so I could have earned interest on it.”
Matthew 25:28 Then the master said, “Now your money will be taken away and given to the servant with 10,000 coins!
Matthew 25:29 Everyone who has something will be given more, and they will have more than enough. But everything will be taken from those who don't have anything.
Matthew 25:30 You are a worthless servant, and you will be thrown out into the dark where people will cry and grit their teeth in pain.”
Matthew 25:31 When the Son of Man comes in his glory with all his angels, he will sit on his royal throne.
Matthew 25:32 The people of all nations will be brought before him, and he will separate them, as shepherds separate their sheep from their goats.
Matthew 25:33 He will place the sheep on his right and the goats on his left.
Matthew 25:34 Then the king will say to those on his right, “My father has blessed you! Come and receive the kingdom that was prepared for you before the world was created.
Matthew 25:35 When I was hungry, you gave me something to eat, and when I was thirsty, you gave me something to drink. When I was a stranger, you welcomed me,
Matthew 25:36 and when I was naked, you gave me clothes to wear. When I was sick, you took care of me, and when I was in jail, you visited me.”
Matthew 25:37 Then the ones who pleased the Lord will ask, “When did we give you something to eat or drink?
Matthew 25:38 When did we welcome you as a stranger or give you clothes to wear
Matthew 25:39 or visit you while you were sick or in jail?”
Matthew 25:40 The king will answer, “Whenever you did it for any of my people, no matter how unimportant they seemed, you did it for me.”
Matthew 25:41 Then the king will say to those on his left, “Get away from me! You are under God's curse. Go into the everlasting fire prepared for the devil and his angels!
Matthew 25:42 I was hungry, but you did not give me anything to eat, and I was thirsty, but you did not give me anything to drink.
Matthew 25:43 I was a stranger, but you did not welcome me, and I was naked, but you did not give me any clothes to wear. I was sick and in jail, but you did not take care of me.”
Matthew 25:44 Then the people will ask, “Lord, when did we fail to help you when you were hungry or thirsty or a stranger or naked or sick or in jail?”
Matthew 25:45 The king will say to them, “Whenever you failed to help any of my people, no matter how unimportant they seemed, you failed to do it for me.”
Matthew 25:46 Then Jesus said, “Those people will be punished forever. But the ones who pleased God will have eternal life.”
Matthew 26:1 When Jesus had finished teaching, he told his disciples,
Matthew 26:2 “You know two days from now will be Passover. This is when the Son of Man will be handed over to his enemies and nailed to a cross.”
Matthew 26:3 At that time the chief priests and the nation's leaders were meeting at the home of Caiaphas the high priest.
Matthew 26:4 They planned how they could sneak around and have Jesus arrested and put to death.
Matthew 26:5 But they said, “We must not do it during Passover, because the people will riot.”
Matthew 26:6 Jesus was in the town of Bethany, eating at the home of Simon, who had leprosy.
Matthew 26:7 A woman came in with a bottle of expensive perfume and poured it on Jesus' head.
Matthew 26:8 But when his disciples saw this, they became angry and complained, “Why such a waste?
Matthew 26:9 We could have sold this perfume for a lot of money and given it to the poor.”
Matthew 26:10 Jesus knew what they were thinking, and he said: Why are you bothering this woman? She has done a beautiful thing for me.
Matthew 26:11 You will always have the poor with you, but you won't always have me.
Matthew 26:12 She has poured perfume on my body to prepare it for burial.
Matthew 26:13 You may be sure that wherever the good news is told all over the world, people will remember what she has done. And they will tell others.
Matthew 26:14 Judas Iscariot was one of the twelve disciples. He went to the chief priests
Matthew 26:15 and asked, “How much will you give me if I help you arrest Jesus?” They paid Judas 30 silver coins,
Matthew 26:16 and from then on he started looking for a good chance to betray Jesus.
Matthew 26:17 On the first day of the Festival of Thin Bread, Jesus' disciples came to him and asked, “Where do you want us to prepare the Passover meal?”
Matthew 26:18 Jesus told them to go to a certain man in the city and tell him, “Our teacher says, ‘My time has come! I want to eat the Passover meal with my disciples in your home.’ ”
Matthew 26:19 They did as Jesus told them and prepared the meal.
Matthew 26:20+MAT When Jesus was eating with his twelve disciples that evening, he said, “One of you will surely hand me over to my enemies.”
Matthew 26:22 The disciples were very sad, and each one said to Jesus, “Lord, you can't mean me!”
Matthew 26:23 He answered, “One of you men who has eaten with me from this dish will betray me.
Matthew 26:24 The Son of Man will die, as the Scriptures say. But it's going to be terrible for the one who betrays me! That man would be better off if he had never been born.”
Matthew 26:25 Judas said, “Teacher, you surely don't mean me!” “That's what you say!” Jesus replied. But later, Judas did betray him.
Matthew 26:26 During the meal Jesus took some bread in his hands. He blessed the bread and broke it. Then he gave it to his disciples and said, “Take this and eat it. This is my body.”
Matthew 26:27 Jesus picked up a cup of wine and gave thanks to God. He then gave it to his disciples and said, “Take this and drink it.
Matthew 26:28 This is my blood, and with it God makes his agreement with you. It will be poured out, so that many people will have their sins forgiven.
Matthew 26:29 From now on I am not going to drink any wine, until I drink new wine with you in my Father's kingdom.”
Matthew 26:30 Then they sang a hymn and went out to the Mount of Olives.
Matthew 26:31 Jesus said to his disciples, “During this very night, all of you will reject me, as the Scriptures say, ‘I will strike down the shepherd, and the sheep will be scattered.’
Matthew 26:32 But after I am raised to life, I will go ahead of you to Galilee.”
Matthew 26:33 Peter spoke up, “Even if all the others reject you, I never will!”
Matthew 26:34 Jesus replied, “I promise you before a rooster crows tonight, you will say three times that you don't know me.”
Matthew 26:35 But Peter said, “Even if I have to die with you, I will never say I don't know you.” All the others said the same thing.
Matthew 26:36 Jesus went with his disciples to a place called Gethsemane. When they got there, he told them, “Sit here while I go over there and pray.”
Matthew 26:37 Jesus took along Peter and the two brothers, James and John. He was very sad and troubled,
Matthew 26:38 and he said to them, “I am so sad that I feel as if I am dying. Stay here and keep awake with me.”
Matthew 26:39 Jesus walked on a little way. Then he knelt with his face to the ground and prayed, “My Father, if it is possible, don't make me suffer by drinking from this cup. But do what you want, and not what I want.”
Matthew 26:40 He came back and found his disciples sleeping. So he said to Peter, “Can't any of you stay awake with me for just one hour?
Matthew 26:41 Stay awake and pray that you won't be tested. You want to do what is right, but you are weak.”
Matthew 26:42 Again Jesus went to pray and said, “My Father, if there is no other way, and I must suffer, I will still do what you want.”
Matthew 26:43 Jesus came back and found them sleeping again. They simply could not keep their eyes open.
Matthew 26:44 He left them and prayed the same prayer once more.
Matthew 26:45 Finally, Jesus returned to his disciples and said, “Are you still sleeping and resting? The time has come for the Son of Man to be handed over to sinners.
Matthew 26:46 Get up! Let's go. The one who will betray me is already here.”
Matthew 26:47 Jesus was still speaking, when Judas the betrayer came up. He was one of the twelve disciples, and a large mob armed with swords and clubs was with him. They had been sent by the chief priests and the nation's leaders.
Matthew 26:48 Judas had told them ahead of time, “Arrest the man I greet with a kiss.”
Matthew 26:49 Judas walked right up to Jesus and said, “Hello, teacher.” Then Judas kissed him.
Matthew 26:50 Jesus replied, “My friend, do what you came for.” The men grabbed Jesus and arrested him.
Matthew 26:51 One of Jesus' followers pulled out a sword. He struck the servant of the high priest and cut off his ear.
Matthew 26:52 But Jesus told him, “Put your sword away. Anyone who lives by fighting will die by fighting.
Matthew 26:53 Don't you know that I could ask my Father, and he would at once send me more than twelve armies of angels?
Matthew 26:54 But then, how could the words of the Scriptures come true, which say this must happen?”
Matthew 26:55 Jesus said to the mob, “Why do you come with swords and clubs to arrest me like a criminal? Day after day I sat and taught in the temple, and you didn't arrest me.
Matthew 26:56 But all this happened, so that what the prophets wrote would come true.” All Jesus' disciples left him and ran away.
Matthew 26:57 After Jesus had been arrested, he was led off to the house of Caiaphas the high priest. The nation's leaders and the teachers of the Law of Moses were meeting there.
Matthew 26:58 But Peter followed along at a distance and came to the courtyard of the high priest's palace. He went in and sat down with the guards to see what was going to happen.
Matthew 26:59 The chief priests and the whole council wanted to put Jesus to death. So they tried to find some people who would tell lies about him in court.
Matthew 26:60 But they could not find any, even though many did come and tell lies. At last, two men came forward
Matthew 26:61 and said, “This man claimed he could tear down God's temple and build it again in three days.”
Matthew 26:62 The high priest stood up and asked Jesus, “Why don't you say something in your own defense? Don't you hear the charges they are making against you?”
Matthew 26:63 But Jesus did not answer. So the high priest said, “With the living God looking on, you must tell the truth. Are you the Messiah, the Son of God?”
Matthew 26:64 “That is what you say!” Jesus answered. “But I tell all of you, ‘Soon you will see the Son of Man sitting at the right side of God All-Powerful and coming on the clouds of heaven.’ ”
Matthew 26:65 The high priest then tore his robe and said, “This man claims to be God! We don't need any more witnesses! You have heard what he said.
Matthew 26:66 What do you think?” They answered, “He is guilty and deserves to die!”
Matthew 26:67 Then they spit in his face and hit him with their fists. Others slapped him
Matthew 26:68 and said, “You think you are the Messiah! So tell us who hit you!”
Matthew 26:69 While Peter was sitting out in the courtyard, a servant girl came up to him and said, “You were with Jesus from Galilee.”
Matthew 26:70 But in front of everyone Peter said, “That isn't so! I don't know what you are talking about!”
Matthew 26:71 When Peter had gone out to the gate, another servant girl saw him and said to some people there, “This man was with Jesus from Nazareth.”
Matthew 26:72 Again Peter denied it, and this time he swore, “I don't even know that man!”
Matthew 26:73 A little while later some people standing there walked over to Peter and said, “We know you are one of them. We can tell it because you talk like someone from Galilee.”
Matthew 26:74 Peter began to curse and swear, “I don't know that man!” Right then a rooster crowed,
Matthew 26:75 and Peter remembered that Jesus had said, “Before a rooster crows, you will say three times you don't know me.” Then Peter went out and cried bitterly.
Matthew 27:1 Early the next morning all the chief priests and the nation's leaders met and decided that Jesus should be put to death.
Matthew 27:2 They tied him up and led him away to Pilate the governor.
Matthew 27:3 Judas had betrayed Jesus, but when he learned that Jesus had been sentenced to death, he was sorry for what he had done. He returned the 30 silver coins to the chief priests and leaders
Matthew 27:4 and said, “I have sinned by betraying a man who has never done anything wrong.” “So what? That's your problem,” they replied.
Matthew 27:5 Judas threw the money into the temple and then went out and hanged himself.
Matthew 27:6 The chief priests picked up the money and said, “This money was paid to have a man killed. We can't put it in the temple treasury.”
Matthew 27:7 Then they had a meeting and decided to buy a field that belonged to someone who made clay pots. They wanted to use it as a graveyard for foreigners.
Matthew 27:8 This is why people still call that place “Field of Blood.”
Matthew 27:9 So the words of the prophet Jeremiah came true, “They took the thirty silver coins, the price of a person among the people of Israel.
Matthew 27:10 They paid it for a potter's field, as the Lord had commanded me.”
Matthew 27:11 Jesus was brought before Pilate the governor, who asked him, “Are you the king of the Jews?” “Those are your words!” Jesus answered.
Matthew 27:12 And when the chief priests and leaders brought their charges against him, he did not say a thing.
Matthew 27:13 Pilate asked him, “Don't you hear what crimes they say you have done?”
Matthew 27:14 But Jesus did not say anything, and the governor was greatly amazed.
Matthew 27:15 During Passover the governor always freed a prisoner chosen by the people.
Matthew 27:16 At that time a well-known terrorist named Jesus Barabbas was in jail.
Matthew 27:17 So when the crowd came together, Pilate asked them, “Which prisoner do you want me to set free? Do you want Jesus Barabbas or Jesus who is called the Messiah?”
Matthew 27:18 Pilate knew the leaders had brought Jesus to him because they were jealous.
Matthew 27:19 While Pilate was judging the case, his wife sent him a message. It said, “Don't have anything to do with that innocent man. I have had nightmares because of him.”
Matthew 27:20 But the chief priests and the leaders convinced the crowds to ask for Barabbas to be set free and for Jesus to be killed.
Matthew 27:21 Pilate asked the crowd again, “Which of these two men do you want me to set free?” “Barabbas!” they shouted.
Matthew 27:22 Pilate asked them, “What am I to do with Jesus, who is called the Messiah?” They all yelled, “Nail him to a cross!”
Matthew 27:23 Pilate answered, “But what crime has he done?” “Nail him to a cross!” they yelled even louder.
Matthew 27:24 Pilate saw that there was nothing he could do and that the people were starting to riot. So he took some water and washed his hands in front of them and said, “I won't have anything to do with killing this man. You are the ones doing it!”
Matthew 27:25 Everyone answered, “We and our own families will take the blame for his death!”
Matthew 27:26 Pilate set Barabbas free. Then he ordered his soldiers to beat Jesus with a whip and nail him to a cross.
Matthew 27:27 The governor's soldiers led Jesus into the fortress and brought together the rest of the troops.
Matthew 27:28 They stripped off Jesus' clothes and put a scarlet robe on him.
Matthew 27:29 They made a crown out of thorn branches and placed it on his head, and they put a stick in his right hand. The soldiers knelt down and pretended to worship him. They made fun of him and shouted, “Hey, you king of the Jews!”
Matthew 27:30 Then they spit on him. They took the stick from him and beat him on the head with it.
Matthew 27:31 When the soldiers had finished making fun of Jesus, they took off the robe. They put his own clothes back on him and led him off to be nailed to a cross.
Matthew 27:32 On the way they met a man named Simon who was from Cyrene, and they forced him to carry Jesus' cross.
Matthew 27:33 They came to a place named Golgotha, which means “Place of a Skull.”
Matthew 27:34 There they gave Jesus some wine mixed with a drug to ease the pain. But when Jesus tasted what it was, he refused to drink it.
Matthew 27:35 The soldiers nailed Jesus to a cross and gambled to see who would get his clothes.
Matthew 27:36 Then they sat down to guard him.
Matthew 27:37 Above his head they put a sign that told why he was nailed there. It read, “This is Jesus, the King of the Jews.”
Matthew 27:38 The soldiers also nailed two criminals on crosses, one to the right of Jesus and the other to his left.
Matthew 27:39 People who passed by said terrible things about Jesus. They shook their heads and
Matthew 27:40 shouted, “So you're the one who claimed you could tear down the temple and build it again in three days! If you are God's Son, save yourself and come down from the cross!”
Matthew 27:41 The chief priests, the leaders, and the teachers of the Law of Moses also made fun of Jesus. They said,
Matthew 27:42 “He saved others, but he can't save himself. If he is the king of Israel, he should come down from the cross! Then we will believe him.
Matthew 27:43 He trusted God, so let God save him, if he wants to. He even said he was God's Son.”
Matthew 27:44 The two criminals also said cruel things to Jesus.
Matthew 27:45 At noon the sky turned dark and stayed that way until three o'clock.
Matthew 27:46 Then about that time Jesus shouted, “Eli, Eli, lema sabachthani?” which means, “My God, my God, why have you deserted me?”
Matthew 27:47 Some of the people standing there heard Jesus and said, “He's calling for Elijah.”
Matthew 27:48 One of them at once ran and grabbed a sponge. He soaked it in wine, then put it on a stick and held it up to Jesus.
Matthew 27:49 Others said, “Wait! Let's see if Elijah will come and save him.”
Matthew 27:50 Once again Jesus shouted, and then he died.
Matthew 27:51 At once the curtain in the temple was torn in two from top to bottom. The earth shook, and rocks split apart.
Matthew 27:52 Graves opened, and many of God's people were raised to life.
Matthew 27:53 They left their graves, and after Jesus had risen to life, they went into the holy city, where they were seen by many people.
Matthew 27:54 The officer and the soldiers guarding Jesus felt the earthquake and saw everything else that happened. They were frightened and said, “This man really was God's Son!”
Matthew 27:55 Many women had come with Jesus from Galilee to be of help to him, and they were there, looking on at a distance.
Matthew 27:56 Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James and Joseph, and the mother of James and John were some of these women.
Matthew 27:57 That evening a rich disciple named Joseph from the town of Arimathea
Matthew 27:58 went and asked for Jesus' body. Pilate gave orders for it to be given to Joseph,
Matthew 27:59 who took the body and wrapped it in a clean linen cloth.
Matthew 27:60 Then Joseph put the body in his own tomb that had been cut into solid rock and had never been used. He rolled a big stone against the entrance to the tomb and went away.
Matthew 27:61 All this time Mary Magdalene and the other Mary were sitting across from the tomb.
Matthew 27:62 On the next day, which was a Sabbath, the chief priests and the Pharisees went together to Pilate.
Matthew 27:63 They said, “Sir, we remember what this liar said while he was still alive. He claimed in three days he would come back from death.
Matthew 27:64 So please order the tomb to be carefully guarded for three days. If you don't, his disciples may come and steal his body. They will tell the people he has been raised to life, and this last lie will be worse than the first one.”
Matthew 27:65 Pilate said to them, “All right, take some of your soldiers and guard the tomb as well as you know how.”
Matthew 27:66 So they sealed it tight and placed soldiers there to guard it.
Matthew 28:1 The Sabbath was over, and it was almost daybreak on Sunday when Mary Magdalene and the other Mary went to see the tomb.
Matthew 28:2 Suddenly a strong earthquake struck, and the Lord's angel came down from heaven. He rolled away the stone and sat on it.
Matthew 28:3 The angel looked as bright as lightning, and his clothes were white as snow.
Matthew 28:4 The guards shook from fear and fell down, as though they were dead.
Matthew 28:5 The angel said to the women, “Don't be afraid! I know you are looking for Jesus, who was nailed to a cross.
Matthew 28:6 He isn't here! God has raised him to life, just as Jesus said he would. Come, see the place where his body was lying.
Matthew 28:7 Now hurry! Tell his disciples he has been raised to life and is on his way to Galilee. Go there, and you will see him. This is what I came to tell you.”
Matthew 28:8 The women were frightened and yet very happy, as they hurried from the tomb and ran to tell his disciples.
Matthew 28:9 Suddenly Jesus met them and greeted them. They went near him, held on to his feet, and worshiped him.
Matthew 28:10 Then Jesus said, “Don't be afraid! Tell my followers to go to Galilee. They will see me there.”
Matthew 28:11 While the women were on their way, some soldiers who had been guarding the tomb went into the city. They told the chief priests everything that had happened.
Matthew 28:12 So the chief priests met with the leaders and decided to bribe the soldiers with a lot of money.
Matthew 28:13 They said to the soldiers, “Tell everyone that Jesus' disciples came during the night and stole his body while you were asleep.
Matthew 28:14 If the governor hears about this, we will talk to him. You won't have anything to worry about.”
Matthew 28:15 The soldiers took the money and did what they were told. The people of Judea still tell each other this story.
Matthew 28:16 Jesus' eleven disciples went to a mountain in Galilee, where Jesus had told them to meet him.
Matthew 28:17 They saw him and worshiped him, but some of them doubted.
Matthew 28:18 Jesus came to them and said: I have been given all authority in heaven and on earth!
Matthew 28:19 Go to the people of all nations and make them my disciples. Baptize them in the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit,
Matthew 28:20 and teach them to do everything I have told you. I will be with you always, even until the end of the world.
Mark 1:1 This is the good news about Jesus Christ, the Son of God.
Mark 1:2 It began just as God had said in the book written by Isaiah the prophet, “I am sending my messenger to get the way ready for you.
Mark 1:3 In the desert someone is shouting, ‘Get the road ready for the Lord! Make a straight path for him.’ ”
Mark 1:4 So John the Baptist showed up in the desert and told everyone, “Turn back to God and be baptized! Then your sins will be forgiven.”
Mark 1:5 From all Judea and Jerusalem crowds of people went to John. They told how sorry they were for their sins, and he baptized them in the Jordan River.
Mark 1:6 John wore clothes made of camel's hair. He had a leather strap around his waist and ate grasshoppers and wild honey.
Mark 1:7 John also told the people, “Someone more powerful is going to come. And I am not good enough even to stoop down and untie his sandals.
Mark 1:8 I baptize you with water, but he will baptize you with the Holy Spirit!”
Mark 1:9 About that time Jesus came from Nazareth in Galilee, and John baptized him in the Jordan River.
Mark 1:10 As soon as Jesus came out of the water, he saw the sky open and the Holy Spirit coming down to him like a dove.
Mark 1:11 A voice from heaven said, “You are my own dear Son, and I am pleased with you.”
Mark 1:12 At once God's Spirit made Jesus go into the desert.
Mark 1:13 He stayed there for 40 days while Satan tested him. Jesus was with the wild animals, but angels took care of him.
Mark 1:14 After John was arrested, Jesus went to Galilee and told the good news that comes from God.
Mark 1:15 He said, “The time has come! God's kingdom will soon be here. Turn back to God and believe the good news!”
Mark 1:16 As Jesus was walking along the shore of Lake Galilee, he saw Simon and his brother Andrew. They were fishermen and were casting their nets into the lake.
Mark 1:17 Jesus said to them, “Follow me! I will teach you how to bring in people instead of fish.”
Mark 1:18 Right then the two brothers dropped their nets and went with him.
Mark 1:19 Jesus walked on and soon saw James and John, the sons of Zebedee. They were in a boat, mending their nets.
Mark 1:20 At once Jesus asked them to come with him. They left their father in the boat with the hired workers and went with him.
Mark 1:21 Jesus and his disciples went to the town of Capernaum. Then on the next Sabbath he went into the synagogue and started teaching.
Mark 1:22 Everyone was amazed at his teaching. He taught with authority, and not like the teachers of the Law of Moses.
Mark 1:23 Suddenly a man with an evil spirit in him entered the synagogue and yelled,
Mark 1:24 “Jesus from Nazareth, what do you want with us? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are! You are God's Holy One.”
Mark 1:25 Jesus told the evil spirit, “Be quiet and come out of the man!”
Mark 1:26 The spirit shook him. Then it gave a loud shout and left.
Mark 1:27 Everyone was completely surprised and kept saying to each other, “What is this? It must be some new kind of powerful teaching! Even the evil spirits obey him.”
Mark 1:28 News about Jesus quickly spread all over Galilee.
Mark 1:29 As soon as Jesus left the synagogue with James and John, they went home with Simon and Andrew.
Mark 1:30 When they got there, Jesus was told that Simon's mother-in-law was sick in bed with fever.
Mark 1:31 Jesus went to her. He took hold of her hand and helped her up. The fever left her, and she served them a meal.
Mark 1:32 That evening after sunset, all who were sick or had demons in them were brought to Jesus.
Mark 1:33 In fact, the whole town gathered around the door of the house.
Mark 1:34 Jesus healed all kinds of terrible diseases and forced out a lot of demons. But the demons knew who he was, and he did not let them speak.
Mark 1:35 Very early the next morning before daylight, Jesus got up and went to a place where he could be alone and pray.
Mark 1:36 Simon and the others started looking for him.
Mark 1:37 And when they found him, they said, “Everyone is looking for you!”
Mark 1:38 Jesus replied, “We must go to the nearby towns, so that I can tell the good news to those people. This is why I have come.”
Mark 1:39 Then Jesus went to their synagogues everywhere in Galilee, where he preached and forced out demons.
Mark 1:40 A man with leprosy came to Jesus and knelt down. He begged, “You have the power to make me well, if only you wanted to.”
Mark 1:41 Jesus felt sorry for the man. So he put his hand on him and said, “I want to! Now you are well.”
Mark 1:42 At once the man's leprosy disappeared, and he was well.
Mark 1:43 After Jesus strictly warned the man, he sent him on his way.
Mark 1:44 He said, “Don't tell anyone about this. Just go and show the priest that you are well. Then take a gift to the temple as Moses commanded, and everyone will know that you have been healed.”
Mark 1:45 The man talked about it so much and told so many people, that Jesus could no longer go openly into a town. He had to stay away from the towns, but people still came to him from everywhere.
Mark 2:1 Jesus went back to Capernaum, and a few days later people heard that he was at home.
Mark 2:2 Then so many of them came to the house that there wasn't even standing room left in front of the door. Jesus was still teaching
Mark 2:3 when four people came up, carrying a man on a mat because he could not walk.
Mark 2:4 But because of the crowd, they could not get him to Jesus. So they made a hole in the roof above him and let the man down in front of everyone.
Mark 2:5 When Jesus saw how much faith they had, he said to the man, “My friend, your sins are forgiven.”
Mark 2:6 Some of the teachers of the Law of Moses were sitting there. They started wondering,
Mark 2:7 “Why would he say such a thing? He must think he is God! Only God can forgive sins.”
Mark 2:8 At once, Jesus knew what they were thinking, and he said, “Why are you thinking such things?
Mark 2:9 Is it easier for me to tell this man his sins are forgiven or to tell him to get up and pick up his mat and go on home?
Mark 2:10 I will show you that the Son of Man has the right to forgive sins here on earth.” So Jesus said to the man,
Mark 2:11 “Get up! Pick up your mat and go on home.”
Mark 2:12 The man got right up. He picked up his mat and went out while everyone watched in amazement. They praised God and said, “We have never seen anything like this!”
Mark 2:13 Once again, Jesus went to the shore of Lake Galilee. A large crowd gathered around him, and he taught them.
Mark 2:14 As he walked along, he saw Levi, the son of Alphaeus. Levi was sitting at the place for paying taxes, and Jesus said to him, “Follow me!” So he got up and went with Jesus.
Mark 2:15 Later, Jesus and his disciples were having dinner at Levi's house. Many tax collectors and other sinners had become followers of Jesus, and they were also guests at the dinner.
Mark 2:16 Some of the teachers of the Law of Moses were Pharisees, and they saw Jesus eating with sinners and tax collectors. So they asked his disciples, “Why does he eat with tax collectors and sinners?”
Mark 2:17 Jesus heard them and answered, “Healthy people don't need a doctor, but sick people do. I didn't come to invite good people to be my followers. I came to invite sinners.”
Mark 2:18 The followers of John the Baptist and the Pharisees often went without eating. Some people came and asked Jesus, “Why do the followers of John and those of the Pharisees often go without eating, while your disciples never do?”
Mark 2:19 Jesus answered: The friends of a bridegroom don't go without eating while he is still with them.
Mark 2:20 But the time will come when he will be taken from them. Then they will go without eating.
Mark 2:21 No one patches old clothes by sewing on a piece of new cloth. The new piece would shrink and tear a bigger hole.
Mark 2:22 No one pours new wine into old wineskins. The wine would swell and burst the old skins. Then the wine would be lost, and the skins would be ruined. New wine must be put into new wineskins.
Mark 2:23 One Sabbath Jesus and his disciples were walking through some wheat fields. His disciples were picking grains of wheat as they went along.
Mark 2:24 Some Pharisees asked Jesus, “Why are your disciples picking grain on the Sabbath? They are not supposed to do that!”
Mark 2:25 Jesus answered, “Haven't you read what David did when he and his followers were hungry and in need?
Mark 2:26 It was during the time of Abiathar the high priest. David went into the house of God and ate the sacred loaves of bread that only priests are allowed to eat. He also gave some to his followers.”
Mark 2:27 Jesus finished by saying, “People were not made for the good of the Sabbath. The Sabbath was made for the good of people.
Mark 2:28 So the Son of Man is Lord over the Sabbath.”
Mark 3:1 The next time Jesus went into the synagogue, a man with a paralyzed hand was there.
Mark 3:2 The Pharisees wanted to accuse Jesus of doing something wrong, and they kept watching to see if Jesus would heal him on the Sabbath.
Mark 3:3 Jesus told the man to stand up where everyone could see him.
Mark 3:4 Then he asked, “On the Sabbath should we do good deeds or evil deeds? Should we save someone's life or destroy it?” But no one said a word.
Mark 3:5 Jesus was angry as he looked around at the people. Yet he felt sorry for them because they were so stubborn. Then he told the man, “Stretch out your hand.” He did, and his bad hand was healed.
Mark 3:6 The Pharisees left. And at once they started making plans with Herod's followers to kill Jesus.
Mark 3:7 Jesus led his disciples down to the shore of the lake. Large crowds followed him from Galilee, Judea,
