Luke 1:65 All the neighbors were frightened because of what had happened, and everywhere in the hill country people kept talking about these things.
Luke 1:66 Everyone who heard about this wondered what this child would grow up to be. They knew the Lord was with him.
Luke 1:67 The Holy Spirit came upon Zechariah, and he began to speak:
Luke 1:68 Praise the Lord, the God of Israel! He has come to save his people.
Luke 1:69 Our God has given us a mighty Savior from the family of David his servant.
Luke 1:70 Long ago the Lord promised by the words of his holy prophets
Luke 1:71 to save us from our enemies and from everyone who hates us.
Luke 1:72 God said he would be kind to our people and keep his sacred promise.
Luke 1:73 He told our ancestor Abraham
Luke 1:74 that he would rescue us from our enemies. Then we could serve him without fear,
Luke 1:75 by being holy and good as long as we live.
Luke 1:76 You, my son, will be called the prophet of God Most High. You will go ahead of the Lord to get everything ready for him.
Luke 1:77 You will tell his people that they can be saved when their sins are forgiven.
Luke 1:78 God's love and kindness will shine upon us like the sun that rises in the sky.
Luke 1:79 On us who live in the dark shadow of death this light will shine to guide us into a life of peace.
Luke 1:80 As John grew up, God's Spirit gave him great power. John lived in the desert until the time he was sent to the people of Israel.
Luke 2:1 About that time Emperor Augustus gave orders for the names of all the people to be listed in record books.
Luke 2:2 These first records were made when Quirinius was governor of Syria.
Luke 2:3 Everyone had to go to their own hometown to be listed.
Luke 2:4 So Joseph had to leave Nazareth in Galilee and go to Bethlehem in Judea. Long ago Bethlehem had been King David's hometown, and Joseph went there because he was from David's family.
Luke 2:5 Mary was engaged to Joseph and traveled with him to Bethlehem. She was soon going to have a baby,
Luke 2:6 and while they were there,
Luke 2:7 she gave birth to her first-born son. She dressed him in baby clothes and laid him on a bed of hay, because there was no room for them in the inn.
Luke 2:8 That night in the fields near Bethlehem some shepherds were guarding their sheep.
Luke 2:9 All at once an angel came down to them from the Lord, and the brightness of the Lord's glory flashed around them. The shepherds were frightened.
Luke 2:10 But the angel said, “Don't be afraid! I have good news for you, which will make everyone happy.
Luke 2:11 This very day in King David's hometown a Savior was born for you. He is Christ the Lord.
Luke 2:12 You will know who he is, because you will find him dressed in baby clothes and lying on a bed of hay.”
Luke 2:13 Suddenly many other angels came down from heaven and joined in praising God. They said:
Luke 2:14 “Praise God in heaven! Peace on earth to everyone who pleases God.”
Luke 2:15 After the angels had left and gone back to heaven, the shepherds said to each other, “Let's go to Bethlehem and see what the Lord has told us about.”
Luke 2:16 They hurried off and found Mary and Joseph, and they saw the baby lying on a bed of hay.
Luke 2:17 When the shepherds saw Jesus, they told his parents what the angel had said about him.
Luke 2:18 Everyone listened and was surprised.
Luke 2:19 But Mary kept thinking about all this and wondering what it meant.
Luke 2:20 As the shepherds returned to their sheep, they were praising God and saying wonderful things about him. Everything they had seen and heard was just as the angel had said.
Luke 2:21 Eight days later Jesus' parents did for him what the Law of Moses commands. And they named him Jesus, just as the angel had told Mary when he promised she would have a baby.
Luke 2:22 The time came for Mary and Joseph to do what the Law of Moses says a mother is supposed to do after her baby is born. They took Jesus to the temple in Jerusalem and presented him to the Lord,
Luke 2:23 just as the Law of the Lord says, “Each first-born baby boy belongs to the Lord.”
Luke 2:24 The Law of the Lord also says parents have to offer a sacrifice, giving at least a pair of doves or two young pigeons. So that is what Mary and Joseph did.
Luke 2:25 At this time a man named Simeon was living in Jerusalem. Simeon was a good man. He loved God and was waiting for him to save the people of Israel. God's Spirit came to him
Luke 2:26 and told him that he would not die until he had seen Christ the Lord.
Luke 2:27 When Mary and Joseph brought Jesus to the temple to do what the Law of Moses says should be done for a new baby, the Spirit told Simeon to go into the temple.
Luke 2:28 Simeon took the baby Jesus in his arms and praised God,
Luke 2:29 “Lord, I am your servant, and now I can die in peace, because you have kept your promise to me.
Luke 2:30 With my own eyes I have seen what you have done to save your people,
Luke 2:31 and foreign nations will also see this.
Luke 2:32 Your mighty power is a light for all nations, and it will bring honor to your people Israel.”
Luke 2:33 Jesus' parents were surprised at what Simeon had said.
Luke 2:34 Then he blessed them and told Mary, “This child of yours will cause many people in Israel to fall and others to stand. The child will be like a warning sign. Many people will reject him,
Luke 2:35 and you, Mary, will suffer as though you had been stabbed by a dagger. But all this will show what people are really thinking.”
Luke 2:36 The prophet Anna was also there in the temple. She was the daughter of Phanuel from the tribe of Asher, and she was very old. In her youth she had been married for seven years, but her husband died.
Luke 2:37 And now she was 84 years old. Night and day she served God in the temple by praying and often going without eating.
Luke 2:38 At this time Anna came in and praised God. She spoke about the child Jesus to everyone who hoped for Jerusalem to be set free.
Luke 2:39 After Joseph and Mary had done everything that the Law of the Lord commands, they returned home to Nazareth in Galilee.
Luke 2:40 The child Jesus grew. He became strong and wise, and God blessed him.
Luke 2:41 Every year Jesus' parents went to Jerusalem for Passover.
Luke 2:42 And when Jesus was twelve years old, they all went there as usual for the celebration.
Luke 2:43 After Passover his parents left, but they did not know that Jesus had stayed on in the city.
Luke 2:44 They thought he was traveling with some other people, and they went a whole day before they started looking for him.
Luke 2:45 When they could not find him with their relatives and friends, they went back to Jerusalem and started looking for him there.
Luke 2:46 Three days later they found Jesus sitting in the temple, listening to the teachers and asking them questions.
Luke 2:47 Everyone who heard him was surprised at how much he knew and at the answers he gave.
Luke 2:48 When his parents found him, they were amazed. His mother said, “Son, why have you done this to us? Your father and I have been very worried, and we have been searching for you!”
Luke 2:49 Jesus answered, “Why did you have to look for me? Didn't you know that I would be in my Father's house?”
Luke 2:50 But they did not understand what he meant.
Luke 2:51 Jesus went back to Nazareth with his parents and obeyed them. His mother kept on thinking about all that had happened.
Luke 2:52 Jesus became wise, and he grew strong. God was pleased with him and so were the people.
Luke 3:1 For 15 years Emperor Tiberius had ruled that part of the world. Pontius Pilate was governor of Judea, and Herod was the ruler of Galilee. Herod's brother, Philip, was the ruler in the countries of Iturea and Trachonitis, and Lysanias was the ruler of Abilene.
Luke 3:2 Annas and Caiaphas were the Jewish high priests. At that time God spoke to Zechariah's son John, who was living in the desert.
Luke 3:3 So John went along the Jordan Valley, telling the people, “Turn back to God and be baptized! Then your sins will be forgiven.”
Luke 3:4 Isaiah the prophet wrote about John when he said, “In the desert someone is shouting, ‘Get the road ready for the Lord! Make a straight path for him.
Luke 3:5 Fill up every valley and level every mountain and hill. Straighten the crooked paths and smooth out the rough roads.
Luke 3:6 Then everyone will see the saving power of God.’ ”
Luke 3:7 Crowds of people came out to be baptized, but John said to them, “You bunch of snakes! Who warned you to run from the coming judgment?
Luke 3:8 Do something to show that you really have given up your sins. Don't start saying you belong to Abraham's family. God can turn these stones into children for Abraham.
Luke 3:9 An ax is ready to cut the trees down at their roots. Any tree that doesn't produce good fruit will be cut down and thrown into a fire.”
Luke 3:10 The crowds asked John, “What should we do?”
Luke 3:11 John told them, “If you have two coats, give one to someone who doesn't have any. If you have food, share it with someone else.”
Luke 3:12 When tax collectors came to be baptized, they asked John, “Teacher, what should we do?”
Luke 3:13 John told them, “Don't make people pay more than they owe.”
Luke 3:14 Some soldiers asked him, “And what about us? What do we have to do?” John told them, “Don't force people to pay money to make you leave them alone. Be satisfied with your pay.”
Luke 3:15 Everyone became excited and wondered, “Could John be the Messiah?”
Luke 3:16 John said, “I am just baptizing with water. But someone more powerful is going to come, and I am not good enough even to untie his sandals. He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and with fire.
Luke 3:17 His threshing fork is in his hand, and he is ready to separate the wheat from the husks. He will store the wheat in his barn and burn the husks with a fire that never goes out.”
Luke 3:18 In many different ways John preached the good news to the people.
Luke 3:19 But to Herod the ruler, he said, “It was wrong for you to take Herodias, your brother's wife.” John also said Herod had done many other bad things.
Luke 3:20 Finally, Herod put John in jail, and this was the worst thing he had done.
Luke 3:21 While everyone else was being baptized, Jesus himself was baptized. Then as he prayed, the sky opened up,
Luke 3:22 and the Holy Spirit came down upon him in the form of a dove. A voice from heaven said, “You are my own dear Son, and I am pleased with you.”
Luke 3:23 When Jesus began to preach, he was about 30 years old. Everyone thought he was the son of Joseph. But his family went back through Heli,
Luke 3:24 Matthat, Levi, Melchi, Jannai, Joseph,
Luke 3:25 Mattathias, Amos, Nahum, Esli, Naggai,
Luke 3:26 Maath, Mattathias, Semein, Josech, Joda;
Luke 3:27 Joanan, Rhesa, Zerubbabel, Shealtiel, Neri,
Luke 3:28 Melchi, Addi, Cosam, Elmadam, Er,
Luke 3:29 Joshua, Eliezer, Jorim, Matthat, Levi;
Luke 3:30 Simeon, Judah, Joseph, Jonam, Eliakim,
Luke 3:31 Melea, Menna, Mattatha, Nathan, David,
Luke 3:32 Jesse, Obed, Boaz, Salmon, Nahshon;
Luke 3:33 Amminadab, Admin, Arni, Hezron, Perez, Judah,
Luke 3:34 Jacob, Isaac, Abraham, Terah, Nahor,
Luke 3:35 Serug, Reu, Peleg, Eber, Shelah;
Luke 3:36 Cainan, Arphaxad, Shem, Noah, Lamech,
Luke 3:37 Methuselah, Enoch, Jared, Mahalaleel, Kenan,
Luke 3:38 Enosh, and Seth. The family of Jesus went all the way back to Adam and then to God.
Luke 4:1 When Jesus returned from the Jordan River, the power of the Holy Spirit was with him, and the Spirit led him into the desert.
Luke 4:2 For 40 days Jesus was tested by the devil, and during that time he went without eating. When it was all over, he was hungry.
Luke 4:3 The devil said to Jesus, “If you are God's Son, tell this stone to turn into bread.”
Luke 4:4 Jesus answered, “The Scriptures say, ‘No one can live only on food.’ ”
Luke 4:5 Then the devil led Jesus up to a high place and quickly showed him all the nations on earth.
Luke 4:6 The devil said, “I will give all this power and glory to you. It has been given to me, and I can give it to anyone I want to.
Luke 4:7 Just worship me, and you can have it all.”
Luke 4:8 Jesus answered, “The Scriptures say: ‘Worship the Lord your God and serve only him!’ ”
Luke 4:9 Finally, the devil took Jesus to Jerusalem and had him stand on top of the temple. The devil said, “If you are God's Son, jump off.
Luke 4:10+LUK The Scriptures say: ‘God will tell his angels to take care of you. They will catch you in their arms, and you will not even hurt your feet on the stones.’ ”
Luke 4:12 Jesus answered, “The Scriptures also say, ‘Don't try to test the Lord your God!’ ”
Luke 4:13 After the devil had finished testing Jesus in every way possible, he left him for a while.
Luke 4:14 Jesus returned to Galilee with the power of the Spirit. News about him spread everywhere.
Luke 4:15 He taught in the Jewish synagogues, and everyone praised him.
Luke 4:16 Jesus went back to Nazareth, where he had been brought up, and as usual he went to the synagogue on the Sabbath. When he stood up to read from the Scriptures,
Luke 4:17 he was given the book of Isaiah the prophet. He opened it and read,
Luke 4:18 “The Lord's Spirit has come to me, because he has chosen me to tell the good news to the poor. The Lord has sent me to announce freedom for prisoners, to give sight to the blind, to free everyone who suffers,
Luke 4:19 and to say, ‘This is the year the Lord has chosen.’ ”
Luke 4:20 Jesus closed the book, then handed it back to the man in charge and sat down. Everyone in the synagogue looked straight at Jesus.
Luke 4:21 Then Jesus said to them, “What you have just heard me read has come true today.”
Luke 4:22 All the people started talking about Jesus and were amazed at the wonderful things he said. They kept on asking, “Isn't he Joseph's son?”
Luke 4:23 Jesus answered: You will certainly want to tell me this saying, “Doctor, first make yourself well.” You will tell me to do the same things here in my own hometown that you heard I did in Capernaum.
Luke 4:24 But you can be sure that no prophets are liked by the people of their own hometown.
Luke 4:25 Once during the time of Elijah there was no rain for three and a half years, and people everywhere were starving. There were many widows in Israel,
Luke 4:26 but Elijah was sent only to a widow in the town of Zarephath near the city of Sidon.
Luke 4:27 During the time of the prophet Elisha, many men in Israel had leprosy. But no one was healed, except Naaman who lived in Syria.
Luke 4:28 When the people in the synagogue heard Jesus say this, they became so angry
Luke 4:29 that they got up and threw him out of town. They dragged him to the edge of the cliff on which the town was built, because they wanted to throw him down from there.
Luke 4:30 But Jesus slipped through the crowd and got away.
Luke 4:31 Jesus went to the town of Capernaum in Galilee and taught the people on the Sabbath.
Luke 4:32 His teaching amazed them because he spoke with power.
Luke 4:33 There in the synagogue was a man with an evil spirit. He yelled out,
Luke 4:34 “Hey, Jesus of Nazareth, what do you want with us? Are you here to get rid of us? I know who you are! You are God's Holy One.”
Luke 4:35 Jesus ordered the evil spirit to be quiet and come out. The demon threw the man to the ground in front of everyone and left without harming him.
Luke 4:36 They all were amazed and kept saying to each other, “What kind of teaching is this? He has power to order evil spirits out of people!”
Luke 4:37 News about Jesus spread all over that part of the country.
Luke 4:38 Jesus left the synagogue and went to Simon's home. When Jesus got there, he was told that Simon's mother-in-law was sick with a high fever.
Luke 4:39 So Jesus went over to her and ordered the fever to go away. Right then she was able to get up and serve them a meal.
Luke 4:40 After the sun had set, people with all kinds of diseases were brought to Jesus. He put his hands on each one of them and healed them.
Luke 4:41 Demons went out of many people and shouted, “You are the Son of God!” But Jesus ordered the demons not to speak because they knew he was the Messiah.
Luke 4:42 The next morning Jesus went out to a place where he could be alone, and crowds came looking for him. When they found him, they tried to stop him from leaving.
Luke 4:43 But Jesus said, “People in other towns must hear the good news about God's kingdom. This is why I was sent.”
Luke 4:44 So he kept on preaching in the synagogues in Judea.
Luke 5:1 Jesus was standing on the shore of Lake Gennesaret, teaching the people as they crowded around him to hear God's message.
Luke 5:2 Near the shore he saw two boats left there by some fishermen who had gone to wash their nets.
Luke 5:3 Jesus got into the boat that belonged to Simon and asked him to row it out a little way from the shore. Then Jesus sat down in the boat to teach the crowd.
Luke 5:4 When Jesus had finished speaking, he told Simon, “Row the boat out into the deep water and let your nets down to catch some fish.”
Luke 5:5 “Master,” Simon answered, “we have worked hard all night long and have not caught a thing. But if you tell me to, I will let the nets down.”
Luke 5:6 They did this and caught so many fish that their nets began ripping apart.
Luke 5:7 Then they signaled for their partners in the other boat to come and help them. The men came, and together they filled the two boats so full that they both began to sink.
Luke 5:8 When Simon Peter saw this happen, he knelt down in front of Jesus and said, “Lord, don't come near me! I am a sinner.”
Luke 5:9 Peter and everyone with him were completely surprised at all the fish they had caught.
Luke 5:10 His partners James and John, the sons of Zebedee, were surprised too. Jesus told Simon, “Don't be afraid! From now on you will bring in people instead of fish.”
Luke 5:11 The men pulled their boats up on the shore. Then they left everything and went with Jesus.
Luke 5:12 Jesus came to a town where there was a man who had leprosy. When the man saw Jesus, he knelt down to the ground in front of Jesus and begged, “Lord, you have the power to make me well, if only you wanted to.”
Luke 5:13 Jesus put his hand on him and said, “I want to! Now you are well.” At once the man's leprosy disappeared.
Luke 5:14 Jesus told him, “Don't tell anyone about this, but go and show yourself to the priest. Offer a gift to the priest, just as Moses commanded, and everyone will know that you have been healed.”
Luke 5:15 News about Jesus kept spreading. Large crowds came to listen to him teach and to be healed of their diseases.
Luke 5:16 But Jesus would often go to some place where he could be alone and pray.
Luke 5:17 One day some Pharisees and experts in the Law of Moses sat listening to Jesus teach. They had come from every village in Galilee and Judea and from Jerusalem. God had given Jesus the power to heal the sick,
Luke 5:18 and some people came carrying a man on a mat because he could not walk. They tried to take him inside the house and put him in front of Jesus.
Luke 5:19 But because of the crowd, they could not get him to Jesus. So they went up on the roof, where they removed some tiles and let the mat down in the middle of the room.
Luke 5:20 When Jesus saw how much faith they had, he said to the man, “My friend, your sins are forgiven.”
Luke 5:21 The Pharisees and the experts began arguing, “Jesus must think he is God! Only God can forgive sins.”
Luke 5:22 Jesus knew what they were thinking, and he said, “Why are you thinking this?
Luke 5:23 Is it easier for me to tell this man that his sins are forgiven or to tell him to get up and walk?
Luke 5:24 But now you will see that the Son of Man has the right to forgive sins here on earth.” Jesus then said to the man, “Get up! Pick up your mat and walk home.”
Luke 5:25 At once the man stood up in front of everyone. He picked up his mat and went home, giving thanks to God.
Luke 5:26 Everyone was amazed and praised God. What they saw surprised them, and they said, “We have seen a great miracle today!”
Luke 5:27 Later, Jesus went out and saw a tax collector named Levi sitting at the place for paying taxes. Jesus said to him, “Follow me.”
Luke 5:28 Levi left everything and went with Jesus.
Luke 5:29 In his home Levi gave a big dinner for Jesus. Many tax collectors and other guests were also there.
Luke 5:30 The Pharisees and some of their teachers of the Law of Moses grumbled to Jesus' disciples, “Why do you eat and drink with these tax collectors and other sinners?”
Luke 5:31 Jesus answered, “Healthy people don't need a doctor, but sick people do.
Luke 5:32 I didn't come to invite good people to turn to God. I came to invite sinners.”
Luke 5:33 Some people said to Jesus, “John's followers often pray and go without eating, and so do the followers of the Pharisees. But your disciples never go without eating or drinking.”
Luke 5:34 Jesus told them, “The friends of a bridegroom don't go without eating while he is still with them.
Luke 5:35 But the time will come when he will be taken from them. Then they will go without eating.”
Luke 5:36 Jesus then told them these sayings: No one uses a new piece of cloth to patch old clothes. The patch would shrink and make the hole even bigger.
Luke 5:37 No one pours new wine into old wineskins. The new wine would swell and burst the old skins. Then the wine would be lost, and the skins would be ruined.
Luke 5:38 New wine must be put only into new wineskins.
Luke 5:39 No one wants new wine after drinking old wine. They say, “The old wine is better.”
Luke 6:1 One Sabbath when Jesus and his disciples were walking through some wheat fields, the disciples picked some wheat. They rubbed the husks off with their hands and started eating the grain.
Luke 6:2 Some Pharisees said, “Why are you picking grain on the Sabbath? You're not supposed to do that!”
Luke 6:3 Jesus answered, “You surely have read what David did when he and his followers were hungry.
Luke 6:4 He went into the house of God and took the sacred loaves of bread that only priests were supposed to eat. He not only ate some himself, but even gave some to his followers.”
Luke 6:5 Jesus finished by saying, “The Son of Man is Lord over the Sabbath.”
Luke 6:6 On another Sabbath Jesus was teaching in a synagogue, and a man with a paralyzed right hand was there.
Luke 6:7 Some Pharisees and teachers of the Law of Moses kept watching Jesus to see if he would heal the man. They did this because they wanted to accuse Jesus of doing something wrong.
Luke 6:8 Jesus knew what they were thinking, so he told the man to stand up where everyone could see him. And the man stood up.
Luke 6:9 Then Jesus asked, “On the Sabbath should we do good deeds or evil deeds? Should we save someone's life or destroy it?”
Luke 6:10 After he had looked around at everyone, he told the man, “Stretch out your hand.” He did, and his bad hand became completely well.
Luke 6:11 The teachers and the Pharisees were furious and started saying to one another, “What can we do about Jesus?”
Luke 6:12 About that time Jesus went off to a mountain to pray, and he spent the whole night there.
Luke 6:13 The next morning he called his disciples together and chose twelve of them to be his apostles.
Luke 6:14 One was Simon, and Jesus named him Peter. Another was Andrew, Peter's brother. There were also James, John, Philip, Bartholomew,
Luke 6:15 Matthew, Thomas, and James the son of Alphaeus. The rest of the apostles were Simon, known as the Eager One,
Luke 6:16 Jude, who was the son of James, and Judas Iscariot, who later betrayed Jesus.
Luke 6:17 Jesus and his apostles went down from the mountain and came to some flat, level ground. Many other disciples were there to meet him. Large crowds of people from all over Judea, Jerusalem, and the coastal towns of Tyre and Sidon were there too.
Luke 6:18 These people had come to listen to Jesus and to be healed of their diseases. All who were troubled by evil spirits were also healed.
Luke 6:19 Everyone was trying to touch Jesus, because power was going out from him and healing them all.
Luke 6:20 Jesus looked at his disciples and said: God will bless you people who are poor. His kingdom belongs to you!
Luke 6:21 God will bless you hungry people. You will have plenty to eat! God will bless you people who are now crying. You will laugh!
Luke 6:22 God will bless you when others hate you and won't have anything to do with you. God will bless you when people insult you and say cruel things about you, all because you are a follower of the Son of Man.
Luke 6:23 Long ago your own people did these same things to the prophets. So when this happens to you, be happy and jump for joy! You will have a great reward in heaven.
Luke 6:24 But you rich people are in for trouble. You have already had an easy life!
Luke 6:25 You well-fed people are in for trouble. You will go hungry! You people who are laughing now are in for trouble. You are going to cry and weep!
Luke 6:26 You are in for trouble when everyone says good things about you. That is what your own people said about those prophets who told lies.
Luke 6:27 This is what I say to all who will listen to me: Love your enemies, and be good to everyone who hates you.
Luke 6:28 Ask God to bless anyone who curses you, and pray for everyone who is cruel to you.
Luke 6:29 If someone slaps you on one cheek, don't stop that person from slapping you on the other cheek. If someone wants to take your coat, don't try to keep back your shirt.
Luke 6:30 Give to everyone who asks and don't ask people to return what they have taken from you.
Luke 6:31 Treat others just as you want to be treated.
Luke 6:32 If you love only someone who loves you, will God praise you for that? Even sinners love people who love them.
Luke 6:33 If you are kind only to someone who is kind to you, will God be pleased with you for that? Even sinners are kind to people who are kind to them.
Luke 6:34 If you lend money only to someone you think will pay you back, will God be pleased with you for that? Even sinners lend to sinners because they think they will get it all back.
Luke 6:35 But love your enemies and be good to them. Lend without expecting to be paid back. Then you will get a great reward, and you will be the true children of God in heaven. He is good even to people who are unthankful and cruel.
Luke 6:36 Have pity on others, just as your Father has pity on you.
Luke 6:37 Jesus said: Don't judge others, and God won't judge you. Don't be hard on others, and God won't be hard on you. Forgive others, and God will forgive you.
Luke 6:38 If you give to others, you will be given a full amount in return. It will be packed down, shaken together, and spilling over into your lap. The way you treat others is the way you will be treated.
Luke 6:39 Jesus also used some sayings as he spoke to the people. He said: Can one blind person lead another blind person? Won't they both fall into a ditch?
Luke 6:40 Are students better than their teacher? But when they are fully trained, they will be like their teacher.
Luke 6:41 You can see the speck in your friend's eye, but you don't notice the log in your own eye.
Luke 6:42 How can you say, “My friend, let me take the speck out of your eye,” when you don't see the log in your own eye? You show-offs! First, get the log out of your own eye; then you can see how to take the speck out of your friend's eye.
Luke 6:43 A good tree cannot produce bad fruit, and a bad tree cannot produce good fruit.
Luke 6:44 You can tell what a tree is like by the fruit it produces. You cannot pick figs or grapes from thornbushes.
Luke 6:45 Good people do good things because of the good in their hearts, but bad people do bad things because of the evil in their hearts. Your words show what is in your heart.
Luke 6:46 Why do you keep on saying that I am your Lord, when you refuse to do what I say?
Luke 6:47 Anyone who comes and listens to me and obeys me
Luke 6:48 is like someone who dug down deep and built a house on solid rock. When a flood came and the river rushed against the house, it was built so well that it didn't even shake.
Luke 6:49 But anyone who hears what I say and doesn't obey me is like someone whose house wasn't built on solid rock. As soon as the river rushed against that house, it was smashed to pieces!
Luke 7:1 After Jesus had finished teaching the people, he went to Capernaum.
Luke 7:2 In this town an army officer's servant was sick and about to die. The officer liked his servant very much.
Luke 7:3 And when he heard about Jesus, he sent some Jewish leaders to ask him to come and heal the servant.
Luke 7:4 The leaders went to Jesus and begged him to do something. They said, “This man deserves your help!
Luke 7:5 He loves our nation and even built us a synagogue.”
Luke 7:6 So Jesus went with them. When Jesus wasn't far from the house, the officer sent some friends to tell him, “Lord, don't go to any trouble for me! I am not good enough for you to come into my house.
Luke 7:7 And I am certainly not worthy to come to you. Just say the word, and my servant will get well.
Luke 7:8 I have officers who give orders to me, and I have soldiers who take orders from me. I can say to one of them, ‘Go!’ and he goes. I can say to another, ‘Come!’ and he comes. I can say to my servant, ‘Do this!’ and he will do it.”
Luke 7:9 When Jesus heard this, he was so surprised that he turned and said to the crowd following him, “In all of Israel I've never found anyone with this much faith!”
Luke 7:10 The officer's friends returned and found the servant well.
Luke 7:11 Soon Jesus and his disciples were on their way to the town of Nain, and a big crowd was going along with them.
Luke 7:12 As they came near the gate of the town, they saw people carrying out the body of a widow's only son. Many people from the town were walking along with her.
Luke 7:13 When the Lord saw the woman, he felt sorry for her and said, “Don't cry!”
Luke 7:14 Jesus went over and touched the stretcher on which the people were carrying the dead boy. They stopped, and Jesus said, “Young man, get up!”
Luke 7:15 The boy sat up and began to speak. Jesus then gave him back to his mother.
Luke 7:16 Everyone was frightened and praised God. They said, “A great prophet is here with us! God has come to his people.”
Luke 7:17 News about Jesus spread all over Judea and everywhere else in that part of the country.
Luke 7:18+LUK John's followers told John everything that was being said about Jesus. So he sent two of them to ask the Lord, “Are you the one we should be looking for? Or must we wait for someone else?”
Luke 7:20 When these messengers came to Jesus, they said, “John the Baptist sent us to ask, ‘Are you the one we should be looking for? Or are we supposed to wait for someone else?’ ”
Luke 7:21 At that time Jesus was healing many people who were sick or in pain or were troubled by evil spirits, and he was giving sight to a lot of blind people.
Luke 7:22 Jesus said to the messengers sent by John, “Go and tell John what you have seen and heard. Blind people are now able to see, and the lame can walk. People who have leprosy are being healed, and the deaf can now hear. The dead are raised to life, and the poor are hearing the good news.
Luke 7:23 God will bless everyone who doesn't reject me because of what I do.”
Luke 7:24 After John's messengers had gone, Jesus began speaking to the crowds about John: What kind of person did you go out to the desert to see? Was he like tall grass blown about by the wind?
Luke 7:25 What kind of man did you really go out to see? Was he someone dressed in fine clothes? People who wear expensive clothes and live in luxury are in the king's palace.
Luke 7:26 What then did you go out to see? Was he a prophet? He certainly was! I tell you that he was more than a prophet.
Luke 7:27 In the Scriptures, God calls John his messenger and says, “I am sending my messenger ahead of you to get things ready for you.”
Luke 7:28 No one ever born on this earth is greater than John. But whoever is least important in God's kingdom is greater than John.
Luke 7:29 Everyone had been listening to John. Even the tax collectors had obeyed God and had done what was right by letting John baptize them.
Luke 7:30 But the Pharisees and the experts in the Law of Moses refused to obey God and be baptized by John.
Luke 7:31 Jesus went on to say: What are you people like? What kind of people are you?
Luke 7:32 You are like children sitting in the market and shouting to each other, “We played the flute, but you would not dance! We sang a funeral song, but you would not cry!”
Luke 7:33 John the Baptist did not go around eating and drinking, and you said, “John has a demon in him!”
Luke 7:34 But because the Son of Man goes around eating and drinking, you say, “Jesus eats and drinks too much! He is even a friend of tax collectors and sinners.”
Luke 7:35 Yet Wisdom is shown to be right by what its followers do.
Luke 7:36 A Pharisee invited Jesus to have dinner with him. So Jesus went to the Pharisee's home and got ready to eat.
Luke 7:37 When a sinful woman in that town found out that Jesus was there, she bought an expensive bottle of perfume.
Luke 7:38 Then she came and stood behind Jesus. She cried and started washing his feet with her tears and drying them with her hair. The woman kissed his feet and poured the perfume on them.
Luke 7:39 The Pharisee who had invited Jesus saw this and said to himself, “If this man really were a prophet, he would know what kind of woman is touching him! He would know that she is a sinner.”
Luke 7:40 Jesus said to the Pharisee, “Simon, I have something to say to you.” “Teacher, what is it?” Simon replied.
Luke 7:41 Jesus told him, “Two people were in debt to a moneylender. One of them owed him 500 silver coins, and the other owed him 50.
Luke 7:42 Since neither of them could pay him back, the moneylender said that they didn't have to pay him anything. Which one of them will like him more?”
Luke 7:43 Simon answered, “I suppose it would be the one who had owed more and didn't have to pay it back.” “You are right,” Jesus said.
Luke 7:44 He turned toward the woman and said to Simon, “Have you noticed this woman? When I came into your home, you didn't give me any water so I could wash my feet. But she has washed my feet with her tears and dried them with her hair.
Luke 7:45 You didn't greet me with a kiss, but from the time I came in, she has not stopped kissing my feet.
Luke 7:46 You didn't even pour olive oil on my head, but she has poured expensive perfume on my feet.
Luke 7:47 So I tell you that all her sins are forgiven, and that is why she has shown great love. But anyone who has been forgiven for only a little will show only a little love.”
Luke 7:48 Then Jesus said to the woman, “Your sins are forgiven.”
Luke 7:49 Some other guests started saying to one another, “Who is this who dares to forgive sins?”
Luke 7:50 But Jesus told the woman, “Because of your faith, you are now saved. May God give you peace!”
Luke 8:1 Soon after this, Jesus was going through towns and villages, telling the good news about God's kingdom. His twelve apostles were with him,
Luke 8:2 and so were some women who had been healed of evil spirits and all sorts of diseases. One of the women was Mary Magdalene, who once had seven demons in her.
Luke 8:3 Joanna, Susanna, and many others had also used what they owned to help Jesus and his disciples. Joanna's husband Chuza was one of Herod's officials.
Luke 8:4 When a large crowd from several towns had gathered around Jesus, he told them this story:
Luke 8:5 A farmer went out to scatter seed in a field. While the farmer was doing this, some of the seeds fell along the road and were stepped on or eaten by birds.
Luke 8:6 Other seeds fell on rocky ground and started growing. But the plants did not have enough water and soon dried up.
Luke 8:7 Some other seeds fell where thornbushes grew up and choked the plants.
Luke 8:8 The rest of the seeds fell on good ground where they grew and produced a hundred times as many seeds. When Jesus had finished speaking, he said, “If you have ears, pay attention!”
Luke 8:9 Jesus' disciples asked him what the story meant.
Luke 8:10 So he answered: I have explained the secrets about God's kingdom to you. But for others I use stories, so they will look, but not see, and they will hear, but not understand.
Luke 8:11 This is what the story means: The seed is God's message,
Luke 8:12 and the seeds that fell along the road are the people who hear the message. But the devil comes and snatches the message out of their hearts, so they will not believe and be saved.
Luke 8:13 The seeds that fell on rocky ground are the people who gladly hear the message and accept it. But they don't have deep roots, and they believe only for a little while. As soon as life gets hard, they give up.
Luke 8:14 The seeds that fell among the thornbushes are also people who hear the message. But they are so eager for riches and pleasures that they never produce anything.
Luke 8:15 Those seeds that fell on good ground are the people who listen to the message and keep it in good and honest hearts. They last and produce a harvest.
Luke 8:16 No one lights a lamp and puts it under a bowl or under a bed. A lamp is always put on a lampstand, so people who come into a house will see the light.
Luke 8:17 There is nothing hidden that will not be found. There is no secret that will not be well known.
Luke 8:18 Pay attention to how you listen! Everyone who has something will be given more, but people who have nothing will lose what little they think they have.
Luke 8:19 Jesus' mother and brothers went to see him, but because of the crowd they could not get near him.
Luke 8:20 Someone told Jesus, “Your mother and brothers are standing outside and want to see you.”
Luke 8:21 Jesus answered, “My mother and my brothers are those people who hear and obey God's message.”
Luke 8:22 One day, Jesus and his disciples got into a boat, and he said, “Let's cross the lake.” They started out,
Luke 8:23 and while they were sailing across, he went to sleep. Suddenly a storm struck the lake, and the boat started sinking. They were in danger.
Luke 8:24 So they went to Jesus and woke him up, “Master, Master! We are about to drown!” Jesus got up and ordered the wind and waves to stop. They obeyed, and everything was calm.
Luke 8:25 Then Jesus asked the disciples, “Don't you have any faith?” But they were frightened and amazed. They said to each other, “Who is this? He can give orders to the wind and the waves, and they obey him!”
Luke 8:26 Jesus and his disciples sailed across Lake Galilee and came to shore near the town of Gerasa.
Luke 8:27 As Jesus was getting out of the boat, he was met by a man from this town. The man had demons in him. He had gone naked for a long time and no longer lived in a house, but in the graveyard.
Luke 8:28 The man saw Jesus and screamed. He knelt down in front of him and shouted, “Jesus, Son of God Most High, what do you want with me? I beg you not to torture me!”
Luke 8:29 He said this because Jesus had already told the evil spirit to go out of him. The man had often been attacked by the demon. And even though he had been bound with chains and leg irons and kept under guard, he smashed whatever bound him. Then the demon would force him out into lonely places.
Luke 8:30 Jesus asked the man, “What is your name?” He answered, “My name is Lots.” He said this because there were “lots” of demons in him.
Luke 8:31 They begged Jesus not to send them to the deep pit, where they would be punished.
Luke 8:32 A large herd of pigs was feeding there on the hillside. So the demons begged Jesus to let them go into the pigs, and Jesus let them go.
Luke 8:33 Then the demons left the man and went into the pigs. The whole herd rushed down the steep bank into the lake and drowned.
Luke 8:34 When the men taking care of the pigs saw this, they ran to spread the news in the town and on the farms.
Luke 8:35 The people went out to see what had happened, and when they came to Jesus, they also found the man. The demons had gone out of him, and he was sitting there at the feet of Jesus. He had clothes on and was in his right mind. But the people were terrified.
Luke 8:36 Then all who had seen the man healed told about it.
Luke 8:37 Everyone from around Gerasa begged Jesus to leave, because they were so frightened. When Jesus got into the boat to start back,
Luke 8:38 the man who had been healed begged to go with him. But Jesus sent him off and said,
Luke 8:39 “Go back home and tell everyone how much God has done for you.” The man then went all over town, telling everything that Jesus had done for him.
Luke 8:40 Everyone had been waiting for Jesus, and when he came back, a crowd was there to welcome him.
Luke 8:41 Just then the man in charge of the synagogue came and knelt down in front of Jesus. His name was Jairus, and he begged Jesus to come to his home
Luke 8:42 because his twelve-year-old child was dying. She was his only daughter. While Jesus was on his way, people were crowding all around him.
Luke 8:43 In the crowd was a woman who had been bleeding for twelve years. She had spent everything she had on doctors, but none of them could make her well.
Luke 8:44 As soon as she came up behind Jesus and barely touched his clothes, her bleeding stopped.
Luke 8:45 “Who touched me?” Jesus asked. While everyone was denying it, Peter said, “Master, people are crowding all around and pushing you from every side.”
Luke 8:46 But Jesus answered, “Someone touched me, because I felt power going out from me.”
Luke 8:47 The woman knew that she could not hide, so she came trembling and knelt down in front of Jesus. She told everyone why she had touched him and that she had been healed at once.
Luke 8:48 Jesus said to the woman, “You are now well because of your faith. May God give you peace!”
Luke 8:49 While Jesus was speaking, someone came from Jairus' home and said, “Your daughter has died! Why bother the teacher anymore?”
Luke 8:50 When Jesus heard this, he told Jairus, “Don't worry! Have faith, and your daughter will get well.”
Luke 8:51 Jesus went into the house, but he did not let anyone else go with him, except Peter, John, James, and the girl's father and mother.
Luke 8:52 Everyone was crying and weeping for the girl. But Jesus said, “The child isn't dead. She is just asleep.”
Luke 8:53 The people laughed at him because they knew she was dead.
Luke 8:54 Jesus took hold of the girl's hand and said, “Child, get up!”
Luke 8:55 She came back to life and got right up. Jesus told them to give her something to eat.
Luke 8:56 Her parents were surprised, but Jesus ordered them not to tell anyone what had happened.
Luke 9:1 Jesus called together his twelve apostles and gave them complete power over all demons and diseases.
Luke 9:2 Then he sent them to tell about God's kingdom and to heal the sick.
Luke 9:3 He told them, “Don't take anything with you! Don't take a walking stick or a traveling bag or food or money or even a change of clothes.
Luke 9:4 When you are welcomed into a home, stay there until you leave that town.
Luke 9:5 If people won't welcome you, leave the town and shake the dust from your feet as a warning to them.”
Luke 9:6 The apostles left and went from village to village, telling the good news and healing people everywhere.
Luke 9:7 Herod the ruler heard about all that was happening, and he was worried. Some people were saying John the Baptist had come back to life.
Luke 9:8 Others were saying Elijah had come or one of the prophets from long ago had come back to life.
Luke 9:9 But Herod said, “I had John's head cut off! Who is this I hear so much about?” Herod was eager to meet Jesus.
Luke 9:10 The apostles came back and told Jesus everything they had done. He then took them with him to the village of Bethsaida, where they could be alone.
Luke 9:11 But a lot of people found out about this and followed him. Jesus welcomed them. He spoke about God's kingdom and healed everyone who was sick.
Luke 9:12 Late in the afternoon the twelve apostles came to Jesus and said, “Send the crowd to the villages and farms around here. They need to find a place to stay and something to eat. There is nothing in this place. It's like a desert!”
Luke 9:13 Jesus answered, “You give them something to eat.” But they replied, “We have only five small loaves of bread and two fish. If we are going to feed all these people, we will have to go and buy food.”
Luke 9:14 There were about 5,000 men in the crowd. Jesus said to his disciples, “Tell the people to sit in groups of 50.”
Luke 9:15 They did this, and all the people sat down.
Luke 9:16 Jesus took the five loaves and the two fish. He looked up toward heaven and blessed the food. Then he broke the bread and fish and handed them to his disciples to give to the people.
Luke 9:17 Everyone ate all they wanted. What was left over filled twelve baskets.
Luke 9:18 When Jesus was alone praying, his disciples came to him, and he asked them, “What do people say about me?”
Luke 9:19 They answered, “Some say you are John the Baptist or Elijah or a prophet from long ago who has come back to life.”
Luke 9:20 Jesus then asked, “But who do you say I am?” Peter answered, “You are the Messiah sent from God.”
Luke 9:21 Jesus strictly warned his disciples not to tell anyone about this.
Luke 9:22 Jesus told his disciples, “The nation's leaders, the chief priests, and the teachers of the Law of Moses will make the Son of Man suffer terribly. They will reject him and kill him, but three days later he will rise to life.”
Luke 9:23 Then Jesus said to all the people: If any of you want to be my followers, you must forget about yourself. You must take up your cross every day and follow me.
Luke 9:24 If you want to save your life, you will destroy it. But if you give up your life for me, you will save it.
Luke 9:25 What will you gain, if you own the whole world but destroy yourself or waste your life?
Luke 9:26 If you are ashamed of me and my message, the Son of Man will be ashamed of you when he comes in his glory and in the glory of his Father and the holy angels.
Luke 9:27 You can be sure some of the people standing here will not die before they see God's kingdom.
Luke 9:28 About eight days later Jesus took Peter, John, and James with him and went up on a mountain to pray.
Luke 9:29 While he was praying, his face changed, and his clothes became shining white.
Luke 9:30 Suddenly Moses and Elijah were there speaking with him.
Luke 9:31 They appeared in heavenly glory and talked about all that Jesus' death in Jerusalem would mean.
Luke 9:32 Peter and the other two disciples had been sound asleep. All at once they woke up and saw how glorious Jesus was. They also saw the two men who were with him.
Luke 9:33 Moses and Elijah were about to leave, when Peter said to Jesus, “Master, it is good for us to be here! Let us make three shelters, one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah.” But Peter did not know what he was talking about.
Luke 9:34 While Peter was still speaking, a shadow from a cloud passed over, and they were frightened as the cloud covered them.
Luke 9:35 From the cloud a voice spoke, “This is my chosen Son. Listen to what he says!”
Luke 9:36 After the voice had spoken, Peter, John, and James saw only Jesus. For some time they kept quiet and did not say anything about what they had seen.
Luke 9:37 The next day Jesus and his three disciples came down from the mountain and were met by a large crowd.
Luke 9:38 Just then someone in the crowd shouted, “Teacher, please do something for my son! He is my only child!
Luke 9:39 A demon often attacks him and makes him scream. It shakes him until he foams at the mouth, and it won't leave him until it has completely worn the boy out.
Luke 9:40 I begged your disciples to force out the demon, but they couldn't do it.”
Luke 9:41 Jesus said to them, “You people are stubborn and don't have any faith! How much longer must I be with you? Why do I have to put up with you?” Then Jesus said to the man, “Bring your son to me.”
Luke 9:42 While the boy was being brought, the demon attacked him and made him shake all over. Jesus ordered the demon to stop. Then he healed the boy and gave him back to his father.
Luke 9:43 Everyone was amazed at God's great power. While everyone was still amazed at what Jesus was doing, he said to his disciples,
Luke 9:44 “Pay close attention to what I am telling you! The Son of Man will be handed over to his enemies.”
Luke 9:45 But the disciples did not know what he meant. The meaning was hidden from them. They could not understand it, and they were afraid to ask.
Luke 9:46 Jesus' disciples were arguing about which one of them was the greatest.
Luke 9:47 Jesus knew what they were thinking, and he had a child stand there beside him.
Luke 9:48 Then he said to his disciples, “When you welcome even a child because of me, you welcome me. And when you welcome me, you welcome the one who sent me. Whichever one of you is the most humble is the greatest.”
Luke 9:49 John said, “Master, we saw a man using your name to force demons out of people. But we told him to stop, because he isn't one of us.”
Luke 9:50 “Don't stop him!” Jesus said. “Anyone who isn't against you is for you.”
Luke 9:51 Not long before it was time for Jesus to be taken up to heaven, he made up his mind to go to Jerusalem.
Luke 9:52 He sent some messengers on ahead to a Samaritan village to get things ready for him.
Luke 9:53 But he was on his way to Jerusalem, so the people there refused to welcome him.
Luke 9:54 When the disciples James and John saw what was happening, they asked, “Lord, do you want us to call down fire from heaven to destroy these people?”
Luke 9:55 But Jesus turned and corrected them for what they had said.
Luke 9:56 Then they all went on to another village.
Luke 9:57 Along the way someone said to Jesus, “I'll follow you anywhere!”
Luke 9:58 Jesus said, “Foxes have dens, and birds have nests, but the Son of Man doesn't have a place to call his own.”
Luke 9:59 Jesus told someone else to come with him. But the man said, “Lord, let me wait until I bury my father.”
Luke 9:60 Jesus answered, “Let the dead take care of the dead, while you go and tell about God's kingdom.”
Luke 9:61 Then someone said to Jesus, “I want to follow you, Lord, but first let me go back and take care of things at home.”
Luke 9:62 Jesus answered, “Anyone who starts plowing and keeps looking back isn't worth a thing to God's kingdom!”
Luke 10:1 Later the Lord chose 72 other followers and sent them out two by two to every town and village where he was about to go.
Luke 10:2 He said to them: A large crop is in the fields, but there are only a few workers. Ask the Lord in charge of the harvest to send out workers to bring it in.
Luke 10:3 Now go, but remember, I am sending you like lambs into a pack of wolves.
Luke 10:4 Don't take along a moneybag or a traveling bag or sandals. And don't waste time greeting people on the road.
Luke 10:5 As soon as you enter a home, say, “God bless this home with peace.”
Luke 10:6 If the people living there are peace-loving, your prayer for peace will bless them. But if they are not peace-loving, your prayer will return to you.
Luke 10:7 Stay with the same family, eating and drinking whatever they give you, because workers are worth what they earn. Don't move around from house to house.
Luke 10:8 If the people of a town welcome you, eat whatever they offer.
Luke 10:9 Heal their sick and say, “God's kingdom will soon be here!”
Luke 10:10 But if the people of a town refuse to welcome you, go out into the street and say,
Luke 10:11 “We are shaking the dust from our feet as a warning to you. And you can be sure that God's kingdom will soon be here!”
Luke 10:12 I tell you that on the day of judgment the people of Sodom will get off easier than the people of that town!
Luke 10:13 You people of Chorazin are in for trouble! You people of Bethsaida are also in for trouble! If the miracles that took place in your towns had happened in Tyre and Sidon, the people there would have turned to God long ago. They would have dressed in sackcloth and put ashes on their heads.
Luke 10:14 On the day of judgment the people of Tyre and Sidon will get off easier than you will.
Luke 10:15 People of Capernaum, do you think you will be honored in heaven? Well, you will go down to hell!
Luke 10:16 My followers, whoever listens to you is listening to me. Anyone who says “No” to you is saying “No” to me. And anyone who says “No” to me is really saying “No” to the one who sent me.
Luke 10:17 When the 72 followers returned, they were excited and said, “Lord, even the demons obeyed when we spoke in your name!”
Luke 10:18 Jesus told them: I saw Satan fall from heaven like a flash of lightning.
Luke 10:19 I have given you the power to trample on snakes and scorpions and to defeat the power of your enemy Satan. Nothing can harm you.
Luke 10:20 But don't be happy because evil spirits obey you. Be happy that your names are written in heaven!
Luke 10:21 At that same time, Jesus felt the joy that comes from the Holy Spirit, and he said: My Father, Lord of heaven and earth, I am grateful that you hid all this from wise and educated people and showed it to ordinary people. Yes, Father, this is what pleased you.
Luke 10:22 My Father has given me everything, and he is the only one who knows the Son. The only one who really knows the Father is the Son. But the Son wants to tell others about the Father, so they can know him too.
Luke 10:23 Jesus then turned to his disciples and said to them in private, “You are really blessed to see what you see!
Luke 10:24 Many prophets and kings were eager to see what you see and to hear what you hear. But I tell you they did not see or hear.”
Luke 10:25 An expert in the Law of Moses stood up and asked Jesus a question to see what he would say. “Teacher,” he asked, “what must I do to have eternal life?”
Luke 10:26 Jesus answered, “What is written in the Scriptures? How do you understand them?”
Luke 10:27 The man replied, “The Scriptures say, ‘Love the Lord your God with all your heart, soul, strength, and mind.’ They also say, ‘Love your neighbors as much as you love yourself.’ ”
Luke 10:28 Jesus said, “You have given the right answer. If you do this, you will have eternal life.”
Luke 10:29 But the man wanted to show that he knew what he was talking about. So he asked Jesus, “Who are my neighbors?”
Luke 10:30 Jesus replied: As a man was going down from Jerusalem to Jericho, robbers attacked him and grabbed everything he had. They beat him up and ran off, leaving him half dead.
Luke 10:31 A priest happened to be going down the same road. But when he saw the man, he walked by on the other side.
Luke 10:32 Later a temple helper came to the same place. But when he saw the man who had been beaten up, he also went by on the other side.
Luke 10:33 A man from Samaria then came traveling along that road. When he saw the man, he felt sorry for him
Luke 10:34 and went over to him. He treated his wounds with olive oil and wine and bandaged them. Then he put him on his own donkey and took him to an inn, where he took care of him.
Luke 10:35 The next morning he gave the innkeeper two silver coins and said, “Please take care of the man. If you spend more than this on him, I will pay you when I return.”
Luke 10:36 Then Jesus asked, “Which one of these three people was a real neighbor to the man who was beaten up by robbers?”
Luke 10:37 The expert in the Law of Moses answered, “The one who showed pity.” Jesus said, “Go and do the same!”
Luke 10:38 The Lord and his disciples were traveling along and came to a village. When they got there, a woman named Martha welcomed him into her home.
Luke 10:39 She had a sister named Mary, who sat down in front of the Lord and was listening to what he said.
Luke 10:40 Martha was worried about all that had to be done. Finally, she went to Jesus and said, “Lord, doesn't it bother you that my sister has left me to do all the work by myself? Tell her to come and help me!”
Luke 10:41 The Lord answered, “Martha, Martha! You are worried and upset about so many things,
Luke 10:42 but only one thing is necessary. Mary has chosen what is best, and it will not be taken away from her.”
Luke 11:1 When Jesus had finished praying, one of his disciples said to him, “Lord, teach us to pray, just as John taught his followers to pray.”
Luke 11:2 So Jesus told them, “Pray in this way: ‘Father, help us to honor your name. Come and set up your kingdom.
Luke 11:3 Give us each day the food we need.
Luke 11:4 Forgive our sins, as we forgive everyone who has done wrong to us. And keep us from being tempted.’ ”
Luke 11:5 Then Jesus went on to say: Suppose one of you goes to a friend in the middle of the night and says, “Let me borrow three loaves of bread.
Luke 11:6 A friend of mine has dropped in, and I don't have a thing for him to eat.”
Luke 11:7 And suppose your friend answers, “Don't bother me! The door is bolted, and my children and I are in bed. I cannot get up to give you something.”
Luke 11:8 He may not get up and give you the bread, just because you are his friend. But he will get up and give you as much as you need, simply because you are not ashamed to keep on asking.
Luke 11:9 So I tell you to ask and you will receive, search and you will find, knock and the door will be opened for you.
Luke 11:10 Everyone who asks will receive, everyone who searches will find, and the door will be opened for everyone who knocks.
Luke 11:11 Which one of you fathers would give your hungry child a snake if the child asked for a fish?
Luke 11:12 Which one of you would give your child a scorpion if the child asked for an egg?
Luke 11:13 As bad as you are, you still know how to give good gifts to your children. But your heavenly Father is even more ready to give the Holy Spirit to anyone who asks.
Luke 11:14 Jesus forced a demon out of a man who could not talk. And after the demon had gone out, the man started speaking, and the crowds were amazed.
Luke 11:15 But some people said, “He forces out demons by the power of Beelzebul, the ruler of the demons!”
Luke 11:16 Others wanted to put Jesus to the test. So they asked him to show them a sign from God.
Luke 11:17 Jesus knew what they were thinking, and he said: A kingdom where people fight each other will end up in ruin. And a family that fights will break up.
Luke 11:18 If Satan fights against himself, how can his kingdom last? Yet you say that I force out demons by the power of Beelzebul.
Luke 11:19 If I use his power to force out demons, whose power do your own followers use to force them out? They are the ones who will judge you.
Luke 11:20 But if I use God's power to force out demons, it proves that God's kingdom has already come to you.
Luke 11:21 When a strong man arms himself and guards his home, everything he owns is safe.
Luke 11:22 But if a stronger man comes and defeats him, he will carry off the weapons in which the strong man trusted. Then he will divide with others what he has taken.
Luke 11:23 If you are not on my side, you are against me. If you don't gather in the crop with me, you scatter it.
Luke 11:24 When an evil spirit leaves a person, it travels through the desert, looking for a place to rest. But when it doesn't find a place, it says, “I will go back to the home I left.”
Luke 11:25 When it gets there and finds the place clean and fixed up,
Luke 11:26 it goes off and finds seven other evil spirits even worse than itself. They all come and make their home there, and that person ends up in worse shape than before.
Luke 11:27 While Jesus was still talking, a woman in the crowd spoke up, “The woman who gave birth to you and nursed you is blessed!”
Luke 11:28 Jesus replied, “That's true, but the people who are really blessed are the ones who hear and obey God's message!”
Luke 11:29 As crowds were gathering around Jesus, he said: You people of today are evil! You keep looking for a sign from God. But what happened to Jonah is the only sign you will be given.
Luke 11:30 Just as Jonah was a sign to the people of Nineveh, the Son of Man will be a sign to the people of today.
Luke 11:31 When the judgment comes, the Queen of the South will stand there with you and condemn you. She traveled a long way to hear Solomon's wisdom, and yet here is something far greater than Solomon.
Luke 11:32 The people of Nineveh will also stand there with you and condemn you. They turned to God when Jonah preached, and yet here is something far greater than Jonah.
Luke 11:33 No one lights a lamp and then hides it or puts it under a clay pot. A lamp is put on a lampstand, so everyone who comes into the house can see the light.
Luke 11:34 Your eyes are the lamp for your body. When your eyes are good, you have all the light you need. But when your eyes are bad, everything is dark.
Luke 11:35 So be sure your light isn't darkness.
Luke 11:36 If you have light, and nothing is dark, then light will be everywhere, as when a lamp shines brightly on you.
Luke 11:37 When Jesus finished speaking, a Pharisee invited him home for a meal. Jesus went and sat down to eat.
Luke 11:38 The Pharisee was surprised that he did not wash his hands before eating.
Luke 11:39 So the Lord said to him: You Pharisees clean the outside of cups and dishes, but on the inside you are greedy and evil.
Luke 11:40 You fools! Didn't God make both the outside and the inside?
Luke 11:41 If you would only give what you have to the poor, everything you do would please God.
Luke 11:42 You Pharisees are in for trouble! You give God a tenth of the spices from your gardens, such as mint and rue. But you cheat people, and you don't love God. You should be fair and kind to others and still give a tenth to God.
Luke 11:43 You Pharisees are in for trouble! You love the front seats in the synagogues, and you like to be greeted with honor in the market.
Luke 11:44 But you are in for trouble! You are like unmarked graves that people walk on without even knowing it.
Luke 11:45 A teacher of the Law of Moses spoke up, “Teacher, you said cruel things about us.”
Luke 11:46 Jesus replied: You teachers are also in for trouble! You load people down with heavy burdens, but you won't lift a finger to help them carry the loads.
Luke 11:47 Yes, you are really in for trouble. You build monuments to honor the prophets your own people murdered long ago.
Luke 11:48 You must think that was the right thing for your people to do, or else you would not have built monuments for the prophets they murdered.
Luke 11:49 Because of your evil deeds, the Wisdom of God said, “I will send prophets and apostles to you. But you will murder some and mistreat others.”
Luke 11:50 You people living today will be punished for all the prophets who have been murdered since the beginning of the world.
Luke 11:51 This includes every prophet from the time of Abel to the time of Zechariah, who was murdered between the altar and the temple. You people will certainly be punished for all of this.
Luke 11:52 You teachers of the Law of Moses are really in for trouble! You carry the keys to the door of knowledge about God. But you never go in, and you keep others from going in.
Luke 11:53 Jesus was about to leave, but the teachers and the Pharisees wanted to get even with him. They tried to make him say what he thought about other things,
Luke 11:54 so they could catch him saying something wrong.
Luke 12:1 As thousands of people crowded around Jesus and were stepping on each other, he told his disciples: Be sure to guard against the dishonest teaching of the Pharisees! It is their way of fooling people.
Luke 12:2 Everything that is hidden will be found out, and every secret will be known.
Luke 12:3 Whatever you say in the dark will be heard when it is day. Whatever you whisper in a closed room will be shouted from the housetops.
Luke 12:4 My friends, don't be afraid of people. They can kill you, but after that, there is nothing else they can do.
Luke 12:5 God is the one you must fear. Not only can he take your life, but he can throw you into hell. God is certainly the one you should fear!
Luke 12:6 Five sparrows are sold for only a few cents, but God doesn't forget a single one of them.
Luke 12:7 Even the hairs on your head are counted. So don't be afraid! You are worth much more than many sparrows.
Luke 12:8 If you tell others that you belong to me, the Son of Man will tell God's angels that you are my followers.
Luke 12:9 But if you reject me, you will be rejected in front of them.
Luke 12:10 If you speak against the Son of Man, you can be forgiven, but if you speak against the Holy Spirit, you cannot be forgiven.
Luke 12:11 When you are brought to trial in the synagogues or before rulers or officials, don't worry about how you will defend yourselves or what you will say.
Luke 12:12 At that time the Holy Spirit will tell you what to say.
Luke 12:13 A man in a crowd said to Jesus, “Teacher, tell my brother to give me my share of what our father left us when he died.”
Luke 12:14 Jesus answered, “Who gave me the right to settle arguments between you and your brother?”
Luke 12:15 Then he said to the crowd, “Don't be greedy! Owning a lot of things won't make your life safe.”
Luke 12:16 So Jesus told them this story: A rich man's farm produced a big crop,
Luke 12:17 and he said to himself, “What can I do? I don't have a place large enough to store everything.”
Luke 12:18 Later, he said, “Now I know what I'll do. I'll tear down my barns and build bigger ones, where I can store all my grain and other goods.
Luke 12:19 Then I'll say to myself, ‘You have stored up enough good things to last for years to come. Live it up! Eat, drink, and enjoy yourself.’ ”
Luke 12:20 But God said to him, “You fool! Tonight you will die. Then who will get what you have stored up?”
Luke 12:21 “This is what happens to people who store up everything for themselves, but are poor in the sight of God.”
Luke 12:22 Jesus said to his disciples: I tell you not to worry about your life! Don't worry about having something to eat or wear.
Luke 12:23 Life is more than food or clothing.
Luke 12:24 Look at the crows! They don't plant or harvest, and they don't have storehouses or barns. But God takes care of them. You are much more important than any birds.
Luke 12:25 Can worry make you live longer?
Luke 12:26 If you don't have power over small things, why worry about everything else?
Luke 12:27 Look how the wild flowers grow! They don't work hard to make their clothes. But I tell you Solomon with all his wealth wasn't as well clothed as one of these flowers.
Luke 12:28 God gives such beauty to everything that grows in the fields, even though it is here today and thrown into a fire tomorrow. Won't he do even more for you? You have such little faith!
Luke 12:29 Don't keep worrying about having something to eat or drink.
Luke 12:30 Only people who don't know God are always worrying about such things. Your Father knows what you need.
Luke 12:31 But put God's work first, and these things will be yours as well.
Luke 12:32 My little group of disciples, don't be afraid! Your Father wants to give you the kingdom.
Luke 12:33 Sell what you have and give the money to the poor. Make yourselves moneybags that never wear out. Make sure your treasure is safe in heaven, where thieves cannot steal it and moths cannot destroy it.
Luke 12:34 Your heart will always be where your treasure is.
Luke 12:35 Be ready and keep your lamps burning
Luke 12:36 just like those servants who wait up for their master to return from a wedding feast. As soon as he comes and knocks, they open the door for him.
Luke 12:37 Servants are fortunate if their master finds them awake and ready when he comes! I promise you he will get ready and let his servants sit down so he can serve them.
Luke 12:38 Those servants are really fortunate if their master finds them ready, even though he comes late at night or early in the morning.
Luke 12:39 You would surely not let a thief break into your home, if you knew when the thief was coming.
Luke 12:40 So always be ready! You don't know when the Son of Man will come.
Luke 12:41 Peter asked Jesus, “Did you say this just for us or for everyone?”
Luke 12:42 The Lord answered: Who are faithful and wise servants? Who are the ones the master will put in charge of giving the other servants their food supplies at the proper time?
Luke 12:43 Servants are fortunate if their master comes and finds them doing their job.
Luke 12:44 A servant who is always faithful will surely be put in charge of everything the master owns.
Luke 12:45 But suppose one of the servants thinks that the master won't return until late. Suppose that servant starts beating all the other servants and eats and drinks and gets drunk.
Luke 12:46 If that happens, the master will come on a day and at a time when the servant least expects him. That servant will then be punished and thrown out with the servants who cannot be trusted.
Luke 12:47 If servants are not ready or willing to do what their master wants them to do, they will be beaten hard.
Luke 12:48 But servants who don't know what their master wants them to do will not be beaten so hard for doing wrong. If God has been generous with you, he will expect you to serve him well. But if he has been more than generous, he will expect you to serve him even better.
Luke 12:49 I came to set fire to the earth, and I wish it were already on fire!
Luke 12:50 I am going to be put to a hard test. And I will have to suffer a lot of pain until it is over.
Luke 12:51 Do you think that I came to bring peace to earth? No indeed! I came to make people choose sides.
Luke 12:52 A family of five will be divided, with two of them against the other three.
Luke 12:53 Fathers and sons will turn against one another, and mothers and daughters will do the same. Mothers-in-law and daughters-in-law will also turn against each other.
Luke 12:54 Jesus said to all the people: As soon as you see a cloud coming up in the west, you say, “It's going to rain,” and it does.
Luke 12:55 When the south wind blows, you say, “It's going to get hot,” and it does.
Luke 12:56 Are you trying to fool someone? You can predict the weather by looking at the earth and sky, but you don't really know what's going on right now.
Luke 12:57 Why don't you understand the right thing to do?
Luke 12:58 When someone accuses you of something, try to settle things before you are taken to court. If you don't, you will be dragged before the judge. Then the judge will hand you over to the jailer, and you will be locked up.
Luke 12:59 You won't get out until you have paid the last cent you owe.
Luke 13:1 About this same time Jesus was told that Pilate had given orders for some people from Galilee to be killed while they were offering sacrifices.
Luke 13:2 Jesus replied: Do you think that these people were worse sinners than everyone else in Galilee just because of what happened to them?
Luke 13:3 Not at all! But you can be sure that if you don't turn back to God, every one of you will also be killed.
Luke 13:4 What about those 18 people who died when the tower in Siloam fell on them? Do you think they were worse than everyone else in Jerusalem?
Luke 13:5 Not at all! But you can be sure that if you don't turn back to God, every one of you will also die.
Luke 13:6 Jesus then told them this story: A man had a fig tree growing in his vineyard. One day he went out to pick some figs, but he didn't find any.
Luke 13:7 So he said to the gardener, “For three years I have come looking for figs on this tree, and I haven't found any yet. Chop it down! Why should it take up space?”
Luke 13:8 The gardener answered, “Master, leave it for another year. I'll dig around it and put some manure on it to make it grow.
Luke 13:9 Maybe it will have figs on it next year. If it doesn't, you can have it cut down.”
Luke 13:10 One Sabbath, Jesus was teaching in a synagogue,
Luke 13:11 and a woman was there who had been crippled by an evil spirit for 18 years. She was completely bent over and could not straighten up.
Luke 13:12 When Jesus saw the woman, he called her over and said, “You are now well.”
Luke 13:13 He placed his hands on her, and at once she stood up straight and praised God.
Luke 13:14 The man in charge of the synagogue was angry because Jesus had healed someone on the Sabbath. So he said to the people, “Each week has six days when we can work. Come and be healed on one of those days, but not on the Sabbath.”
Luke 13:15 The Lord replied, “Are you trying to fool someone? Won't any one of you untie your ox or donkey and lead it out to drink on a Sabbath?
Luke 13:16 This woman belongs to the family of Abraham, but Satan has kept her bound for 18 years. Isn't it right to set her free on the Sabbath?”
Luke 13:17 Jesus' words made his enemies ashamed. But everyone else in the crowd was happy about the wonderful things he was doing.
Luke 13:18 Jesus said, “What is God's kingdom like? What can I compare it with?
Luke 13:19 It is like what happens when someone plants a mustard seed in a garden. The seed grows as big as a tree, and birds nest in its branches.”
Luke 13:20 Then Jesus said, “What can I compare God's kingdom with?
Luke 13:21 It is like what happens when a woman mixes yeast into three batches of flour. Finally, all the dough rises.”
Luke 13:22 As Jesus was on his way to Jerusalem, he taught the people in the towns and villages.
Luke 13:23 Someone asked him, “Lord, are only a few people going to be saved?” Jesus answered:
Luke 13:24 Do all you can to go in by the narrow door! A lot of people will try to get in, but will not be able to.
Luke 13:25 Once the owner of the house gets up and locks the door, you will be left standing outside. You will knock on the door and say, “Sir, open the door for us!” But the owner will answer, “I don't know a thing about you!”
Luke 13:26 Then you will start saying, “We dined with you, and you taught in our streets.”
Luke 13:27 But he will say, “I really don't know who you are! Get away from me, you evil people!”
Luke 13:28 Then when you have been thrown outside, you will weep and grit your teeth because you will see Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and all the prophets in God's kingdom.
Luke 13:29 People will come from all directions and sit down to feast in God's kingdom.
Luke 13:30 There the ones who are now least important will be the most important, and those who are now most important will be least important.
Luke 13:31 At that time some Pharisees came to Jesus and said, “You had better get away from here, because Herod wants to kill you!”
Luke 13:32 Jesus said to them: Go tell that fox, “I am going to force out demons and heal people today and tomorrow, and three days later I'll be through.”
Luke 13:33 But I am going on my way today and tomorrow and the next day. After all, Jerusalem is the place where prophets are killed.
Luke 13:34 Jerusalem, Jerusalem! Your people have killed the prophets and have stoned the messengers who were sent to you. I have often wanted to gather your people, as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings. But you wouldn't let me.
Luke 13:35 Now your temple will be deserted. You won't see me again until the time when you say, “Blessed is the one who comes in the name of the Lord.”
Luke 14:1 One Sabbath, Jesus was having dinner in the home of an important Pharisee, and everyone was carefully watching Jesus.
Luke 14:2 All of a sudden a man with swollen legs stood up in front of him.
Luke 14:3 Jesus turned and asked the Pharisees and the teachers of the Law of Moses, “Is it right to heal on the Sabbath?”
Luke 14:4 But they did not say a word. Jesus took hold of the man. Then he healed him and sent him away.
Luke 14:5 Afterwards, Jesus asked the people, “If your son or ox falls into a well, wouldn't you pull him out at once, even on the Sabbath?”
Luke 14:6 There was nothing they could say.
Luke 14:7 Jesus saw how the guests had tried to take the best seats. So he told them:
Luke 14:8 When you are invited to a wedding feast, don't sit in the best place. Someone more important may have been invited.
Luke 14:9 Then the one who invited you will come and say, “Give your place to this other guest!” You will be embarrassed and will have to sit in the worst place.
Luke 14:10 When you are invited to be a guest, go and sit in the worst place. Then the one who invited you may come and say, “My friend, take a better seat!” You will then be honored in front of all the other guests.
Luke 14:11 If you put yourself above others, you will be put down. But if you humble yourself, you will be honored.
Luke 14:12 Then Jesus said to the man who had invited him: When you give a dinner or a banquet, don't invite your friends and family and relatives and rich neighbors. If you do, they will invite you in return, and you will be paid back.
Luke 14:13 When you give a feast, invite the poor, the paralyzed, the lame, and the blind.
Luke 14:14 They cannot pay you back. But God will bless you and reward you when his people rise from death.
Luke 14:15 After Jesus had finished speaking, one of the guests said, “The greatest blessing of all is to be at the banquet in God's kingdom!”
Luke 14:16 Jesus told him: A man once gave a great banquet and invited a lot of guests.
Luke 14:17 When the banquet was ready, he sent a servant to tell the guests, “Everything is ready! Please come.”
Luke 14:18 One guest after another started making excuses. The first one said, “I bought some land, and I've got to look it over. Please excuse me.”
Luke 14:19 Another guest said, “I bought five teams of oxen, and I need to try them out. Please excuse me.”
Luke 14:20 Still another guest said, “I've just now married, and I can't be there.”
Luke 14:21 The servant told his master what happened, and the master became so angry he said, “Go as fast as you can to every street and alley in town! Bring in everyone who is poor or paralyzed or blind or lame.”
Luke 14:22 When the servant returned, he said, “Master, I've done what you told me, and there is still plenty of room for more people.”
Luke 14:23 His master then told him, “Go out along the back roads and make people come in, so my house will be full.
Luke 14:24 Not one of the guests I first invited will get even a bite of my food!”
Luke 14:25 Large crowds were walking along with Jesus, when he turned and said:
Luke 14:26 You cannot be my disciple, unless you love me more than you love your father and mother, your wife and children, and your brothers and sisters. You cannot follow me unless you love me more than you love your own life.
Luke 14:27 You cannot be my disciple unless you carry your own cross and follow me.
Luke 14:28 Suppose one of you wants to build a tower. What is the first thing you will do? Won't you sit down and figure out how much it will cost and if you have enough money to pay for it?
Luke 14:29 Otherwise, you will start building the tower, but not be able to finish. Then everyone who sees what is happening will laugh at you.
Luke 14:30 They will say, “You started building, but could not finish the job.”
Luke 14:31 What will a king do if he has only 10,000 soldiers to defend himself against a king who is about to attack him with 20,000 soldiers? Before he goes out to battle, won't he first sit down and decide if he can win?
Luke 14:32 If he thinks he won't be able to defend himself, he will send messengers and ask for peace while the other king is still a long way off.
Luke 14:33 So then, you cannot be my disciple unless you give away everything you own.
Luke 14:34 Salt is good, but if it no longer tastes like salt, how can it be made to taste salty again?
Luke 14:35 It is no longer good for the soil or even for the manure pile. People simply throw it out. If you have ears, pay attention!
Luke 15:1 Tax collectors and sinners were all crowding around to listen to Jesus.
