Luke 15:2 So the Pharisees and the teachers of the Law of Moses started grumbling, “This man is friendly with sinners. He even eats with them.”
Luke 15:3 Then Jesus told them this story:
Luke 15:4 If any of you has 100 sheep, and one of them gets lost, what will you do? Won't you leave the 99 in the field and go look for the lost sheep until you find it?
Luke 15:5 And when you find it, you will be so glad that you will put it on your shoulder
Luke 15:6 and carry it home. Then you will call in your friends and neighbors and say, “Let's celebrate! I've found my lost sheep.”
Luke 15:7 Jesus said, “In the same way there is more happiness in heaven because of one sinner who turns to God than over 99 good people who don't need to.”
Luke 15:8 Jesus told the people another story: What will a woman do if she has ten silver coins and loses one of them? Won't she light a lamp, sweep the floor, and look carefully until she finds it?
Luke 15:9 Then she will call in her friends and neighbors and say, “Let's celebrate! I've found the coin I lost.”
Luke 15:10 Jesus said, “In the same way God's angels are happy when even one person turns to him.”
Luke 15:11 Jesus told them yet another story: Once a man had two sons.
Luke 15:12 The younger son said to his father, “Give me my share of the property.” So the father divided his property between his two sons.
Luke 15:13 Not long after that, the younger son packed up everything he owned and left for a foreign country, where he wasted all his money in wild living.
Luke 15:14 He had spent everything, when a bad famine spread through that whole land. Soon he had nothing to eat.
Luke 15:15 He went to work for a man in that country, and the man sent him out to take care of his pigs.
Luke 15:16 He would have been glad to eat what the pigs were eating, but no one gave him a thing.
Luke 15:17 Finally, he came to his senses and said, “My father's workers have plenty to eat, and here I am, starving to death!
Luke 15:18 I will go to my father and say to him, ‘Father, I have sinned against God in heaven and against you.
Luke 15:19 I am no longer good enough to be called your son. Treat me like one of your workers.’ ”
Luke 15:20 The younger son got up and started back to his father. But when he was still a long way off, his father saw him and felt sorry for him. He ran to his son and hugged and kissed him.
Luke 15:21 The son said, “Father, I have sinned against God in heaven and against you. I am no longer good enough to be called your son.”
Luke 15:22 But his father said to the servants, “Hurry and bring the best clothes and put them on him. Give him a ring for his finger and sandals for his feet.
Luke 15:23 Get the best calf and prepare it, so we can eat and celebrate.
Luke 15:24 This son of mine was dead, but has now come back to life. He was lost and has now been found.” And they began to celebrate.
Luke 15:25 The older son had been out in the field. But when he came near the house, he heard the music and dancing.
Luke 15:26 So he called one of the servants over and asked, “What's going on here?”
Luke 15:27 The servant answered, “Your brother has come home safe and sound, and your father ordered us to kill the best calf.”
Luke 15:28 The older brother got so angry that he would not even go into the house. His father came out and begged him to go in.
Luke 15:29 But he said to his father, “For years I have worked for you like a slave and have always obeyed you. But you have never even given me a little goat, so that I could give a dinner for my friends.
Luke 15:30 This other son of yours wasted your money on prostitutes. And now that he has come home, you ordered the best calf to be killed for a feast.”
Luke 15:31 His father replied, “My son, you are always with me, and everything I have is yours.
Luke 15:32 But we should be glad and celebrate! Your brother was dead, but he is now alive. He was lost and has now been found.”
Luke 16:1 Jesus said to his disciples: A rich man once had a manager to take care of his business. But he was told that his manager was wasting money.
Luke 16:2 So the rich man called him in and said, “What is this I hear about you? Tell me what you have done! You are no longer going to work for me.”
Luke 16:3 The manager said to himself, “What shall I do now that my master is going to fire me? I can't dig ditches, and I'm ashamed to beg.
Luke 16:4 I know what I'll do, so that people will welcome me into their homes after I've lost my job.”
Luke 16:5 Then one by one he called in the people who were in debt to his master. He asked the first one, “How much do you owe my master?”
Luke 16:6 “A hundred barrels of olive oil,” the man answered. So the manager said, “Take your bill and sit down and quickly write ‘50.’ ”
Luke 16:7 The manager asked someone else who was in debt to his master, “How much do you owe?” “A thousand sacks of wheat,” the man replied. The manager said, “Take your bill and write ‘800.’ ”
Luke 16:8 The master praised his dishonest manager for looking out for himself so well. That's how it is! The people of this world look out for themselves better than the people who belong to the light.
Luke 16:9 My disciples, I tell you to use wicked wealth to make friends for yourselves. Then when it is gone, you will be welcomed into an eternal home.
Luke 16:10 Anyone who can be trusted in little matters can also be trusted in important matters. But anyone who is dishonest in little matters will be dishonest in important matters.
Luke 16:11 If you cannot be trusted with this wicked wealth, who will trust you with true wealth?
Luke 16:12 And if you cannot be trusted with what belongs to someone else, who will give you something that will be your own?
Luke 16:13 You cannot be the slave of two masters. You will like one more than the other or be more loyal to one than to the other. You cannot serve God and money.
Luke 16:14 The Pharisees really loved money. So when they heard what Jesus said, they made fun of him.
Luke 16:15 But Jesus told them: You are always making yourselves look good, but God sees what is in your heart. The things that most people think are important are worthless as far as God is concerned.
Luke 16:16 Until the time of John the Baptist, people had to obey the Law of Moses and the Books of the Prophets. But since God's kingdom has been preached, everyone is trying hard to get in.
Luke 16:17 Heaven and earth will disappear before the smallest letter of the Law does.
Luke 16:18 It is a terrible sin for a man to divorce his wife and marry another woman. It is also a terrible sin for a man to marry a divorced woman.
Luke 16:19 There was once a rich man who wore expensive clothes and every day ate the best food.
Luke 16:20 But a poor beggar named Lazarus was brought to the gate of the rich man's house.
Luke 16:21 He was happy just to eat the scraps that fell from the rich man's table. His body was covered with sores, and dogs kept coming up to lick them.
Luke 16:22 The poor man died, and angels took him to the place of honor next to Abraham. The rich man also died and was buried.
Luke 16:23 He went to hell and was suffering terribly. When he looked up and saw Abraham far off and Lazarus at his side,
Luke 16:24 he said to Abraham, “Have pity on me! Send Lazarus to dip his finger in water and touch my tongue. I'm suffering terribly in this fire.”
Luke 16:25 Abraham answered, “My friend, remember that while you lived, you had everything good, and Lazarus had everything bad. Now he is happy, and you are in pain.
Luke 16:26 And besides, there is a deep ditch between us, and no one from either side can cross over.”
Luke 16:27 But the rich man said, “Abraham, then please send Lazarus to my father's home.
Luke 16:28 Let him warn my five brothers, so they won't come to this horrible place.”
Luke 16:29 Abraham answered, “Your brothers can read what Moses and the prophets wrote. They should pay attention to that.”
Luke 16:30 Then the rich man said, “No, that's not enough! If only someone from the dead would go to them, they would listen and turn to God.”
Luke 16:31 So Abraham said, “If they won't pay attention to Moses and the prophets, they won't listen even to someone who comes back from the dead.”
Luke 17:1 Jesus said to his disciples: There will always be something that causes people to sin. But anyone who causes them to sin is in for trouble. A person who causes even one of my little followers to sin
Luke 17:2 would be better off thrown into the ocean with a heavy stone tied around their neck.
Luke 17:3 So be careful what you do. Correct any followers of mine who sin, and forgive the ones who say they are sorry.
Luke 17:4 Even if one of them mistreats you seven times in one day and says, “I am sorry,” you should still forgive that person.
Luke 17:5 The apostles said to the Lord, “Make our faith stronger!”
Luke 17:6 Jesus replied: If you had faith no bigger than a tiny mustard seed, you could tell this mulberry tree to pull itself up, roots and all, and to plant itself in the ocean. And it would!
Luke 17:7 If your servant comes in from plowing or from taking care of the sheep, would you say, “Welcome! Come on in and have something to eat”?
Luke 17:8 No, you wouldn't say that. You would say, “Prepare me something to eat. Get ready to serve me, so I can have my meal. Then later on you can eat and drink.”
Luke 17:9 Servants don't deserve special thanks for doing what they are supposed to do.
Luke 17:10 And that's how it should be with you. When you've done all you should, then say, “We are merely servants, and we have simply done our duty.”
Luke 17:11 On his way to Jerusalem, Jesus went along the border between Samaria and Galilee.
Luke 17:12 As he was going into a village, ten men with leprosy came toward him. They stood at a distance
Luke 17:13 and shouted, “Jesus, Master, have pity on us!”
Luke 17:14 Jesus looked at them and said, “Go show yourselves to the priests.” On their way they were healed.
Luke 17:15 When one of them discovered that he was healed, he came back, shouting praises to God.
Luke 17:16 He bowed down at the feet of Jesus and thanked him. The man was from the country of Samaria.
Luke 17:17 Jesus asked, “Weren't ten men healed? Where are the other nine?
Luke 17:18 Why was this foreigner the only one who came back to thank God?”
Luke 17:19 Then Jesus told the man, “You may get up and go. Your faith has made you well.”
Luke 17:20 Some Pharisees asked Jesus when God's kingdom would come. He answered, “God's kingdom isn't something you can see.
Luke 17:21 There is no use saying, ‘Look! Here it is’ or ‘Look! There it is.’ God's kingdom is here with you.”
Luke 17:22 Jesus said to his disciples: The time will come when you will long to see one of the days of the Son of Man, but you will not.
Luke 17:23 When people say to you, “Look there,” or “Look here,” don't go looking for him.
Luke 17:24 The day of the Son of Man will be like lightning flashing across the sky.
Luke 17:25 But first he must suffer terribly and be rejected by the people of today.
Luke 17:26 When the Son of Man comes, things will be just as they were when Noah lived.
Luke 17:27 People were eating, drinking, and getting married right up to the day when Noah went into the big boat. Then the flood came and drowned everyone on earth.
Luke 17:28 When Lot lived, people were also eating and drinking. They were buying, selling, planting, and building.
Luke 17:29 But on the very day Lot left Sodom, fiery flames poured down from the sky and killed everyone.
Luke 17:30 The same will happen on the day when the Son of Man appears.
Luke 17:31 At that time no one on a rooftop should go down into the house to get anything. No one in a field should go back to the house for anything.
Luke 17:32 Remember what happened to Lot's wife.
Luke 17:33 People who try to save their lives will lose them, and those who lose their lives will save them.
Luke 17:34 On that night two people will be sleeping in the same bed, but only one will be taken. The other will be left.
Luke 17:35+LUK Two women will be together grinding wheat, but only one will be taken. The other will be left.
Luke 17:37 Then Jesus' disciples spoke up, “But where will this happen, Lord?” Jesus said, “Where there is a corpse, there will always be vultures.”
Luke 18:1 Jesus told his disciples a story about how they should keep on praying and never give up:
Luke 18:2 In a town there was once a judge who didn't fear God or care about people.
Luke 18:3 In that same town there was a widow who kept going to the judge and saying, “Make sure that I get fair treatment in court.”
Luke 18:4 For a while the judge refused to do anything. Finally, he said to himself, “Even though I don't fear God or care about people,
Luke 18:5 I will help this widow because she keeps on bothering me. If I don't help her, she will wear me out.”
Luke 18:6 The Lord said: Think about what that crooked judge said.
Luke 18:7 Won't God protect his chosen ones who pray to him day and night? Won't he be concerned for them?
Luke 18:8 He will surely hurry and help them. But when the Son of Man comes, will he find on this earth anyone with faith?
Luke 18:9 Jesus told a story to some people who thought they were better than others and who looked down on everyone else:
Luke 18:10 Two men went into the temple to pray. One was a Pharisee and the other a tax collector.
Luke 18:11 The Pharisee stood over by himself and prayed, “God, I thank you that I am not greedy, dishonest, and unfaithful in marriage like other people. And I am really glad that I am not like that tax collector over there.
Luke 18:12 I go without eating for two days a week, and I give you one tenth of all I earn.”
Luke 18:13 The tax collector stood off at a distance and did not think he was good enough even to look up toward heaven. He was so sorry for what he had done that he pounded his chest and prayed, “God, have pity on me! I am such a sinner.”
Luke 18:14 Then Jesus said, “When the two men went home, it was the tax collector and not the Pharisee who was pleasing to God. If you put yourself above others, you will be put down. But if you humble yourself, you will be honored.”
Luke 18:15 Some people brought their little children for Jesus to bless. But when his disciples saw them doing this, they told the people to stop bothering him.
Luke 18:16 So Jesus called the children over to him and said, “Let the children come to me! Don't try to stop them. People who are like these children belong to God's kingdom.
Luke 18:17 You will never get into God's kingdom unless you enter it like a child!”
Luke 18:18 An important man asked Jesus, “Good Teacher, what must I do to have eternal life?”
Luke 18:19 Jesus said, “Why do you call me good? Only God is good.
Luke 18:20 You know the commandments: ‘Be faithful in marriage. Do not murder. Do not steal. Do not tell lies about others. Respect your father and mother.’ ”
Luke 18:21 He told Jesus, “I have obeyed all these commandments since I was a young man.”
Luke 18:22 When Jesus heard this, he said, “There is one thing you still need to do. Go and sell everything you own! Give the money to the poor, and you will have riches in heaven. Then come and be my follower.”
Luke 18:23 When the man heard this, he was sad, because he was very rich.
Luke 18:24 Jesus saw how sad the man was. So he said, “It's terribly hard for rich people to get into God's kingdom!
Luke 18:25 In fact, it's easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich person to get into God's kingdom.”
Luke 18:26 When the crowd heard this, they asked, “How can anyone ever be saved?”
Luke 18:27 Jesus replied, “There are some things that people cannot do, but God can do anything.”
Luke 18:28 Peter said, “Remember, we left everything to be your followers!”
Luke 18:29 Jesus answered, “You can be sure that anyone who gives up home or wife or brothers or family or children because of God's kingdom
Luke 18:30 will be given much more in this life. And in the future world they will have eternal life.”
Luke 18:31 Jesus took the twelve apostles aside and said: We are now on our way to Jerusalem. Everything that the prophets wrote about the Son of Man will happen there.
Luke 18:32 He will be handed over to foreigners, who will make fun of him, mistreat him, and spit on him.
Luke 18:33 They will beat him and kill him, but three days later he will rise to life.
Luke 18:34 The apostles did not understand what Jesus was talking about. They could not understand, because the meaning of what he said was hidden from them.
Luke 18:35 When Jesus was coming close to Jericho, a blind man sat begging beside the road.
Luke 18:36 The man heard the crowd walking by and asked what was happening.
Luke 18:37 Some people told him that Jesus from Nazareth was passing by.
Luke 18:38 So the blind man shouted, “Jesus, Son of David, have pity on me!”
Luke 18:39 The people who were going along with Jesus told the man to be quiet. But he shouted even louder, “Son of David, have pity on me!”
Luke 18:40 Jesus stopped and told some people to bring the blind man over to him. When the blind man was getting near, Jesus asked,
Luke 18:41 “What do you want me to do for you?” “Lord, I want to see!” he answered.
Luke 18:42 Jesus replied, “Look and you will see! Your eyes are healed because of your faith.”
Luke 18:43 At once the man could see, and he went with Jesus and started thanking God. When the crowds saw what happened, they praised God.
Luke 19:1 Jesus was going through Jericho,
Luke 19:2 where a man named Zacchaeus lived. He was in charge of collecting taxes and was very rich.
Luke 19:3+LUK Jesus was heading his way, and Zacchaeus wanted to see what he was like. But Zacchaeus was a short man and could not see over the crowd. So he ran ahead and climbed up into a sycamore tree.
Luke 19:5 When Jesus got there, he looked up and said, “Zacchaeus, hurry down! I want to stay with you today.”
Luke 19:6 Zacchaeus hurried down and gladly welcomed Jesus.
Luke 19:7 Everyone who saw this started grumbling, “This man Zacchaeus is a sinner! And Jesus is going home to eat with him.”
Luke 19:8 Later that day Zacchaeus stood up and said to the Lord, “I will give half of my property to the poor. And I will now pay back four times as much to everyone I have ever cheated.”
Luke 19:9 Jesus said to Zacchaeus, “Today you and your family have been saved, because you are a true son of Abraham.
Luke 19:10 The Son of Man came to look for and to save people who are lost.”
Luke 19:11 The crowd was still listening to Jesus as he was getting close to Jerusalem. Many of them thought that God's kingdom would soon appear,
Luke 19:12 and Jesus told them this story: A prince once went to a foreign country to be crowned king and then to return.
Luke 19:13 But before leaving, he called in ten servants and gave each of them some money. He told them, “Use this to earn more money until I get back.”
Luke 19:14 But the people of his country hated him, and they sent messengers to the foreign country to say, “We don't want this man to be our king.”
Luke 19:15 After the prince had been made king, he returned and called in his servants. He asked them how much they had earned with the money they had been given.
Luke 19:16 The first servant came and said, “Sir, with the money you gave me I have earned ten times as much.”
Luke 19:17 “That's fine, my good servant!” the king said. “Since you have shown that you can be trusted with a small amount, you will be given ten cities to rule.”
Luke 19:18 The second one came and said, “Sir, with the money you gave me, I have earned five times as much.”
Luke 19:19 The king said, “You will be given five cities.”
Luke 19:20 Another servant came and said, “Sir, here is your money. I kept it safe in a handkerchief.
Luke 19:21 You are a hard man, and I was afraid of you. You take what isn't yours, and you harvest crops you didn't plant.”
Luke 19:22 “You worthless servant!” the king told him. “You have condemned yourself by what you have just said. You knew I am a hard man, taking what isn't mine and harvesting what I've not planted.
Luke 19:23 Why didn't you put my money in the bank? On my return, I could have had the money together with interest.”
Luke 19:24 Then he said to some other servants standing there, “Take the money away from him and give it to the servant who earned ten times as much.”
Luke 19:25 But they said, “Sir, he already has ten times as much!”
Luke 19:26 The king replied, “Those who have something will be given more. But everything will be taken away from those who don't have anything.
Luke 19:27 Now bring me the enemies who didn't want me to be their king. Kill them while I watch!”
Luke 19:28 When Jesus had finished saying all this, he went on toward Jerusalem.
Luke 19:29 As he was getting near Bethphage and Bethany on the Mount of Olives, he sent two of his disciples on ahead.
Luke 19:30 He told them, “Go into the next village, where you will find a young donkey that has never been ridden. Untie the donkey and bring it here.
Luke 19:31 If anyone asks why you are doing this, just say, ‘The Lord needs it.’ ”
Luke 19:32 They went off and found everything just as Jesus had said.
Luke 19:33 While they were untying the donkey, its owners asked, “Why are you doing that?”
Luke 19:34 They answered, “The Lord needs it.”
Luke 19:35 Then they led the donkey to Jesus. They put some of their clothes on its back and helped Jesus get on.
Luke 19:36 And as he rode along, the people spread clothes on the road in front of him.
Luke 19:37 When Jesus started down the Mount of Olives, his large crowd of disciples were happy and praised God because of all the miracles they had seen.
Luke 19:38 They shouted, “Blessed is the king who comes in the name of the Lord! Peace in heaven and glory to God.”
Luke 19:39 Some Pharisees in the crowd said to Jesus, “Teacher, make your disciples stop shouting!”
Luke 19:40 But Jesus answered, “If they keep quiet, these stones will start shouting.”
Luke 19:41 When Jesus came closer and could see Jerusalem, he cried
Luke 19:42 and said: It is too bad that today your people don't know what will bring them peace! Now it is hidden from them.
Luke 19:43 Jerusalem, the time will come when your enemies will build walls around you to attack you. Armies will surround you and close in on you from every side.
Luke 19:44 They will level you to the ground and kill your people. Not one stone in your buildings will be left on top of another. This will happen because you did not see that God had come to save you.
Luke 19:45 When Jesus entered the temple, he started chasing out the people who were selling things.
Luke 19:46 He told them, “The Scriptures say, ‘My house should be a place of worship.’ But you have made it a place where robbers hide!”
Luke 19:47 Each day, Jesus kept on teaching in the temple. So the chief priests, the teachers of the Law of Moses, and some other important people tried to have him killed.
Luke 19:48 But they could not find a way to do it, because everyone else was eager to listen to him.
Luke 20:1 One day, Jesus was teaching in the temple and telling the good news. So the chief priests, the teachers, and the nation's leaders
Luke 20:2 asked him, “What right do you have to do these things? Who gave you this authority?”
Luke 20:3 Jesus replied, “I want to ask you a question.
Luke 20:4 Who gave John the right to baptize? Was it God in heaven or merely some human being?”
Luke 20:5 They talked this over and said to each other, “We can't say God gave John this right. Jesus will ask us why we didn't believe John.
Luke 20:6 And we can't say it was merely some human who gave John the right to baptize. The crowd will stone us to death, because they think John was a prophet.”
Luke 20:7 So they told Jesus, “We don't know who gave John the right to baptize.”
Luke 20:8 Jesus replied, “Then I won't tell you who gave me the right to do what I do.”
Luke 20:9 Jesus told the people this story: A man once planted a vineyard and rented it out. Then he left the country for a long time.
Luke 20:10 When it was time to harvest the crop, he sent a servant to ask the renters for his share of the grapes. But they beat up the servant and sent him away without anything.
Luke 20:11 So the owner sent another servant. The renters also beat him up. They insulted him terribly and sent him away without a thing.
Luke 20:12 The owner sent a third servant. He was also beaten terribly and thrown out of the vineyard.
Luke 20:13 The owner then said to himself, “What am I going to do? I know what. I'll send my son, the one I love so much. They will surely respect him!”
Luke 20:14 When the renters saw the owner's son, they said to one another, “Someday he will own the vineyard. Let's kill him! Then we can have it all for ourselves.”
Luke 20:15 So they threw him out of the vineyard and killed him. Jesus asked, “What do you think the owner of the vineyard will do?
Luke 20:16 I'll tell you what. He will come and kill those renters and let someone else have his vineyard.” When the people heard this, they said, “This must never happen!”
Luke 20:17 But Jesus looked straight at them and said, “Then what do the Scriptures mean when they say, ‘The stone the builders tossed aside is now the most important stone of all’?
Luke 20:18 Anyone who stumbles over this stone will get hurt, and anyone it falls on will be smashed to pieces.”
Luke 20:19 The chief priests and the teachers of the Law of Moses knew that Jesus was talking about them when he was telling this story. They wanted to arrest him right then, but they were afraid of the people.
Luke 20:20 Jesus' enemies kept watching him closely, because they wanted to hand him over to the Roman governor. So they sent some men who pretended to be good. But they were really spies trying to catch Jesus saying something wrong.
Luke 20:21 The spies said to him, “Teacher, we know you teach the truth about what God wants people to do. And you treat everyone with the same respect, no matter who they are.
Luke 20:22 Tell us, should we pay taxes to the Emperor or not?”
Luke 20:23 Jesus knew they were trying to trick him. So he told them,
Luke 20:24 “Show me a coin.” Then he asked, “Whose picture and name are on it?” “The Emperor's,” they answered.
Luke 20:25 Then he told them, “Give the Emperor what belongs to him and give God what belongs to God.”
Luke 20:26 Jesus' enemies could not catch him saying anything wrong there in front of the people. They were amazed at his answer and kept quiet.
Luke 20:27 The Sadducees did not believe that people would rise to life after death. So some of them came to Jesus
Luke 20:28 and said: Teacher, Moses wrote that if a married man dies and has no children, his brother should marry the widow. Their first son would then be thought of as the son of the dead brother.
Luke 20:29 There were once seven brothers. The first one married, but died without having any children.
Luke 20:30 The second one married his brother's widow, and he also died without having any children.
Luke 20:31 The same thing happened to the third one. Finally, all seven brothers married this woman and died without having any children.
Luke 20:32 At last the woman died.
Luke 20:33 When God raises people from death, whose wife will this woman be? All seven brothers had married her.
Luke 20:34 Jesus answered: The people in this world get married.
Luke 20:35 But in the future world no one who is worthy to rise from death will either marry
Luke 20:36 or die. They will be like the angels and will be God's children, because they have been raised to life.
Luke 20:37 In the story about the burning bush, Moses clearly shows that people will live again. He said, “The Lord is the God worshiped by Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.”
Luke 20:38 So the Lord isn't the God of the dead, but of the living. This means that everyone is alive as far as God is concerned.
Luke 20:39 Some of the teachers of the Law of Moses said, “Teacher, you have given a good answer!”
Luke 20:40 From then on, no one dared to ask Jesus any questions.
Luke 20:41 Jesus asked, “Why do people say that the Messiah will be the son of King David?
Luke 20:42 In the book of Psalms, David himself says, ‘The Lord said to my Lord, Sit at my right side
Luke 20:43 until I make your enemies into a footstool for you.’
Luke 20:44 David spoke of the Messiah as his Lord, so how can the Messiah be his son?”
Luke 20:45 While everyone was listening to Jesus, he said to his disciples:
Luke 20:46 Guard against the teachers of the Law of Moses! They love to walk around in long robes, and they like to be greeted in the market. They want the front seats in the synagogues and the best seats at banquets.
Luke 20:47 But they cheat widows out of their homes and then pray long prayers just to show off. These teachers will be punished most of all.
Luke 21:1 Jesus looked up and saw some rich people tossing their gifts into the offering box.
Luke 21:2 He also saw a poor widow putting in a few cents.
Luke 21:3 And he said, “I tell you that this poor woman has put in more than all the others.
Luke 21:4 Everyone else gave what they didn't need. But she is very poor and gave everything she had.”
Luke 21:5 Some people were talking about the beautiful stones used to build the temple and about the gifts that had been placed in it. Jesus said,
Luke 21:6 “Do you see these stones? The time is coming when not one of them will be left in place. They will all be knocked down.”
Luke 21:7 Some people asked, “Teacher, when will all this happen? How can we know when these things are about to take place?”
Luke 21:8 Jesus replied: Don't be fooled by those who will come and claim to be me. They will say, “I am Christ!” and “Now is the time!” But don't follow them.
Luke 21:9 When you hear about wars and riots, don't be afraid. These things will have to happen first, but this isn't the end.
Luke 21:10 Nations will go to war against one another, and kingdoms will attack each other.
Luke 21:11 There will be great earthquakes, and in many places people will starve to death and suffer terrible diseases. All sorts of frightening things will be seen in the sky.
Luke 21:12 Before all this happens, you will be arrested and punished. You will be tried in your synagogues and put in jail. Because of me you will be placed on trial before kings and governors.
Luke 21:13 But this will be your chance to tell about your faith.
Luke 21:14 Don't worry about what you will say to defend yourselves.
Luke 21:15 I will give you the wisdom to know what to say. None of your enemies will be able to oppose you or to say that you are wrong.
Luke 21:16 You will be betrayed by your own parents, brothers, family, and friends. Some of you will even be killed.
Luke 21:17 Because of me, you will be hated by everyone.
Luke 21:18 But don't worry!
Luke 21:19 You will be saved by being faithful to me.
Luke 21:20 When you see Jerusalem surrounded by soldiers, you will know that it will soon be destroyed.
Luke 21:21 If you are living in Judea at this time, run to the mountains. If you are in the city, leave it. And if you are out in the country, don't go back into the city.
Luke 21:22 This time of punishment is what is written about in the Scriptures.
Luke 21:23 It will be an awful time for women who are expecting babies or nursing young children! Everywhere in the land people will suffer horribly and be punished.
Luke 21:24 Some of them will be killed by swords. Others will be carried off to foreign countries. Jerusalem will be overrun by foreign nations until their time comes to an end.
Luke 21:25 Strange things will happen to the sun, moon, and stars. The nations on earth will be afraid of the roaring sea and tides, and they won't know what to do.
Luke 21:26 People will be so frightened that they will faint because of what is happening to the world. Every power in the sky will be shaken.
Luke 21:27 Then the Son of Man will be seen, coming in a cloud with power and great glory.
Luke 21:28 When all of this starts happening, stand up straight and be brave. You will soon be set free.
Luke 21:29 Then Jesus told them a story: When you see a fig tree or any other tree
Luke 21:30 putting out leaves, you know that summer will soon come.
Luke 21:31 So, when you see these things happening, you know that God's kingdom will soon be here.
Luke 21:32 You can be sure that some of the people of this generation will still be alive when all of this takes place.
Luke 21:33 The sky and the earth won't last forever, but my words will.
Luke 21:34 Don't spend all of your time thinking about eating or drinking or worrying about life. If you do, the final day will suddenly catch you
Luke 21:35 like a trap. This day will surprise everyone on earth.
Luke 21:36 Watch out and keep praying that you can escape all that is going to happen and that the Son of Man will be pleased with you.
Luke 21:37 Jesus taught in the temple each day, and he spent each night on the Mount of Olives.
Luke 21:38 Everyone got up early and came to the temple to hear him teach.
Luke 22:1 The Festival of Thin Bread, also called Passover, was near.
Luke 22:2 The chief priests and the teachers of the Law of Moses were looking for a way to get rid of Jesus, because they were afraid of what the people might do.
Luke 22:3 Then Satan entered the heart of Judas Iscariot, who was one of the twelve apostles.
Luke 22:4 Judas went to talk with the chief priests and the officers of the temple police about how he could help them arrest Jesus.
Luke 22:5 They were very pleased and offered to pay Judas some money.
Luke 22:6 He agreed and started looking for a good chance to betray Jesus when the crowds were not around.
Luke 22:7 The day had come for the Festival of Thin Bread, and it was time to kill the Passover lambs.
Luke 22:8 So Jesus said to Peter and John, “Go and prepare the Passover meal for us to eat.”
Luke 22:9 But they asked, “Where do you want us to prepare it?”
Luke 22:10 Jesus told them, “As you go into the city, you will meet a man carrying a jar of water. Follow him into the house
Luke 22:11 and say to the owner, ‘Our teacher wants to know where he can eat the Passover meal with his disciples.’
Luke 22:12 The owner will take you upstairs and show you a large room ready for you to use. Prepare the meal there.”
Luke 22:13 Peter and John left. They found everything just as Jesus had told them, and they prepared the Passover meal.
Luke 22:14 When the time came for Jesus and the apostles to eat,
Luke 22:15 he said to them, “I have very much wanted to eat this Passover meal with you before I suffer.
Luke 22:16 I tell you I will not eat another Passover meal until it is finally eaten in God's kingdom.”
Luke 22:17 Jesus took a cup of wine in his hands and gave thanks to God. Then he told the apostles, “Take this wine and share it with each other.
Luke 22:18 I tell you that I will not drink any more wine until God's kingdom comes.”
Luke 22:19 Jesus took some bread in his hands and gave thanks for it. He broke the bread and handed it to his apostles. Then he said, “This is my body, which is given for you. Eat this as a way of remembering me!”
Luke 22:20 After the meal he took another cup of wine in his hands. Then he said, “This is my blood. It is poured out for you, and with it God makes his new agreement.
Luke 22:21 The one who will betray me is here at the table with me!
Luke 22:22 The Son of Man will die in the way that has been decided for him, but it will be terrible for the one who betrays him!”
Luke 22:23 Then the apostles started arguing about who would ever do such a thing.
Luke 22:24 The apostles got into an argument about which one of them was the greatest.
Luke 22:25 So Jesus told them: Foreign kings order their people around, and powerful rulers call themselves everyone's friends.
Luke 22:26 But don't be like them. The most important one of you should be like the least important, and your leader should be like a servant.
Luke 22:27 Who do people think is the greatest, a person who is served or one who serves? Isn't it the one who is served? But I have been with you as a servant.
Luke 22:28 You have stayed with me in all my troubles.
Luke 22:29 So I will give you the right to rule as kings, just as my Father has given me the right to rule as a king.
Luke 22:30 You will eat and drink with me in my kingdom, and you will each sit on a throne to judge the twelve tribes of Israel.
Luke 22:31 Jesus said, “Simon, listen to me! Satan has demanded the right to test each one of you, as a farmer does when he separates wheat from the husks.
Luke 22:32 But Simon, I have prayed that your faith will be strong. And when you have come back to me, help the others.”
Luke 22:33 Peter said, “Lord, I am ready to go with you to jail and even to die with you.”
Luke 22:34 Jesus replied, “Peter, I tell you that before a rooster crows tomorrow morning, you will say three times that you don't know me.”
Luke 22:35 Jesus asked his disciples, “When I sent you out without a moneybag or a traveling bag or sandals, did you need anything?” “No!” they answered.
Luke 22:36 Jesus told them, “But now, if you have a moneybag, take it with you. Also take a traveling bag, and if you don't have a sword, sell some of your clothes and buy one.
Luke 22:37 Do this because the Scriptures say, ‘He was considered a criminal.’ This was written about me, and it will soon come true.”
Luke 22:38 The disciples said, “Lord, here are two swords!” “Enough of that!” Jesus replied.
Luke 22:39 Jesus went out to the Mount of Olives, as he often did, and his disciples went with him.
Luke 22:40 When they got there, he told them, “Pray that you won't be tested.”
Luke 22:41 Jesus walked on a little way before he knelt down and prayed,
Luke 22:42 “Father, if you will, please don't make me suffer by drinking from this cup. But do what you want, and not what I want.”
Luke 22:43 Then an angel from heaven came to help him.
Luke 22:44 Jesus was in great pain and prayed so sincerely that his sweat fell to the ground like drops of blood.
Luke 22:45 Jesus got up from praying and went over to his disciples. They were asleep and worn out from being so sad.
Luke 22:46 He said to them, “Why are you asleep? Wake up and pray that you won't be tested.”
Luke 22:47 While Jesus was still speaking, a crowd came up. It was led by Judas, one of the twelve apostles. He went over to Jesus and greeted him with a kiss.
Luke 22:48 Jesus asked Judas, “Are you betraying the Son of Man with a kiss?”
Luke 22:49 When Jesus' disciples saw what was about to happen, they asked, “Lord, should we attack them with a sword?”
Luke 22:50 One of the disciples even struck at the high priest's servant with his sword and cut off the servant's right ear.
Luke 22:51 “Enough of that!” Jesus said. Then he touched the servant's ear and healed it.
Luke 22:52 Jesus spoke to the chief priests, the temple police, and the leaders who had come to arrest him. He said, “Why do you come out with swords and clubs and treat me like a criminal?
Luke 22:53 I was with you every day in the temple, and you didn't arrest me. But this is your time, and darkness is in control.”
Luke 22:54 Jesus was arrested and led away to the house of the high priest, while Peter followed at a distance.
Luke 22:55 Some people built a fire in the middle of the courtyard and were sitting around it. Peter sat there with them,
Luke 22:56 and a servant girl saw him. Then after she had looked at him carefully, she said, “This man was with Jesus!”
Luke 22:57 Peter said, “Woman, I don't even know that man!”
Luke 22:58 A little later someone else saw Peter and said, “You are one of them!” “No, I'm not!” Peter replied.
Luke 22:59 About an hour later another man insisted, “This man must have been with Jesus. They both come from Galilee.”
Luke 22:60 Peter replied, “I don't know what you are talking about!” Right then, while Peter was still speaking, a rooster crowed.
Luke 22:61 The Lord turned and looked at Peter. And Peter remembered that the Lord had said, “Before a rooster crows tomorrow morning, you will say three times that you don't know me.”
Luke 22:62 Then Peter went out and cried bitterly.
Luke 22:63 The men who were guarding Jesus made fun of him and beat him.
Luke 22:64 They put a blindfold on him and said, “Tell us who struck you!”
Luke 22:65 They kept on insulting Jesus in many other ways.
Luke 22:66 At daybreak the nation's leaders, the chief priests, and the teachers of the Law of Moses got together and brought Jesus before their council.
Luke 22:67 They said, “Tell us! Are you the Messiah?” Jesus replied, “If I said so, you wouldn't believe me.
Luke 22:68 And if I asked you a question, you wouldn't answer.
Luke 22:69 But from now on, the Son of Man will be seated at the right side of God All-Powerful.”
Luke 22:70 Then they asked, “Are you the Son of God?” Jesus answered, “You say I am!”
Luke 22:71 They replied, “Why do we need more witnesses? He said it himself!”
Luke 23:1 Everyone in the council got up and led Jesus off to Pilate.
Luke 23:2 They started accusing him and said, “We caught this man trying to get our people to riot and to stop paying taxes to the Emperor. He also claims that he is the Messiah, our king.”
Luke 23:3 Pilate asked Jesus, “Are you the king of the Jews?” “Those are your words,” Jesus answered.
Luke 23:4 Pilate told the chief priests and the crowd, “I don't find him guilty of anything.”
Luke 23:5 But they all kept on saying, “He has been teaching and causing trouble all over Judea. He started in Galilee and has now come all the way here.”
Luke 23:6 When Pilate heard this, he asked, “Is this man from Galilee?”
Luke 23:7 After Pilate learned that Jesus came from the region ruled by Herod, he sent him to Herod, who was in Jerusalem at that time.
Luke 23:8 For a long time Herod had wanted to see Jesus and was very happy because he finally had this chance. He had heard many things about Jesus and hoped to see him work a miracle.
Luke 23:9 Herod asked him a lot of questions, but Jesus did not answer.
Luke 23:10 Then the chief priests and the teachers of the Law of Moses stood up and accused him of all kinds of bad things.
Luke 23:11 Herod and his soldiers made fun of Jesus and insulted him. They put a fine robe on him and sent him back to Pilate.
Luke 23:12 That same day Herod and Pilate became friends, even though they had been enemies before this.
Luke 23:13 Pilate called together the chief priests, the leaders, and the people.
Luke 23:14 He told them, “You brought Jesus to me and said he was a troublemaker. But I have questioned him here in front of you, and I have not found him guilty of anything that you say he has done.
Luke 23:15 Herod didn't find him guilty either and sent him back. This man doesn't deserve to be put to death!
Luke 23:16+LUK I will just have him beaten with a whip and set free.”
Luke 23:18 But the whole crowd shouted, “Kill Jesus! Give us Barabbas!”
Luke 23:19 Now Barabbas was in jail because he had started a riot in the city and had murdered someone.
Luke 23:20 Pilate wanted to set Jesus free, so he spoke again to the crowds.
Luke 23:21 But they kept shouting, “Nail him to a cross! Nail him to a cross!”
Luke 23:22 Pilate spoke to them a third time, “But what crime has he done? I have not found him guilty of anything for which he should be put to death. I will have him beaten with a whip and set free.”
Luke 23:23 The people kept on shouting as loud as they could for Jesus to be put to death.
Luke 23:24 Finally, Pilate gave in.
Luke 23:25 He freed the man who was in jail for rioting and murder, because he was the one the crowd wanted to be set free. Then Pilate handed Jesus over for them to do what they wanted with him.
Luke 23:26 As Jesus was being led away, some soldiers grabbed hold of a man named Simon who was from Cyrene. He was coming in from the fields, but they put the cross on him and made him carry it behind Jesus.
Luke 23:27 A large crowd was following Jesus, and in the crowd a lot of women were crying and weeping for him.
Luke 23:28 Jesus turned to the women and said: Women of Jerusalem, don't cry for me! Cry for yourselves and for your children.
Luke 23:29 Someday people will say, “Women who never had children are really fortunate!”
Luke 23:30 At that time everyone will say to the mountains, “Fall on us!” They will say to the hills, “Hide us!”
Luke 23:31 If this can happen when the wood is green, what do you think will happen when it is dry?
Luke 23:32 Two criminals were led out to be put to death with Jesus.
Luke 23:33 When the soldiers came to the place called “The Skull,” they nailed Jesus to a cross. They also nailed the two criminals to crosses, one on each side of Jesus.
Luke 23:34+LUK Jesus said, “Father, forgive these people! They don't know what they're doing.” While the crowd stood there watching Jesus, the soldiers gambled for his clothes. The leaders insulted him by saying, “He saved others. Now he should save himself, if he really is God's chosen Messiah!”
Luke 23:36 The soldiers made fun of Jesus and brought him some wine.
Luke 23:37 They said, “If you are the king of the Jews, save yourself!”
Luke 23:38 Above him was a sign that said, “This is the King of the Jews.”
Luke 23:39 One of the criminals hanging there also insulted Jesus by saying, “Aren't you the Messiah? Save yourself and save us!”
Luke 23:40 But the other criminal told the first one off, “Don't you fear God? Aren't you getting the same punishment as this man?
Luke 23:41 We got what was coming to us, but he didn't do anything wrong.”
Luke 23:42 Then he said to Jesus, “Remember me when you come into power!”
Luke 23:43 Jesus replied, “I promise that today you will be with me in paradise.”
Luke 23:44 Around noon the sky turned dark and stayed that way until the middle of the afternoon.
Luke 23:45 The sun stopped shining, and the curtain in the temple split down the middle.
Luke 23:46 Jesus shouted, “Father, I put myself in your hands!” Then he died.
Luke 23:47 When the Roman officer saw what had happened, he praised God and said, “Jesus must really have been a good man!”
Luke 23:48 A crowd had gathered to see the terrible sight. Then after they had seen it, they felt brokenhearted and went home.
Luke 23:49 All of Jesus' close friends and the women who had come with him from Galilee stood at a distance and watched.
Luke 23:50+LUK There was a man named Joseph, who was from Arimathea in Judea. Joseph was a good and honest man, and he was eager for God's kingdom to come. He was also a member of the council, but he did not agree with what they had decided.
Luke 23:52 Joseph went to Pilate and asked for Jesus' body.
Luke 23:53 He took the body down from the cross and wrapped it in fine cloth. Then he put it in a tomb that had been cut out of solid rock and had never been used.
Luke 23:54 It was Friday, and the Sabbath was about to begin.
Luke 23:55 The women who had come with Jesus from Galilee followed Joseph and watched how Jesus' body was placed in the tomb.
Luke 23:56 Then they went to prepare some sweet-smelling spices for his burial. But on the Sabbath they rested, as the Law of Moses commands.
Luke 24:1 Very early on Sunday morning the women went to the tomb, carrying the spices they had prepared.
Luke 24:2 When they found the stone rolled away from the entrance,
Luke 24:3 they went in. But they did not find the body of the Lord Jesus,
Luke 24:4 and they did not know what to think. Suddenly two men in shining white clothes stood beside them.
Luke 24:5 The women were afraid and bowed to the ground. But the men said, “Why are you looking in the place of the dead for someone who is alive?
Luke 24:6 Jesus isn't here! He has been raised from death. Remember that while he was still in Galilee, he told you,
Luke 24:7 ‘The Son of Man will be handed over to sinners who will nail him to a cross. But three days later he will rise to life.’ ”
Luke 24:8 Then they remembered what Jesus had said.
Luke 24:9+LUK Mary Magdalene, Joanna, Mary the mother of James, and some other women were the ones who had gone to the tomb. When they returned, they told the eleven apostles and the others what had happened.
Luke 24:11 The apostles thought it was all nonsense, and they would not believe.
Luke 24:12 But Peter ran to the tomb. And when he stooped down and looked in, he saw only the burial clothes. Then he returned, wondering what had happened.
Luke 24:13 That same day two of Jesus' disciples were going to the village of Emmaus, which was about eleven kilometers from Jerusalem.
Luke 24:14 As they were talking and thinking about what had happened,
Luke 24:15 Jesus came near and started walking along beside them.
Luke 24:16 But they did not know who he was.
Luke 24:17 Jesus asked them, “What were you talking about as you walked along?” The two of them stood there looking sad and gloomy.
Luke 24:18 Then the one named Cleopas asked Jesus, “Are you the only person from Jerusalem who didn't know what was happening there these last few days?”
Luke 24:19 “What do you mean?” Jesus asked. They answered: Those things that happened to Jesus from Nazareth. By what he did and said he showed that he was a powerful prophet, who pleased God and all the people.
Luke 24:20 Then the chief priests and our leaders had him arrested and sentenced to die on a cross.
Luke 24:21 We had hoped that he would be the one to set Israel free! But it has already been three days since all this happened.
Luke 24:22 Some women in our group surprised us. They had gone to the tomb early in the morning,
Luke 24:23 but did not find the body of Jesus. They came back, saying they had seen a vision of angels who told them that he is alive.
Luke 24:24 Some men from our group went to the tomb and found it just as the women had said. But they didn't see Jesus either.
Luke 24:25 Then Jesus asked the two disciples, “Why can't you understand? How can you be so slow to believe all that the prophets said?
Luke 24:26 Didn't you know that the Messiah would have to suffer before he was given his glory?”
Luke 24:27 Jesus then explained everything written about himself in the Scriptures, beginning with the Law of Moses and the Books of the Prophets.
Luke 24:28 When the two of them came near the village where they were going, Jesus seemed to be going farther.
Luke 24:29 They begged him, “Stay with us! It's already late, and the sun is going down.” So Jesus went into the house to stay with them.
Luke 24:30 After Jesus sat down to eat, he took some bread. He blessed it and broke it. Then he gave it to them.
Luke 24:31 At once they knew who he was, but he disappeared.
Luke 24:32 They said to each other, “When he talked with us along the road and explained the Scriptures to us, didn't it warm our hearts?”
Luke 24:33 So they got up and returned to Jerusalem. The two disciples found the eleven apostles and the others gathered together.
Luke 24:34 And they learned from the group that the Lord was really alive and had appeared to Peter.
Luke 24:35 Then the disciples from Emmaus told what happened on the road and how they knew he was the Lord when he broke the bread.
Luke 24:36 While Jesus' disciples were talking about what had happened, Jesus appeared and greeted them.
Luke 24:37 They were frightened and terrified because they thought they were seeing a ghost.
Luke 24:38 But Jesus said, “Why are you so frightened? Why do you doubt?
Luke 24:39 Look at my hands and my feet and see who I am! Touch me and find out for yourselves. Ghosts don't have flesh and bones as you see I have.”
Luke 24:40 After Jesus said this, he showed them his hands and his feet.
Luke 24:41 The disciples were so glad and amazed that they could not believe it. Jesus then asked them, “Do you have something to eat?”
Luke 24:42 They gave him a piece of broiled fish.
Luke 24:43 He took it and ate it as they watched.
Luke 24:44 Jesus said to them, “While I was still with you, I told you that everything written about me in the Law of Moses, the Books of the Prophets, and in the Psalms had to happen.”
Luke 24:45 Then he helped them understand the Scriptures.
Luke 24:46 He told them: The Scriptures say that the Messiah must suffer, then three days later he will rise from death.
Luke 24:47 They also say that all people of every nation must be told in my name to turn to God, in order to be forgiven. So beginning in Jerusalem,
Luke 24:48 you must tell everything that has happened.
Luke 24:49 I will send you the one my Father has promised, but you must stay in the city until you are given power from heaven.
Luke 24:50 Jesus led his disciples out to Bethany, where he raised his hands and blessed them.
Luke 24:51 As he was doing this, he left and was taken up to heaven.
Luke 24:52 After his disciples had worshiped him, they returned to Jerusalem and were very happy.
Luke 24:53 They spent their time in the temple, praising God.
John 1:1 In the beginning was the one who is called the Word. The Word was with God and was truly God.
John 1:2 From the very beginning the Word was with God.
John 1:3 And with this Word, God created all things. Nothing was made without the Word. Everything that was created
John 1:4 received its life from him, and his life gave light to everyone.
John 1:5 The light keeps shining in the dark, and darkness has never put it out.
John 1:6 God sent a man named John,
John 1:7 who came to tell about the light and to lead all people to have faith.
John 1:8 John wasn't this light. He came only to tell about the light.
John 1:9 The true light that shines on everyone was coming into the world.
John 1:10 The Word was in the world, but no one knew him, though God had made the world with his Word.
John 1:11 He came into his own world, but his own nation did not welcome him.
John 1:12 Yet some people accepted him and put their faith in him. So he gave them the right to be the children of God.
John 1:13 They were not God's children by nature or because of any human desires. God himself was the one who made them his children.
John 1:14 The Word became a human being and lived here with us. We saw his true glory, the glory of the only Son of the Father. From him the complete gifts of undeserved grace and truth have come down to us.
John 1:15 John spoke about him and shouted, “This is the one I told you would come! He is greater than I am, because he was alive before I was born.”
John 1:16 Because of all that the Son is, we have been given one blessing after another.
John 1:17 The Law was given by Moses, but Jesus Christ brought us undeserved kindness and truth.
John 1:18 No one has ever seen God. The only Son, who is truly God and is closest to the Father, has shown us what God is like.
John 1:19+JHN The religious authorities in Jerusalem sent priests and temple helpers to ask John who he was. He told them plainly, “I am not the Messiah.”
John 1:21 Then when they asked him if he were Elijah, he said, “No, I am not!” And when they asked if he were the Prophet, he also said “No!”
John 1:22 Finally, they said, “Who are you then? We have to give an answer to the ones who sent us. Tell us who you are!”
John 1:23 John answered in the words of the prophet Isaiah, “I am only someone shouting in the desert, ‘Get the road ready for the Lord!’ ”
John 1:24 Some Pharisees had also been sent to John.
John 1:25 They asked him, “Why are you baptizing people, if you are not the Messiah or Elijah or the Prophet?”
John 1:26 John told them, “I use water to baptize people. But here with you is someone you don't know.
John 1:27 Even though I came first, I am not good enough to untie his sandals.”
John 1:28 John said this as he was baptizing east of the Jordan River in Bethany.
John 1:29 The next day, John saw Jesus coming toward him and said: Here is the Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world!
John 1:30 He is the one I told you about when I said, “Someone else will come, who is greater than I am, because he was alive before I was born.”
John 1:31 I didn't know who he was. But I came to baptize you with water, so that everyone in Israel would see him.
John 1:32 I was there and saw the Spirit come down on him like a dove from heaven. And the Spirit stayed on him.
John 1:33 Before this I didn't know who he was. But the one who sent me to baptize with water had told me, “You will see the Spirit come down and stay on someone. Then you will know that he is the one who will baptize with the Holy Spirit.”
John 1:34 I saw this happen, and I tell you that he is the Son of God.
John 1:35 The next day, John was there again, and two of his followers were with him.
John 1:36 When he saw Jesus walking by, he said, “Here is the Lamb of God!”
John 1:37 John's two followers heard him, and they went with Jesus.
John 1:38 When Jesus turned and saw them, he asked, “What do you want?” They answered, “Rabbi, where do you live?” The Hebrew word “Rabbi” means “Teacher.”
John 1:39 Jesus replied, “Come and see!” It was already about four o'clock in the afternoon when they went with him and saw where he lived. So they stayed on for the rest of the day.
John 1:40 One of the two men who had heard John and had gone with Jesus was Andrew, the brother of Simon Peter.
John 1:41 The first thing Andrew did was to find his brother and tell him, “We have found the Messiah!” The Hebrew word “Messiah” means the same as the Greek word “Christ.”
John 1:42 Andrew brought his brother to Jesus. And when Jesus saw him, he said, “Simon son of John, you will be called Cephas.” This name can be translated as “Peter.”
John 1:43+JHN The next day Jesus decided to go to Galilee. There he met Philip, who was from Bethsaida, the hometown of Andrew and Peter. Jesus said to Philip, “Follow me.”
John 1:45 Philip then found Nathanael and said, “We have found the one that Moses and the Prophets wrote about. He is Jesus, the son of Joseph from Nazareth.”
John 1:46 Nathanael asked, “Can anything good come from Nazareth?” Philip answered, “Come and see.”
John 1:47 When Jesus saw Nathanael coming toward him, he said, “Here is a true descendant of our ancestor Israel. And he isn't deceitful.”
John 1:48 “How do you know me?” Nathanael asked. Jesus answered, “Before Philip called you, I saw you under the fig tree.”
John 1:49 Nathanael said, “Rabbi, you are the Son of God and the King of Israel!”
John 1:50 Jesus answered, “Did you believe me just because I said that I saw you under the fig tree? You will see something even greater.
John 1:51 I tell you for certain you will see heaven open and God's angels going up and coming down on the Son of Man.”
John 2:1 Three days later Mary, the mother of Jesus, was at a wedding feast in the village of Cana in Galilee.
John 2:2 Jesus and his disciples had also been invited and were there.
John 2:3 When the wine was all gone, Mary said to Jesus, “They don't have any more wine.”
John 2:4 Jesus replied, “Mother, my time hasn't yet come! You must not tell me what to do.”
John 2:5 Mary then said to the servants, “Do whatever Jesus tells you to do.”
John 2:6 At the feast there were six stone water jars that were used by the people for washing themselves in the way that their religion said they must. Each jar held about 100 liters.
John 2:7 Jesus told the servants to fill them to the top with water. Then after the jars had been filled,
John 2:8 he said, “Now take some water and give it to the man in charge of the feast.” The servants did as Jesus told them,
John 2:9 and the man in charge drank some of the water that had now turned into wine. He did not know where the wine had come from, but the servants did. He called the bridegroom over
John 2:10 and said, “The best wine is always served first. Then after the guests have had plenty, the other wine is served. But you have kept the best until last!”
John 2:11 This was Jesus' first miracle, and he did it in the village of Cana in Galilee. There Jesus showed his glory, and his disciples put their faith in him.
John 2:12 After this, he went with his mother, his brothers, and his disciples to the town of Capernaum, where they stayed for a few days.
John 2:13 Not long before the Jewish festival of Passover, Jesus went to Jerusalem.
John 2:14 There he found people selling cattle, sheep, and doves in the temple. He also saw moneychangers sitting at their tables.
John 2:15 So he took some rope and made a whip. Then he chased everyone out of the temple, together with their sheep and cattle. He turned over the tables of the moneychangers and scattered their coins.
John 2:16 Jesus said to the people who had been selling doves, “Get those doves out of here! Don't make my Father's house a marketplace.”
John 2:17 The disciples then remembered that the Scriptures say, “My love for your house burns in me like a fire.”
John 2:18 The Jewish leaders asked Jesus, “What miracle will you work to show us why you have done this?”
John 2:19 “Destroy this temple,” Jesus answered, “and in three days I will build it again!”
John 2:20 The leaders replied, “It took 46 years to build this temple. What makes you think you can rebuild it in three days?”
John 2:21 But Jesus was talking about his body as a temple.
John 2:22 And when he was raised from death, his disciples remembered what he had told them. Then they believed the Scriptures and the words of Jesus.
John 2:23 In Jerusalem during Passover many people put their faith in Jesus, because they saw him work miracles.
John 2:24 But Jesus knew what was in their hearts, and he would not let them have power over him.
John 2:25 No one had to tell him what people were like. He already knew.
John 3:1 There was a man named Nicodemus who was a Pharisee and a Jewish leader.
John 3:2 One night he went to Jesus and said, “Rabbi, we know that God has sent you to teach us. You could not work these miracles, unless God were with you.”
John 3:3 Jesus replied, “I tell you for certain that you must be born from above before you can see God's kingdom!”
John 3:4 Nicodemus asked, “How can a grown man ever be born a second time?”
John 3:5 Jesus answered: I tell you for certain that before you can get into God's kingdom, you must be born not only by water, but by the Spirit.
John 3:6 Humans give life to their children. Yet only God's Spirit can change you into a child of God.
John 3:7 Don't be surprised when I say that you must be born from above.
John 3:8 Only God's Spirit gives new life. The Spirit is like the wind that blows wherever it wants to. You can hear the wind, but you don't know where it comes from or where it is going.
John 3:9 “How can this be?” Nicodemus asked.
John 3:10 Jesus replied: How can you be a teacher of Israel and not know these things?
John 3:11 I tell you for certain we know what we are talking about because we have seen it ourselves. But none of you will accept what we say.
John 3:12 If you don't believe when I talk to you about things on earth, how can you possibly believe if I talk to you about things in heaven?
John 3:13 No one has gone up to heaven except the Son of Man, who came down from there.
John 3:14 And the Son of Man must be lifted up, just as the metal snake was lifted up by Moses in the desert.
John 3:15 Then everyone who has faith in the Son of Man will have eternal life.
John 3:16 God loved the people of this world so much that he gave his only Son, so that everyone who has faith in him will have eternal life and never really die.
John 3:17 God did not send his Son into the world to condemn its people. He sent him to save them!
John 3:18 No one who has faith in God's Son will be condemned. But everyone who doesn't have faith in him has already been condemned for not having faith in God's only Son.
John 3:19 The light has come into the world, and people who do evil things are judged guilty because they love the dark more than the light.
John 3:20 People who do evil hate the light and won't come to the light, because it clearly shows what they have done.
John 3:21 But everyone who lives by the truth will come to the light, because they want others to know that God is really the one doing what they do.
John 3:22 Later, Jesus and his disciples went to Judea, where he stayed with them for a while and was baptizing people.
John 3:23+JHN John had not yet been put in jail. He was at Aenon near Salim, where there was a lot of water, and people were coming there for John to baptize them.
John 3:25 John's followers got into an argument with a Jewish man about a ceremony of washing.
John 3:26 They went to John and said, “Rabbi, you spoke about a man when you were with him east of the Jordan. He is now baptizing people, and everyone is going to him.”
John 3:27 John replied: No one can do anything unless God in heaven allows it.
John 3:28 You surely remember how I told you that I am not the Messiah. I am only the one sent ahead of him.
John 3:29 At a wedding the groom is the one who gets married. The best man is glad just to be there and to hear the groom's voice. That's why I am so glad.
John 3:30 Jesus must become more important, while I become less important.
John 3:31 God's Son comes from heaven and is above all others. Everyone who comes from the earth belongs to the earth and speaks about earthly things. The one who comes from heaven is above all others.
John 3:32 He speaks about what he has seen and heard, and yet no one believes him.
John 3:33 But everyone who does believe him has shown that God is truthful.
John 3:34 The Son was sent to speak God's message, and he has been given the full power of God's Spirit.
John 3:35 The Father loves the Son and has given him everything.
John 3:36 Everyone who has faith in the Son has eternal life. But no one who rejects him will ever share in that life, and God will be angry with them forever.
John 4:1 Jesus knew that the Pharisees had heard that he was winning and baptizing more followers than John was.
John 4:2 But Jesus' disciples were really the ones doing the baptizing, and not Jesus himself.
John 4:3 Jesus left Judea and started for Galilee again.
John 4:4 This time he had to go through Samaria,
John 4:5 and on his way he came to the town of Sychar. It was near the field that Jacob had long ago given to his son Joseph.
John 4:6+JHN The well that Jacob had dug was still there, and Jesus sat down beside it because he was tired from traveling. It was noon, and after Jesus' disciples had gone into town to buy some food, a Samaritan woman came to draw water from the well. Jesus asked her, “Would you please give me a drink of water?”
John 4:9 “You are a Jew,” she replied, “and I am a Samaritan woman. How can you ask me for a drink of water when Jews and Samaritans won't have anything to do with each other?”
John 4:10 Jesus answered, “You don't know what God wants to give you, and you don't know who is asking you for a drink. If you did, you would ask me for the water that gives life.”
John 4:11 “Sir,” the woman said, “you don't even have a bucket, and the well is deep. Where are you going to get this life-giving water?
John 4:12 Our ancestor Jacob dug this well for us, and his family and animals got water from it. Are you greater than Jacob?”
John 4:13 Jesus answered, “Everyone who drinks this water will get thirsty again.
John 4:14 But no one who drinks the water I give will ever be thirsty again. The water I give will become in that person a flowing fountain that gives eternal life.”
John 4:15 The woman replied, “Sir, please give me a drink of that water! Then I won't get thirsty and have to come to this well again.”
John 4:16 Jesus told her, “Go and bring your husband.”
John 4:17+JHN The woman answered, “I don't have a husband.” “That's right,” Jesus replied, “you're telling the truth. You don't have a husband. You have already been married five times, and the man you are now living with isn't your husband.”
John 4:19 The woman said, “Sir, I can see that you are a prophet.
John 4:20 My ancestors worshiped on this mountain, but you Jews say Jerusalem is the only place to worship.”
John 4:21 Jesus said to her: Believe me, the time is coming when you won't worship the Father either on this mountain or in Jerusalem.
John 4:22 You Samaritans don't really know the one you worship. But we Jews do know the God we worship, and by using us, God will save the world.
John 4:23 But a time is coming, and it is already here! Even now the true worshipers are being led by the Spirit to worship the Father according to the truth. These are the ones the Father is seeking to worship him.
John 4:24 God is Spirit, and those who worship God must be led by the Spirit to worship him according to the truth.
John 4:25 The woman said, “I know that the Messiah will come. He is the one we call Christ. When he comes, he will explain everything to us.”
John 4:26 “I am that one,” Jesus told her, “and I am speaking to you now.”
John 4:27 The disciples returned about this time and were surprised to find Jesus talking with a woman. But none of them asked him what he wanted or why he was talking with her.
John 4:28 The woman left her water jar and ran back into town, where she said to the people,
John 4:29 “Come and see a man who told me everything I have ever done! Could he be the Messiah?”
John 4:30 Everyone in town went out to see Jesus.
John 4:31 While this was happening, Jesus' disciples were saying to him, “Teacher, please eat something.”
John 4:32 But Jesus told them, “I have food you don't know anything about.”
John 4:33 His disciples started asking each other, “Has someone brought him something to eat?”
John 4:34 Jesus said: My food is to do what God wants! He is the one who sent me, and I must finish the work that he gave me to do.
John 4:35 You may say there are still four months until harvest time. But I tell you to look, and you will see that the fields are ripe and ready to harvest.
John 4:36 Even now the harvest workers are receiving their reward by gathering a harvest that brings eternal life. Then everyone who planted the seed and everyone who harvests the crop will celebrate together.
John 4:37 So the saying proves true, “Some plant the seed, and others harvest the crop.”
John 4:38 I am sending you to harvest crops in fields where others have done all the hard work.
John 4:39 A lot of Samaritans in that town put their faith in Jesus because the woman had said, “This man told me everything I have ever done.”
John 4:40 They came and asked him to stay in their town, and he stayed on for two days.
John 4:41 Many more Samaritans put their faith in Jesus because of what they heard him say.
John 4:42 They told the woman, “We no longer have faith in Jesus just because of what you told us. We have heard him ourselves, and we are certain that he is the Savior of the world!”
John 4:43+JHN Jesus had said, “Prophets are honored everywhere, except in their own country.” Then two days later he left
John 4:45 and went to Galilee. The people there welcomed him, because they had gone to the festival in Jerusalem and had seen everything he had done.
John 4:46 While Jesus was in Galilee, he returned to the village of Cana, where he had turned the water into wine. There was an official in Capernaum whose son was sick.
John 4:47 And when the man heard that Jesus had come from Judea, he went and begged him to keep his son from dying.
John 4:48 Jesus told the official, “You won't have faith unless you see miracles and wonders!”
John 4:49 The man replied, “Lord, please come before my son dies!”
John 4:50 Jesus then said, “Your son will live. Go on home to him.” The man believed Jesus and started back home.
John 4:51 Some of the official's servants met him along the road and told him, “Your son is better!”
John 4:52 He asked them when the boy got better, and they answered, “The fever left him yesterday at one o'clock.”
John 4:53 The boy's father realized that at one o'clock the day before, Jesus had told him, “Your son will live!” So the man and everyone in his family put their faith in Jesus.
John 4:54 This was the second miracle that Jesus worked after he left Judea and went to Galilee.
John 5:1 Later, Jesus went to Jerusalem for another Jewish festival.
John 5:2 In the city near the sheep gate was a pool with five porches, and its name in Hebrew was Bethzatha.
John 5:3+JHN Many sick, blind, lame, and paralyzed people were lying close to the pool.
John 5:5 Beside the pool was a man who had been sick for 38 years.
John 5:6 When Jesus saw the man and realized that he had been crippled for a long time, he asked him, “Do you want to be healed?”
John 5:7 The man answered, “Sir, I don't have anyone to put me in the pool when the water is stirred up. I try to get in, but someone else always gets there first.”
John 5:8 Jesus told him, “Pick up your mat and walk!”
John 5:9 Right then the man was healed. He picked up his mat and started walking around. The day on which this happened was a Sabbath.
John 5:10 When the Jewish leaders saw the man carrying his mat, they said to him, “This is the Sabbath! No one is allowed to carry a mat on the Sabbath.”
John 5:11 But he replied, “The man who healed me told me to pick up my mat and walk.”
John 5:12 They asked him, “Who is this man that told you to pick up your mat and walk?”
John 5:13 But he did not know who Jesus was, and Jesus had left because of the crowd.
John 5:14 Later, Jesus met the man in the temple and told him, “You are now well. But don't sin anymore or something worse might happen to you.”
John 5:15 The man left and told the leaders that Jesus was the one who had healed him.
John 5:16 They started making a lot of trouble for Jesus because he did things like this on the Sabbath.
John 5:17 But Jesus said, “My Father has never stopped working, and this is why I keep on working.”
John 5:18 Now the leaders wanted to kill Jesus for two reasons. First, he had broken the law of the Sabbath. But even worse, he had said God was his Father, which made him equal with God.
John 5:19 Jesus told the people: I tell you for certain the Son cannot do anything on his own. He can do only what he sees the Father doing, and he does exactly what he sees the Father do.
John 5:20 The Father loves the Son and has shown him everything he does. The Father will show him even greater things, and you will be amazed.
John 5:21 Just as the Father raises the dead and gives life, so the Son gives life to anyone he wants to.
John 5:22 The Father doesn't judge anyone, but he has made his Son the judge of everyone.
John 5:23 The Father wants all people to honor the Son as much as they honor him. When anyone refuses to honor the Son, this is the same as refusing to honor the Father who sent him.
John 5:24 I tell you for certain that everyone who hears my message and has faith in the one who sent me has eternal life and will never be condemned. They have already gone from death to life.
John 5:25 I tell you for certain the time will come, and it is already here, when all of the dead will hear the voice of the Son of God. And those who listen to it will live!
John 5:26 The Father has the power to give life, and he has given that same power to the Son.
John 5:27 And he has given his Son the right to judge everyone, because he is the Son of Man.
John 5:28 Don't be surprised! The time will come when all of the dead will hear the voice of the Son of Man,
John 5:29 and they will come out of their graves. Everyone who has done good things will rise to life, but everyone who has done evil things will rise and be condemned.
John 5:30 I cannot do anything on my own. The Father sent me, and he is the one who told me how to judge. I judge with fairness, because I obey him, and I don't just try to please myself.
John 5:31 If I speak for myself, there is no way to prove I am telling the truth.
John 5:32 But there is someone else who speaks for me, and I know what he says is true.
John 5:33 You sent messengers to John, and he told them the truth.
John 5:34 I don't depend on what people say about me, but I tell you these things so that you may be saved.
John 5:35 John was a lamp that gave a lot of light, and you were glad to enjoy his light for a while.
John 5:36 But something more important than John speaks for me. I mean the things that the Father has given me to do! All of these speak for me and prove that the Father sent me.
John 5:37 The Father who sent me also speaks for me, but you have never heard his voice or seen him face to face.
John 5:38 You have not believed his message, because you refused to have faith in the one he sent.
John 5:39 You search the Scriptures, because you think you will find eternal life in them. The Scriptures tell about me,
John 5:40 but you refuse to come to me for eternal life.
John 5:41 I don't care about human praise,
John 5:42 but I do know that none of you love God.
John 5:43 I have come with my Father's authority, and you have not welcomed me. But you will welcome people who come on their own.
John 5:44 How could you possibly believe? You like to have your friends praise you, and you don't care about praise that the only God can give!
John 5:45 Don't think that I will be the one to accuse you to the Father. You have put your hope in Moses, yet he is the very one who will accuse you.
John 5:46 Moses wrote about me, and if you had believed Moses, you would have believed me.
John 5:47 But if you don't believe what Moses wrote, how can you believe what I say?
John 6:1 Jesus crossed Lake Galilee, which was also known as Lake Tiberias.
John 6:2 A large crowd had seen him work miracles to heal the sick, and those people went with him.
John 6:3+JHN It was almost time for the Jewish festival of Passover, and Jesus went up on a mountain with his disciples and sat down.
John 6:5 When Jesus saw the large crowd coming toward him, he asked Philip, “Where will we get enough food to feed all these people?”
John 6:6 He said this to test Philip, since he already knew what he was going to do.
John 6:7 Philip answered, “Don't you know that it would take almost a year's wages just to buy only a little bread for each of these people?”
John 6:8 Andrew, the brother of Simon Peter, was one of the disciples. He spoke up and said,
John 6:9 “There is a boy here who has five small loaves of barley bread and two fish. But what good is that with all these people?”
John 6:10 The ground was covered with grass, and Jesus told his disciples to tell everyone to sit down. About 5,000 men were in the crowd.
John 6:11 Jesus took the bread in his hands and gave thanks to God. Then he passed the bread to the people, and he did the same with the fish, until everyone had plenty to eat.
John 6:12 The people ate all they wanted, and Jesus told his disciples to gather up the leftovers, so that nothing would be wasted.
John 6:13 The disciples gathered them up and filled twelve large baskets with what was left over from the five barley loaves.
John 6:14 After the people had seen Jesus work this miracle, they began saying, “This must be the Prophet who is to come into the world!”
John 6:15 Jesus realized that they would try to force him to be their king. So he went up on a mountain, where he could be alone.
John 6:16 That evening, Jesus' disciples went down to the lake.
John 6:17 They got into a boat and started across for Capernaum. Later that evening Jesus had still not come to them,
John 6:18 and a strong wind was making the water rough.
John 6:19 When the disciples had rowed for five or six kilometers, they saw Jesus walking on the water. He kept coming closer to the boat, and they were terrified.
John 6:20 But he said, “I am Jesus! Don't be afraid!”
John 6:21 The disciples wanted to take him into the boat, but suddenly the boat reached the shore where they were headed.
John 6:22 The people who had stayed on the east side of the lake knew that only one boat had been there. They also knew that Jesus had not left in it with his disciples. But the next day
John 6:23 some boats from Tiberias sailed near the place where the crowd had eaten the bread for which the Lord had given thanks.
John 6:24 They saw that Jesus and his disciples had left. Then they got into the boats and went to Capernaum to look for Jesus.
