Acts 1:14 The apostles often met together and prayed with a single purpose in mind. The women and Mary the mother of Jesus would meet with them, and so would his brothers.
Acts 1:15 One day there were about 120 of the Lord's followers meeting together, and Peter stood up to speak to them.
Acts 1:16+ACT He said: My friends, long ago by the power of the Holy Spirit, David said something about Judas, and what he said has now happened. Judas was one of us and had worked with us, but he brought the mob to arrest Jesus.
Acts 1:18 Then Judas bought some land with the money he was given for doing that evil thing. He fell headfirst into the field. His body burst open, and all his insides came out.
Acts 1:19 When the people of Jerusalem found out about this, they called the place Akeldama, which in the local language means “Field of Blood.”
Acts 1:20 In the book of Psalms it says, “Leave his house empty, and don't let anyone live there.” It also says, “Let someone else have his job.”
Acts 1:21+ACT So we need someone else to help us tell others that Jesus has been raised from death. He must also be one of the men who was with us from the very beginning. He must have been with us from the time the Lord Jesus was baptized by John until the day he was taken to heaven.
Acts 1:23 Two men were suggested: One of them was Joseph Barsabbas, known as Justus, and the other was Matthias.
Acts 1:24 Then they all prayed, “Lord, you know what everyone is like! Show us the one you have chosen
Acts 1:25 to be an apostle and to serve in place of Judas, who got what he deserved.”
Acts 1:26 They drew names, and Matthias was chosen to join the group of the eleven apostles.
Acts 2:1 On the day of Pentecost all the Lord's followers were together in one place.
Acts 2:2 Suddenly there was a noise from heaven like the sound of a mighty wind! It filled the house where they were meeting.
Acts 2:3 Then they saw what looked like fiery tongues moving in all directions, and a tongue came and settled on each person there.
Acts 2:4 The Holy Spirit took control of everyone, and they began speaking whatever languages the Spirit let them speak.
Acts 2:5 Many religious Jews from every country in the world were living in Jerusalem.
Acts 2:6 And when they heard this noise, a crowd gathered. But they were surprised, because they were hearing everything in their own languages.
Acts 2:7 They were excited and amazed, and said: Don't all these who are speaking come from Galilee?
Acts 2:8 Then why do we hear them speaking our very own languages?
Acts 2:9 Some of us are from Parthia, Media, and Elam. Others are from Mesopotamia, Judea, Cappadocia, Pontus, Asia,
Acts 2:10 Phrygia, Pamphylia, Egypt, parts of Libya near Cyrene, Rome,
Acts 2:11 Crete, and Arabia. Some of us were born Jews, and others of us have chosen to be Jews. Yet we all hear them using our own languages to tell the wonderful things God has done.
Acts 2:12 Everyone was excited and confused. Some of them even kept asking each other, “What does all this mean?”
Acts 2:13 Others made fun of the Lord's followers and said, “They are drunk.”
Acts 2:14 Peter stood with the eleven apostles and spoke in a loud and clear voice to the crowd: Friends and everyone else living in Jerusalem, listen carefully to what I have to say!
Acts 2:15 You are wrong to think that these people are drunk. After all, it is only nine o'clock in the morning.
Acts 2:16 But this is what God told the prophet Joel to say,
Acts 2:17 “When the last days come, I will give my Spirit to everyone. Your sons and daughters will prophesy. Your young men will see visions, and your old men will have dreams.
Acts 2:18 In those days I will give my Spirit to my servants, both men and women, and they will prophesy.
Acts 2:19 “I will work miracles in the sky above and wonders on the earth below. There will be blood and fire and clouds of smoke.
Acts 2:20 The sun will turn dark, and the moon will be as red as blood before the great and wonderful day of the Lord appears.
Acts 2:21 Then the Lord will save everyone who asks for his help.”
Acts 2:22 Now, listen to what I have to say about Jesus from Nazareth. God proved he sent Jesus to you by having him work miracles, wonders, and signs. All of you know this.
Acts 2:23 God had already planned and decided that Jesus would be handed over to you. So you took him and had evil men put him to death on a cross.
Acts 2:24 But God set him free from death and raised him to life. Death could not hold him in its power.
Acts 2:25 What David said are really the words of Jesus, “I always see the Lord near me, and I will not be afraid with him at my right side.
Acts 2:26 Because of this, my heart will be glad, my words will be joyful, and I will live in hope.
Acts 2:27 The Lord won't leave me in the grave. I am his holy one, and he won't let my body decay.
Acts 2:28 He has shown me the path to life, and he makes me glad by being near me.”
Acts 2:29 My friends, it is right for me to speak to you about our ancestor David. He died and was buried, and his tomb is still here.
Acts 2:30 But David was a prophet, and he knew that God had made a promise he would not break. He had told David someone from his own family would someday be king.
Acts 2:31 David knew this would happen, and so he told us Christ would be raised to life. He said God would not leave him in the grave or let his body decay.
Acts 2:32 All of us can tell you that God has raised Jesus to life!
Acts 2:33 Jesus was taken up to sit at the right side of God, and he was given the Holy Spirit, just as the Father had promised. Jesus is also the one who has given the Spirit to us, and this is what you are now seeing and hearing.
Acts 2:34 David didn't go up to heaven. So he wasn't talking about himself when he said, “The Lord told my Lord to sit at his right side,
Acts 2:35 until he made my Lord's enemies into a footstool for him.”
Acts 2:36 Everyone in Israel should then know for certain that God has made Jesus both Lord and Christ, even though you put him to death on a cross.
Acts 2:37 When the people heard this, they were very upset. They asked Peter and the other apostles, “Friends, what should we do?”
Acts 2:38 Peter said to them, “Turn to God and be baptized, every one of you, in the name of Jesus Christ for the forgiveness of your sins, and you will receive the gift of the Holy Spirit.
Acts 2:39 This promise is for you and your children. It is for everyone our Lord God will choose, no matter where they live.”
Acts 2:40 Peter told them many other things as well. Then he said, “I beg you to save yourselves from what will happen to all these evil people.”
Acts 2:41 On that day about 3,000 believed his message and were baptized.
Acts 2:42 They spent their time learning from the apostles, and they were like family to each other. They also broke bread and prayed together.
Acts 2:43 Everyone was amazed by the many miracles and wonders that the apostles worked.
Acts 2:44 All the Lord's followers often met together, and they shared everything they had.
Acts 2:45 They would sell their property and possessions and give the money to whoever was in need.
Acts 2:46 Day after day they met together in the temple. They broke bread together in different homes and shared their food happily and freely,
Acts 2:47 while praising God. Everyone liked them, and each day the Lord added to their group others who were being saved.
Acts 3:1 The time of prayer was about three o'clock in the afternoon, and Peter and John were going into the temple.
Acts 3:2 A man who had been born lame was being carried to the temple door. Each day he was placed beside this door, known as the Beautiful Gate. He sat there and begged from the people who were going in.
Acts 3:3 The man saw Peter and John entering the temple, and he asked them for money.
Acts 3:4 But they looked straight at him and said, “Look up at us!”
Acts 3:5 The man stared at them and thought he was going to get something.
Acts 3:6 But Peter said, “I don't have any silver or gold! But I will give you what I do have. In the name of Jesus Christ from Nazareth, get up and start walking.”
Acts 3:7 Peter then took him by the right hand and helped him up. At once the man's feet and ankles became strong,
Acts 3:8 and he jumped up and started walking. He went with Peter and John into the temple, walking and jumping and praising God.
Acts 3:9 Everyone saw him walking around and praising God.
Acts 3:10 They knew he was the beggar who had been lying beside the Beautiful Gate, and they were completely surprised. They could not imagine what had happened to the man.
Acts 3:11 While the man kept holding on to Peter and John, the whole crowd ran to them in amazement at the place known as Solomon's Porch.
Acts 3:12 Peter saw that a crowd had gathered, and he said: Friends, why are you surprised at what has happened? Why are you staring at us? Do you think we have some power of our own? Do you think we were able to make this man walk because we are so religious?
Acts 3:13 The God that Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and our other ancestors worshiped has brought honor to his Servant Jesus. He is the one you betrayed. You turned against him when he was being tried by Pilate, even though Pilate wanted to set him free.
Acts 3:14 You rejected Jesus, who was holy and good. You asked for a murderer to be set free,
Acts 3:15 and you killed the one who leads people to life. But God raised him from death, and all of us can tell you what he has done.
Acts 3:16 You see this man, and you know him. He put his faith in the name of Jesus and was made strong. Faith in Jesus made this man completely well while everyone was watching.
Acts 3:17 My friends, I am sure you and your leaders didn't know what you were doing.
Acts 3:18 But God had his prophets tell that his Messiah would suffer, and now he has kept this promise.
Acts 3:19 So turn to God! Give up your sins, and you will be forgiven.
Acts 3:20 Then the time will come when the Lord will give you fresh strength. He will send you Jesus, his chosen Messiah.
Acts 3:21 But Jesus must stay in heaven until God makes all things new, just as his holy prophets promised long ago.
Acts 3:22 Moses said, “The Lord your God will choose one of your own people to be a prophet, just as he chose me. Listen to everything he tells you.
Acts 3:23 No one who disobeys this prophet will be one of God's people any longer.”
Acts 3:24 Samuel and all the other prophets who came later also spoke about what is now happening.
Acts 3:25 You are really the ones God told his prophets to speak to. And you were given the promise God made to your ancestors. He said to Abraham, “All nations on earth will be blessed because of someone from your family.”
Acts 3:26 God sent his chosen Son to you first, because God wanted to bless you and make each one of you turn away from your sins.
Acts 4:1 The apostles were still talking to the people, when some priests, the captain of the temple guard, and some Sadducees arrived.
Acts 4:2 These men were angry because the apostles were teaching the people that the dead would be raised from death, just as Jesus had been raised from death.
Acts 4:3 It was already late in the afternoon, and they arrested Peter and John and put them in jail for the night.
Acts 4:4 But a lot of people who had heard the message believed it. So by now there were about 5,000 followers of the Lord.
Acts 4:5 The next morning the leaders, the elders, and the teachers of the Law of Moses met in Jerusalem.
Acts 4:6 The high priest Annas was there, as well as Caiaphas, John, Alexander, and other members of the high priest's family.
Acts 4:7 They brought in Peter and John and made them stand in the middle while they questioned them. They asked, “By what power and in whose name have you done this?”
Acts 4:8 Peter was filled with the Holy Spirit and told the nation's leaders and the elders:
Acts 4:9 You are questioning us today about a kind deed in which a man who could not walk was healed.
Acts 4:10 But there is something we must tell you and everyone else in Israel. This man is standing here completely well because of the power of Jesus Christ from Nazareth. You put Jesus to death on a cross, but God raised him to life.
Acts 4:11 He is the stone you builders thought was worthless, and now he is the most important stone of all.
Acts 4:12 Only Jesus has the power to save! His name is the only one in all the world that can save anyone.
Acts 4:13 The officials were amazed to see how brave Peter and John were, and they knew that these two apostles were only ordinary men and not well educated. The officials were certain these men had been with Jesus.
Acts 4:14 But they could not deny what had happened. The man who had been healed was standing there with the apostles.
Acts 4:15 The officials commanded them to leave the council room. Then the officials said to each other,
Acts 4:16 “What can we do with these men? Everyone in Jerusalem knows about this miracle, and we cannot say it didn't happen.
Acts 4:17 But to keep this thing from spreading, we will warn them never again to speak to anyone about the name of Jesus.”
Acts 4:18 So they called the two apostles back in and told them they must never, for any reason, teach anything about the name of Jesus.
Acts 4:19 Peter and John answered, “Do you think God wants us to obey you or to obey him?
Acts 4:20 We cannot keep quiet about what we have seen and heard.”
Acts 4:21+ACT The officials could not find any reason to punish Peter and John. So they threatened them and let them go. The man who was healed by this miracle was more than 40 years old, and everyone was praising God for what had happened.
Acts 4:23 As soon as Peter and John had been set free, they went back and told the others everything the chief priests and the leaders had said to them.
Acts 4:24 When the rest of the Lord's followers heard this, they prayed together and said: Master, you created heaven and earth, the sea, and everything in them.
Acts 4:25 And by the Holy Spirit you spoke to our ancestor David. He was your servant, and you told him to say: “Why are all the Gentiles so furious? Why do people make foolish plans?
Acts 4:26 The kings of earth prepare for war, and the rulers join together against the Lord and his Messiah.”
Acts 4:27 Here in Jerusalem, Herod and Pontius Pilate got together with the Gentiles and the people of Israel. Then they turned against your holy Servant Jesus, your chosen Messiah.
Acts 4:28 They did what you in your power and wisdom had already decided would happen.
Acts 4:29 Lord, listen to their threats! We are your servants. So make us brave enough to speak your message.
Acts 4:30 Show your mighty power, as we heal people and work miracles and wonders in the name of your holy Servant Jesus.
Acts 4:31 After they had prayed, the meeting place shook. They were all filled with the Holy Spirit and bravely spoke God's message.
Acts 4:32 The group of followers all felt the same way about everything. None of them claimed that their possessions were their own, and they shared everything they had with each other.
Acts 4:33 In a powerful way the apostles told everyone that the Lord Jesus was now alive. God greatly blessed his followers,
Acts 4:34 and no one went in need of anything. Everyone who owned land or houses would sell them and bring the money
Acts 4:35 to the apostles. Then they would give the money to anyone in need.
Acts 4:36+ACT Joseph was one of the followers who had sold a piece of property and brought the money to the apostles. He was a Levite from Cyprus, and the apostles called him Barnabas, which means “one who encourages others.”
Acts 5:1 Ananias and his wife Sapphira also sold a piece of property.
Acts 5:2 But they agreed to cheat and keep some of the money for themselves. So when Ananias took the rest of the money to the apostles,
Acts 5:3 Peter said, “Why has Satan made you keep back some of the money from the sale of the property? Why have you lied to the Holy Spirit?
Acts 5:4 The property was yours before you sold it, and even after you sold it, the money was still yours. What made you do such a thing? You didn't lie to people. You lied to God!”
Acts 5:5 As soon as Ananias heard this, he dropped dead, and everyone who heard about it was frightened.
Acts 5:6 Some young men came in and wrapped up his body. Then they took it out and buried it.
Acts 5:7 Three hours later Sapphira came in, but she did not know what had happened to her husband.
Acts 5:8 Peter asked her, “Tell me, did you sell the property for this amount?” “Yes,” she answered, “that's the amount.”
Acts 5:9 Then Peter said, “Why did the two of you agree to test the Lord's Spirit? The men who buried Ananias are by the door, and they will carry you out!”
Acts 5:10 At once she fell at Peter's feet and died. When the young men came back in, they found Sapphira lying there dead. So they carried her out and buried her beside her husband.
Acts 5:11 The church members were afraid, and so was everyone else who heard what had happened.
Acts 5:12 The apostles worked many miracles and wonders among the people. All of the Lord's followers often met in the part of the temple known as Solomon's Porch.
Acts 5:13 No one outside their group dared join them, even though everyone liked them very much.
Acts 5:14 Many men and women started having faith in the Lord.
Acts 5:15 Then sick people were brought out to the road and placed on mats. It was hoped that Peter would walk by, and his shadow would fall on them and heal them.
Acts 5:16 A lot of people living in the towns near Jerusalem brought those who were sick or troubled by evil spirits, and they were all healed.
Acts 5:17 The high priest and all the other Sadducees who were with him became jealous.
Acts 5:18 They arrested the apostles and put them in the city jail.
Acts 5:19 But that night an angel from the Lord opened the doors of the jail and led the apostles out. The angel said,
Acts 5:20 “Go to the temple and tell the people everything about this new life.”
Acts 5:21 So they went into the temple before sunrise and started teaching. The high priest and his men called together their council, which included all of Israel's leaders. Then they ordered the apostles to be brought to them from the jail.
Acts 5:22 The temple police who were sent to the jail did not find the apostles. They returned and said,
Acts 5:23 “We found the jail locked tight and the guards standing at the doors. But when we opened the doors and went in, we didn't find anyone there.”
Acts 5:24 The captain of the temple police and the chief priests listened to their report, but they did not know what to think about it.
Acts 5:25 Just then someone came in and said, “Now those men you put in jail are in the temple, teaching the people!”
Acts 5:26 The captain went with some of the temple police and brought the apostles back. But they did not use force. They were afraid that the people might start throwing stones at them.
Acts 5:27 When the apostles were brought before the council, the high priest said to them,
Acts 5:28 “We told you plainly not to teach in the name of Jesus. But look what you have done! You have been teaching all over Jerusalem, and you are trying to blame us for his death.”
Acts 5:29 Peter and the apostles replied: We don't obey people. We obey God.
Acts 5:30 You killed Jesus by nailing him to a cross. But the God our ancestors worshiped raised him to life
Acts 5:31 and made him our Leader and Savior. Then God gave him a place at his right side, so that the people of Israel would turn back to him and be forgiven.
Acts 5:32 We are here to tell you about all this, and so is the Holy Spirit, who is God's gift to everyone who obeys God.
Acts 5:33 When the council members heard this, they became so angry they wanted to kill the apostles.
Acts 5:34 But one of the members was the Pharisee Gamaliel, a highly respected teacher. He ordered the apostles to be taken out of the room for a little while.
Acts 5:35 Then he said to the council: Men of Israel, be careful what you do with these men.
Acts 5:36 Not long ago Theudas claimed to be someone important, and about 400 men joined him. But he was killed, and all his followers were scattered. That was the end of that.
Acts 5:37 Later, when the people of our nation were being counted, Judas from Galilee showed up. A lot of people followed him, but he was killed, and all his followers were scattered.
Acts 5:38 So I advise you to stay away from these men. Leave them alone. If what they are planning is something of their own doing, it will fail.
Acts 5:39 But if God is behind it, you cannot stop it anyway, unless you want to fight against God. The council members agreed with what he said,
Acts 5:40 and they called the apostles back in. They had them beaten with a whip and warned them not to speak in the name of Jesus. Then they let them go.
Acts 5:41 The apostles left the council and were happy, because God had considered them worthy to suffer for the sake of Jesus.
Acts 5:42 Every day they spent time in the temple and in one home after another. They never stopped teaching and telling the good news that Jesus is the Messiah.
Acts 6:1 A lot of people were now becoming followers of the Lord. But some of the ones who spoke Greek started complaining about the ones who spoke Aramaic. They complained that the Greek-speaking widows were not given their share when the food supplies were handed out each day.
Acts 6:2 The twelve apostles called the whole group of followers together and said, “We should not give up preaching God's message in order to serve at tables.
Acts 6:3 My friends, choose seven men who are respected and wise and filled with God's Spirit. We will put them in charge of these things.
Acts 6:4 We can spend our time praying and serving God by preaching.”
Acts 6:5 This suggestion pleased everyone, and they began by choosing Stephen. He had great faith and was filled with the Holy Spirit. Then they chose Philip, Prochorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas, and also Nicolaus, who worshiped with the Jewish people in Antioch.
Acts 6:6 These men were brought to the apostles. Then the apostles prayed and placed their hands on the men to show they had been chosen to do this work.
Acts 6:7 God's message spread, and many more people in Jerusalem became followers. Even a large number of priests put their faith in the Lord.
Acts 6:8 God gave Stephen the power to work great miracles and wonders among the people.
Acts 6:9 But some men from Cyrene and Alexandria were members of a group who called themselves “Free Men.” They started arguing with Stephen. Some others from Cilicia and Asia also argued with him.
Acts 6:10 But they were no match for Stephen, who spoke with the great wisdom that the Spirit gave him.
Acts 6:11 So they talked some men into saying, “We heard Stephen say terrible things against Moses and God!”
Acts 6:12 They turned the people and their leaders and the teachers of the Law of Moses against Stephen. Then they all grabbed him and dragged him in front of the council.
Acts 6:13 Some men agreed to tell lies about Stephen, and they said, “This man keeps on saying terrible things about this holy temple and the Law of Moses.
Acts 6:14 We have heard him claim that Jesus from Nazareth will destroy this place and change the customs Moses gave us.”
Acts 6:15 Then all the council members stared at Stephen. They saw that his face looked like the face of an angel.
Acts 7:1 The high priest asked Stephen, “Are they telling the truth about you?”
Acts 7:2 Stephen answered: Friends, listen to me. Our glorious God appeared to our ancestor Abraham while he was still in Mesopotamia, before he had moved to Haran.
Acts 7:3 God told him, “Leave your country and your relatives and go to a land that I will show you.”
Acts 7:4 Then Abraham left the land of the Chaldeans and settled in Haran. After his father died, Abraham came and settled in this land where you now live.
Acts 7:5 God didn't give him any part of it, not even a square meter. But God did promise to give it to him and his family forever, even though Abraham didn't have any children.
Acts 7:6 God said Abraham's descendants would live for a while in a foreign land. There they would be slaves and would be mistreated 400 years.
Acts 7:7 But he also said, “I will punish the nation that makes them slaves. Then later they will come and worship me in this place.”
Acts 7:8 God said to Abraham, “Every son in each family must be circumcised to show you have kept your agreement with me.” So when Isaac was eight days old, Abraham circumcised him. Later, Isaac circumcised his son Jacob, and Jacob circumcised his twelve sons.
Acts 7:9 These men were our ancestors. Joseph was also one of our famous ancestors. His brothers were jealous of him and sold him as a slave to be taken to Egypt. But God was with him
Acts 7:10 and rescued him from all his troubles. God made him so wise that the Egyptian king Pharaoh thought highly of him. The king even made Joseph governor over Egypt and put him in charge of everything he owned.
Acts 7:11 Everywhere in Egypt and Canaan the grain crops failed. There was terrible suffering, and our ancestors could not find enough to eat.
Acts 7:12 But when Jacob heard there was grain in Egypt, he sent our ancestors there for the first time.
Acts 7:13 It was on their second trip that Joseph told his brothers who he was, and the king learned about Joseph's family.
Acts 7:14 Joseph sent for his father and his relatives. In all, there were 75 of them.
Acts 7:15 His father went to Egypt and died there, just as our ancestors did.
Acts 7:16 Later their bodies were taken back to Shechem and placed in the tomb that Abraham had bought from the sons of Hamor.
Acts 7:17 Finally, the time came for God to do what he had promised Abraham. By then the number of our people in Egypt had greatly increased.
Acts 7:18 Another king was ruling Egypt, and he didn't know anything about Joseph.
Acts 7:19 He tricked our ancestors and was cruel to them. He even made them leave their babies outside, so they would die.
Acts 7:20 During this time Moses was born. He was a very beautiful child, and for three months his parents took care of him in their home.
Acts 7:21 Then when they were forced to leave him outside, the king's daughter found him and raised him as her own son.
Acts 7:22 Moses was given the best education in Egypt. He was a strong man and a powerful speaker.
Acts 7:23 When Moses was 40 years old, he wanted to help the Israelites because they were his own people.
Acts 7:24 One day he saw an Egyptian mistreating one of them. So he rescued the man and killed the Egyptian.
Acts 7:25 Moses thought the rest of his people would realize God was going to use him to set them free. But they didn't understand.
Acts 7:26 The next day Moses saw two of his own people fighting, and he tried to make them stop. He said, “Men, you are both Israelites. Why are you so cruel to each other?”
Acts 7:27 But the man who had started the fight pushed Moses aside and asked, “Who made you our ruler and judge?
Acts 7:28 Are you going to kill me, just as you killed that Egyptian yesterday?”
Acts 7:29 When Moses heard this, he ran away to live in the country of Midian. His two sons were born there.
Acts 7:30 Forty years later, an angel appeared to Moses from a burning bush in the desert near Mount Sinai.
Acts 7:31 Moses was surprised by what he saw. He went closer to get a better look, and the Lord said,
Acts 7:32 “I am the God who was worshiped by your ancestors, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.” Moses started shaking all over and didn't dare to look at the bush.
Acts 7:33 The Lord said to him, “Take off your sandals, because the place where you are standing is holy.
Acts 7:34 With my own eyes I have seen the suffering of my people in Egypt. I have heard their groans and have come down to rescue them. Now I am sending you back to Egypt.”
Acts 7:35 This was the same Moses that the people rejected by saying, “Who made you our leader and judge?” God's angel had spoken to Moses from the bush. And God had even sent the angel to help Moses rescue the people and be their leader.
Acts 7:36 In Egypt and at the Red Sea and in the desert, Moses rescued the people by working miracles and wonders for 40 years.
Acts 7:37 Moses is the one who told the people of Israel, “God will choose one of your people to be a prophet, just as he chose me.”
Acts 7:38 Moses brought our people together in the desert, and the angel spoke to him on Mount Sinai. There he was given these life-giving words to pass on to us.
Acts 7:39 But our ancestors refused to obey Moses. They rejected him and wanted to go back to Egypt.
Acts 7:40 The people said to Aaron, “Make some gods to lead us! Moses led us out of Egypt, but we don't know what's happened to him now.”
Acts 7:41 Then they made an idol in the shape of a calf. They offered sacrifices to the idol and were pleased with what they had done.
Acts 7:42 God turned his back on his people and left them. Then they worshiped the stars in the sky, just as it says in the Book of the Prophets, “People of Israel, you didn't offer sacrifices and offerings to me during those 40 years in the desert.
Acts 7:43 Instead, you carried the tent where the god Molech is worshiped, and you took along the star of your god Rephan. You made those idols and worshiped them. So now I will have you carried off beyond Babylonia.”
Acts 7:44 The tent where our ancestors worshiped God was with them in the desert. This was the same tent that God had commanded Moses to make. And it was made like the model that Moses had seen.
Acts 7:45 Later it was given to our ancestors, and they took it with them when they went with Joshua. They carried the tent along as they took over the land from those people that God had chased out for them. Our ancestors used this tent until the time of King David.
Acts 7:46 He pleased God and asked him if he could build a house of worship for the people of Israel.
Acts 7:47 And it was finally King Solomon who built a house for God.
Acts 7:48 But the Most High God doesn't live in houses made by humans. It is just as the prophet said, when he spoke for the Lord,
Acts 7:49 “Heaven is my throne, and the earth is my footstool. What kind of house will you build for me? In what place will I rest?
Acts 7:50 I have made everything.”
Acts 7:51 You stubborn and hardheaded people! You are always fighting against the Holy Spirit, just as your ancestors did.
Acts 7:52 Is there one prophet that your ancestors didn't mistreat? They killed the prophets who told about the coming of the One Who Obeys God. And now you have turned against him and killed him.
Acts 7:53 Angels gave you God's Law, but you still don't obey it.
Acts 7:54 When the council members heard Stephen's speech, they were angry and furious.
Acts 7:55 But Stephen was filled with the Holy Spirit. He looked toward heaven, where he saw our glorious God and Jesus standing at his right side.
Acts 7:56 Then Stephen said, “I see heaven open and the Son of Man standing at the right side of God!”
Acts 7:57 The council members shouted and covered their ears. At once they all attacked Stephen
Acts 7:58 and dragged him out of the city. Then they started throwing stones at him. The men who had brought charges against him put their coats at the feet of a young man named Saul.
Acts 7:59 As Stephen was being stoned to death, he called out, “Lord Jesus, please welcome me!”
Acts 7:60 He knelt down and shouted, “Lord, don't blame them for what they have done.” Then he died.
Acts 8:1+ACT Saul approved the stoning of Stephen. Some faithful followers of the Lord buried Stephen and mourned very much for him. At that time the church in Jerusalem suffered terribly. All of the Lord's followers, except the apostles, were scattered everywhere in Judea and Samaria.
Acts 8:3 Saul started making a lot of trouble for the church. He went from house to house, arresting men and women and putting them in jail.
Acts 8:4 The Lord's followers who had been scattered went from place to place, telling the good news.
Acts 8:5 Philip went to the city of Samaria and told the people about Christ.
Acts 8:6 They crowded around Philip because they were eager to hear what he was saying and to see him work miracles.
Acts 8:7 Many people with evil spirits were healed, and the spirits went out of them with a shout. A lot of paralyzed and lame people were also healed.
Acts 8:8 Everyone in that city was very glad because of what was happening.
Acts 8:9 For some time a man named Simon had lived there and had amazed the people of Samaria. He practiced witchcraft and claimed to be somebody great.
Acts 8:10 Everyone, rich and poor, crowded around him. They said, “This man is the power of God called ‘The Great Power.’ ”
Acts 8:11 For a long time, Simon had used witchcraft to amaze the people, and they kept crowding around him.
Acts 8:12 But when they believed what Philip was saying about God's kingdom and about the name of Jesus Christ, they were all baptized.
Acts 8:13 Even Simon believed and was baptized. He stayed close to Philip, because he marveled at all the miracles and wonders.
Acts 8:14 The apostles in Jerusalem heard that some people in Samaria had accepted God's message, and they sent Peter and John.
Acts 8:15 When the two apostles arrived, they prayed that these people would be given the Holy Spirit.
Acts 8:16 Before this, the Holy Spirit had not been given to any of them, though some of them had been baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.
Acts 8:17 Peter and John then placed their hands on everyone who had faith in the Lord, and they were given the Holy Spirit.
Acts 8:18 Simon noticed that the Spirit was given only when the apostles placed their hands on the people. So he brought money
Acts 8:19 and said to Peter and John, “Let me have this power too! Then anyone I place my hands on will also be given the Holy Spirit.”
Acts 8:20 Peter said to him, “You and your money will both end up in hell if you think you can buy God's gift!
Acts 8:21 You don't have any part in this, and God sees that your heart isn't right.
Acts 8:22 Get rid of these evil thoughts and ask God to forgive you.
Acts 8:23 I can see that you are jealous and bound by your evil ways.”
Acts 8:24 Simon said, “Please pray to the Lord, so that what you said won't happen to me.”
Acts 8:25 After Peter and John had preached about the Lord, they returned to Jerusalem. On their way they told the good news in many villages of Samaria.
Acts 8:26 The Lord's angel said to Philip, “Go south along the desert road that leads from Jerusalem to Gaza.”
Acts 8:27 So Philip left. An important Ethiopian official happened to be going along that road in his chariot. He was the chief treasurer for Candace, the Queen of Ethiopia. The official had gone to Jerusalem to worship
Acts 8:28 and was now on his way home. He was sitting in his chariot, reading the book of the prophet Isaiah.
Acts 8:29 The Spirit told Philip to catch up with the chariot.
Acts 8:30 Philip ran up close and heard the man reading aloud from the book of Isaiah. Philip asked him, “Do you understand what you are reading?”
Acts 8:31 The official answered, “How can I understand unless someone helps me?” He then invited Philip to come up and sit beside him.
Acts 8:32 The man was reading the passage that said, “He was led like a sheep on its way to be killed. He was silent as a lamb whose wool is being cut off, and he did not say a word.
Acts 8:33 He was treated like a nobody and did not receive a fair trial. How can he have children, if his life is snatched away?”
Acts 8:34 The official said to Philip, “Tell me, was the prophet talking about himself or about someone else?”
Acts 8:35 So Philip began at this place in the Scriptures and explained the good news about Jesus.
Acts 8:36+ACT As they were going along the road, they came to a place where there was some water. The official said, “Look! Here is some water. Why can't I be baptized?”
Acts 8:38 He ordered the chariot to stop. Then they both went down into the water, and Philip baptized him.
Acts 8:39 After they had come out of the water, the Lord's Spirit took Philip away. The official never saw him again, but he was very happy as he went on his way.
Acts 8:40 Philip later appeared in Azotus. He went from town to town, all the way to Caesarea, telling people about Jesus.
Acts 9:1 Saul kept on threatening to kill the Lord's followers. He even went to the high priest
Acts 9:2 and asked for letters to the leaders of the synagogues in Damascus. He did this because he wanted to arrest and take to Jerusalem any man or woman who had accepted the Lord's Way.
Acts 9:3 When Saul had almost reached Damascus, a bright light from heaven suddenly flashed around him.
Acts 9:4 He fell to the ground and heard a voice saying, “Saul! Saul! Why are you so cruel to me?”
Acts 9:5 “Who are you?” Saul asked. “I am Jesus,” the Lord answered. “I am the one you are so cruel to.
Acts 9:6 Now get up and go into the city, where you will be told what to do.”
Acts 9:7 The men with Saul stood there speechless. They had heard the voice, but they had not seen anyone.
Acts 9:8 Saul got up from the ground, and when he opened his eyes, he could not see a thing. Someone then led him by the hand to Damascus,
Acts 9:9 and for three days he was blind and did not eat or drink.
Acts 9:10 A follower named Ananias lived in Damascus, and the Lord spoke to him in a vision. Ananias answered, “Lord, here I am.”
Acts 9:11 The Lord said to him, “Get up and go to the house of Judas on Straight Street. When you get there, you will find a man named Saul from the city of Tarsus. Saul is praying,
Acts 9:12 and he has seen a vision. He saw a man named Ananias coming to him and putting his hands on him, so he could see again.”
Acts 9:13 Ananias replied, “Lord, a lot of people have told me about the terrible things this man has done to your followers in Jerusalem.
Acts 9:14 Now the chief priests have given him the power to come here and arrest anyone who worships in your name.”
Acts 9:15 The Lord said to Ananias, “Go! I have chosen him to tell foreigners, kings, and the people of Israel about me.
Acts 9:16 I will show him how much he must suffer for worshiping in my name.”
Acts 9:17 Ananias left and went into the house where Saul was staying. Ananias placed his hands on him and said, “Saul, the Lord Jesus has sent me. He is the same one who appeared to you along the road. He wants you to be able to see and to be filled with the Holy Spirit.”
Acts 9:18 Suddenly something like fish scales fell from Saul's eyes, and he could see. He got up and was baptized.
Acts 9:19 Then he ate and felt much better. For several days Saul stayed with the Lord's followers in Damascus.
Acts 9:20 Soon he went to the synagogues and started telling people that Jesus is the Son of God.
Acts 9:21 Everyone who heard Saul was amazed and said, “Isn't this the man who caused so much trouble for those people in Jerusalem who worship in the name of Jesus? Didn't he come here to arrest them and take them to the chief priests?”
Acts 9:22 Saul preached with such power that he completely confused the Jewish people in Damascus, as he tried to show them that Jesus is the Messiah.
Acts 9:23 Later some of them made plans to kill Saul,
Acts 9:24 but he found out about it. He learned that they were guarding the gates of the city day and night in order to kill him.
Acts 9:25 Then one night his followers let him down over the city wall in a large basket.
Acts 9:26 When Saul arrived in Jerusalem, he tried to join the followers. But they were all afraid of him, because they did not believe he was a true follower.
Acts 9:27 Then Barnabas helped him by taking him to the apostles. He explained how Saul had seen the Lord and how the Lord had spoken to him. Barnabas also said when Saul was in Damascus, he had spoken bravely in the name of Jesus.
Acts 9:28 Saul moved about freely with the followers in Jerusalem and told everyone about the Lord.
Acts 9:29 He was always arguing with the Jews who spoke Greek, and so they tried to kill him.
Acts 9:30 But the followers found out about this and took Saul to Caesarea. From there they sent him to the city of Tarsus.
Acts 9:31 The church in Judea, Galilee, and Samaria now had a time of peace and kept on worshiping the Lord. The church became stronger, as the Holy Spirit encouraged it and helped it grow.
Acts 9:32 While Peter was traveling from place to place, he visited the Lord's followers who lived in the town of Lydda.
Acts 9:33 There he met a man named Aeneas, who for eight years had been sick in bed and could not move.
Acts 9:34 Peter said to Aeneas, “Jesus Christ has healed you! Get up and make up your bed.” At once he stood up.
Acts 9:35 Many people in the towns of Lydda and Sharon saw Aeneas and became followers of the Lord.
Acts 9:36 In Joppa there was a follower named Tabitha. Her Greek name was Dorcas, which means “deer.” She was always doing good things for people and had given much to the poor.
Acts 9:37 But she got sick and died, and her body was washed and placed in an upstairs room.
Acts 9:38 Joppa wasn't far from Lydda, and the followers heard that Peter was there. They sent two men to say to him, “Please come with us as quickly as you can!”
Acts 9:39 At once, Peter went with them. The men took Peter upstairs into the room. Many widows were there crying. They showed him the coats and clothes that Dorcas had made while she was still alive.
Acts 9:40 After Peter had sent everyone out of the room, he knelt down and prayed. Then he turned to the body of Dorcas and said, “Tabitha, get up!” The woman opened her eyes, and when she saw Peter, she sat up.
Acts 9:41 He took her by the hand and helped her to her feet. Peter called in the widows and the other followers and showed them that Dorcas had been raised from death.
Acts 9:42 Everyone in Joppa heard what had happened, and many of them put their faith in the Lord.
Acts 9:43 Peter stayed on for a while in Joppa in the house of a man named Simon, who made leather.
Acts 10:1 In Caesarea there was a man named Cornelius, who was the captain of a group of soldiers called “The Italian Unit.”
Acts 10:2 Cornelius was a very religious man. He worshiped God, and so did everyone else who lived in his house. He had given a lot of money to the poor and was always praying to God.
Acts 10:3 One afternoon at about three o'clock, Cornelius had a vision. He saw an angel from God coming to him and calling him by name.
Acts 10:4 Cornelius was surprised and stared at the angel. Then he asked, “What is this all about?” The angel answered, “God has heard your prayers and knows about your gifts to the poor.
Acts 10:5 Now send some men to Joppa for a man named Simon Peter.
Acts 10:6 He is staying with Simon the leather maker, who lives in a house near the sea.”
Acts 10:7 After saying this, the angel left. Cornelius called in two of his servants and one of his soldiers who worshiped God.
Acts 10:8 He explained everything to them and sent them off to Joppa.
Acts 10:9 The next day about noon these men were coming near Joppa. Peter went up on the roof of the house to pray
Acts 10:10 and became very hungry. While the food was being prepared, he fell sound asleep and had a vision.
Acts 10:11 He saw heaven open, and something came down like a huge sheet held up by its four corners.
Acts 10:12 In it were all kinds of animals, reptiles, and birds.
Acts 10:13 A voice said to him, “Peter, get up! Kill these and eat them.”
Acts 10:14 But Peter said, “Lord, I can't do that! I've never eaten anything that is unclean and not fit to eat.”
Acts 10:15 The voice spoke to him again, “When God says that something can be used for food, don't say it isn't fit to eat.”
Acts 10:16 This happened three times before the sheet was suddenly taken back to heaven.
Acts 10:17 Peter was still wondering what all this meant, when the men sent by Cornelius came and stood at the gate. They had found their way to Simon's house
Acts 10:18 and were asking if Simon Peter was staying there.
Acts 10:19 While Peter was still thinking about the vision, the Holy Spirit said to him, “Three men are here looking for you.
Acts 10:20 Hurry down and go with them. Don't worry, I sent them.”
Acts 10:21 Peter went down and said to the men, “I am the one you are looking for. Why have you come?”
Acts 10:22 They answered, “Captain Cornelius sent us. He is a good man who worships God and is liked by the Jewish people. One of God's holy angels told Cornelius to send for you, so he could hear what you have to say.”
Acts 10:23 Peter invited them to spend the night. The next morning, Peter and some of the Lord's followers in Joppa left with the men who had come from Cornelius.
Acts 10:24 The next day they arrived in Caesarea where Cornelius was waiting for them. He had also invited his relatives and close friends.
Acts 10:25 When Peter arrived, Cornelius greeted him. Then he knelt at Peter's feet and started worshiping him.
Acts 10:26 But Peter took hold of him and said, “Stand up! I am nothing more than a human.”
Acts 10:27 As Peter entered the house, he was still talking with Cornelius. Many people were there,
Acts 10:28 and Peter said to them, “You know that we Jews are not allowed to have anything to do with other people. But God has shown me that he doesn't think anyone is unclean or unfit.
Acts 10:29 I agreed to come here, but I want to know why you sent for me.”
Acts 10:30 Cornelius answered: Four days ago at about three o'clock in the afternoon I was praying at home. Suddenly a man in bright clothes stood in front of me.
Acts 10:31 He said, “Cornelius, God has heard your prayers, and he knows about your gifts to the poor.
Acts 10:32 Now send to Joppa for Simon Peter. He is visiting in the home of Simon the leather maker, who lives near the sea.”
Acts 10:33 I sent for you at once, and you have been good enough to come. All of us are here in the presence of the Lord God, so that we can hear what he has to say.
Acts 10:34 Peter then said: Now I am certain that God treats all people alike.
Acts 10:35 God is pleased with everyone who worships him and does right, no matter what nation they come from.
Acts 10:36 This is the same message that God gave to the people of Israel, when he sent Jesus Christ, the Lord of all, to offer peace to them.
Acts 10:37 You surely know what happened everywhere in Judea. It all began in Galilee after John had told everyone to be baptized.
Acts 10:38 God gave the Holy Spirit and power to Jesus from Nazareth. He was with Jesus, as he went around doing good and healing everyone who was under the power of the devil.
Acts 10:39 We all saw what Jesus did both in Israel and in the city of Jerusalem. Jesus was put to death on a cross.
Acts 10:40 But three days later, God raised him to life and let him be seen.
Acts 10:41 Not everyone saw him. He was seen only by us, who ate and drank with him after he was raised from death. We were the ones God chose to tell others about him.
Acts 10:42 God told us to announce clearly to the people that Jesus is the one he has chosen to judge the living and the dead.
Acts 10:43 Every one of the prophets has said that all who have faith in Jesus will have their sins forgiven in his name.
Acts 10:44 While Peter was still speaking, the Holy Spirit took control of everyone who was listening.
Acts 10:45 Some Jewish followers of the Lord had come with Peter, and they were surprised that the Holy Spirit had been given to Gentiles.
Acts 10:46 Now they were hearing Gentiles speaking unknown languages and praising God. Peter said,
Acts 10:47 “These Gentiles have been given the Holy Spirit, just as we have! I am certain that no one would dare stop us from baptizing them.”
Acts 10:48 Peter ordered them to be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ, and they asked him to stay on for a few days.
Acts 11:1 The apostles and the followers in Judea heard that Gentiles had accepted God's message.
Acts 11:2 So when Peter came to Jerusalem, some of the Jewish followers started arguing with him. They wanted Gentile followers to be circumcised, and
Acts 11:3 they said, “You stayed in the homes of Gentiles, and you even ate with them!”
Acts 11:4 Then Peter told them exactly what had happened:
Acts 11:5 I was in the town of Joppa and was praying when I fell sound asleep and had a vision. I saw heaven open, and something like a huge sheet held by its four corners came down to me.
Acts 11:6 When I looked in it, I saw animals, wild beasts, reptiles, and birds.
Acts 11:7 I heard a voice saying to me, “Peter, get up! Kill these and eat them.”
Acts 11:8 But I said, “Lord, I can't do that! I've never taken a bite of anything that is unclean and not fit to eat.”
Acts 11:9 The voice from heaven spoke to me again, “When God says that something can be used for food, don't say it isn't fit to eat.”
Acts 11:10 This happened three times before it was all taken back into heaven.
Acts 11:11 Suddenly three men from Caesarea stood in front of the house where I was staying.
Acts 11:12 The Holy Spirit told me to go with them and not to worry. Then six of the Lord's followers went with me to the home of a man
Acts 11:13 who told us that an angel had appeared to him. The angel had ordered him to send to Joppa for someone named Simon Peter.
Acts 11:14 Then Peter would tell him how he and everyone in his house could be saved.
Acts 11:15 After I started speaking, the Holy Spirit was given to them, just as the Spirit had been given to us at the beginning.
Acts 11:16 I remembered that the Lord had said, “John baptized with water, but you will be baptized with the Holy Spirit.”
Acts 11:17 God gave those Gentiles the same gift that he gave us when we put our faith in the Lord Jesus Christ. So how could I have gone against God?
Acts 11:18 When they heard Peter say this, they stopped arguing and started praising God. They said, “God has now let Gentiles turn to him, and he has given life to them!”
Acts 11:19 Some of the Lord's followers had been scattered because of the terrible trouble that started when Stephen was killed. They went as far as Phoenicia, Cyprus, and Antioch, but they told the message only to the Jews.
Acts 11:20 Some of the followers from Cyprus and Cyrene went to Antioch and started telling Gentiles the good news about the Lord Jesus.
Acts 11:21 The Lord's power was with them, and many people turned to the Lord and put their faith in him.
Acts 11:22 News of what was happening reached the church in Jerusalem. Then they sent Barnabas to Antioch.
Acts 11:23 When Barnabas got there and saw how God had blessed them with undeserved grace, he was very glad. So he begged them to remain faithful to the Lord with all their hearts.
Acts 11:24 Barnabas was a good man of great faith, and he was filled with the Holy Spirit. Many more people turned to the Lord.
Acts 11:25 Barnabas went to Tarsus to look for Saul.
Acts 11:26 He found Saul and brought him to Antioch, where they met with the church for a whole year and taught many of its people. There in Antioch the Lord's followers were first called Christians.
Acts 11:27 During this time some prophets from Jerusalem came to Antioch.
Acts 11:28 One of them was Agabus. Then with the help of the Spirit, he told that there would be a terrible famine everywhere in the world. And it happened when Claudius was Emperor.
Acts 11:29 The followers in Antioch decided to send whatever help they could to the followers in Judea.
Acts 11:30 So they appointed Barnabas and Saul to take their gifts to the church leaders in Jerusalem.
Acts 12:1 At that time King Herod caused terrible suffering for some members of the church.
Acts 12:2 He ordered soldiers to cut off the head of James, the brother of John.
Acts 12:3 When Herod saw that this pleased the Jewish people, he had Peter arrested during the Festival of Thin Bread.
Acts 12:4 He put Peter in jail and ordered four squads of soldiers to guard him. Herod planned to put him on trial in public after the festival.
Acts 12:5 While Peter was being kept in jail, the church never stopped praying to God for him.
Acts 12:6 The night before Peter was to be put on trial, he was asleep and bound by two chains. A soldier was guarding him on each side, and two other soldiers were guarding the entrance to the jail.
Acts 12:7 Suddenly an angel from the Lord appeared, and light flashed around in the cell. The angel poked Peter in the side and woke him up. Then he said, “Quick! Get up!” The chains fell off his hands,
Acts 12:8 and the angel said, “Get dressed and put on your sandals.” Peter did what he was told. Then the angel said, “Now put on your coat and follow me.”
Acts 12:9 Peter left with the angel, but he thought everything was only a dream.
Acts 12:10 They went past the two groups of soldiers, and when they came to the iron gate to the city, it opened by itself. They went out and were going along the street, when all at once the angel disappeared.
Acts 12:11 Peter now realized what had happened, and he said, “I am certain that the Lord sent his angel to rescue me from Herod and from everything the Jewish leaders planned to do to me.”
Acts 12:12 Then Peter went to the house of Mary the mother of John whose other name was Mark. Many of the Lord's followers had come together there and were praying.
Acts 12:13 Peter knocked on the gate, and a servant named Rhoda came to answer.
Acts 12:14 When she heard Peter's voice, she was too excited to open the gate. She ran back into the house and said Peter was standing there.
Acts 12:15 “You are crazy!” everyone told her. But she kept saying it was Peter. Then they said, “It must be his angel.”
Acts 12:16 But Peter kept on knocking, until finally they opened the gate. They saw him and were completely amazed.
Acts 12:17 Peter motioned for them to keep quiet. Then he told how the Lord had led him out of jail. He also said, “Tell James and the others what has happened.” After that, he left and went somewhere else.
Acts 12:18 The next morning the soldiers who had been on guard were terribly worried and wondered what had happened to Peter.
Acts 12:19 Herod ordered his own soldiers to search for him, but they could not find him. Then he questioned the guards and had them put to death. After this, Herod left Judea to stay in Caesarea for a while.
Acts 12:20 Herod and the people of Tyre and Sidon were very angry with each other. But their country got its food supply from the region that he ruled. So a group of them went to see Blastus, who was one of Herod's high officials. They convinced Blastus that they wanted to make peace between their cities and Herod,
Acts 12:21 and a day was set for them to meet with him. Herod came dressed in his royal robes. He sat down on his throne and made a speech.
Acts 12:22 The people shouted, “You speak more like a god than a man!”
Acts 12:23 At once an angel from the Lord struck him down because he took the honor that belonged to God. Later, Herod was eaten by worms and died.
Acts 12:24 God's message kept spreading.
Acts 12:25 And after Barnabas and Saul had done the work they were sent to do, they went back to Jerusalem with John, whose other name was Mark.
Acts 13:1 The church at Antioch had several prophets and teachers. They were Barnabas, Simeon, also called Niger, Lucius from Cyrene, Manaen, who was Herod's close friend, and Saul.
Acts 13:2 While they were worshiping the Lord and going without eating, the Holy Spirit told them, “Appoint Barnabas and Saul to do the work for which I have chosen them.”
Acts 13:3 Everyone prayed and went without eating for a while longer. Next, they placed their hands on Barnabas and Saul to show that they had been appointed to do this work. Then everyone sent them on their way.
Acts 13:4 After Barnabas and Saul had been sent by the Holy Spirit, they went to Seleucia. From there they sailed to the island of Cyprus.
Acts 13:5 They arrived at Salamis and began to preach God's message in the synagogues. They also had John as a helper.
Acts 13:6 Barnabas and Saul went all the way to the city of Paphos on the other end of the island, where they met a Jewish man named Bar-Jesus. He practiced witchcraft and was a false prophet.
Acts 13:7 He also worked for Sergius Paulus, who was very smart and was the governor of the island. Sergius Paulus wanted to hear God's message, and he sent for Barnabas and Saul.
Acts 13:8 But Bar-Jesus, whose other name was Elymas, was against them. He even tried to keep the governor from having faith in the Lord.
Acts 13:9 Then Saul, better known as Paul, was filled with the Holy Spirit. He looked straight at Elymas
Acts 13:10 and said, “You son of the devil! You are a liar, a crook, and an enemy of everything that is right. When will you stop speaking against the true ways of the Lord?
Acts 13:11 The Lord is going to punish you by making you completely blind for a while.” Suddenly the man's eyes were covered by a dark mist, and he went around trying to get someone to lead him by the hand.
Acts 13:12 When the governor saw what had happened, he was amazed at this teaching about the Lord. So he put his faith in the Lord.
Acts 13:13 Paul and the others left Paphos and sailed to Perga in Pamphylia. But John left them and went back to Jerusalem.
Acts 13:14 The rest of them went on from Perga to Antioch in Pisidia. Then on the Sabbath they went to the synagogue and sat down.
Acts 13:15 After the reading of the Law and the Prophets, the leaders sent someone over to tell Paul and Barnabas, “Friends, if you have anything to say that will help the people, please say it.”
Acts 13:16 Paul got up. He motioned with his hand and said: People of Israel, and everyone else who worships God, listen!
Acts 13:17 The God of Israel chose our ancestors, and he let our people prosper while they were living in Egypt. Then with his mighty power he led them out,
Acts 13:18 and for about 40 years he took care of them in the desert.
Acts 13:19 He destroyed seven nations in the land of Canaan and gave their land to our people.
Acts 13:20 All this happened in about 450 years. Then God gave our people judges until the time of the prophet Samuel,
Acts 13:21 but the people demanded a king. So for 40 years God gave them King Saul, the son of Kish from the tribe of Benjamin.
Acts 13:22 Later, God removed Saul and let David rule in his place. God said about him, “David the son of Jesse is the kind of person who pleases me most! He does everything I want him to do.”
Acts 13:23 God promised that someone from David's family would come to save the people of Israel, and this one is Jesus.
Acts 13:24 But before Jesus came, John was telling everyone in Israel to turn back to God and be baptized.
Acts 13:25 Then, when John's work was almost done, he said, “Who do you people think I am? Do you think I am the Promised One? He will come later, and I am not good enough to untie his sandals.”
Acts 13:26 Now listen, you descendants of Abraham! Pay attention, all of you Gentiles who are here to worship God! Listen to this message about how to be saved, because it is for everyone.
Acts 13:27 The people of Jerusalem and their leaders didn't realize who Jesus was. And they didn't understand the words of the prophets they read each Sabbath. So they condemned Jesus just as the prophets had said.
Acts 13:28+ACT They did exactly what the Scriptures said they would. Even though they couldn't find any reason to put Jesus to death, they still asked Pilate to have him killed. After Jesus had been put to death, he was taken down from the cross and placed in a tomb.
Acts 13:30 But God raised him from death!
Acts 13:31 Then for many days Jesus appeared to his followers who had gone with him from Galilee to Jerusalem. Now they are telling our people about him.
Acts 13:32 God made a promise to our ancestors. And we are here to tell you the good news
Acts 13:33 that he has kept this promise to us. It is just as the second Psalm says about Jesus, “You are my son because today I have become your Father.”
Acts 13:34 God raised Jesus from death and will never let his body decay. It is just as God said, “I will make to you the same holy promises that I made to David.”
Acts 13:35 And in another psalm it says, “God will never let the body of his Holy One decay.”
Acts 13:36 When David was alive, he obeyed God. Then after he died, he was buried in the family grave, and his body decayed.
Acts 13:37 But God raised Jesus from death, and his body did not decay.
Acts 13:38 My friends, the message is that Jesus can forgive your sins! The Law of Moses could not set you free from all your sins.
Acts 13:39 But everyone who has faith in Jesus is set free.
Acts 13:40 Make sure what the prophets have said doesn't happen to you. They said,
Acts 13:41 “Look, you people who make fun of God! Be amazed and disappear. I will do something today that you won't believe, even if someone tells you about it!”
Acts 13:42 As Paul and Barnabas were leaving the synagogue, the people begged them to say more about these same things on the next Sabbath.
Acts 13:43 After the service, many Jews and a lot of Gentiles who worshiped God went with them. Paul and Barnabas begged them all to remain faithful to God, who had treated them with undeserved grace.
Acts 13:44 The next Sabbath almost everyone in town came to hear the message about the Lord.
Acts 13:45 When the Jewish people saw the crowds, they were very jealous. They insulted Paul and spoke against everything he said.
Acts 13:46 But Paul and Barnabas bravely said: We had to tell God's message to you before we told it to anyone else. But you rejected the message! This proves that you don't deserve eternal life. Now we are going to the Gentiles.
Acts 13:47 The Lord has given us this command, “I have placed you here as a light for the Gentiles. You are to take the saving power of God to people everywhere on earth.”
Acts 13:48 This message made the Gentiles glad, and they praised what they had heard about the Lord. Everyone who had been chosen for eternal life then put their faith in the Lord.
Acts 13:49 The message about the Lord spread all over this region.
Acts 13:50 But the Jewish leaders went to some of the important men in the town and to some respected women who were religious. They turned them against Paul and Barnabas and started making trouble for them. They even chased them out of this part of the country.
Acts 13:51 Paul and Barnabas shook the dust from that place off their feet and went on to the city of Iconium.
Acts 13:52 But the Lord's followers in Antioch were very happy and were filled with the Holy Spirit.
Acts 14:1 Paul and Barnabas spoke in the synagogue in Iconium, just as they had done at Antioch, and many Jews and Gentiles put their faith in the Lord.
Acts 14:2 But the Jews who did not have faith in him made the other Gentiles angry and turned them against the Lord's followers.
Acts 14:3 Paul and Barnabas stayed there for a while, having faith in the Lord and bravely speaking his message. The Lord gave them the power to work miracles and wonders, and he showed that their message about his gift of undeserved grace was true.
Acts 14:4 The people of Iconium did not know what to think. Some of them believed the Jewish group, and others believed the apostles.
Acts 14:5 Finally, some Gentiles and Jews, together with their leaders, decided to make trouble for Paul and Barnabas and to stone them to death.
Acts 14:6+ACT But when the two apostles found out what was happening, they escaped to the region of Lycaonia. They preached the good news there in the towns of Lystra and Derbe and in the nearby countryside.
Acts 14:8 In Lystra there was a man who had been born with paralyzed feet and had never been able to walk.
Acts 14:9 The man was listening to Paul speak, when Paul saw that he had faith in Jesus and could be healed. So he looked straight at the man
Acts 14:10 and shouted, “Stand up!” The man jumped up and started walking around.
Acts 14:11 When the crowd saw what Paul had done, they yelled out in the language of Lycaonia, “The gods have turned into humans and have come down to us!”
Acts 14:12 The people then gave Barnabas the name Zeus, and they gave Paul the name Hermes, because he did the talking.
Acts 14:13 The temple of Zeus was near the entrance to the city. Its priest and the crowds wanted to offer a sacrifice to Barnabas and Paul. So the priest brought some bulls and flowers to the city gates.
Acts 14:14 When the two apostles found out about this, they tore their clothes in horror and ran to the crowd, shouting:
Acts 14:15 Why are you doing this? We are humans just like you. Please give up all this foolishness. Turn to the living God, who made the sky, the earth, the sea, and everything in them.
Acts 14:16 In times past, God let each nation go its own way.
Acts 14:17 But he showed he was there by the good things he did. God sends rain from heaven and makes your crops grow. He gives food to you and makes your hearts glad.
Acts 14:18 Even after Paul and Barnabas had said all this, they could hardly keep the people from offering a sacrifice to them.
Acts 14:19 Some Jewish leaders from Antioch and Iconium came and turned the crowds against Paul. They hit him with stones and dragged him out of the city, thinking he was dead.
Acts 14:20 But when the Lord's followers gathered around Paul, he stood up and went back into the city. The next day he and Barnabas went to Derbe.
Acts 14:21 Paul and Barnabas preached the good news in Derbe and won some people to the Lord. Then they went back to Lystra, Iconium, and Antioch in Pisidia.
Acts 14:22 They encouraged the followers and begged them to remain faithful. They told them, “We have to suffer a lot before we can get into God's kingdom.”
Acts 14:23 Paul and Barnabas chose some leaders for each of the churches. Then they went without eating and prayed that the Lord would take good care of these leaders who had trusted in the Lord.
Acts 14:24 Paul and Barnabas went on through Pisidia to Pamphylia,
Acts 14:25 where they preached in the town of Perga. Then they went down to Attalia
Acts 14:26 and sailed to Antioch in Syria. It was there that they had been placed in God's care for the work they had now completed.
Acts 14:27 After arriving in Antioch, they called the church together. They told the people what God had helped them do and how he had made it possible for the Gentiles to believe.
Acts 14:28 Then they stayed there with the followers for a long time.
Acts 15:1 Some people came from Judea and started teaching the Lord's followers that they could not be saved, unless they were circumcised as Moses had taught.
Acts 15:2 This caused trouble, and Paul and Barnabas argued with them about this teaching. So it was decided to send Paul and Barnabas and a few others to Jerusalem to discuss this problem with the apostles and the church leaders.
Acts 15:3 The men who were sent by the church went through Phoenicia and Samaria, telling how the Gentiles had turned to God. This news made the Lord's followers very happy.
Acts 15:4 When the men arrived in Jerusalem, they were welcomed by the church, including the apostles and the leaders. They told them everything God had helped them do.
Acts 15:5 But some Pharisees had become followers of the Lord. They stood up and said, “Gentiles who have faith in the Lord must be circumcised and told to obey the Law of Moses.”
Acts 15:6 The apostles and church leaders met to discuss this problem about Gentiles.
Acts 15:7 They had talked it over for a long time, when Peter got up and said: My friends, you know that God decided long ago to let me be the one from your group to preach the good news to the Gentiles. God did this so they would hear and obey him.
Acts 15:8 He knows what is in everyone's heart. And he showed he had chosen the Gentiles, when he gave them the Holy Spirit, just as he had given his Spirit to us.
Acts 15:9 God treated them in the same way that he treated us. They put their faith in him, and he made their hearts pure.
Acts 15:10 Now why are you trying to make God angry by placing a heavy burden on these followers? This burden was too heavy for us or our ancestors.
Acts 15:11 But we believe that we will be saved by the gift of undeserved grace from our Lord Jesus Christ, just as the Gentiles are.
Acts 15:12 Everyone kept quiet and listened as Barnabas and Paul told how God had given them the power to work a lot of miracles and wonders for the Gentiles.
Acts 15:13 After they had finished speaking, James said: My friends, listen to me!
Acts 15:14 Simon Peter has told how God first came to the Gentiles and made some of them his own people.
Acts 15:15 This agrees with what the prophets wrote,
Acts 15:16 “I, the Lord, will return and rebuild David's fallen house. I will build it from its ruins and set it up again.
Acts 15:17 Then other nations will turn to me and be my chosen ones. I, the Lord, say this.
Acts 15:18 I promised it long ago.”
Acts 15:19 And so, my friends, I don't think we should place burdens on the Gentiles who are turning to God.
Acts 15:20 We should simply write and tell them not to eat anything that has been offered to idols. They should be told not to eat the meat of any animal that has been strangled or that still has blood in it. They must also not commit any terrible sexual sins.
Acts 15:21 We must remember that the Law of Moses has been preached in city after city for many years, and every Sabbath it is read in our synagogues.
Acts 15:22 The apostles, the leaders, and all the church members decided to send some men to Antioch along with Paul and Barnabas. They chose Silas and Judas Barsabbas, who were two leaders of the Lord's followers.
Acts 15:23 They wrote a letter that said: We apostles and leaders send friendly greetings to all of you Gentiles who are followers of the Lord in Antioch, Syria, and Cilicia.
Acts 15:24 We have heard that some people from here have terribly upset you by what they said. But we did not send them!
Acts 15:25 So we met together and decided to choose some men and to send them to you along with our good friends Barnabas and Paul.
Acts 15:26 These men have risked their lives for our Lord Jesus Christ.
Acts 15:27 We are also sending Judas and Silas, who will tell you in person the same things that we are writing.
Acts 15:28 The Holy Spirit has shown us that we should not place any extra burden on you.
Acts 15:29 But you should not eat anything offered to idols. You should not eat any meat that still has the blood in it or any meat of any animal that has been strangled. You must also not commit any terrible sexual sins. If you follow these instructions, you will do well. We send our best wishes.
Acts 15:30 The four men left Jerusalem and went to Antioch. Then they called the church members together and gave them the letter.
Acts 15:31 When the letter was read, everyone was pleased and greatly encouraged.
Acts 15:32 Judas and Silas were prophets, and they spoke a long time, encouraging and helping the Lord's followers.
Acts 15:33 The men from Jerusalem stayed on in Antioch for a while. And when they left to return to the ones who had sent them, the followers wished them well.
Acts 15:34+ACT But Paul and Barnabas stayed on in Antioch, where they and many others taught and preached about the Lord.
Acts 15:36 Sometime later Paul said to Barnabas, “Let's go back and visit the Lord's followers in the cities where we preached his message. Then we will know how they are doing.”
Acts 15:37 Barnabas wanted to take along John, whose other name was Mark.
Acts 15:38 But Paul did not want to, because Mark had left them in Pamphylia and had stopped working with them.
Acts 15:39 Paul and Barnabas argued, then each of them went his own way. Barnabas took Mark and sailed to Cyprus,
Acts 15:40 but Paul took Silas and left after the followers had placed them in God's care.
Acts 15:41 They traveled through Syria and Cilicia, encouraging the churches.
Acts 16:1 Paul and Silas went back to Derbe and Lystra, where there was a follower named Timothy. His mother was also a follower. She was Jewish, and his father was Greek.
Acts 16:2 The Lord's followers in Lystra and Iconium said good things about Timothy,
Acts 16:3 and Paul wanted him to go with them. But Paul first had him circumcised, because all the Jewish people around there knew that Timothy's father was Greek.
Acts 16:4 As Paul and the others went from city to city, they told the followers what the apostles and leaders in Jerusalem had decided, and they urged them to follow these instructions.
Acts 16:5 The churches became stronger in their faith, and each day more people put their faith in the Lord.
Acts 16:6 Paul and his friends went through Phrygia and Galatia, but the Holy Spirit would not let them preach in Asia.
Acts 16:7 After they arrived in Mysia, they tried to go into Bithynia, but the Spirit of Jesus would not let them.
Acts 16:8 So they went on through Mysia until they came to Troas.
Acts 16:9 During the night, Paul had a vision of someone from Macedonia who was standing there and begging him, “Come over to Macedonia and help us!”
Acts 16:10 After Paul had seen the vision, we began looking for a way to go to Macedonia. We were sure that God had called us to preach the good news there.
Acts 16:11 We sailed straight from Troas to Samothrace, and the next day we arrived in Neapolis.
Acts 16:12 From there we went to Philippi, which is a Roman colony in the first district of Macedonia. We spent several days in Philippi.
Acts 16:13 Then on the Sabbath we went outside the city gate to a place by the river, where we thought there would be a Jewish meeting place for prayer. We sat down and talked with the women who came.
Acts 16:14 One of them was Lydia, who was from the city of Thyatira and sold expensive purple cloth. She was a worshiper of the Lord God, and he made her willing to accept what Paul was saying.
Acts 16:15 Then after she and her family were baptized, she kept on begging us, “If you think I really do have faith in the Lord, come stay in my home.” Finally, we accepted her invitation.
Acts 16:16 One day on our way to the place of prayer, we were met by a slave girl. She had a spirit in her that gave her the power to tell the future. By doing this she made a lot of money for her owners.
Acts 16:17 The girl followed Paul and the rest of us, and she kept yelling, “These men are servants of the Most High God! They are telling you how to be saved.”
Acts 16:18 This went on for several days. Finally, Paul got so upset that he turned and said to the spirit, “In the name of Jesus Christ, I order you to leave this girl alone!” At once the evil spirit left her.
Acts 16:19 When the girl's owners realized they had lost all chances for making more money, they grabbed Paul and Silas and dragged them into court.
Acts 16:20 They told the officials, “These Jews are upsetting our city!
Acts 16:21 They are telling us to do things we Romans are not allowed to do.”
Acts 16:22 The crowd joined in the attack on Paul and Silas. Then the officials tore the clothes off the two men and ordered them to be beaten with a whip.
Acts 16:23 After they had been badly beaten, they were put in jail, and the jailer was told to guard them carefully.
Acts 16:24 The jailer did as he was told. He put them deep inside the jail and chained their feet to heavy blocks of wood.
Acts 16:25 About midnight Paul and Silas were praying and singing praises to God, while the other prisoners listened.
Acts 16:26 Suddenly a strong earthquake shook the jail to its foundations. The doors opened, and the chains fell from all the prisoners.
Acts 16:27 When the jailer woke up and saw that the doors were open, he thought that the prisoners had escaped. He pulled out his sword and was about to kill himself.
Acts 16:28 But Paul shouted, “Don't harm yourself! No one has escaped.”
Acts 16:29 The jailer asked for a torch and went into the jail. He was shaking all over as he knelt down in front of Paul and Silas.
Acts 16:30 After he had led them out of the jail, he asked, “What must I do to be saved?”
Acts 16:31 They replied, “Have faith in the Lord Jesus and you will be saved! This is also true for everyone who lives in your home.”
Acts 16:32 Then Paul and Silas told him and everyone else in his house about the Lord.
Acts 16:33 While it was still night, the jailer took them to a place where he could wash their cuts and bruises. Then he and everyone in his home were baptized.
Acts 16:34 They were very glad they had put their faith in God. After this, the jailer took Paul and Silas to his home and gave them something to eat.
Acts 16:35 The next morning the officials sent some police with orders for the jailer to let Paul and Silas go.
Acts 16:36 The jailer told Paul, “The officials have ordered me to set you free. Now you can leave in peace.”
Acts 16:37 But Paul told the police, “We are Roman citizens, and the Roman officials had us beaten in public without giving us a trial. They threw us into jail. Now do they think they can secretly send us away? No, they cannot! They will have to come here themselves and let us out.”
Acts 16:38 When the police told the officials that Paul and Silas were Roman citizens, the officials were afraid.
Acts 16:39 So they came and apologized. They led them out of the jail and asked them to please leave town.
Acts 16:40 But Paul and Silas went straight to the home of Lydia, where they saw the Lord's followers and encouraged them. Then they left.
Acts 17:1 After Paul and his friends had traveled through Amphipolis and Apollonia, they went on to Thessalonica. A synagogue was in that city.
Acts 17:2 So as usual, Paul went there to worship, and on three Sabbaths he spoke to the people. He used the Scriptures
Acts 17:3 to show them that the Messiah had to suffer, but that he would rise from death. Paul also told them that Jesus is the Messiah he was preaching about.
Acts 17:4 Some of them believed what Paul had said, and they became followers with Paul and Silas. Some Gentiles and many important women also believed the message.
Acts 17:5 The Jewish leaders were jealous and got some troublemakers who hung around the marketplace to start a riot in the city. They wanted to drag Paul and Silas out to the mob, and so they went straight to Jason's home.
Acts 17:6 But when they did not find them there, they dragged out Jason and some of the Lord's followers. They took them to the city authorities and shouted, “Paul and Silas have been upsetting things everywhere. Now they have come here,
Acts 17:7 and Jason has welcomed them into his home. All of them break the laws of the Roman Emperor by claiming that someone named Jesus is king.”
Acts 17:8 The officials and the people were upset when they heard this.
Acts 17:9 So they made Jason and the other followers pay bail before letting them go.
Acts 17:10 That same night the Lord's followers sent Paul and Silas on to Berea, and after they arrived, they went to the synagogue.
Acts 17:11 The people in Berea were much nicer than those in Thessalonica, and they gladly accepted the message. Day after day they studied the Scriptures to see if these things were true.
Acts 17:12 Many of them put their faith in the Lord, including some important Greek women and several men.
Acts 17:13 When the Jewish leaders in Thessalonica heard that Paul had been preaching God's message in Berea, they went there and caused trouble by turning the crowds against Paul.
Acts 17:14 At once the followers sent Paul down to the coast, but Silas and Timothy stayed in Berea.
Acts 17:15 Some men went with Paul as far as Athens, and then returned with instructions for Silas and Timothy to join him as soon as possible.
Acts 17:16 While Paul was waiting in Athens, he was upset to see all the idols in the city.
Acts 17:17 He went to the synagogue to speak to the Jews and to anyone who worshiped with them. Day after day he also spoke to everyone he met in the market.
Acts 17:18 Some of them were Epicureans and some were Stoics, and they started arguing with him.
